title: Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidson slams Saudi flags 'nonsense'
text: Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson has slammed the "nonsense" of Saudi flags being flown outside businesses in Scotland. Davidson said it was "completely unacceptable" that the flags of a country with a "disgraceful human rights record" were being displayed in Scotland. Her comments came after a number of businesses in Scotland were seen flying the Saudi flag in support of the country's Crown Prince, Mohammed bin Salman. Bin Salman has been accused of human rights abuses, including the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Davidson said: "It is completely unacceptable that the flags of a country with such a disgraceful human rights record are being flown in Scotland. "The Saudi regime has been responsible for the deaths of thousands of innocent people in Yemen, and its treatment of its own citizens is appalling. "I urge businesses in Scotland to remove these flags immediately. They have no place in our country." Davidson's comments were echoed by a number of other Scottish politicians. Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard said: "The Saudi regime is a brutal dictatorship that has no respect for human rights. "It is deeply offensive to see their flags flying in Scotland. I urge businesses to remove them immediately." Scottish Green co-leader Patrick Harvie said: "The Saudi regime is one of the most repressive in the world. "It is deeply concerning to see their flags being flown in Scotland. I urge businesses to remove them immediately." The Scottish government has also been urged to take action to prevent Saudi flags from being flown in Scotland. Scottish Green MSP Ross Greer has lodged a motion in the Scottish Parliament calling on the government to "take all necessary steps to ensure that the flags of countries with poor human rights records are not flown on Scottish government buildings or land". The motion is due to be debated in the Scottish Parliament in the coming weeks.

title: Dead soldiers in Powys served with Territorial Army
text: In a poignant ceremony held in the rolling hills of Powys, Wales, remains of 10 British soldiers who perished during World War I were finally laid to rest. These fallen heroes, long unidentified, had belonged to the Territorial Army, a volunteer force made up of civilians who served alongside the regular military. Their remains were discovered during the excavation of a trench system on private land near the village of Llanfyllin. They were found buried alongside their personal belongings, including buttons, badges, and fragments of uniforms, which helped identify them as members of the Territorial Army. The soldiers were part of the 1/5th Battalion, The King's Shropshire Light Infantry, a unit that saw heavy fighting during the Battle of the Somme in 1916. The battle was one of the bloodiest in British military history, with hundreds of thousands of casualties. The remains of the soldiers were recovered by a team of archaeologists and historians. They were carefully examined and identified using a combination of forensic techniques, including DNA analysis and the study of dental records. The soldiers were identified as: - Private John Evans, aged 20 - Private William Jones, aged 22 - Private Thomas Davies, aged 23 - Private Richard Thomas, aged 24 - Private Edward Williams, aged 26 - Private David Roberts, aged 27 - Private John Hughes, aged 28 - Private William Davies, aged 29 - Private Thomas Jones, aged 30 - Private John Williams, aged 31 The soldiers' remains were interred in a military cemetery in Powys. They were given a full military funeral, with representatives from the British Army, the Royal British Legion, and the local community in attendance. The ceremony was a moving tribute to the fallen soldiers and a reminder of the sacrifices made by the Territorial Army during World War I. Their legacy as brave and dedicated volunteers will continue to inspire future generations.

title: Elon Musk's Boring Company presents LA tunnel plan
text: Elon Musk's Boring Company has unveiled plans for a network of tunnels under Los Angeles, designed to alleviate traffic congestion in the sprawling metropolis. The ambitious project, dubbed the "LA Loop," envisions a network of high-speed, underground tunnels that would transport passengers in autonomous electric vehicles. The Boring Company's proposal calls for the construction of up to 60 miles of tunnels, with stations located near major destinations such as LAX Airport, Downtown Los Angeles, and Santa Monica. Passengers would enter the tunnels through dedicated stations and board autonomous vehicles for a high-speed journey to their destination. According to Musk, the LA Loop could significantly reduce travel times. For example, a trip from LAX to Downtown Los Angeles, which currently takes about 45 minutes by car during peak hours, could be completed in just 15 minutes through the tunnel. The Boring Company has already begun drilling exploratory tunnels in Los Angeles, and Musk has stated that he hopes to start construction on the full network by the end of 2023. The project is expected to cost several billion dollars and will require the approval of local authorities and environmental regulators. The LA Loop has been met with mixed reactions. Some transportation experts have praised the project's potential to reduce congestion, while others have questioned its feasibility and environmental impact. Critics have also raised concerns about the safety and reliability of autonomous vehicles in an underground environment. Despite the challenges, Musk remains optimistic about the project. He believes that the LA Loop could revolutionize urban transportation and make Los Angeles a more livable city. Key features of the LA Loop: - High-speed tunnels: The tunnels would be designed for speeds of up to 125 miles per hour. - Autonomous vehicles: Passengers would ride in autonomous electric vehicles, eliminating the need for human drivers. - Multiple stations: The network would have multiple stations located near major destinations throughout Los Angeles. - Reduced travel times: The Boring Company claims that the LA Loop could reduce travel times by up to 75%. - Environmental benefits: By reducing traffic congestion, the LA Loop could have positive environmental impacts, such as reducing air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Manchester derby racist abuse claim: Man arrested
text: Manchester derby racist abuse claim: Man arrested A man has been arrested following a claim of racist abuse during the Manchester derby on Saturday. The incident is alleged to have occurred during the first half of the match at the Etihad Stadium, in which Manchester City beat Manchester United 6-3. Greater Manchester Police said a 41-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of a racially aggravated public order offence. He remains in custody for questioning. The alleged abuse was directed at Manchester United midfielder Fred, who is Brazilian. The incident is being investigated by the police and the Football Association (FA). On Sunday, Manchester City said they were "appalled" by the allegations and pledged to take the "strongest possible action" against anyone found guilty of racial abuse. "Manchester City strongly condemns all forms of racism and discrimination," the club said in a statement. "We are working with the police and the Football Association to identify and take action against anyone involved in this incident. "We will continue to do everything in our power to ensure that Etihad Stadium is a welcoming and inclusive environment for all." Manchester United also condemned the alleged abuse and said they were working with the police to investigate the incident. In a statement, the club said: "Manchester United is appalled by the alleged incident of racist abuse during yesterday's match with Manchester City. "We are working with the police and the Football Association to investigate this incident and we will take the strongest possible action against anyone found guilty of racial abuse. "Racism has no place in football or society and we are committed to working to eradicate it from our game." The FA said it was "deeply concerned" by the allegations and pledged to take "strong action" against anyone found guilty of racism. In a statement, the FA said: "The FA is deeply concerned by the allegations of racist abuse during Manchester City v Manchester United on Saturday. "We strongly condemn all forms of discrimination and we are working with the clubs and the police to investigate this incident and take appropriate action. "We will continue to work with our members and partners to eradicate racism from football."

title: Food bank charity gives record level of supplies
text: Food banks are providing a record number of emergency food supplies as the cost-of-living crisis deepens, figures show. In December, the Trussell Trust handed out more than 2.5 million food parcels - the highest monthly total since the charity began recording data in 2013. It comes as inflation hit a 40-year high of 10.5% in December, and energy bills continue to soar. The Trussell Trust said the figures were "a damning indictment of the state of our society". Emma Revie, chief executive of the Trussell Trust, said: "The fact that food banks are providing record levels of emergency food to people in the UK is a damning indictment of the state of our society. "We should not be in a situation where people are having to turn to food banks because they cannot afford to feed themselves and their families." The charity said that the cost-of-living crisis was having a "devastating impact" on people, with more and more families struggling to make ends meet. "We are seeing people who have never needed to use a food bank before," Ms Revie said. "This includes people in work, who are simply unable to keep up with the rising cost of living." The Trussell Trust said that the government needed to take action to help people, including increasing benefits and the minimum wage. "We cannot continue to live in a society where people are forced to rely on charity to put food on the table," Ms Revie said. In response to the figures, the government said it was "committed to supporting people with the cost of living". A spokesperson said: "We recognise the pressures people are facing and are providing £26 billion of support this year through our Energy Price Guarantee, Household Support Fund and other measures." The spokesperson added that the government was "also taking action to support low-income households through the tax system, including increasing the National Living Wage and reducing taxes." But critics say that the government is not doing enough to help people, and that the cost-of-living crisis is only going to get worse. The Resolution Foundation think tank said that the government's support package was "not enough" and that the number of people living in poverty was set to rise by 1.3 million this year. Torsten Bell, the foundation's chief executive, said: "The government needs to do more to help people with the cost of living, or we will see more and more people being forced to rely on food banks."

title: Diabetes life expectancy 'improving', study finds
text: Diabetes Life Expectancy 'Improving', Study Finds A new study has found that people with diabetes are living longer than ever before. The research, published in the journal Diabetologia, found that the average life expectancy for people with diabetes has increased by more than 10 years since the 1980s. The study analyzed data from over 1 million people with diabetes in the UK. Researchers found that the average life expectancy for people with type 1 diabetes has increased from 54 years in the 1980s to 75 years today. For people with type 2 diabetes, the average life expectancy has increased from 68 years in the 1980s to 80 years today. The study also found that the gap in life expectancy between people with diabetes and those without diabetes is narrowing. In the 1980s, people with diabetes were expected to die 10 years earlier than those without diabetes. Today, the gap has narrowed to just 5 years. The researchers say that the improvements in life expectancy are due to a number of factors, including better diabetes management, improved access to healthcare, and the development of new diabetes medications. "These findings are very encouraging," said lead author Professor John McMurray of the University of Glasgow. "They show that people with diabetes are living longer and healthier lives than ever before." However, Professor McMurray cautioned that there is still more work to be done. "Diabetes is still a serious disease, and it can lead to a number of complications, including heart disease, stroke, and kidney failure," he said. "We need to continue to work to improve diabetes care and to find ways to prevent these complications." The study's findings are in line with other recent research that has shown that the life expectancy of people with diabetes is improving. A study published in the journal The Lancet in 2018 found that the average life expectancy for people with type 1 diabetes in the UK had increased by 12 years since the 1990s. The improvements in life expectancy for people with diabetes are a testament to the hard work of researchers, healthcare professionals, and people with diabetes themselves. With continued research and innovation, we can continue to improve the lives of people with diabetes and help them live longer, healthier lives.

title: Arlene Foster 'lost friends' after attending Martin McGuinness funeral
text: Arlene Foster, the former First Minister of Northern Ireland, has revealed that she lost friends after attending the funeral of Martin McGuinness, the former Deputy First Minister and IRA commander. Speaking to the BBC, Foster said that she had received "a lot of hurtful comments" from people who were angry that she had attended McGuinness's funeral. "I lost friends over it," she said. "People who I thought were friends said some very hurtful things to me." Foster said that she had decided to attend McGuinness's funeral because she felt it was important to show respect for his family and for the people who had voted for him. "I knew that it would be a difficult decision, but I felt that it was the right thing to do," she said. Foster's decision to attend McGuinness's funeral was seen by some as a sign that she was willing to reach out to former enemies. However, others criticized her for attending the funeral of a man who had been responsible for the deaths of many innocent people. Foster said that she understood why people were angry with her, but she insisted that she had made the right decision. "I believe that we need to build bridges between people in Northern Ireland," she said. "We need to find a way to live together in peace." Foster's decision to attend McGuinness's funeral is a reminder of the complex and often difficult process of reconciliation in Northern Ireland. It is a process that will take time, but it is a process that is essential for the future of the province. In a separate interview with the BBC, McGuinness's widow, Bernie, said that she was grateful to Foster for attending her husband's funeral. "It was a very difficult time for us," she said. "But Arlene's presence at the funeral meant a lot to us." Bernie McGuinness said that she believed that her husband would have been proud of Foster for attending his funeral. "He always said that we need to find a way to live together in peace," she said. "I think he would have been very pleased that Arlene was there."

title: Troubles pension: Criteria for ex-prisoners to receive settlements revealed
text: Troubles pension: Criteria for ex-prisoners to receive settlements revealed Former prisoners can apply for payments under the Troubles pension scheme if they were convicted of a Troubles-related offence and served at least two years in prison. They must also have been released from prison by July 1998 and not have been convicted of a further Troubles-related offence since then. The pension is not available to those who were convicted of certain serious offences, including murder, rape and kidnapping. The scheme is open to both British and Irish citizens, as well as those from other countries who were resident in Northern Ireland at the time of their offence. Ex-prisoners who are eligible for the pension will receive a lump sum payment of £10,000, as well as an annual pension of £2,500. The pension is not means-tested and is not taxable. The scheme is being administered by the Victims and Survivors Service (VSS), which is part of the Northern Ireland Civil Service. Applications for the pension can be made online or by post. The VSS has said that it expects to receive around 10,000 applications for the pension. The scheme has been welcomed by some victims' groups, but others have criticised it, saying that it is too generous and that it does not go far enough to help victims of the Troubles. The scheme has also been criticised by some politicians, who say that it is unfair to give money to people who committed crimes during the Troubles. Examples of Troubles-related offences: Arson Bombing Causing an explosion Directing terrorism Firearms offences Handling explosives Hijacking Kidnapping Murder Possession of explosives Possession of firearms Rioting Terrorism Serious Troubles-related offences that are not eligible for the pension: Murder Rape Kidnapping

title: Snow: Norfolk has Covid mass vaccination centre and schools closed by Storm Darcy
text: Norfolk is one of several areas of England and Scotland affected by heavy snowfall and ice, with more snow expected on Sunday. A Covid-19 mass vaccination centre at Norwich's Norfolk Showground has been forced to close as a result of the weather conditions. All schools across the county were also closed on Sunday, after being advised to do so by the Department for Education. Residents are being urged to only travel if "absolutely necessary" as the snow and ice makes conditions dangerous. The Met Office has issued an amber weather warning for snow across Norfolk and other parts of eastern England. The warning is in force until 11:00 GMT on Monday, and the Met Office is warning of travel disruption, power cuts and the potential for injuries from slips and falls. Norfolk County Council has said it is working to clear the roads, but is urging people to avoid non-essential travel. "We are doing everything we can to keep the roads clear, but we are advising people to only travel if absolutely necessary," said John Burt, the council's cabinet member for highways. "The snow and ice is making driving conditions very difficult, and we don't want to see anyone put themselves at unnecessary risk." The council is also urging people to check on elderly or vulnerable neighbours to ensure they are safe and warm. Eastern Power Networks, which supplies electricity to Norfolk, said it was aware of power cuts in the area. "We are doing everything we can to restore power as quickly as possible," said a company spokesman. "We would like to remind people to stay away from any fallen power lines, as they could be dangerous." The snow is also causing disruption to rail services in Norfolk. Greater Anglia has said that all services between Norwich and London Liverpool Street are suspended until further notice. The company is advising passengers to check the latest train times before travelling. The snow is expected to continue to fall throughout Sunday, with further accumulations possible. The Met Office is warning that the snow could cause travel chaos and power cuts. People are being urged to only travel if absolutely necessary, and to check on elderly or vulnerable neighbours to ensure they are safe and warm.

title: King's Lynn incinerator: Alternative technology considered
text: King's Lynn incinerator: Alternative technology considered King's Lynn incinerator could be replaced with a new facility using alternative technology, under plans being considered by Norfolk County Council. The incinerator, which burns waste to generate electricity, has been in operation since 1998 and is nearing the end of its operational life. The county council is now exploring options for its replacement, including the use of alternative technologies such as gasification or pyrolysis. Gasification involves heating waste in a low-oxygen environment to produce a gas that can be used to generate electricity or heat. Pyrolysis is a similar process, but it takes place in the absence of oxygen, producing a solid char that can be used as a fuel. Both gasification and pyrolysis are considered to be more environmentally friendly than incineration, as they produce fewer emissions. They can also be used to process a wider range of waste materials, including plastics and hazardous waste. The county council is currently carrying out a feasibility study to assess the potential for using alternative technologies at the King's Lynn incinerator site. The study is due to be completed in the summer of 2023. In the meantime, the council is continuing to operate the incinerator in a safe and efficient manner. The plant is subject to regular environmental monitoring and meets all relevant emissions standards. A spokesperson for the county council said: "We are committed to exploring all options for the future of the King's Lynn incinerator. We are particularly interested in the potential for using alternative technologies that are more environmentally friendly and can process a wider range of waste materials." "The feasibility study will help us to assess the potential for these technologies and to make an informed decision about the future of the incinerator." The King's Lynn incinerator is one of three in Norfolk. The other two incinerators are located in Norwich and Great Yarmouth. The county council is also exploring options for replacing the Norwich incinerator, which is also nearing the end of its operational life. The Great Yarmouth incinerator is a newer facility and is not currently due for replacement.

title: Samsung apologises to sick factory workers
text: Samsung Apologises to Sick Factory Workers South Korean tech giant Samsung has issued an apology to hundreds of former factory workers who developed cancer and other illnesses after being exposed to toxic chemicals. The company said it "deeply regrets" the suffering caused to the workers, who were employed at its semiconductor and LCD factories in the cities of Suwon and Asan between 1990 and 2004. Samsung has agreed to pay compensation to the workers, who have been suffering from a range of illnesses, including leukemia, breast cancer, and lymphoma. The company said it will also establish a fund to support the workers and their families. The apology comes after a years-long campaign by the workers and their supporters, who have been demanding compensation and an apology from Samsung. The workers have accused the company of failing to protect them from the toxic chemicals used in the factories. Samsung has previously denied any wrongdoing, but the company's apology suggests that it is now accepting responsibility for the workers' illnesses. In a statement, Samsung said: "We deeply regret the physical and mental pain experienced by our former employees who developed illnesses while working at our semiconductor and LCD factories." "We sincerely apologise for not being able to provide a safe and healthy working environment for them," the statement added. The apology has been welcomed by the workers and their supporters. However, they say that the company must do more to ensure that such a tragedy does not happen again. "This is a victory for the workers and their families," said Hwang Sang-ki, head of the advocacy group Ban Asbestos Network Korea. "But Samsung must also take concrete steps to prevent this from happening again." The apology is a significant step, but it is only a first step. Samsung must now follow through on its promises to compensate the workers and their families and to establish a fund to support them. The company must also take steps to ensure that its factories are safe and healthy for all workers.

title: Spatial Framework: Housing plan undergoing 'radical rewrite'
text: Spatial Framework: Housing plan undergoing 'radical rewrite' The Scottish government's housing plan is being "radically rewritten" to meet the needs of local authorities and communities, Housing Minister Kevin Stewart has said. The Spatial Framework, which sets out where new homes should be built, was published in 2022 but has been criticized by some councils for not being ambitious enough. Stewart said the plan was being "refreshed" to ensure it is "fit for purpose" and meets the needs of the people of Scotland. He said: "We are committed to delivering more affordable homes for people across Scotland. The Spatial Framework is a key part of that, and we want to make sure it is fit for purpose. "We have listened to the concerns of local authorities and communities, and we are now working to address them. We will be publishing a revised Spatial Framework in the coming months." The Scottish government has committed to building 110,000 affordable homes by 2032. The Spatial Framework is designed to help achieve this target by identifying areas where new homes should be built. However, some councils have argued that the plan is not ambitious enough and does not take into account the needs of their local communities. The City of Edinburgh Council, for example, has said that the plan does not provide enough new homes for the city. The council has also said that the plan does not take into account the need for more affordable housing. The Scottish government has said that it is committed to working with local authorities to ensure that the Spatial Framework meets their needs. Stewart said: "We are committed to working with local authorities to deliver more affordable homes for the people of Scotland. We will continue to listen to their concerns and work with them to ensure that the Spatial Framework meets their needs." The revised Spatial Framework is expected to be published in the coming months.

title: Maghera firm makes chair for Pope Francis
text: Nestled in the heart of the picturesque village of Maghera, Northern Ireland, lies the renowned furniture manufacturer, Lapwood. With a rich heritage spanning over a century, Lapwood has garnered international acclaim for its exquisite craftsmanship and unwavering commitment to excellence. Recently, the company embarked on a momentous undertaking – the creation of a bespoke chair for His Holiness Pope Francis. The commission presented a unique opportunity for Lapwood to showcase its unparalleled skills and the unwavering dedication of its artisans. Meticulously crafted from the finest materials, the chair exudes an aura of elegance and reverence. Constructed from solid mahogany, its intricate carvings depict scenes from the life of Christ, a testament to the company's deep-rooted faith. The upholstery, a sumptuous blend of velvet and silk, was meticulously hand-stitched to perfection. Each stitch, a symbol of devotion, was lovingly executed, imbuing the chair with an ethereal beauty. Completing the masterpiece was a stunning canopy, its intricate embroidery portraying the symbols of the papacy, a fitting tribute to the spiritual leader. The journey of creating the papal chair was not without its challenges. Lapwood's craftsmen, guided by their unwavering passion, meticulously poured over every detail, ensuring that the finished product would be a masterpiece worthy of its august recipient. Long hours were spent in the workshop, each stroke of the chisel and stitch of the needle a testament to the artisans' unwavering dedication. Finally, the moment arrived when the chair was complete. It was a sight to behold, a work of art that transcended mere craftsmanship. With a mixture of pride and trepidation, Lapwood presented the papal chair to His Holiness Pope Francis during a special ceremony at the Vatican. Pope Francis, known for his humility and compassion, was deeply moved by the gift. He expressed his gratitude, praising Lapwood for its exceptional artistry and the profound symbolism imbued within the chair. It was a moment of immense pride for the company, a testament to its unwavering commitment to excellence and the profound impact it had on the spiritual leader. From its humble beginnings in the heart of rural Ireland, Lapwood has risen to become a global leader in bespoke furniture design. The papal chair, a masterpiece of craftsmanship and devotion, stands as a testament to the company's extraordinary talent and the enduring power of human artistry.

title: The rocket that eats itself
text: The Rocket That Eats Itself In a groundbreaking achievement, scientists have unveiled a revolutionary rocket design that consumes its own fuel tank to generate thrust. This innovative concept, known as the "cannibal rocket," has the potential to significantly enhance the efficiency and performance of space missions. The secret behind the cannibal rocket lies in its ability to use its own fuel tank as a source of propellant. By meticulously tailoring the shape and structure of the tank, engineers have enabled it to act as a nozzle that guides the expanding gases expelled by the engine. This eliminates the need for a separate nozzle, reducing the weight and complexity of the rocket. As the rocket ascends, it strategically consumes its fuel tank from the bottom upwards. This continuous process provides a constant flow of propellant to the engine, ensuring sustained thrust without the need for additional fuel tanks. The result is a more efficient and compact propulsion system that can carry a greater payload into space. The concept of a cannibal rocket has been explored for decades, but practical challenges have hindered its development. One major obstacle was the need to maintain the structural integrity of the fuel tank as it gradually erodes. To overcome this, researchers employed advanced materials and sophisticated engineering techniques to ensure that the tank can withstand the intense heat and pressure during the combustion process. The potential applications of cannibal rockets are vast. They could enable longer and more ambitious space missions, such as manned expeditions to Mars or the exploration of distant asteroids. Additionally, the reduced weight and complexity of these rockets could make them more cost-effective for commercial satellite launches and other space-based activities. Moreover, the cannibal rocket concept has implications beyond space exploration. The same principles could be applied to other propulsion systems, such as hypersonic aircraft and underwater vehicles. By eliminating the need for separate fuel tanks and nozzles, these systems can achieve greater efficiency and performance. The development of the cannibal rocket represents a significant milestone in rocketry. Its innovative design promises to revolutionize space exploration and open up new possibilities for the future of space travel. As scientists continue to refine and optimize this concept, we can expect to witness even greater advancements in the efficiency and capabilities of rockets in the years to come.

title: Footballer’s rare cancer tumour ‘size of a tennis ball’
text: Footballer's Rare Cancer Tumour 'Size of a Tennis Ball' Former footballer Andy Woodward has revealed he had a rare cancer tumour the size of a tennis ball removed from his kidney. The 49-year-old, who played for Blackburn Rovers, Sheffield United and England, underwent surgery in December 2021 after being diagnosed with clear cell renal cell carcinoma. Woodward, who retired from playing in 2004, said he had been experiencing back pain and fatigue for several months before being diagnosed. "It was a massive shock," he told the BBC. "I'm a fit and healthy guy, I don't smoke, I don't drink much, so it was a big surprise." The tumour was removed during a six-hour operation at St James's University Hospital in Leeds. "The surgeon said it was the biggest he had ever seen," said Woodward. "It was the size of a tennis ball and had grown into my kidney." Woodward is now recovering from surgery and is undergoing regular check-ups. He said he is "grateful" to the NHS for the care he has received. "I'm just so lucky that it was found early," he said. "If I had left it any longer, it could have been a lot worse." Clear cell renal cell carcinoma is a type of kidney cancer that is most common in people over the age of 50. It is usually curable if it is found early. Woodward said he is speaking out about his experience to raise awareness of the disease. "I want people to know that kidney cancer can happen to anyone, even young and healthy people," he said. "If you're experiencing any unusual symptoms, please get checked out by your doctor." Woodward's former clubs have expressed their support for him. Blackburn Rovers said in a statement: "We are incredibly proud of Andy for speaking out about his experience. He is an inspiration to us all." Sheffield United said: "Andy is a true warrior and we are behind him every step of the way." The Football Association (FA) has also praised Woodward for his bravery. "Andy is a role model for everyone in football," said an FA spokesperson. "His story is a powerful reminder that it is important to get checked out if you are experiencing any unusual symptoms."

title: #unfairandlovely: A new social campaign celebrates dark skin
text: #UnfairandLovely: A New Social Campaign Celebrates Dark Skin In a society that often glorifies fair skin, a new social campaign is challenging the narrative and celebrating the beauty of dark skin. #UnfairandLovely, launched by the non-profit organization Women of Worth, aims to empower individuals with darker skin tones and promote self-acceptance. The campaign's name cleverly plays on the derogatory term "unfair," which is often used to describe people with dark skin. By reclaiming this term, #UnfairandLovely turns the negative connotation on its head and transforms it into a positive affirmation. The campaign has gained significant traction on social media, with thousands of people sharing stories and images under the #UnfairandLovely hashtag. Participants have shared photos of themselves embracing their dark skin, along with personal narratives about the challenges and triumphs they have faced. "Growing up, I always felt like I didn't fit in because of my dark skin," said one participant. "I was constantly bombarded with messages that fair skin was better and more desirable. But this campaign has helped me to break free from that mindset and to embrace my unique beauty." #UnfairandLovely is not just about changing perceptions of beauty but also about challenging the systemic biases that perpetuate colorism. Colorism, the discrimination based on skin color, often results in reduced opportunities, both socially and economically, for people with darker skin tones. The campaign is calling for an end to these discriminatory practices and for the promotion of inclusivity and equality. It advocates for representation of dark-skinned individuals in all areas of society, from media to education and the workplace. "We want to create a world where everyone, regardless of their skin color, feels valued and respected," said the founder of Women of Worth. "This campaign is a catalyst for that change." #UnfairandLovely has also partnered with brands and organizations to promote diversity and inclusion. One such partnership is with the beauty company Dove, which has a long-standing commitment to celebrating women of all skin colors. Through its #UnfairandLovely campaign, Women of Worth is igniting a global conversation about the importance of embracing diversity and challenging the harmful beauty standards that have long marginalized people with darker skin. The campaign is a powerful reminder that beauty comes in all shapes, sizes, and shades.

title: Wrexham's Supporters Trust backs rival takeover bid
text: Wrexham's Supporters Trust (WST) has thrown its weight behind a rival takeover bid for the National League club. Wrexham Supporters Trust has confirmed it is backing a rival takeover bid for the club. A consortium led by local businessman Humphrey Ker has emerged as a potential buyer for the Racecourse Ground outfit. Ker's group is understood to have made an offer to buy the club from current owners Rob McElhenney and Ryan Reynolds. WST board members met with Ker and his consortium on Tuesday to discuss their plans for Wrexham. The trust has now released a statement confirming that it is backing the consortium's bid. The statement reads: "The Wrexham Supporters Trust board has met with the consortium led by Humphrey Ker and has been impressed with their plans for the club. "The consortium has a clear vision for the future of Wrexham AFC and has the financial backing to achieve its ambitions. "The trust believes that the consortium's bid is in the best interests of the club and its supporters. "We urge all Wrexham fans to get behind the consortium and its plans for the club." The consortium's bid is the second to be made public for Wrexham. Last month, a group led by former Wales international defender Craig Morgan also announced plans to buy the club. It is understood that McElhenney and Reynolds are still in talks with both consortiums. The American duo have owned Wrexham since 2020 and have overseen a period of significant investment in the club. However, they have also been criticized by some fans for their lack of involvement in the day-to-day running of the club. It is not yet clear when McElhenney and Reynolds will make a decision on which consortium to sell the club to. However, the WST's backing for the Ker consortium is a significant development in the takeover saga.

title: US Supreme Court hears case of Mexican teen slain by border patrol
text: In a highly anticipated case that has garnered international attention, the US Supreme Court heard arguments this week in the wrongful death lawsuit brought by the family of 16-year-old Sergio Adrián Hernández Güereca. Hernández was shot and killed in 2010 by a US Border Patrol agent while playing with friends on the Mexican side of the border. The case has raised fundamental questions about the excessive use of force, the rights of individuals at the border, and the accountability of law enforcement officers. The Mexican government has filed an amicus brief in support of the Hernández family, arguing that the shooting violated international law and the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations. The central issue before the Court is whether US agents can be held liable under US law for actions taken outside US territory. The Biden administration has argued that agents have qualified immunity from such suits, while the Hernández family's lawyers contend that the agents' actions were clearly unreasonable and excessive. During the oral arguments, Justice Elena Kagan expressed concern that a ruling in favor of the government would give agents "carte blanche" to use deadly force along the border. She questioned why the agents could not have used non-lethal means, such as warning shots or pepper spray, to deter Hernández and his friends. Justice Samuel Alito, however, suggested that the agents were justified in using deadly force because they believed Hernández was throwing rocks at them, which posed a threat to their safety. He argued that the agents had a "split-second" to make a decision and should not be held liable for their actions. The case has also sparked a broader debate about US border policy and the treatment of migrants. Advocates for immigrant rights have condemned the shooting as an example of excessive force and the militarization of the border. They argue that the use of deadly force against unarmed individuals violates basic human rights. The Court's decision in this case is expected to have significant implications for the accountability of law enforcement officers and the rights of individuals at the border. It will also send a message about US border policy and the treatment of migrants. A ruling in favor of the government could grant agents wide latitude to use deadly force, while a ruling in favor of the Hernández family could strengthen the protections for individuals at the border.

title: Northampton Town loan firm received £900k in VAT repayments
text: Northampton Town loan firm received £900k in VAT repayments A loan firm based in Northampton has received almost £900,000 in VAT repayments over the past four years, despite concerns about its lending practices. The firm, which cannot be named for legal reasons, has been the subject of numerous complaints from customers who say they were charged excessive interest rates and fees. In 2019, the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) investigated the firm and found that it had breached a number of regulations. The FCA imposed a £50,000 fine on the firm and ordered it to repay £1.2 million to customers. Despite the FCA's action, the firm has continued to receive VAT repayments. HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) has confirmed that the firm received £898,742 in VAT repayments between 2018 and 2022. HMRC said that it had carried out a review of the firm's VAT claims and was satisfied that they were valid. However, HMRC did not disclose the specific criteria that it used to assess the validity of the claims. The firm's receipt of VAT repayments has raised concerns among consumer groups. They argue that the repayments are effectively subsidising a firm that has been found to have breached regulations and charged excessive interest rates to customers. "It is deeply concerning that a firm that has been found to have breached regulations is still able to receive VAT repayments," said James Daley, managing director of Fairer Finance. "This suggests that there is a loophole in the system that allows firms to avoid paying their fair share of tax." The Treasury has said that it is unaware of any specific concerns about the firm's VAT repayments. However, the Treasury said that it would be willing to review the matter if specific evidence was provided. The firm declined to comment on its VAT repayments. Timeline of events 2018: The firm receives £224,432 in VAT repayments. 2019: The FCA investigates the firm and finds that it has breached regulations. title: Theresa May's 'honeymoon period' boosts Tory polling
text: Theresa May's "honeymoon period" as Prime Minister has boosted the Conservative Party's standing in the polls, according to a new survey. The poll, conducted by YouGov for The Times, found that the Conservatives have opened up a seven-point lead over the Labour Party, with 42% of voters saying they would vote Tory if an election were held tomorrow. This is the first time the Conservatives have led Labour in the polls since the 2015 general election. May's personal approval ratings have also improved since she became Prime Minister, with 46% of voters saying they approve of the way she is doing her job. This is up from 36% when she first took office. The poll suggests that May is enjoying a "honeymoon period" as Prime Minister, similar to that experienced by her predecessor David Cameron after the 2010 general election. Cameron's honeymoon period lasted around six months, and it remains to be seen whether May will be able to sustain her current levels of support for a similar amount of time. However, the poll also found that the public is still divided over May's policies. Only 37% of voters say they support her plan to trigger Article 50 and begin the process of leaving the European Union, while 39% oppose it. May's popularity is also likely to be tested by the upcoming negotiations with the EU over the terms of Britain's exit. If she is able to secure a good deal for the UK, it could further boost her support. However, if the negotiations are difficult or unsuccessful, it could damage her reputation and lead to a decline in her popularity. Overall, the poll suggests that May is enjoying a positive start to her premiership. However, it remains to be seen whether she will be able to sustain her current levels of support in the long term.

title: Welsh Government to implement ban on microbeads
text: The Welsh Government has announced a ban on the manufacture, sale, and use of products containing microbeads in Wales. Microbeads are tiny plastic particles that are often found in personal care products such as face washes, scrubs, and toothpastes. They are also used in industrial products such as paints and polishes. Microbeads are a major source of pollution, as they can easily enter the environment through wastewater treatment plants. Once in the environment, they can be ingested by marine life, where they can accumulate in the food chain and potentially cause harm to human health. The Welsh Government's ban on microbeads is part of a wider effort to reduce plastic pollution in Wales. The ban will come into force in 2023, and will apply to all products that are manufactured, sold, or used in Wales. The Welsh Government is the first UK government to implement a ban on microbeads. The ban has been welcomed by environmental groups, who have long campaigned for action to be taken on microbeads. "This is a landmark decision that will help to protect our environment and our health," said Friends of the Earth Cymru campaigner, Haf Elgar. "Microbeads are a major source of plastic pollution, and they can have a devastating impact on marine life. This ban will help to reduce the amount of plastic pollution in our oceans, and it will protect the health of our planet for future generations." The Welsh Government's ban on microbeads is a significant step forward in the fight against plastic pollution. It is hoped that other governments will follow Wales' lead and implement similar bans. In addition to the ban on microbeads, the Welsh Government is also working to reduce plastic pollution through a number of other measures. These include: A ban on the sale of single-use plastic bags A commitment to reduce the use of single-use plastics in the public sector Investment in research and development to find new and innovative ways to reduce plastic pollution The Welsh Government is committed to taking action on plastic pollution. The ban on microbeads is a significant step forward, and it is hoped that other governments will follow Wales' lead.

title: Porthmadog bypass section opens early for Cob festival
text: Porthmadog bypass section opens early for Cob festival A section of the new Porthmadog bypass has opened early to allow access to the town's popular Cob festival. The £135m bypass is due to open in full later this year, but the section between the A497 and the B4411 has been completed early to provide a vital link to the festival site. The festival attracts thousands of visitors to Porthmadog each year, and the new bypass will help to ease congestion and improve access to the event. The Welsh Government has provided £75m towards the cost of the bypass, with the remaining £60m coming from the UK Government. The bypass is expected to reduce journey times between Porthmadog and the A487 by up to 10 minutes, and it will also improve safety by removing through traffic from the town centre. The opening of the bypass section is a major milestone in the project, and it is a welcome boost for the Cob festival. Festival organisers delighted Festival organiser Alun Roberts said: "We are delighted that the bypass section has opened early for the Cob festival. "The Cob festival is a major event for Porthmadog, and we are expecting thousands of visitors this year. The new bypass will make it easier for people to get to the festival, and it will also help to improve safety in the town centre." It will make it easier for businesses to get their goods to market, and it will also attract new businesses to the area. The Welsh Government has said that the bypass is a key part of its plans to improve the economy of North Wales. Environmental benefits The bypass will also have environmental benefits. title: 'Lamentable' defence spending decisions attacked by MPs
text: MPs from across the political spectrum have strongly criticized the government's 'deplorable' defence spending decisions, accusing it of putting the UK's security at risk. The criticism came after the government announced plans to cut the number of British troops by 9,500, as well as reduce the size of the Royal Navy and the Royal Air Force. The cuts have been met with widespread condemnation from MPs, who argue that they will weaken the UK's ability to defend itself against potential threats. Tobias Ellwood, the Conservative MP who chairs the Commons Defence Committee, said the cuts were a "false economy" that would "diminish our ability to respond to threats around the world." He added: "It is a deplorable state of affairs when our armed forces are being cut at a time when the threats we face are increasing." Labour's shadow defence secretary, John Healey, said the cuts were a "betrayal" of the armed forces and would leave the UK "less safe." He said: "These cuts will make it harder for our armed forces to protect our country and its interests. It is a betrayal of our armed forces and it will make the UK less safe." The Liberal Democrats' defence spokesman, Jamie Stone, said the cuts were "short-sighted" and would "damage the UK's reputation as a global leader." He said: "These cuts are short-sighted and will damage the UK's reputation as a global leader. They will leave us less able to respond to threats around the world and will make us more vulnerable to attack." The government has defended the cuts, arguing that they are necessary to reduce the UK's budget deficit. A spokesperson for the Ministry of Defence said: "The government is committed to ensuring that the UK has the armed forces it needs to defend itself against all threats. We are making the necessary changes to ensure that our armed forces are fit for the future." However, the government's assurances have failed to convince MPs, who are demanding that the cuts be reversed. A group of cross-party MPs have tabled an amendment to the government's defence spending plans, which would require the government to increase defence spending by £20 billion over the next four years. The amendment is expected to be debated in the House of Commons in the coming weeks.

title: Jeremy Corbyn: Children's talents being squandered
text: Amidst the political turmoil engulfing the country, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has decried the government's "systematic dismantling" of vital services, warning that the nation's children are bearing the brunt of austerity measures. In a blistering speech delivered at a children's center in one of London's most deprived boroughs, Corbyn accused the Conservatives of "squandering the talents of a generation" through relentless cuts to education and youth services. "Every child in this country deserves the opportunity to reach their full potential," Corbyn proclaimed. "But this government is shamefully denying them that chance by ripping away the resources they need to thrive." The Labour leader painted a grim picture of a society where children from disadvantaged backgrounds are increasingly condemned to a future of poverty and inequality. He pointed to the closure of youth clubs, the reduction of educational support, and the rising cost of childcare as evidence of the government's neglect. "These services are not luxuries," Corbyn emphasized. "They are essential for giving our children the best possible start in life. By cutting them, the government is condemning countless young people to a cycle of deprivation and hopelessness." Corbyn's speech resonated strongly with the audience at the children's center, many of whom have witnessed firsthand the devastating impact of austerity on their communities. Parents and children alike expressed their frustration and anger at the government's policies. "My son used to go to the youth club every week," one mother lamented. "It was the only place he could go to feel safe and have fun. But now it's closed, and he's just hanging around the streets with nothing to do." A young boy named Daniel, who attends a local primary school, spoke of his dreams of becoming a doctor one day. However, he expressed concern that he may not be able to afford university fees without the support of free school meals. "I want to do well in school, but it's hard when you're always hungry," Daniel said. "I don't know how I'm going to pay for university if the government keeps cutting the budgets." Corbyn concluded his speech by pledging to reverse the government's austerity agenda and invest heavily in children's services. He promised to restore funding to schools, youth clubs, and childcare providers, ensuring that every child has the chance to succeed, regardless of their background. "Our children are our future," Corbyn declared. "We cannot afford to squander their talents. We must invest in them now, so that they can build a better future for themselves and for our country."

title: Download festival resurrected as government pilot
text: Download Festival Resurrected as Government Pilot After a two-year hiatus due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the iconic Download Festival is set to make a grand return this summer. However, this year's event will be unlike any other, as it will serve as a government pilot scheme for testing the safety of large-scale gatherings. The festival, held at Donington Park in Leicestershire, England, will take place from June 10-12 and will feature a host of rock and metal bands, including headliners Iron Maiden, KISS, and Biffy Clyro. However, attendees will be required to follow a strict set of rules and regulations to ensure the safety of all participants. All attendees will be required to present proof of a negative COVID-19 test within 24 hours of entering the site. They will also be encouraged to wear face coverings in crowded areas and to maintain social distancing whenever possible. The festival site will be divided into different zones, each with its own dedicated amenities and entry and exit points. This will help to reduce the risk of overcrowding and to facilitate contact tracing in the event of an outbreak. In addition, the festival will be implementing a number of other safety measures, such as: Enhanced cleaning and disinfection of all surfaces Increased availability of hand sanitizer stations The provision of face coverings for those who need them A dedicated medical team on site The government is closely monitoring the Download Festival pilot scheme and will use the data collected to inform its decision-making on the safe reopening of other large-scale events. Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden said: "We are committed to getting live events back up and running as soon as possible, and the Download Festival pilot scheme is a vital step in that process. We will be closely monitoring the event and using the data collected to ensure that we can reopen other events in a safe and responsible way." Download Festival organizer Andy Copping said: "We are delighted to be working with the government on this pilot scheme. The safety of our attendees is our top priority, and we are confident that the measures we are putting in place will allow us to deliver a safe and enjoyable event." The Download Festival pilot scheme is a significant step forward in the UK's recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. It is a sign that the government is committed to reopening the economy and getting live events back up and running.

title: Danny Kinahan appointed as NI's first veterans commissioner
text: Danny Kinahan appointed as NI's first veterans commissioner Danny Kinahan has been appointed as Northern Ireland's first veterans commissioner. The role was created in response to the recommendations of the Weston Review, which found that there was a need for a dedicated commissioner to advocate for the needs of veterans and their families. Kinahan is a former Royal Marine who served in Northern Ireland during the Troubles. He has also worked as a community worker and youth mentor. He said he was "honored" to be appointed to the role and pledged to work tirelessly to support veterans. "I am deeply committed to ensuring that veterans and their families receive the recognition and support they deserve," he said. "I will work closely with veterans' organizations, government departments, and other stakeholders to make sure that their needs are met." The veterans commissioner will be responsible for: Advocating for the needs of veterans and their families Providing advice and support to veterans on a range of issues, including welfare, housing, and employment Monitoring the delivery of services to veterans Raising awareness of the needs of veterans Working with other organizations to provide support to veterans The appointment of a veterans commissioner is a significant step forward in the recognition of the contribution made by veterans to Northern Ireland. The commissioner will play a vital role in ensuring that veterans and their families receive the support they need and deserve. Reaction to the appointment: The appointment of Danny Kinahan as veterans commissioner has been welcomed by veterans' organizations. The Royal British Legion said that the appointment was a "positive step forward" and that Kinahan was "well-respected" within the veterans' community. The Northern Ireland Veterans Association said that Kinahan was a "great choice" for the role and that he would bring "a wealth of experience" to the post. The appointment has also been welcomed by politicians. Northern Ireland Secretary Brandon Lewis said that Kinahan was a "highly experienced and respected individual" who would "do an excellent job" in the role. DUP leader Jeffrey Donaldson said that the appointment was a "positive development" and that Kinahan would "provide invaluable support to veterans." title: Lyft valued at $24bn ahead of share market debut
text: Lyft valued at $24bn ahead of share market debut Ride-hailing firm Lyft has confirmed plans to float on the US stock market, valuing the company at $24bn (£18bn). The firm, which is the second largest ride-hailing company in the US, will list its shares on the Nasdaq exchange on Friday. It comes as Uber, its main rival, prepares for its own stock market flotation later this year. Lyft's initial public offering (IPO) will raise $2.3bn, the company said. The firm had previously been valued at $15.1bn when it raised $600m from investors last year. The size of Lyft's IPO values it well below Uber, which was valued at $76bn following its most recent fundraising. Lyft's prospectus for the IPO reveals that the company made a loss of $911m on revenue of $2.16bn in 2018. However, it says that the number of active riders on its platform increased by 53% over the year to 30.7 million. Lyft says in the prospectus that it believes it is "well-positioned" to benefit from the growth of the ride-hailing market. "We believe that the ride-hailing market is a large and growing market with significant growth potential," the firm said. "We are well-positioned to capitalise on this growth potential by leveraging our strong brand, our large and growing network of drivers and riders, and our innovative technology." Lyft's stock market debut comes at a time of increased scrutiny of the ride-hailing industry. In recent months, there have been concerns raised about the safety of passengers and drivers, as well as the working conditions of drivers. Lyft says in its prospectus that it is "committed to operating our business in a safe and responsible manner". "We believe that our commitment to safety will be a key competitive advantage for us as we continue to grow our business," the firm said. Lyft's IPO is expected to be one of the largest in the US this year. The company's shares will trade under the ticker symbol "LYFT".

title: Further rise in NHS Scotland consultant vacancies
text: A sharp rise in consultant vacancies at NHS Scotland has been recorded, with the number of unfilled posts increasing by 10% in the past year, new figures show. There are now 1,018 consultant vacancies in Scotland, up from 929 in June 2022. This is the highest number of vacancies since records began in 2007. The British Medical Association (BMA) Scotland said the figures were "extremely concerning" and warned that the NHS was facing a "staffing crisis". Dr Lewis Morrison, chairman of BMA Scotland, said: "These figures lay bare the extent of the staffing crisis facing the NHS in Scotland. With over 1,000 consultant posts now vacant, it is clear that the health service is struggling to attract and retain the staff it needs to deliver safe and effective patient care." He added: "The Scottish government must take urgent action to address this issue. We need to see a long-term plan to increase the number of consultants working in Scotland, and we need to make sure that the NHS is an attractive place to work." The Scottish government said it was "committed to increasing the number of consultants working in Scotland" and that it was "working closely with NHS boards to address the issue of vacancies". A spokesperson for the government said: "We are investing £10 million in a new national recruitment campaign to attract more consultants to Scotland. We are also working to improve the working environment for consultants, and we are providing support for those who are new to the role." However, the BMA said that the government's plans were not enough. Dr Morrison said: "The Scottish government's plans to increase the number of consultants working in Scotland are welcome, but they do not go far enough. We need to see a long-term plan that will address the root causes of the staffing crisis in the NHS." He added: "The NHS is facing a perfect storm of challenges, including an aging population, increasing demand for services, and a shortage of staff. The Scottish government must take urgent action to address these challenges and ensure that the NHS is able to continue to provide safe and effective patient care."

title: Newtownabbey murder: police investigate drugs links
text: Police in Northern Ireland are investigating whether a murder in Newtownabbey on Tuesday evening was linked to drugs. The victim, named locally as Gary Coleman, 42, was shot several times outside his home in the Rathcoole area at around 7pm. Detective Chief Inspector John Caldwell said: "We are treating this as a murder investigation and our inquiries are ongoing. Caldwell said police were "keeping an open mind" about the motive for the killing but that one line of inquiry was whether it was linked to drugs. "We are aware that Mr Coleman had previous convictions for drug offences and we are investigating whether this was a factor in his murder," he said. "We would appeal to anyone who has any information about this murder to contact us." The murder has shocked the local community, with many people expressing their condolences to Coleman's family. One resident, who did not want to be named, said: "This is a terrible tragedy. Gary was a well-known character in the area and he will be sadly missed." title: Doctors 'miss' underweight children, UCL study suggests
text: Doctors 'miss' underweight children, UCL study suggests Children who are underweight are being "missed" by doctors, a new study suggests. The research, published in the journal Pediatrics, found that nearly half of underweight children in the UK are not identified by their GP. This is despite the fact that underweight children are at increased risk of health problems, including stunted growth, delayed development, and weakened immune systems. The study, led by researchers at University College London (UCL), analyzed data from over 3,000 children aged 0-19 in the UK. They found that 5.4% of children were underweight, defined as having a body mass index (BMI) below the 5th percentile. However, only 27.6% of underweight children had been identified by their GP. This means that nearly half of underweight children are not receiving the care and support they need to improve their health. The researchers say that there are a number of reasons why doctors may miss underweight children. One reason is that underweight children may not be noticeably thin. Another reason is that doctors may not be routinely measuring children's weight and height. The researchers say that it is important for doctors to be aware of the signs and symptoms of underweight children. They also say that doctors should routinely measure children's weight and height. This will help to ensure that underweight children are identified and receive the care they need. The study also found that underweight children were more likely to be from disadvantaged backgrounds. This suggests that poverty may be a risk factor for underweight. The researchers say that further research is needed to explore the link between poverty and underweight. They also say that interventions are needed to improve the health of underweight children. These interventions could include providing financial support to families, improving access to healthy food, and increasing awareness of the importance of healthy eating.

title: UK banks 'prepared for Brexit and trade war fall-out'
text: UK banks 'prepared for Brexit and trade war fall-out' British banks are well-prepared to withstand the potential economic fallout from Brexit and a global trade war, according to a new report. The analysis by consultancy firm EY found that UK lenders have increased their capital buffers and reduced their exposure to risky assets in recent years. This has made them more resilient to financial shocks. The report also found that UK banks have been diversifying their sources of funding, making them less reliant on wholesale markets. This means that they are less likely to be affected by a downturn in the global economy. "UK banks have taken a number of steps to prepare for the potential impact of Brexit and a trade war," said EY's banking and capital markets leader, Omar Ali. "These measures have made them more resilient to financial shocks and better able to support the UK economy." The report comes as the UK prepares to leave the European Union on 29 March 2019. There is uncertainty about the terms of the UK's exit from the EU, and some businesses are concerned about the potential impact on the UK economy. However, the EY report suggests that UK banks are well-prepared for any potential economic shocks. The report found that UK banks have increased their capital buffers by 25% since 2014. This means that they have more money available to absorb losses in the event of a downturn. UK banks have also reduced their exposure to risky assets. The report found that the proportion of risky assets on UK banks' balance sheets has fallen from 30% to 20% since 2014. This means that UK banks are less likely to be affected by a fall in asset prices. In addition, UK banks have been diversifying their sources of funding. The report found that the proportion of wholesale funding on UK banks' balance sheets has fallen from 60% to 40% since 2014. This means that UK banks are less reliant on short-term funding, which can be more expensive and less stable. The EY report suggests that UK banks are well-prepared for any potential economic shocks. The report found that UK banks have increased their capital buffers, reduced their exposure to risky assets, and diversified their sources of funding. These measures have made them more resilient to financial shocks and better able to support the UK economy.

title: Flinstshire man awarded £3,750 after care package stopped
text: A Flintshire man has been awarded £3,750 after his care package was stopped without warning. The 65-year-old, who wishes to remain anonymous, was receiving a care package from Flintshire County Council which included help with washing, dressing, and cooking. However, in January 2023, the council stopped the care package without giving him any notice. The man was left struggling to cope and had to rely on help from friends and family. He complained to the council and the Local Government Ombudsman, who found that the council had failed to properly assess his needs before stopping his care package. The ombudsman ordered the council to pay the man £3,750 in compensation and to reinstate his care package. The man said he was "relieved" that the ombudsman had found in his favor. "I was really struggling to cope without my care package," he said. "I'm glad that the council has been ordered to pay me compensation and to reinstate my care package." A spokesperson for Flintshire County Council said: "We are sorry that Mr X's care package was stopped without proper notice. "We have now reinstated his care package and have paid him £3,750 in compensation. "We have also reviewed our procedures to ensure that this does not happen again." The Local Government Ombudsman said that the council had failed to follow its own policies and procedures when it stopped the man's care package. The ombudsman said: "The council should have carried out a proper assessment of Mr X's needs before stopping his care package. "The council also failed to give Mr X any notice that his care package was going to be stopped. "This caused Mr X a great deal of distress and inconvenience." The ombudsman ordered the council to pay the man £3,750 in compensation and to reinstate his care package. The council has now reinstated the man's care package and has paid him £3,750 in compensation.

title: Doctors said Herefordshire woman's bowel cancer was piles
text: A Herefordshire woman is urging people not to ignore symptoms of bowel cancer after doctors initially mistook hers for piles. Jackie Trow, from Ledbury, was diagnosed with stage three bowel cancer in February 2023, having initially gone to her GP in September 2022 with bleeding and changes to her bowel habits. However, she was told she had piles and was given cream. "I just thought, 'Oh well, I've got piles, I'll just crack on'," she said. But her symptoms did not improve and she returned to the GP in December 2022, when she was referred for further tests. These tests revealed a tumor in her bowel and she was diagnosed with cancer. Trow, 59, underwent surgery to remove the tumor in January 2023 and is now undergoing chemotherapy. She said she was "shocked" to be diagnosed with cancer and said she had no idea she was at risk. "I'm quite fit and healthy, I don't smoke, I don't drink, I eat healthily," she said. "I had no idea I was at risk of bowel cancer." Trow is now urging people not to ignore symptoms of bowel cancer and to seek medical advice as soon as possible. "If you have any changes in your bowel habits, or any bleeding, don't just ignore it," she said. "Go to your GP and get checked out. It could save your life." Dr. Matt Watkinson, a GP at Ledbury Medical Practice, said it is important to be aware of the symptoms of bowel cancer and to seek medical advice if you have any concerns. "Bowel cancer is the fourth most common cancer in the UK and it's important to be aware of the symptoms," he said. "These symptoms can include bleeding from the back passage, changes in bowel habits, abdominal pain, and unexplained weight loss. "If you have any of these symptoms, it's important to see your GP as soon as possible. Early diagnosis and treatment can improve your chances of survival."

title: Unhealthy food 'returning to school' warn caterers
text: Unhealthy Food 'Returning to School' Warn Caterers School caterers have raised concerns that unhealthy food is making a comeback in schools, undermining efforts to promote healthy eating habits among children. The warning comes as new research suggests that the proportion of schools offering unhealthy food options has increased in recent years. A survey conducted by the School Food Trust found that 43% of schools now offer sugary drinks, compared to 12% in 2013. The survey also revealed that 25% of schools offer crisps, and 42% offer chocolate bars. These findings contradict government guidelines, which recommend that schools should provide healthy and nutritious food options for their pupils. The catering industry has attributed the increase in unhealthy food offerings to a number of factors, including budget constraints and parental pressure. Some caterers argue that they are forced to sell unhealthy food to make ends meet, while others claim that parents demand access to such products. However, public health experts argue that schools have a responsibility to protect the health of their pupils. They emphasize that unhealthy food can contribute to a range of health problems, including obesity, tooth decay, and heart disease. "Schools should be places where children can learn about and access healthy food," said Dr. Susan Jebb, a nutrition and public health expert at the University of Oxford. "Offering unhealthy options undermines these efforts and sends the wrong message to children." The return of unhealthy food to schools has prompted calls for stricter regulations. Some experts are proposing a ban on the sale of sugary drinks and junk food in schools, while others believe that schools should be given more resources to provide healthier options. The government has stated that it is committed to improving the health of children and will explore a range of options to reduce the availability of unhealthy food in schools. In the meantime, caterers and parents are urged to work together to ensure that children have access to healthy and nutritious food. "It's important that we all play our part in creating a healthy school environment," said Barbara Crowther, chief executive of the School Food Trust. "Schools, caterers, and parents all have a role to fulfill."

title: Covid: UK must prepare for 'hard winter' of flu - expert
text: The UK must prepare itself for a "hard winter" of flu, with Covid-19 continuing to circulate, an expert has warned. Professor Peter Openshaw, a member of the New and Emerging Respiratory Virus Threats Advisory Group (Nervtag), said there was "no room for complacency". He said the UK's flu vaccine programme was one of the best in the world, but it was "not perfect". The NHS is urging people to get their flu jab as soon as possible to protect themselves from the virus. Eligible people in England can book their jab online or by calling 119. Prof Openshaw told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "I think we need to be thinking about the winter ahead as being a potentially difficult winter, because we've got flu coming back and we've still got Covid circulating. "I think flu could be quite severe this year. We haven't had much flu for the last couple of years because of all the other measures that we've had in place to try and control Covid. "But flu is still out there and it's likely to come back quite strongly this year." He said it was important to remember that flu can be a "very nasty disease" and can lead to hospitalisation and even death. "I would urge everybody to take up the offer of flu vaccination. It's the best way to protect yourself and your loved ones," he said. Dr Susan Hopkins, chief medical adviser at the UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA), said the flu jab was "the best way to protect yourself and your loved ones". She said: "The flu vaccine is safe and effective. It's the best way to protect yourself and your loved ones from the virus. "I urge everyone who is eligible to get their flu jab as soon as possible." The flu vaccine is offered free to people at risk, including those aged 65 and over, pregnant women, and people with certain health conditions. The NHS is also offering a free Covid-19 booster jab to people aged 50 and over, and those with certain health conditions. People can book their Covid-19 booster jab online or by calling 119.

title: High heels row: Petition for work dress code law rejected
text: A petition calling for a law against mandatory high-heel dress codes in the workplace has been rejected by the UK government, despite receiving over 150,000 signatures. The petition, started by Nicola Thorp in 2016 after she was sent home from work for refusing to wear high heels, argued that such dress codes were discriminatory and caused physical pain. In its response, the government said that existing laws already provided sufficient protection against discrimination and that it did not believe a specific law on high heels was necessary. It also pointed out that employers were free to set their own dress codes, as long as they were applied fairly and did not discriminate against any particular group of employees. Thorp, who launched a campaign called "Time's Up on Heels" after her experience, said she was "deeply disappointed" by the government's decision. She argued that the existing laws on discrimination were not strong enough to protect women from being forced to wear high heels, and that a specific law was needed to make it clear that such dress codes were unacceptable. "This is a missed opportunity to send a clear message that women should not be discriminated against because of their choice of footwear," Thorp said. "It is time for the government to take action and ensure that women are not forced to choose between their dignity and their livelihood." The government's decision has also been criticized by trade unions and women's rights groups. The Trades Union Congress (TUC) said that the government was "out of touch" with the experiences of women in the workplace, while the Fawcett Society said that the decision was "a blow to women's equality." The issue of high-heel dress codes has been debated for many years, with some arguing that they are a form of sexism and discrimination, while others contend that they are a legitimate part of a professional dress code. A number of countries, including Canada and Australia, have already banned mandatory high-heel dress codes, while others, such as the UK and the US, are still considering the issue. In the UK, the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) has said that it is unlawful for employers to discriminate against employees on the basis of their sex, which could include forcing them to wear high heels. However, the EHRC has also said that employers are able to set dress codes, as long as they are applied fairly and do not discriminate against any particular group of employees.

title: Derek Bonnard: Cleveland officer 'branded criminal'
text: Derek Bonnard was a Cleveland police officer who was branded a criminal after he was convicted of stealing $200,000 from a drug dealer.
