title: Are these north Wales hills sitting on a gold mine?
text: Nestled amidst the breathtaking landscape of north Wales, the rugged hills of Bwlchgwyn and Cefn Mawr have long held a tantalizing secret - the potential to harbor vast reserves of gold. Recent exploration by mining company Alba Mineral Resources has ignited excitement among geologists and investors alike, raising the tantalizing prospect that these hills could be sitting on a gold mine. Historical records hint at the presence of gold in the area dating back to Roman times. However, it was not until the 19th century that serious exploration began. In the 1860s, a gold rush gripped the region, attracting miners from far and wide. While some small-scale mining operations did uncover some gold, the veins proved to be narrow and inconsistent, leading to the eventual decline of the rush. Fast forward to the present day, and Alba Mineral Resources has embarked on a renewed exploration campaign using cutting-edge technology. Their focus is on a potentially large gold deposit that lies deep beneath the hills, known as the Bwlchgwyn Gold Project. Through extensive drilling and core sampling, Alba has identified several gold-bearing zones. The most significant of these is the Central Zone, which has shown consistently high gold grades over a substantial area. Further drilling is underway to delineate the full extent of this zone and to estimate the potential size and value of the deposit. "The results we've seen so far are very encouraging," said Alba's exploration manager, Dr. Mark Jones. "We're excited about the potential of this project to deliver a significant new gold resource for Wales." The company's exploration activities have sparked interest from the wider mining industry and the financial community. Investors are keen to get involved in what could potentially be a lucrative investment opportunity. However, it is important to note that exploration is still ongoing, and there is no guarantee that the Bwlchgwyn Gold Project will ultimately prove to be economically viable. Further drilling and analysis are required to fully understand the size and quality of the deposit. Furthermore, the project would require significant investment and infrastructure to develop. Environmental considerations and local community engagement will also be key factors in determining the future of the project. Despite these uncertainties, the potential rewards of the Bwlchgwyn Gold Project are undeniably tantalizing. If Alba's exploration efforts prove successful, it could transform the area, bringing economic benefits and creating new jobs. It could also establish north Wales as a significant player in the global gold mining industry.

title: India mango farmers angry at dump plan
text: In the verdant heart of India's mango-producing belt, a storm of anger is brewing among farmers over the government's plans to dump thousands of tonnes of imported Alphonso mangoes. The move, intended to ease dwindling domestic supplies and cool soaring prices, has sent shockwaves through a community that relies heavily on the fruit for their livelihoods. Farmers fear the influx of foreign mangoes will flood the market, driving down prices and potentially ruining their businesses. "This is a death knell for mango farmers," said Sanjay Jadhav, a farmer from the western state of Maharashtra. "Why import mangoes when our own farmers are struggling?" The government's decision stems from a shortfall in domestic production this year due to unfavourable weather conditions. To address the gap, it granted permission to import 20,000 tonnes of Alphonso mangoes from the neighbouring country of Pakistan. However, farmers argue that the imported mangoes will not only harm their livelihoods but also compromise the reputation of Indian Alphonso mangoes, renowned worldwide for their sweet and juicy flavour. "Pakistan produces different varieties of Alphonso mangoes," said Satish Patwari, a farmer from the Alphonso-growing district of Ratnagiri. "Mixing them with our own mangoes will damage the brand and reduce consumer confidence." The farmers' concerns are echoed by industry experts, who warn that the import plan could disrupt the delicate balance of the mango market. "The government should have explored alternative options, such as increasing domestic production or importing from other countries with similar mango varieties," said Parag Parikh, an agricultural economist. The government, for its part, insists that the import move is a temporary measure to ensure adequate supply and prevent price spikes. It has promised to provide compensation to farmers affected by the decision. But for the mango farmers of India, the government's assurances ring hollow. They demand a reversal of the import decision and a long-term plan to support domestic mango production. "We are not asking for handouts," said Jadhav. "We want the government to create a supportive environment where mango farmers can thrive and continue to produce the best mangoes in the world." As the mango season approaches its peak, the battle between India's mango farmers and the government continues to simmer, threatening the livelihoods of thousands and the reputation of an iconic fruit.

title: Ari Fuld killing: $1m raised for family by crowdfunders
text: In a remarkable display of global solidarity, over $1 million has been raised for the family of Ari Fuld, an Israeli-American father of four who was brutally murdered in a terrorist attack in the West Bank on Sunday. The outpouring of support has been driven by a crowdfunding campaign launched by Fuld's friends in the US, which has seen donations pour in from around the world. Fuld, a 45-year-old dual US-Israeli citizen, was stabbed to death while driving his car near the Jewish settlement of Efrat. The attack was claimed by the Palestinian militant group Hamas, which hailed Fuld's killing as a "heroic operation" against Israeli settlers. The crowdfunding campaign, hosted on the GoFundMe platform, was set up by Fuld's close friend, Rabbi Yaakov Menken. The initial goal was to raise $500,000 to support Fuld's wife and four young children, but that target was quickly surpassed. As of Tuesday morning, the campaign had raised over $1.1 million, with donations coming from more than 14,000 people from 50 countries. In a statement posted on the GoFundMe page, Rabbi Menken thanked the global community for their "overwhelming outpouring of love and support." He said that the money raised would help Fuld's family "during this incredibly difficult time" and allow them to focus on rebuilding their lives. "Ari was a true hero who dedicated his life to protecting Israel and its people," Rabbi Menken wrote. "His legacy will live on through the countless lives he touched and the impact he had on the world." The killing of Ari Fuld has been widely condemned by world leaders, including US President Donald Trump and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Trump called the attack a "horrific act of terrorism" and vowed to stand with Israel in the fight against terrorism. Netanyahu vowed to "bring the despicable murderers to justice" and said that Fuld's death would not be in vain. The crowdfunding campaign for Ari Fuld's family has been praised as a powerful example of how people from around the world can come together in the face of tragedy. It is a testament to the deep bonds of friendship and solidarity that unite people across borders and religious divides.

title: Google Android phone shipments increase by 886%
text: Google Android Phone Shipments Surge by 886% Google's Android operating system has seen a remarkable surge in popularity, with shipments of Android-powered smartphones increasing by 886% year-over-year in the second quarter of 2023. This exponential growth has cemented Android's position as the dominant force in the mobile phone market. According to data from market research firm Canalys, Android's market share reached an astounding 87% in Q2, a significant increase from its 75% share in the same period last year. This surge has been driven by a combination of factors, including the growing popularity of budget-friendly Android devices and the expansion of the Android ecosystem. The rapid growth of Android shipments has been particularly noticeable in emerging markets, where the demand for affordable smartphones is high. Android phones have become increasingly accessible to a broader range of consumers, thanks to the availability of low-cost models and the flexibility of the Android platform. In addition, Google's efforts to enhance the Android experience have played a significant role in its success. Regular software updates, improved security features, and a wide selection of apps and services have made Android devices more appealing to users. The dominance of Android has also been bolstered by the rise of Chinese smartphone manufacturers. Companies like Huawei, Xiaomi, and OPPO have been aggressively pushing their Android-powered devices into the global market, challenging established players like Apple and Samsung. The growth of Android shipments has had a significant impact on the smartphone industry. It has led to increased competition, lower prices for consumers, and a wider range of devices to choose from. Furthermore, Android's dominance has spurred innovation in the mobile ecosystem, with developers creating new apps and services specifically designed for the platform. As Android continues to gain ground, it is expected to further reshape the smartphone market. The platform's affordability, flexibility, and growing ecosystem position it well to maintain its leadership position for the foreseeable future.

title: Covid in Scotland: Hundreds hit with Covid fines over new year
text: Hundreds of people across Scotland have been fined for breaching Covid-19 regulations over the New Year period. Police Scotland said on Monday that 300 fixed penalty notices were issued between December 31 and January 2. The force said the majority of fines were for house parties, with others issued for large gatherings in public places. Assistant Chief Constable Alan Speirs said: "Our approach throughout the pandemic has been to engage with the public, explain the regulations and encourage compliance. "However, we will not hesitate to use enforcement where necessary to protect public health." The Scottish government has urged people to follow the rules in place to help stop the spread of the virus. First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said: "The vast majority of people in Scotland are following the rules and doing everything they can to help suppress the virus. "But it is clear that a small minority are not and their actions are putting others at risk. "We have repeatedly asked people to follow the rules and we have given them plenty of time to do so. "But we will not hesitate to take action against those who continue to flout the rules and put others at risk." The Scottish government has introduced a number of measures to help stop the spread of the virus, including a ban on gatherings of more than six people from different households. People are also being urged to stay at home as much as possible and to work from home if they can. The Scottish government has also introduced a number of financial support measures to help businesses and individuals affected by the pandemic. These measures include grants for businesses, loans for individuals and a temporary increase in Universal Credit payments. The Scottish government has said that it will continue to review the situation and will make changes to the regulations as necessary. The Scottish government has also urged people to get vaccinated against Covid-19. The vaccine is free and available to everyone over the age of 12. The Scottish government has said that the vaccine is the best way to protect yourself and others from the virus.

title: Covid: Wales-wide lockdown questioned by Tories
text: The Welsh government's decision to impose a Wales-wide lockdown has been criticised by the Welsh Conservatives, who have called for a more targeted approach. First Minister Mark Drakeford announced on Friday that Wales would enter a 17-day "firebreak" lockdown from 6pm on Friday 23 October, amid rising Covid-19 cases. The lockdown will see schools, non-essential shops and hospitality businesses close, and people will be advised to stay at home as much as possible. But Welsh Conservative leader Paul Davies said the lockdown was a "blunt instrument" that would "do more harm than good". He said the government should have considered a more targeted approach, such as localised lockdowns in areas with high levels of Covid-19 cases. "The Welsh government has once again taken the easy option of a blanket lockdown, rather than taking a more targeted approach," Mr Davies said. "This lockdown will have a devastating impact on our economy and will cause untold damage to our businesses and livelihoods. "The Welsh government needs to think again and come up with a more proportionate response to the current situation." The Welsh government has defended its decision to impose a lockdown, saying it is necessary to prevent the NHS from being overwhelmed. Health Minister Vaughan Gething said the lockdown was "not an easy decision" but that it was "the right decision". "We know that a lockdown will have a significant impact on people's lives, but we believe that it is necessary to protect the NHS and save lives," Mr Gething said. "We are asking everyone in Wales to play their part and follow the rules of the lockdown. "By working together, we can get through this difficult time." The lockdown in Wales will be reviewed after 17 days.

title: Uber sells self-driving cars to focus on profits
text: In a surprising move, transportation giant Uber has announced the sale of its self-driving car unit to Aurora Innovation, a leading autonomous vehicle technology company. This decision marks a significant shift in Uber's strategy as it pivots its focus towards profitability and core ride-hailing services. Uber's self-driving car program has been in development for several years, with a substantial investment of time and resources. However, despite early promises and successful demonstration projects, the company has faced challenges in bringing its autonomous vehicles to commercial operation. The technical and regulatory hurdles proved more complex and time-consuming than initially anticipated. Moreover, Uber's self-driving car ambitions have faced financial constraints. The unit has consistently operated at a loss, and recent market conditions have made it difficult for the company to justify continued investment in a venture that is not yet generating revenue. By selling its self-driving car unit, Uber is acknowledging the challenges involved in bringing autonomous vehicles to market. Instead, it will focus on its core ride-hailing business, which has proven to be a profitable and growing segment. Uber's decision to prioritize profitability is not unexpected in the current economic climate. The company has recently made several cost-cutting moves, including layoffs and the sale of non-core assets. By divesting its self-driving car unit, Uber can free up capital and resources to invest in its core business and improve its financial performance. Aurora Innovation, the buyer of Uber's self-driving car unit, is a well-funded and experienced player in the autonomous vehicle industry. The company has a strong track record in developing and testing self-driving technologies and has partnerships with major automakers such as Toyota and Hyundai. The acquisition of Uber's self-driving car unit will boost Aurora Innovation's capabilities and accelerate its progress towards commercializing autonomous vehicles. Aurora will gain access to Uber's extensive data, software, and hardware, as well as a team of experienced engineers and scientists. While Uber's decision to sell its self-driving car unit may disappoint some, it is a pragmatic move that reflects the challenges and uncertainties of the autonomous vehicle industry. Uber's prioritization of profitability and focus on its core ride-hailing business will ensure its long-term sustainability and success.

text: Janet Jackson, 50, has confirmed that she is expecting her first child with her husband, Wissam Al Mana. Jackson's pregnancy is a reminder that it is possible to have a happy and healthy pregnancy later in life. She is an inspiration to women everywhere who dream of becoming a parent.

title: Coronavirus: Norwich theatre group facing huge job losses
text: Coronavirus: Norwich theatre group facing huge job losses A Norwich theatre group is facing the loss of up to 80% of its workforce due to the coronavirus pandemic. Norwich Theatre Royal and Playhouse is one of the largest regional theatres in the UK, employing around 200 people. But the theatre has been closed since March and is not expected to reopen until next year. As a result, the theatre has launched a redundancy consultation process, which could see up to 160 jobs lost. The theatre's chief executive, Stephen Crocker, said the decision was "heartbreaking". "We have spent the last few months exploring every possible avenue to avoid redundancies," he said. "But the reality is that the impact of COVID-19 has been devastating for our industry. "We have lost millions of pounds in revenue and we have no idea when we will be able to reopen." The theatre has been receiving government support through the furlough scheme, but this scheme is due to end in October. Without further support, the theatre will not be able to afford to keep all of its staff on. The news has been met with shock and sadness by the theatre's staff and supporters. "This is a huge blow for Norwich," said one employee. "The theatre is a vital part of the city's cultural life and it would be a tragedy to lose it." The theatre is now appealing for financial support from the government and the public. "We are doing everything we can to save jobs," said Crocker. "But we need help. We need the government to extend the furlough scheme and we need the public to support us by buying tickets for our future shows." The theatre has launched a fundraising campaign called #SaveOurTheatre. The campaign aims to raise £1 million to help the theatre through the crisis. "We are determined to come out of this stronger than ever," said Crocker. "But we need your help. Please support us and help us to save Norwich Theatre Royal and Playhouse."

title: Google blocking 18m coronavirus scam emails every day
text: Google Blocks 18 Million Coronavirus Scam Emails Daily Amidst the ongoing battle against the COVID-19 pandemic, Google has revealed that its security systems are actively blocking a staggering 18 million coronavirus-related scam emails every single day. These malicious emails often attempt to exploit the heightened anxiety surrounding the virus and target vulnerable individuals. Cybercriminals use deceptive tactics to lure recipients into clicking on malicious links or providing sensitive information, such as passwords and credit card numbers. Google's security measures employ a combination of algorithms, machine learning, and human analysis to identify and block these scam emails. The company's Gmail service, which handles billions of emails daily, plays a pivotal role in protecting users from these threats. According to Google, the most common types of coronavirus scam emails include: Phishing attempts: Emails that appear to come from legitimate organizations, such as government agencies or healthcare providers, but contain malicious links that redirect recipients to websites designed to steal personal data. Misinformation campaigns: Emails that spread false or misleading information about the virus, such as promoting unproven treatments or claiming that the pandemic is a hoax. Financial scams: Emails that offer fraudulent deals or services, such as fake cures or financial assistance, and request payment in advance. Google urges users to exercise caution when receiving emails related to COVID-19. The company advises individuals to: Be wary of emails from unknown senders or organizations. Avoid clicking on suspicious links or opening attachments. Never share sensitive information, such as passwords or credit card numbers, via email. Report phishing attempts or other suspicious emails to Google. In addition to its automated security measures, Google also advises users to educate themselves about common scams and cyber threats. By staying informed, individuals can better protect themselves from falling victim to these malicious attempts. The company's efforts to combat coronavirus-related scams are part of its ongoing commitment to user safety and cybersecurity. By leveraging its advanced technology and expertise, Google aims to provide a secure online environment for its billions of users worldwide.

title: Does Labour have an 'Ed Miliband problem'?
text: Labour's leadership contest has reached its final stages, with the party membership set to vote on their next leader. The frontrunner in the race is Keir Starmer, the shadow Brexit secretary, who is seen as the most electable candidate. However, his main rival, Rebecca Long-Bailey, is seen as the candidate most likely to unite the party. One of the key issues in the contest has been the legacy of Ed Miliband, the former Labour leader who lost the 2015 general election. Miliband was a divisive figure, and his leadership is seen by some as one of the reasons for Labour's defeat. Starmer has sought to distance himself from Miliband's legacy, while Long-Bailey has embraced it. She has said that she wants to "finish the job" that Miliband started, and she has promised to continue his policies on issues such as austerity and inequality. Some commentators believe that Labour's defeat in 2015 was due to Miliband's unpopularity, and that the party needs to move away from his legacy in order to win back voters. Others argue that Miliband was a victim of circumstances, and that the party should not abandon his policies. The issue of Miliband's legacy is likely to continue to be a major talking point in the Labour leadership contest. It is a question that the party will need to answer if it wants to win the next general election. A recent poll by YouGov found that 42% of Labour members believe that Miliband was a good leader, while 38% believe that he was a bad leader. The poll also found that 52% of Labour members believe that the party should move away from Miliband's legacy, while 33% believe that it should continue his policies. These findings suggest that there is no clear consensus among Labour members on Miliband's legacy. It is an issue that is likely to continue to be debated in the run-up to the party's leadership election. The Labour leadership contest is a crucial moment for the party. The party is at a crossroads, and it needs to decide which direction it wants to go in. The issue of Miliband's legacy is a key part of that decision.

title: Coronavirus: St Albans' The Horn venue 'gobsmacked' at support
text: Coronavirus: St Albans' The Horn venue 'gobsmacked' at support Music venue The Horn in St Albans has said it is "gobsmacked" by the support it has received from the local community during the coronavirus lockdown. The venue, which has been closed since March, has launched a crowdfunder to help it survive the pandemic and has already raised more than £20,000. Manager Ollie Wozencroft said he was "overwhelmed" by the response from people who had donated money, bought merchandise and sent messages of support. "We're a small, independent venue and we've always relied on the support of the local community," he said. "But the response we've had during this crisis has been incredible. It's really humbling." The Horn has been a popular music venue in St Albans for more than 30 years, hosting a variety of live music events, from local bands to international touring acts. However, like all music venues, it has been hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic, which has forced it to close its doors and cancel all its events. Wozencroft said the venue was facing a "significant financial challenge" as a result of the lockdown, but he was determined to keep it open. "We're not going to give up without a fight," he said. "We're a vital part of the local music scene and we're determined to come out of this stronger than ever." The crowdfunder has been set up to help The Horn cover its operating costs during the lockdown, including rent, utilities and staff wages. Wozencroft said he was "gobsmacked" by the amount of money that had been raised so far, but he stressed that the venue still needed more support to survive. "We're incredibly grateful for all the support we've received so far, but we're not out of the woods yet," he said. "We still need people to donate what they can to help us keep The Horn open." To donate to The Horn's crowdfunder, visit www.crowdfunder.co.uk/the-horn-st-albans.

title: Ring of Peace: Iconic Belfast mural 'speaks' with 'advertising' addition
text: Amidst the bustling streets of Belfast, where history and modernity intertwine, the iconic Ring of Peace mural has witnessed another chapter in its storied existence. This time, it has found an unlikely ally in the realm of advertising, giving rise to a unique and thought-provoking collaboration. The Ring of Peace mural, created in 1995 by artist Colin Davidson, is a poignant symbol of Belfast's troubled past and its subsequent journey towards peace. Depicting a series of hands interlocked, the mural has become a beacon of hope and reconciliation in a city scarred by conflict. However, in a recent twist, the mural has been incorporated into an advertising campaign for 'Aeon', a new men's fragrance. The campaign features a large-scale projection of the fragrance's logo onto the mural, alongside the slogan "Unite the Senses." The juxtaposition of an advertising message with the deeply symbolic mural has sparked a heated debate among Belfast residents and beyond. Some have hailed the collaboration as a creative and innovative way to engage with the city's history, while others have expressed concerns about the potential commercialization of such a significant landmark. Supporters of the campaign argue that it provides a contemporary interpretation of the mural's message of unity and peace. By incorporating the mural into the advertising, they believe, the campaign helps to spread its message to a wider audience. Furthermore, they contend that the revenue generated could potentially be used to fund local community initiatives. Detractors, on the other hand, worry that the advertising projection detracts from the mural's authenticity and historical significance. They argue that the commercialization of such a sacred space disrespects the victims of the conflict and undermines the mural's message of reconciliation. The debate over the Ring of Peace mural and its advertising addition highlights the complex and evolving nature of Belfast's relationship with its past. As the city continues to heal and move forward, it must strike a delicate balance between commemorating its history and embracing new forms of expression. Ultimately, it is up to each individual to decide whether the advertising projection enhances or diminishes the impact of the Ring of Peace mural. Regardless of one's stance, the collaboration serves as a reminder that even the most deeply embedded symbols can be reinterpreted and recontextualized over time.

title: Delay for Nasa's Tess planet-hunter
text: NASA's TESS Planet-Hunter Mission Delayed NASA's Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) mission has been delayed by a technical issue, the space agency announced on Friday. The launch, which was originally scheduled for March 5, has been postponed indefinitely until the problem can be resolved. The issue is with the spacecraft's propulsion system. During a routine test, engineers discovered a leak in one of the thrusters that is used to control the satellite's orientation. NASA is currently working to identify and fix the leak, but it is unclear how long this will take. "We are disappointed to have to delay the launch of TESS, but we are committed to ensuring that the mission is a success," said Paul Hertz, director of NASA's Astrophysics Division. "We will take the time necessary to resolve this issue and ensure that the spacecraft is ready to begin its mission to discover new exoplanets." TESS is designed to survey the entire sky for exoplanets, or planets that orbit stars other than the Sun. The mission will use a wide-field camera to search for planets that transit, or pass in front of, their host stars. By measuring the dips in brightness caused by these transits, astronomers can determine the size, mass, and orbit of the planets. TESS is expected to discover thousands of new exoplanets, including many that are potentially habitable for life. The mission will also help astronomers to better understand the formation and evolution of planetary systems. The delay in TESS's launch is a setback for NASA, but it is not expected to have a major impact on the mission's overall goals. The spacecraft is still expected to be fully operational by the end of 2018, and it will have a two-year primary mission to survey the entire sky. NASA is expected to provide more updates on the status of TESS in the coming weeks.

title: Shark kills number 100 million annually, research says
text: Shark Kills Number 100 Million Annually, Research Says A new study has revealed that sharks kill an estimated 100 million animals annually, making them one of the deadliest predators on the planet. The research, published in the journal Nature, analyzed data from over 500 scientific studies to estimate the number of animals killed by sharks each year. The study found that sharks kill a wide range of animals, including fish, seals, sea turtles, and even other sharks. The researchers estimate that sharks kill approximately 63 million fish, 27 million seals, 10 million sea turtles, and 1 million other sharks each year. The researchers also found that the number of animals killed by sharks is increasing each year. This is likely due to a number of factors, including climate change, overfishing, and pollution. Climate change is causing the oceans to warm, which is forcing sharks to move into new areas. This increased competition for food and habitat is leading to more shark attacks on other animals. Overfishing is also a major threat to sharks. Sharks are often caught as bycatch in fishing nets, and this can lead to their deaths. In addition, overfishing is reducing the number of prey available to sharks, which can also lead to increased shark attacks on other animals. Pollution is another major threat to sharks. Sharks are often exposed to harmful chemicals, such as mercury and PCBs. These chemicals can damage sharks' immune systems and make them more susceptible to disease. The researchers say that the increasing number of shark kills is a cause for concern. They say that sharks play an important role in the marine ecosystem, and their loss could have a ripple effect on other animals. The researchers say that more research is needed to understand the factors that are driving the increase in shark kills. They also say that steps need to be taken to protect sharks and their habitat. One way to protect sharks is to reduce the amount of fishing that occurs in their habitats. Another way to protect sharks is to reduce pollution. The researchers say that by taking these steps, we can help to ensure that sharks continue to play an important role in the marine ecosystem for generations to come.

title: 'Suckers list': Scammers target over 1,000 people in NI
text: Over 1,000 people in Northern Ireland have been targeted by scammers who stole more than £30m over four years. The figures were released by the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) which has published a list of the top 10 scams affecting consumers in the UK. The most common scam in Northern Ireland was the 'suckers list', which involves fraudsters sending out an email or text message offering a high-value item or service at a very low price. The victim is then asked to pay upfront, but the item or service never arrives. Other common scams include: Advance fee fraud: fraudsters ask for money upfront for a service or product that never materialises. Identity theft: fraudsters steal personal information, such as your name, address and bank details, to commit fraud in your name. Phishing: fraudsters send out emails or text messages that look like they are from a legitimate organisation, such as your bank, in order to trick you into revealing personal information. Telephone preference service (TPS) fraud: fraudsters call people who are registered with the TPS, offering to remove them from the list for a fee. The CMA said that the total amount lost to scams in the UK was £1.3bn over the four years from 2017 to 2020. The CMA's chief executive, Andrea Coscelli, said: "Scams can have a devastating impact on victims, both financially and emotionally. We are determined to crack down on these criminals and protect consumers from harm." The CMA has urged people to be vigilant and to be aware of the warning signs of a scam. These include: Being asked to pay upfront for a service or product that you have not yet received. Being asked to provide personal information, such as your bank details, over the phone or email. Being pressured to make a decision quickly. Being offered a deal that seems too good to be true. If you think you have been the victim of a scam, you should report it to Action Fraud on 0300 123 2040. You can also report it to the CMA at https://www.gov.uk/report-scam-to-cma.

title: Driverless cars 'to increase congestion' says government
text: Driverless cars 'to increase congestion' says government The government has warned that driverless cars could lead to increased congestion on the roads. A new report by the Department for Transport (DfT) suggests that the widespread use of autonomous vehicles could lead to a rise in traffic levels as people become more reliant on them. The report says that driverless cars could make journeys more convenient, but they could also lead to more people choosing to travel by car, rather than using public transport or walking. This could lead to a significant increase in congestion, particularly in urban areas. The DfT report also warns that driverless cars could make it more difficult for pedestrians and cyclists to cross the road. The report says that the government is committed to working with the automotive industry to develop and test driverless cars, but it is also important to consider the potential risks. Transport Secretary Chris Grayling said: "Driverless cars have the potential to revolutionize the way we travel, but we need to be aware of the potential risks and challenges. "We need to ensure that driverless cars are safe, reliable and do not lead to increased congestion." The DfT report is based on a study of the impact of driverless cars on traffic in London. The study found that the introduction of driverless cars could lead to a 20% increase in traffic levels in the capital. The study also found that driverless cars could make it more difficult for pedestrians and cyclists to cross the road. The RAC Foundation, a motoring research charity, said that the government's concerns were "valid". RAC Foundation spokesman Steve Gooding said: "The government is right to be cautious about the potential impact of driverless cars on congestion. "We need to make sure that we don't end up with a situation where driverless cars simply replace human drivers, leading to more cars on the road and more congestion." The government is currently consulting on the future of driverless cars. The consultation will close on 11 September 2018.

title: Covid-19: Hong Kong-Singapore travel corridor postponed
text: Covid-19: Hong Kong-Singapore travel corridor postponed Hong Kong and Singapore have postponed the launch of their much-anticipated travel corridor due to a surge in coronavirus cases in the city-state. The so-called air travel bubble was due to begin on 22 November, allowing quarantine-free travel between the two cities. But Singapore's Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Wednesday that the launch would be delayed, citing a "significant increase" in the number of Covid-19 cases in the city-state in recent days. The ministry did not give a new date for the launch of the travel corridor. Hong Kong's government said it "deeply regrets" the postponement but understands the decision made by Singapore. "We will continue to closely monitor the situation in Singapore and will work with the Singapore government to explore the earliest possible resumption of the travel corridor," a government spokesman said. The travel corridor was seen as a major step forward in the recovery of the two cities' economies, which have been hit hard by the pandemic. Singapore has reported more than 58,000 cases of Covid-19, including 29 deaths. Hong Kong has reported more than 5,400 cases, including 108 deaths. The postponement of the travel corridor is a setback for both cities, but it is also a reminder that the pandemic is not over. The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that the global pandemic is "accelerating" and that the world is "on the brink of a dangerous winter". The WHO has urged countries to take steps to slow the spread of the virus, including implementing social distancing measures, wearing masks, and increasing testing and contact tracing. The postponement of the Hong Kong-Singapore travel corridor is a reminder that the pandemic is still a threat and that we must all continue to take steps to protect ourselves and others.

title: Average speed cameras 'possible for Avon and Somerset'
text: Average Speed Cameras Possible for Avon and Somerset Avon and Somerset Police are considering introducing average speed cameras on some of the county's busiest roads in a bid to reduce speeding and improve road safety. The cameras would be used to monitor traffic over a longer distance, calculating the average speed of vehicles as they pass through a series of cameras. This is in contrast to traditional speed cameras, which only measure the speed of vehicles at a single point in time. The cameras would be used on roads with a high history of speeding and collisions, and where other measures, such as increased police patrols, have not been effective in reducing speeds. The cameras would be used to gather data on speeding habits and to identify repeat offenders. The cameras would be placed at strategic locations along the road, and would use a combination of sensors and cameras to track the speed of vehicles. The data would then be processed to calculate the average speed of each vehicle. If a vehicle is found to be exceeding the speed limit, the driver would be issued with a speeding ticket. The tickets would be processed in the same way as speeding tickets issued by traditional speed cameras. The introduction of average speed cameras is a controversial issue, with some drivers arguing that they are unfair and that they punish drivers who are simply making a mistake. However, the police argue that the cameras are an effective way to reduce speeding and improve road safety. The police are currently in the process of consulting with local communities and stakeholders about the proposed introduction of average speed cameras. A decision on whether or not to introduce the cameras is expected to be made later this year. In addition to the proposed average speed cameras, Avon and Somerset Police are also exploring the use of other technologies to reduce speeding, such as mobile speed cameras and speed awareness courses. The police are committed to reducing speeding on the county's roads and improving road safety for all users. The introduction of average speed cameras is one of a number of measures that the police are considering in order to achieve this goal.

title: Stonehenge's tallest stone 'points at winter sunrise'
text: In the enigmatic landscape of Salisbury Plain, where ancient secrets whisper among the rolling hills, stands the enigmatic Stonehenge. Among its iconic megaliths, one towering stone holds a celestial secret that has captivated researchers and enthusiasts for centuries. The tallest stone at Stonehenge, known as Stone 56, is an imposing sentinel that rises over 30 feet in height. Its weathered surface bears witness to the relentless passage of time, yet its astronomical alignment remains as precise as ever. As the winter solstice approaches, the rising sun casts an ethereal glow upon Stonehenge. In a breathtaking celestial phenomenon, Stone 56 perfectly aligns with the horizon, marking the moment when daylight hours begin to lengthen after the shortest day of the year. This extraordinary alignment is no mere coincidence. Stonehenge's architects meticulously positioned the stones to observe the astronomical cycles. The winter sunrise alignment served as a celestial calendar, guiding ancient people through the changing seasons. By tracking the sun's position in relation to Stone 56, they could determine the time of year and prepare for agricultural activities. The winter solstice marked the return of longer days and the promise of renewed life, making the alignment a significant event in their calendar. The sophistication of Stonehenge's astronomical knowledge continues to astound modern researchers. The builders of Stonehenge possessed an understanding of celestial mechanics that was far beyond what was previously believed possible in prehistoric times. The winter sunrise alignment is a testament to their ingenuity and the profound connection they shared with the natural world. Stonehenge stands as a symbol of human curiosity, ingenuity, and the enduring power of celestial knowledge. As the sun rises over the ancient stones each year, casting its golden rays upon Stone 56, it evokes a sense of awe and wonder. Stonehenge becomes a timeless portal connecting us to our ancestors, who gazed upon the same celestial spectacle thousands of years ago. In the tapestry of human history, Stonehenge's tallest stone serves as a beacon of scientific achievement and a poignant reminder of the interconnectedness of humanity and the cosmos.

title: Merseyside leaders 'favour circuit breaker lockdown'
text: Merseyside leaders have called for a two-week "circuit breaker" lockdown to tackle rising coronavirus cases in the region. The leaders of Liverpool, Sefton, Wirral, Knowsley, Halton, and St Helens have written to the government, urging it to impose the measures as soon as possible. In the letter, the leaders say that the region is facing a "significant and growing problem" with the virus, with cases rising rapidly in all six boroughs. They say that a circuit breaker lockdown would help to slow the spread of the virus and give the NHS time to prepare for a potential second wave. The leaders have also called for additional support for businesses and workers affected by the lockdown. A circuit breaker lockdown would involve closing all non-essential businesses, schools, and universities for two weeks. People would be advised to stay at home as much as possible, and only essential travel would be permitted. The government has not yet responded to the leaders' request. However, Health Secretary Matt Hancock has said that the government is "keeping all options on the table" in terms of measures to tackle the virus. A circuit breaker lockdown would be a significant step, and it is likely to be met with some resistance. However, the leaders of Merseyside believe that it is necessary to prevent the NHS from being overwhelmed and to save lives. The decision of whether or not to impose a circuit breaker lockdown will ultimately be made by the government. However, the request from the leaders of Merseyside is likely to add to the pressure on the government to take action. In addition to the circuit breaker lockdown, the leaders of Merseyside have also called for a number of other measures to be implemented, including: Increased testing and contact tracing More support for businesses and workers A public awareness campaign to encourage people to follow the rules A review of the government's current strategy for dealing with the pandemic The leaders say that these measures are essential to prevent the virus from spreading further and to protect the people of Merseyside.

title: What is 'Sharenting' and should we be doing it?
text: What is 'Sharenting' and should we be doing it? Sharenting is a term used to describe the act of parents sharing photos or videos of their children on social media platforms. While it can be a way to share happy moments with friends and family, there are also some potential risks and ethical concerns to consider. Benefits of Sharenting Sharing happy moments: Parents may want to share photos or videos of their children to capture and preserve special moments. Connecting with others: Sharenting can be a way for parents to connect with other parents, share parenting tips, and build a community. Documenting growth: Some parents use social media to document their children's growth and development, creating a visual record of their lives. Risks Associated with Sharenting Privacy concerns: Children may not be aware that their photos or videos are being shared publicly, and they may not have given their consent. Cyberbullying: Children's photos or videos could be used to bully or harass them, especially if they contain embarrassing or sensitive information. Identity theft: Children's personal information, such as their full name and birthday, could be used by identity thieves. Exploitation: Children's photos or videos could be used for commercial purposes without their consent or compensation. Ethical Considerations Children's right to privacy: Children have a right to privacy, and parents should consider whether sharing their photos or videos publicly is in their best interests. Consent: It is important to get children's consent before sharing their photos or videos, especially as they get older and are able to understand the implications. Respecting boundaries: Parents should be mindful of their children's wishes and respect their privacy when they ask for it. Should We Be Sharenting? The decision of whether or not to sharent is a personal one. There are both benefits and risks to consider, and it is important to weigh them carefully. If you do decide to share photos or videos of your children, there are some steps you can take to minimize the risks: Get children's consent: Always ask your children's permission before sharing their photos or videos publicly. Share with trusted people: Only share photos or videos with people you trust, such as close friends or family members. Use privacy settings: Use the privacy settings on social media platforms to control who can see your posts. Be mindful of what you share: Avoid sharing photos or videos that could be embarrassing or hurtful to your child. Respect children's boundaries: If your child asks you to remove a photo or video, do so immediately. Ultimately, the decision of whether or not to sharent is up to each parent. By considering the benefits, risks, and ethical implications, parents can make an informed choice that is in the best interests of their children.

title: Firefighters rescue 'record' number of people
text: Firefighters have rescued a record number of people from fires in England this year, new figures show. The National Fire Chiefs Council (NFCC) said there were 4,850 rescues between April and September 2022, up from 4,432 during the same period last year. The majority of rescues (65%) were from house fires, while others were from commercial buildings, vehicles, and other structures. The NFCC said the increase in rescues is likely due to a number of factors, including the rising number of fires in the UK, the increased use of smoke alarms, and the improved training of firefighters. "This is a significant increase in the number of rescues that firefighters are carrying out," said Mark Hardingham, chair of the NFCC's Protection Committee. "It is a testament to the hard work and dedication of our firefighters that they are able to save so many lives." The figures come as the number of fires in the UK continues to rise. According to the NFCC, there were 244,000 fires in the UK in 2021/22, up from 218,000 the previous year. The NFCC is calling on the public to take steps to reduce the risk of fire in their homes and businesses. "We urge everyone to take fire safety seriously," said Hardingham. "There are a number of simple steps that you can take to reduce the risk of a fire in your home or business, such as fitting smoke alarms, checking electrical appliances regularly, and keeping flammable materials away from heat sources." The NFCC also recommends that people have a fire escape plan in place and practice it regularly. "If there is a fire in your home or business, it is important to know what to do and how to get out safely," said Hardingham. "Having a fire escape plan in place and practicing it regularly will help you to stay calm and make the right decisions in an emergency."

text: Despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, Liam Payne and Alesso have managed to release a music video for their new single, "Midnight," without leaving their homes. title: Abuser ordered to tell police about new relationships
text: An abuser has been ordered by a court to tell police about any new relationships he forms. The man, who cannot be named to protect the identity of his victim, was given the order as part of a two-year suspended sentence. He had previously pleaded guilty to causing actual bodily harm and coercive and controlling behaviour. The court heard that the man had subjected his victim to a campaign of violence and intimidation, including punching her, kicking her, and threatening to kill her. He also controlled her finances, isolated her from her friends and family, and made her feel worthless. In a victim impact statement, the woman said that the abuse had had a devastating impact on her life. She said: "I was living in constant fear. I couldn't sleep, I couldn't eat, and I couldn't leave the house. I felt like I was going to die." The woman said that she was now rebuilding her life, but that she still lived with the fear that her abuser would find her. She said: "I am terrified that he will come after me again. I don't know how I would cope if he did." The court heard that the man had a history of violence and had been convicted of assaulting a previous partner. The judge said that the man posed a significant risk to women and that the order was necessary to protect them. The judge said: "This is a very serious case of domestic violence. The defendant subjected his victim to a sustained campaign of violence and intimidation. He has shown no remorse for his actions and poses a significant risk to women." The order means that the man must tell the police about any new relationships he forms within three days. He must also provide the police with the name, address, and contact details of his new partner. The order will remain in place for two years. If the man breaches the order, he could be jailed. The police said that they would be working with the man to ensure that he complies with the order. A spokesman said: "This order is a welcome step in protecting women from domestic violence. It sends a clear message that this type of behaviour will not be tolerated."

title: Neil Gorsuch pick: How did Trump keep choice secret?
text: Neil Gorsuch's nomination to the Supreme Court was a closely guarded secret, with President Trump only revealing his pick to a select few aides. According to sources familiar with the process, Trump began meeting with potential nominees in November, but kept the list of candidates very small. He eventually settled on Gorsuch, a federal appeals court judge from Colorado, in early January. Trump's decision to keep the nomination secret was a departure from the norm. In recent years, presidents have typically announced their Supreme Court picks weeks or even months in advance. This gives the public and the Senate time to vet the nominee and prepare for the confirmation hearings. However, Trump's team believed that keeping the nomination secret would give them an advantage. They feared that if the list of candidates was made public, it would be leaked to the media and the Democrats would have time to mount a campaign against the nominee. In the end, Trump's strategy was successful. The nomination of Gorsuch was a surprise to many, and the Democrats were left scrambling to prepare for the confirmation hearings. Gorsuch was eventually confirmed by the Senate in a 54-45 vote. There are a number of reasons why Trump may have chosen to keep the nomination secret. First, he may have wanted to avoid the media scrutiny that would have come with a public announcement. Second, he may have wanted to prevent the Democrats from having time to organize opposition to the nominee. Third, he may have simply wanted to keep his options open until the last minute. Whatever his reasons, Trump's decision to keep the nomination secret was a significant departure from the norm. It is a sign of the new era of politics in which we live, in which secrecy and surprise have become the norm. The nomination of Neil Gorsuch is a major victory for President Trump. Gorsuch is a conservative judge who is likely to side with the court's conservative bloc on many issues. His appointment will likely have a significant impact on American law for years to come.

title: Call for e-cigarette safety warnings
text: Call for E-cigarette Safety Warnings As the popularity of electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) continues to surge, concerns have been raised about their potential health risks. In a bid to mitigate these concerns, the BBC is calling for mandatory safety warnings to be placed on all e-cigarette packaging. E-cigarettes are battery-powered devices that deliver nicotine, flavourings, and other chemicals in aerosol form. While they are often marketed as a safer alternative to traditional cigarettes, there is growing evidence that they may pose health risks of their own. Long-term studies on the effects of e-cigarettes are still lacking, but research has shown that they can damage cells, increase inflammation, and harm the cardiovascular system. Some studies have also linked e-cigarette use to lung damage, including a condition called "popcorn lung". In addition to the potential health hazards, e-cigarettes are also a gateway to nicotine addiction for young people. The sweet flavours and sleek designs of e-cigarettes make them appealing to children and teenagers, who may not realize the risks involved. Mandatory safety warnings on e-cigarette packaging would be a crucial step towards protecting public health. These warnings should clearly state the potential health risks associated with e-cigarette use, including the risk of addiction and the long-term health consequences. Warnings should also include information on how to avoid the dangers of e-cigarettes, such as avoiding products containing harmful ingredients or using them as a gateway to smoking. The tobacco industry has long used misleading advertising tactics to downplay the risks of smoking. E-cigarette manufacturers are employing similar tactics, targeting young people and making unsubstantiated claims about the safety of their products. Mandatory safety warnings would provide consumers with accurate information about the risks of e-cigarettes, allowing them to make informed decisions about their health. It is essential that the government takes action to protect the public from the dangers posed by these unregulated products. In conclusion, the BBC calls for mandatory safety warnings to be placed on all e-cigarette packaging. These warnings are vital for informing consumers about the potential health risks, preventing e-cigarette addiction, and protecting the health of the general public.

title: Forgotten cache of RNLI pictures 'preserved for posterity'
text: Forgotten Cache of RNLI Pictures Preserved for Posterity A remarkable cache of historic photographs, capturing the heroic work of the Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI), has been rediscovered and meticulously preserved. These images, long hidden away in a forgotten archive, provide a poignant and captivating glimpse into the lifesaving service's extraordinary past. The collection spans decades, from the early days of the RNLI in the mid-19th century to the present day. It features dramatic scenes of rescues at sea, from storm-tossed lifeboats battling towering waves to daring rescues of stranded individuals. Notable among them is a series of images depicting the infamous Penlee lifeboat disaster of 1981, in which 16 people tragically lost their lives. The photographs not only document the RNLI's valiant efforts but also offer invaluable insights into the evolution of lifesaving techniques and equipment. They showcase the transition from traditional open lifeboats rowed by brave volunteers to the modern, technologically advanced vessels that patrol the UK's coastline today. The cache was discovered by a team of RNLI archivists who were conducting a thorough review of the organization's vast collection of historical artifacts. "We were astonished to find these images," said lead archivist Emily Jones. "They had been completely forgotten about and were in danger of being lost forever." The images were carefully scanned and digitized, ensuring their preservation for future generations. They are now available online through the RNLI's website, allowing the public to explore this extraordinary heritage and appreciate the remarkable stories behind them. "These photographs are not only a valuable historical record but also a powerful reminder of the courage and selflessness of the RNLI's crews," said RNLI CEO Mark Dowie. "They serve as a testament to the organization's unwavering commitment to saving lives at sea." The rediscovered cache has sparked renewed interest in the RNLI's history and the vital role it plays in coastal safety. It has also inspired the creation of a new documentary film, "RNLI: The Forgotten Heroes," which will premiere on BBC Four later this year. The film will showcase the extraordinary images and the stories behind them, highlighting the unwavering heroism of the RNLI's brave volunteers. The preservation of this forgotten cache of photographs ensures that the legacy of the RNLI's lifesaving work will continue to inspire and inform future generations, safeguarding the memory of those who have risked their lives to protect others.

title: 'No sprinklers in 96% of London high-rise council blocks'
text: No Sprinklers in 96% of London High-Rise Council Blocks London's high-rise council blocks are dangerously ill-prepared for a fire, with 96% lacking sprinklers. This shocking statistic was revealed by a freedom of information request submitted by the BBC. Sprinklers are a proven life-saving measure, and their widespread absence in London's council blocks is a serious threat to residents. In the event of a fire, sprinklers can contain the blaze, allowing time for people to escape and for firefighters to arrive. The London Fire Brigade has repeatedly called for sprinklers to be installed in all high-rise buildings, regardless of their age or height. However, the government has so far refused to make them mandatory, arguing that it would be too expensive. The cost of installing sprinklers in all of London's high-rise council blocks is estimated to be around £1.5bn. This is a significant investment, but it is a small price to pay for the safety of the people who live in these buildings. The Grenfell Tower fire in 2017, which claimed the lives of 72 people, highlighted the urgent need for sprinklers in high-rise buildings. The fire spread rapidly through the building, due in part to the lack of sprinklers. In the wake of the Grenfell fire, the government announced that it would invest £400m in fire safety measures, including sprinklers. However, this funding is only a fraction of what is needed to make all of London's high-rise council blocks safe. The mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, has called on the government to do more to ensure the safety of residents in high-rise buildings. He said: "It is unacceptable that so many Londoners are living in homes that are not properly protected from fire." The lack of sprinklers in London's high-rise council blocks is a national scandal. The government must act now to make these buildings safe for residents.

title: Coronavirus: Paris poised for maximum Covid alert
text: Paris is on the brink of being placed under maximum Covid alert, as the French capital battles a surge in infections. title: Outrage as Emirates tells cabin crew to remove Taiwan flag pins
text: Cabin crew for Emirates have been told to remove pins bearing the Taiwanese flag from their uniforms, sparking outrage and accusations of bowing to pressure from China. The directive from the Dubai-based airline, first reported by Taiwan News, comes amid heightened tensions between China and Taiwan, which Beijing claims as its own territory. "We urge the company to reconsider its decision and respect the rights of its employees to express their support for Taiwan," the ministry said in a statement. In a statement, Emirates said it "respects the sovereignty and territorial integrity of all nations" and that its uniform policy is "in line with our commitment to neutrality and respect for international laws and regulations." The airline added that it "does not tolerate any form of discrimination or bias against any nationality or group of people." However, critics have accused Emirates of succumbing to pressure from China, which has been increasingly assertive in its claims over Taiwan. "This is a clear case of China bullying a foreign company into submission," said Wu Chih-chung, a spokesman for Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party. "It's outrageous and it shows that China is willing to go to any lengths to silence its critics." The incident has also sparked anger among Taiwanese netizens, who have taken to social media to express their outrage. "This is a disgrace," wrote one user on Facebook. The controversy comes at a sensitive time for relations between Taiwan and China. In recent months, China has stepped up its military activity around Taiwan, and has also been pressuring other countries to cut ties with the island. Taiwan, meanwhile, has been pushing back against China's claims, and has been seeking support from the international community. The Emirates incident is likely to further strain relations between the two sides.

title: Cat ownership rise driven by men, survey suggests
text: Cat ownership has surged in recent years, with men driving the trend, a survey suggests. The study, by the pet food brand Purina, found that the number of male cat owners in the UK has risen by 15% in the past five years. This has helped to close the gap with female cat owners, who still make up the majority (57%) of cat owners. The survey also found that men are more likely to own cats than dogs, with 38% of men owning a cat compared to 30% of women. This is a reversal of the trend seen in previous years, when women were more likely to own cats than men. There are a number of factors that may be driving the increase in male cat ownership. One possibility is that men are becoming more aware of the benefits of owning a cat. Cats are relatively low-maintenance pets that can provide companionship and affection. They can also be helpful for reducing stress and loneliness. Another possibility is that men are more likely to be living in urban areas, where cats are a more popular pet than dogs. Dogs require more space and exercise than cats, which can make them less suitable for people living in apartments or other small spaces. Whatever the reason, the increase in male cat ownership is a positive trend. Cats can provide companionship, affection, and other benefits to their owners. They can also help to improve people's mental and physical health. The survey also found that cat ownership is more popular among younger people. This is likely due to the fact that younger people are more likely to live in urban areas and to be aware of the benefits of owning a cat. The increase in cat ownership is a positive trend for a number of reasons. Cats can provide companionship, affection, and other benefits to their owners. They can also help to improve people's mental and physical health. If you are thinking about getting a pet, a cat may be the perfect choice for you.

title: Pro-and anti-Spearmint Rhino protesters in Sheffield stand-off
text: Pro- and anti-Spearmint Rhino protesters have clashed in a stand-off in Sheffield city centre. Around 20 protesters from Sheffield Against Men's Violence (SAMV) gathered outside the club, holding placards and chanting slogans. They were met by a group of around 10 counter-protesters, who said they were there to support the club and its workers. The two groups faced off across the street, with police officers standing between them. There were several heated exchanges, but the protest remained peaceful. SAMV said it was protesting against the club's "exploitation of women". "Spearmint Rhino is a symbol of the objectification and commodification of women," said a spokesperson for the group. "We are here to say that we will not tolerate this kind of business in our city." The counter-protesters said they were there to support the club and its workers. "These women have the right to work where they want," said one counter-protester. "They are not being exploited. They are choosing to do this work." The protest lasted for around two hours, before both groups dispersed. A spokesperson for Spearmint Rhino said the club was "disappointed" by the protest. "We are a legitimate business," the spokesperson said. "We provide a safe and enjoyable environment for our customers and our staff." South Yorkshire Police said it was aware of the protest and that officers were in attendance. "The protest was peaceful and there were no arrests," a police spokesperson said.

title: Appeal after storm grounds seabirds in Pembrokeshire
text: Appeal after storm grounds seabirds in Pembrokeshire A wildlife charity is appealing for help after a severe storm washed hundreds of seabirds ashore in Pembrokeshire. The RSPCA said it had received reports of more than 500 birds being found grounded along the county's coastline over the weekend. The charity said the birds, which included guillemots, razorbills and puffins, were likely to have been blown inland by the strong winds and high waves. Many of the birds were found exhausted and hypothermic, and some had suffered injuries. The RSPCA is urging people to report any sightings of grounded seabirds to its helpline on 0300 1234 999. The charity said it was working with other organisations, including the Welsh Wildlife Trust, to rescue and rehabilitate the birds. "We are doing everything we can to help these birds," said RSPCA inspector Keith Hogben. "But we need the public's help to let us know where the birds are so we can get them to safety as quickly as possible." The RSPCA said it was particularly concerned about the welfare of puffins, which are a protected species in the UK. "Puffins are particularly vulnerable to this type of weather because they are not strong fliers," said Hogben. "They can easily be blown inland by the wind and become exhausted and hypothermic." The RSPCA is advising people not to try to handle grounded seabirds themselves. "If you find a grounded seabird, please call the RSPCA helpline on 0300 1234 999," said Hogben. "We will then be able to send a trained rescuer to help the bird." The RSPCA said it was also reminding people to keep their dogs on leads near the coast. "Dogs can chase and injure grounded seabirds," said Hogben. "Please keep your dog on a lead if you are walking near the coast." The RSPCA said it was grateful to the members of the public who had already reported sightings of grounded seabirds. "We are very grateful to the public for their help," said Hogben. "We couldn't do this without you."

title: South Korea warns Japan over comfort women review
text: South Korea has warned Japan of "grave consequences" if it reviews a landmark agreement on wartime sex slaves. The 2015 deal saw Japan apologise and make a 1bn yen (£7.2m) payment to South Korean victims of its wartime sexual slavery. But Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has said his government is considering whether to revise elements of the deal. South Korea's foreign ministry said such a review would "fundamentally shake" bilateral ties. During World War Two, tens of thousands of women were forced into sexual slavery by the Japanese army. The BBC's Laura Bicker in Seoul says that South Korea has been incensed by Mr Abe's comments. "This could be a major turning point in relations between the two countries," she says. The 2015 agreement was reached after extensive negotiations led by then South Korean President Park Geun-hye and Mr Abe. It was hailed as a rare breakthrough on an issue that has long been a source of tension between the two nations. But Mr Abe has since said that the deal was "rushed" and he had "serious doubts" about whether it addressed Japan's legal responsibilities. South Korea's foreign ministry said in a statement: "If the Japanese government unilaterally revises the agreement, it will fundamentally shake the foundation of the Republic of Korea-Japan relations." The ministry added that South Korea had repeatedly warned Japan against revisiting the deal. "If the Japanese government defies those warnings, it will inevitably face grave consequences," the statement said. Japan's chief cabinet secretary Yoshihide Suga said that the government was still "examining the facts" about the 2015 deal. He added that Japan "intends to continue working with the Republic of Korea to build future-oriented relations based on the correct understanding of history". The US has said it is monitoring the situation closely. "We believe that it is of paramount importance for both Japan and the Republic of Korea to work together to resolve this and other historical issues in a sensitive manner," a state department spokesperson said.

title: Grape choke inquest: PC 'desperate' for help with girl
text: In a tragic incident that has sent shockwaves through the community, an inquest has revealed the desperate efforts made by a police officer to save an 11-year-old girl who choked to death on a grape. The inquest heard how PC David Clifton was on patrol in a park when he was approached by the girl's mother, who frantically told him that her daughter was choking. PC Clifton immediately rushed to the scene and found the girl lying on the ground, unconscious and unresponsive. She was not breathing and had no pulse. Without hesitation, PC Clifton began performing CPR, assisted by members of the public who had witnessed the incident. However, despite their best efforts, the girl's condition deteriorated rapidly. Paramedics arrived on the scene and took over resuscitation attempts, but the girl was pronounced dead shortly after arrival at the hospital. The inquest heard that the girl had been eating grapes when she suddenly started choking. Her airway became completely blocked, preventing her from breathing. PC Clifton told the inquest that he had been "desperate" to save the girl, but that there was nothing he could do. He said he had "tried everything" to clear her airway, but the grape was lodged too deeply. The coroner praised PC Clifton's "heroic" efforts and said he had done everything in his power to save the girl. However, he ruled that her death was a tragic accident and that there was nothing that could have been done to prevent it. The girl's family expressed their gratitude to PC Clifton and the paramedics who had tried to save her. They said they were "heartbroken" by her death, but comforted by the knowledge that she had received the best possible care. The inquest has highlighted the importance of first aid training and the need for members of the public to be aware of the dangers of choking. It is hoped that the lessons learned from this tragedy will help to prevent similar incidents from happening in the future.

title: Cancer patient 'given drug overdose after hospital pharmacy error'
text: A cancer patient was given a fatal overdose of chemotherapy drugs after a "catastrophic" error at a hospital pharmacy, an inquest has heard. Tracey Wright, 59, was receiving treatment for breast cancer at the Royal Berkshire Hospital in Reading when she was given a dose of vinblastine that was 10 times the safe limit. The inquest heard that the error occurred because a pharmacist misread the patient's weight and calculated the wrong dose. The pharmacist, who has not been named, has since been suspended from the Royal Pharmaceutical Society. Mrs. Wright's family said they were "devastated" by her death and called for a full investigation into the incident. They said they had been told that the hospital had since changed its procedures to prevent a similar error from happening again. The inquest heard that Mrs. Wright was admitted to the Royal Berkshire Hospital in March 2018 for a course of chemotherapy. She was given her first dose of vinblastine on March 27 and suffered no adverse effects. However, when she returned for her second dose on April 3, she was given a dose that was 10 times the safe limit. The inquest heard that the pharmacist who calculated the dose had misread Mrs. Wright's weight as 54 kg instead of 5.4 kg. As a result of the overdose, Mrs. Wright suffered a cardiac arrest and died on April 5. The inquest heard that the hospital had since carried out a full investigation into the incident and had identified a number of areas where improvements could be made. The hospital said it had changed its procedures to prevent a similar error from happening again. These changes include: Introducing a new system for checking and double-checking the doses of chemotherapy drugs. Providing additional training for pharmacists who calculate and prepare chemotherapy drugs. Implementing a new system for monitoring the administration of chemotherapy drugs. The hospital said it had also offered its sincere apologies to Mrs. Wright's family and expressed its condolences for their loss. The inquest is ongoing.

title: Tupac-loving US public servant fired as emails emerge

title: Banksy donates funds from anti-arms artwork sale
text: In a compassionate gesture of solidarity, renowned street artist Banksy has donated an undisclosed amount of funds raised from the sale of an anti-arms artwork to a humanitarian organization providing assistance to conflict-affected communities. The artwork, titled "Love is in the Bin," was famously self-destructed in a shredder concealed within the frame moments after it was sold for over $1.4 million at Sotheby's auction house in 2018. Undeterred, Sotheby's resold the artwork with its shredded remnants intact, retitled as "Love is in the Bin (Shredded)," for a staggering $25.4 million in 2021. Banksy's donation represents a significant portion of the proceeds from this sale. The recipient of the funds, whose identity remains undisclosed at Banksy's request, is a non-profit organization specializing in providing medical care, food, and shelter to communities ravaged by armed conflicts and humanitarian crises around the world. "This donation is a testament to Banksy's unwavering commitment to using his art to highlight the devastating consequences of armed conflicts," said a spokesperson for the organization. "These funds will go a long way in providing vital assistance to those who have been most affected by war and violence." Banksy has long been an outspoken critic of the arms industry and the proliferation of weapons in conflict zones. His anti-war message has been expressed through a series of thought-provoking and often subversive works of art, including murals, sculptures, and installations. The donation of funds from the sale of "Love is in the Bin (Shredded)" marks a significant step in the artist's ongoing efforts to raise awareness and generate support for those suffering the devastating effects of armed conflicts. It is a powerful reminder of the transformative power of art in fostering compassion and promoting social justice. Banksy's anonymous donation underscores the artist's belief in the power of grassroots organizations to make a tangible difference in the lives of those most in need. title: Brexit: Single market membership 'probably unlikely'
text: Brexit: Single Market Membership 'Probably Unlikely' As the UK government continues to negotiate its exit from the European Union, the possibility of remaining a member of the single market has become increasingly remote. This could lead to job losses and lower wages. However, there is no guarantee that these new deals will be as выгодный as the UK's current access to the single market. This could lead to the UK becoming more isolated and less influential in the world. The government has also said that it wants to leave the single market in order to be able to control its own immigration policy. However, it is not clear how leaving the single market would allow the UK to do this. The UK would still be able to trade with EU countries, and people would still be able to move freely between the UK and the EU. The government has said that it is willing to walk away from the negotiations without a deal if it cannot get the deal it wants. This would mean that the UK would leave the EU without any transition period, and there would be no new trade deal in place.
