title: Brexit Party joins cross-party alliance for voting reform
text: The Brexit Party has joined a cross-party alliance of small parties and independent politicians calling for changes to the UK's electoral system. The alliance, known as the Electoral Reform Alliance (ERA), wants to introduce proportional representation (PR) into the UK's parliamentary elections. Under the current first-past-the-post system, the candidate with the most votes in each constituency is elected as the MP, even if they do not receive a majority of the votes. This can lead to situations where a party with a large share of the national vote ends up with very few MPs, while a party with a smaller share of the vote can end up with a large number of MPs. PR systems are designed to ensure that the proportion of seats won by each party more closely reflects the proportion of votes cast for that party. The ERA is calling for a form of PR known as the single transferable vote (STV). Under STV, voters rank candidates in order of preference. If no candidate receives an outright majority of first-preference votes, the candidate with the fewest votes is eliminated and their votes are transferred to their second-preference candidate. This process continues until one candidate receives a majority of the votes. The Brexit Party's decision to join the ERA is a significant development, as it suggests that there is growing support for electoral reform among parties from across the political spectrum. The Conservative Party has traditionally been opposed to PR, but there have been growing calls for the party to reconsider its position in recent years. The Liberal Democrats and the Green Party have long been supporters of PR, and the Labour Party has also expressed support for the idea in the past. The ERA is hoping to build on this growing support and persuade the government to hold a referendum on electoral reform. A referendum on electoral reform was held in 2011, but it was defeated by a large margin. However, the ERA believes that public opinion has shifted in favor of PR since then, and that a new referendum would produce a different result.

title: Nicky Verstappen cold case killing ends in jail after 22 years

title: Scottish wildcats 'not wild' about snow, says SNH report
text: Despite their rugged appearance and habitat, Scottish wildcats are "not wild" about snow, according to a new report by NatureScot, formerly known as Scottish Natural Heritage (SNH). The study found that the iconic felines, which are native to Scotland and have been designated as a priority species for conservation, struggle to hunt and move in snowy conditions. The report, which was based on data collected from GPS tracking collars fitted to 12 wildcats in the Cairngorms National Park, found that the animals' activity levels dropped significantly when snow cover exceeded 10 cm. This was likely due to the difficulty they had in moving through the snow and finding prey. Dr. Robbie McDonald, NatureScot's Species Conservation Officer, said: "This study provides us with valuable insights into the behaviour of Scottish wildcats in snowy conditions. We know that wildcats are adapted to living in harsh conditions, but our research shows that they do struggle when the snow gets too deep. This is something we need to be aware of as we consider the future conservation of this iconic species." The study also found that wildcats were more likely to use roads and tracks when there was snow on the ground. This suggests that they may be using these features to help them move around and find food. However, Dr. McDonald warned that this could also make them more vulnerable to being hit by vehicles. He said: "We need to be mindful of the potential impacts of snow on wildcats and take steps to mitigate these risks. For example, we could consider reducing the speed limit on roads in areas where wildcats are known to occur, or erecting signs to warn drivers of the presence of these animals." The Scottish wildcat is one of the UK's most endangered mammals, with an estimated population of just 100-300 individuals. The species has been in decline for a number of years due to habitat loss, persecution, and interbreeding with domestic cats. NatureScot is working to conserve the Scottish wildcat by protecting and managing its habitat, reducing the number of feral cats, and raising awareness of the importance of this iconic species.

title: Alison Lapper's son Parys 'bullied at school' before death
text: Alison Lapper's son Parys, who was born with the same rare condition as his mother, was bullied at school before his death, according to an inquest. title: Police swoop on suspected darknet fake banknote buyers

title: Port of Dover facing 'unnecessary holdups' on 1 January
text: Port of Dover facing 'unnecessary holdups' on 1 January The Port of Dover is facing "unnecessary holdups" on 1 January, with lorries backed up for miles as new post-Brexit border checks come into force. "The government needs to take urgent action to resolve this situation. Otherwise, we are going to see even more chaos in the coming days." The delays at the Port of Dover are likely to have a significant impact on businesses across the UK. This is just the start of the new trading relationship with the EU and it is already causing significant disruption. The government has said that it is "confident" that the delays at the Port of Dover will be resolved "as quickly as possible." However, the RHA said that the government's "complacency" is "unacceptable." Burnett said: "The government has had months to prepare for this. It is simply not good enough to say that they are confident that the delays will be resolved. "The government needs to take action now to prevent this situation from getting even worse."

title: Air pollution: Houses on polluted street face demolition
text: Air pollution: Houses on polluted street face demolition Residents living on one of the UK's most polluted streets could have their homes demolished as part of a council's efforts to improve air quality and public health. Lambeth Council in south London is considering demolishing four Victorian houses on Brixton Road, which has been identified as having some of the worst air pollution in the country. The council says the demolition of the houses would create a wider pavement, allowing more space for pedestrians and cyclists, and would also improve air flow along the street. The council is also proposing to introduce a number of other measures to reduce air pollution on Brixton Road, including: Reducing the speed limit to 20mph Introducing a new bus lane Planting more trees Installing air quality monitors The council says that the measures are necessary to protect the health of residents, as air pollution has been linked to a number of health problems, including asthma, heart disease, and cancer. The council's proposals have been met with mixed reactions from residents. Some residents have welcomed the plans, saying that they believe the measures will improve the air quality and make the street safer for pedestrians and cyclists. However, other residents have expressed concerns about the plans, saying that they believe the demolition of the houses is unnecessary and that the council should focus on other measures to reduce air pollution. The council is currently consulting on its proposals and will make a final decision on whether to proceed with the demolition of the houses later this year. Air pollution is a major problem in the UK, with an estimated 40,000 deaths each year being attributed to exposure to air pollution. The government has committed to reducing air pollution levels in the UK, and has introduced a number of measures to achieve this, including: Setting legal limits for air pollution Investing in cleaner transport Promoting energy efficiency Encouraging walking and cycling The government's air quality strategy is also aimed at reducing air pollution levels in the UK by 2030.

title: Drug mule cat gets caught in Russian jail
text: In a bizarre twist of fate, a cat named Busya has become an unlikely member of an international drug smuggling ring. The unsuspecting feline was discovered carrying a small amount of drugs in a Russian prison, sending shockwaves through the facility. Busya, a stray cat that wandered into the prison grounds, was apprehended by guards after they noticed her unusual behavior. Upon closer inspection, they discovered a small package of narcotics concealed within the cat's collar. The discovery left the prison staff baffled and amused in equal measure. The incident has raised concerns about the extent to which animals may be used as unwitting couriers for illicit substances. Experts believe that drug traffickers may be exploiting the trusting nature of animals to smuggle drugs past security checkpoints. "This is the first time we have heard of a cat being used as a drug mule," said a prison spokesperson. "It's a very unusual and creative way to try to smuggle drugs into the prison." The package of drugs found on Busya contained a small quantity of methamphetamine and heroin. The drugs were believed to be intended for inmates within the prison. "We are investigating how the drugs got onto the cat and who may be responsible," said the spokesperson. "We are taking this matter very seriously." Busya has since been taken into custody by the prison authorities and is being held in a veterinary clinic for observation. The cat is said to be in good health and is not believed to have suffered any harm from the incident. The Russian authorities are now investigating the incident and are determined to find those responsible for using Busya as a drug mule. They are also considering implementing new measures to prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future. The incident highlights the lengths to which drug smugglers will go to transport their illegal goods. It also raises questions about the welfare of animals that may be unwittingly involved in criminal activities.

title: Row erupts after nine die in south-east Turkish bomb
text: At least nine people have been killed and 27 injured in a car bomb explosion in the south-eastern Turkish city of Diyarbakir. The blast, which occurred in a busy commercial area, has been blamed on the outlawed Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK). The PKK, which has been fighting for greater autonomy for Turkey's Kurdish minority, has denied responsibility. But Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has vowed to "crush" the group. The explosion, which occurred at around 11am local time (08:00 GMT), caused widespread panic and damage. Footage shared on social media showed thick black smoke billowing into the air, as well as the wreckage of cars and buildings. Ambulances and fire engines were quickly on the scene, and the injured were taken to nearby hospitals. The Turkish government has declared a state of emergency in the region, and security forces have been deployed to prevent further attacks. The PKK has been fighting for greater autonomy for Turkey's Kurdish minority for decades. The conflict has claimed tens of thousands of lives. In recent years, the PKK has been designated as a terrorist organisation by Turkey, the United States and the European Union. But the group's supporters argue that it is fighting for a just cause. The bombing in Diyarbakir is likely to further escalate tensions between the Turkish government and the PKK. It is also likely to increase pressure on the international community to take action to end the conflict. The United States and the European Union have both condemned the bombing, and have called on all parties to renounce violence. But it is unclear what further steps the international community can take to resolve the conflict. The Turkish government has been accused of human rights abuses in its crackdown on the PKK. But the PKK has also been accused of carrying out terrorist attacks. The conflict in south-eastern Turkey is a complex and long-running one. It is likely to continue for many years to come.

title: Scottish deposit return scheme plan praised
text: Scotland's Deposit Return Scheme (DRS) has been widely praised for its potential to significantly reduce litter and increase recycling rates. The scheme, which is set to launch in August 2023, will require retailers to charge a 20p deposit on all single-use drinks containers made of plastic, metal, or glass. Consumers will be able to get their deposit back when they return the empty container to a designated recycling point. The DRS has been in development for several years and has been the subject of extensive consultation with businesses, environmental groups, and the public. The Scottish government believes that the scheme will be a major step forward in tackling the problem of litter and waste. Environmental groups have welcomed the DRS, saying that it will help to reduce the number of plastic bottles and cans that are littered or landfilled. The scheme is also expected to increase recycling rates, as it will make it easier for people to recycle their drinks containers. Businesses have been more cautious about the DRS, expressing concerns about the cost of implementing the scheme and the potential for fraud. However, the Scottish government has said that it will provide financial support to businesses to help them implement the DRS. The DRS is part of a wider package of measures that the Scottish government is introducing to reduce litter and waste. The government has also introduced a ban on single-use plastic straws and cotton buds, and it is planning to introduce a tax on single-use plastic bags. The DRS is a bold and ambitious scheme, but it has the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing litter and waste in Scotland. The scheme is supported by a wide range of stakeholders, and it is expected to be a major success. In a statement, the Scottish government said: "The Deposit Return Scheme is a key part of our plans to make Scotland a zero-waste society. The scheme will help to reduce litter, increase recycling rates, and create a more sustainable future for Scotland."

title: Brazilian press reacts to latest leaked tape scandal
text: Brazilian Press Reacts to Latest Leaked Tape Scandal Brazilian media has erupted in outrage following the release of a leaked tape allegedly capturing former President Michel Temer negotiating bribes with a meatpacking executive. The scandal has reignited political turmoil in a country already grappling with corruption and economic crisis. Explosive Accusations On May 17, 2019, Brazilian news outlet "O Globo" published audio recordings purportedly showing Temer discussing illegal payments with Joesley Batista, former CEO of meatpacking giant JBS. In the tapes, Temer appears to be negotiating the purchase of the silence of another politician implicated in previous corruption scandals. Political Earthquake The leak has sent shockwaves through Brazilian politics. Temer's opponents have seized on the tapes as further evidence of his involvement in the massive "Car Wash" corruption investigation that has already ensnared dozens of high-profile figures. Temer denies any wrongdoing, but the scandal has raised questions about his credibility and the integrity of his administration. Media Outrage Brazilian media has been swift to condemn the allegations against Temer. Newspapers have run banner headlines denouncing the recordings as proof of "rottenness" at the heart of the government. Television networks have dedicated hours of coverage to the scandal, analyzing the tapes and interviewing experts. Public Fury The leaked tapes have also sparked widespread public anger. Brazilians are already disillusioned with their political leaders following years of corruption scandals. The latest revelations have further eroded trust in the government and raised fears of a return to the political instability that plagued the country in the past. Calls for Impeachment Opposition lawmakers have called for Temer's immediate impeachment. They argue that the tapes provide irrefutable evidence of corruption and that he is no longer fit to lead the country. However, Temer has enough support in Congress to block impeachment proceedings, and it is unclear if there is enough public pressure to force his removal from office. Fallout and Consequences The leaked tape scandal has had significant consequences. It has further weakened Temer's already fragile government and cast doubt on the legitimacy of his presidency. The scandal has also raised serious questions about the state of Brazilian politics and the country's ability to overcome its deep-seated corruption problem. As investigations continue and the fallout from the scandal unfolds, it remains to be seen how this latest crisis will shape the future of Brazil.

title: Stephen Ward: Lloyd Webber 'proud' as new musical opens
text: Stephen Ward: Lloyd Webber 'proud' as new musical opens Andrew Lloyd Webber has said he is "proud" as his new musical about the Profumo affair opens in the West End.Stephen Ward* tells the story of the osteopath who was at the center of the scandal that rocked the British establishment in the 1960s. The musical has been praised by critics, with The Guardian calling it "a triumph" and The Telegraph saying it is "a must-see." The cast includes Alexander Hanson as Stephen Ward, Charlotte Spencer as Christine Keeler, and Joshua James as John Profumo. The Profumo affair was a major political scandal that shook the British government in the early 1960s. It involved the Secretary of State for War, John Profumo, who had an affair with Christine Keeler, a 19-year-old model. Keeler was also involved with a Soviet naval attaché, which raised concerns about a security risk. The scandal led to Profumo's resignation and the downfall of the Conservative government. It also had a profound impact on British society, leading to a loss of trust in the establishment and a loosening of sexual mores. Lloyd Webber said he was drawn to the story of Stephen Ward because it was "such a tragedy." "He was a brilliant man who was destroyed by the scandal," Lloyd Webber said. Lloyd Webber said he hoped the musical would help to raise awareness of the Profumo affair and its impact on British society. "I think it's important to remember what happened," he said. "We can learn from the mistakes of the past and make sure that they don't happen again."

title: Llandeilo bypass delayed until 2025 by Welsh Government
text: The £120m Llandeilo bypass has been delayed by two years and is now not expected to open until 2025, the Welsh Government has announced. The road scheme, which aims to ease congestion in the Carmarthenshire town, was originally due to be completed in 2023. But the project has been hit by a number of delays, including the discovery of archaeological remains and the need for additional environmental assessments. The Welsh Government said it was "disappointed" by the delay, but insisted that the bypass was still "essential" to improving the area's infrastructure. "The Llandeilo bypass is an essential project that will improve journey times, reduce congestion and provide better access to the town centre," said a Welsh Government spokesperson. "We are disappointed that the project has been delayed, but we are committed to delivering it as soon as possible." The delay has been met with disappointment by local businesses and residents, who have been calling for the bypass for many years. "This is a huge blow to Llandeilo," said David Jenkins, who runs a local shop. "The bypass is essential to the town's future. It will reduce congestion, improve air quality and make it easier for people to get to and from the town centre." "I'm very disappointed by the delay," said local resident Mary Jones. "I've been waiting for the bypass for years. It's a shame that we have to wait even longer." The Welsh Government said it was working with the contractor to minimize further delays. "We are working closely with the contractor to ensure that the project is completed as quickly as possible," said the spokesperson. "We understand the frustration that this delay will cause, but we ask people to bear with us. The bypass is an important investment in Llandeilo and the surrounding area. It will make a real difference to the lives of local people." The Llandeilo bypass is part of the Welsh Government's wider investment in infrastructure in the region. Other projects include the £1bn M4 relief road around Newport and the £500m A487 improvement scheme between Swansea and Carmarthen. The Welsh Government said it was committed to improving transport links in Wales and that the Llandeilo bypass was an important part of that strategy.

title: Culture shock for Stormont's youngest MLA, Megan Fearon
text: Megan Fearon, the youngest MLA in Stormont, has spoken of the culture shock she experienced when she first entered the Northern Ireland Assembly. The 25-year-old Alliance Party MLA said she was surprised by the "adversarial" nature of politics at Stormont. "I was used to a much more collaborative approach in my previous role," she said. "But here, it's very much about scoring points off each other. It can be quite off-putting." Fearon also said she was surprised by the lack of diversity in the Assembly. "I'm one of only a handful of women MLAs," she said. "And there are very few people from ethnic minority backgrounds. It's not representative of the society we live in." Fearon said she believes that Stormont needs to change if it is to be more effective. "We need to find a way to work together more collaboratively," she said. "And we need to make the Assembly more representative of the people we represent." Fearon's comments come as the Assembly is facing a number of challenges, including the ongoing Brexit negotiations and the recent collapse of the power-sharing government. It is unclear whether Fearon's call for change will be heeded by her fellow MLAs. However, her comments highlight the challenges facing Stormont and the need for reform. Here are some additional details about Megan Fearon's background and political views: Fearon is a graduate of Queen's University Belfast, where she studied politics and international relations. She was elected to the Assembly in 2017, representing the constituency of Newry and Armagh. Fearon is a member of the Alliance Party, which is a centrist party that supports Irish reunification. She is a strong advocate for social justice and equality, and has spoken out on issues such as abortion rights and same-sex marriage. Fearon is seen as a rising star in the Alliance Party, and is tipped as a potential future leader of the party.

title: Venezuela opposition wins EU's top human rights prize
text: Venezuela Opposition Wins EU's Top Human Rights Prize The European Union (EU) has awarded its prestigious Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought to the Venezuelan opposition, recognising their "courageous and tireless efforts" against President Nicolás Maduro's authoritarian regime. The prize was accepted on behalf of the opposition by Juan Guaidó, the self-proclaimed interim president of Venezuela, who has been a vocal critic of Maduro. In a statement, the EU Parliament said: "The opposition has consistently defended democracy, the rule of law and human rights." "Despite the regime's repression and persecution, they have remained steadfast in their commitment to a peaceful and democratic solution to the crisis in Venezuela." The opposition has been fighting for years against Maduro's regime, which has been accused of widespread human rights abuses, including arbitrary arrests, torture, and extrajudicial killings. The Sakharov Prize, named after the Soviet dissident Andrei Sakharov, is awarded annually to individuals or organisations that have made an exceptional contribution to the promotion of human rights and democracy. Past winners include Nelson Mandela, Aung San Suu Kyi, and Malala Yousafzai. The EU's award to the Venezuelan opposition is a significant recognition of their struggle and a clear message of support from the international community. The opposition has welcomed the award, saying it is a "recognition of the courage and determination of the Venezuelan people." "We will not rest until we have achieved our goal of a free and democratic Venezuela," said Guaidó. The Maduro regime has dismissed the award as "interference" in Venezuela's internal affairs. The EU's decision to award the Sakharov Prize to the Venezuelan opposition is likely to further strain relations between the bloc and Maduro's regime. The EU has already imposed sanctions on Venezuela, and has called for the release of political prisoners and the restoration of democracy. The Maduro regime has accused the EU of supporting the opposition's "coup attempt" and of trying to undermine his government. Despite the challenges they face, the Venezuelan opposition remains committed to its goal of a free and democratic country. The EU's Sakharov Prize is a powerful symbol of support for their struggle and a reminder that the international community stands with them.

title: Q&A: What now for staff at clinical waste firm HES?
text: Q&A: What now for staff at clinical waste firm HES? Following the liquidation of healthcare waste management firm Healthcare Environmental Services (HES), employees are facing an uncertain future. Here's a Q&A on the latest developments: What happened to HES? HES was placed into liquidation on 28 February 2023, after experiencing financial difficulties. The company, which operated across the UK, had been facing challenges for several months. What does liquidation mean? Liquidation is a legal process that involves winding up a company's affairs. An official liquidator is appointed to oversee the process, which typically includes selling off the company's assets and distributing the proceeds to creditors. What happens to employees when a company goes into liquidation? Employees who are made redundant due to liquidation may be entitled to certain payments, including redundancy pay, unpaid wages, and holiday pay. They may also be able to claim benefits from the government. What are the prospects for HES employees? The prospects for HES employees are unclear at this stage. The liquidator is currently assessing the company's financial situation and will need to sell off its assets to generate funds for creditors. It's possible that some employees may be retained if a buyer is found for the business. What should HES employees do? HES employees should contact Jobcentre Plus to register as unemployed and explore job search options. They should also check their contracts to determine their entitlements and consult with legal professionals if necessary. What is the government doing to support HES employees? The government has announced that it will provide support to HES employees through the Jobcentre Plus Rapid Response Service. This service offers guidance and support to help people find new jobs or retrain. What are the unions saying? The unions representing HES employees have expressed concern about the impact of the liquidation on their members. They are calling for the government and the liquidator to provide support and ensure that workers are treated fairly. Additional Information Employees can find more information on their rights and entitlements at the government website: www.gov.uk/redundancy The insolvency practitioner handling HES's liquidation is FRP Advisory LLP. The National Association of Waste Disposal Officers (NAWDO) is providing support to HES employees. HES employees should stay informed through updates from the liquidator and their union representatives.

title: Royals race America's Cup yachts around NZ harbour
text: Royals race America's Cup yachts around NZ harbour Auckland, New Zealand - Members of the British royal family took to the waters of Auckland's Waitematā Harbour on Wednesday, racing each other on America's Cup yachts. The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and their children, Prince George and Princess Charlotte, joined the crew of the INEOS Team UK boat, while the Earl and Countess of Wessex raced on board the Emirates Team New Zealand yacht. The two teams competed in a short race around the harbor, with INEOS Team UK emerging victorious. Afterward, the royals met with members of both teams and thanked them for their hospitality. "It was an incredible experience to be able to race on these boats, and I'm very grateful to both teams for giving us the opportunity," he said. The Duchess of Cambridge said that she was "proud" of her husband and children for taking part in the race. "It was a great day out for the whole family," she said. The Earl and Countess of Wessex also enjoyed their time on the water, with the Countess saying that she was "amazed" by the speed of the boats. "It was a once-in-a-lifetime experience," she said. The America's Cup is the oldest international sporting trophy, and is awarded to the winner of a series of yacht races. The 36th America's Cup is being held in Auckland, New Zealand, from March 6 to 21, 2021. The INEOS Team UK and the Emirates Team New Zealand are two of the favorites to win the America's Cup. INEOS Team UK is led by Sir Ben Ainslie, who is one of the most successful sailors in history. Emirates Team New Zealand is the defending champion, having won the America's Cup in 2017. The race between the two royal teams was a friendly competition, but it also served as a reminder of the intense rivalry between the two countries in the America's Cup.

title: Storm Callum: Amber weather alert issued for Wales
text: Storm Callum: Amber weather alert issued for Wales The Met Office has issued an amber weather warning for Wales as Storm Callum is set to bring heavy rain and strong winds to the country. Avoid walking near trees or power lines. If you see flooding, do not attempt to drive through it. Be aware of the risks of hypothermia. Keep your mobile phone charged and have a battery pack or power bank in case of power cuts. Listen to the advice of the emergency services."

title: Private schools extend lead in entrants to university
text: Private schools have further extended their lead in terms of university entrants, with nearly a quarter (23.4%) of all pupils accepted onto degree courses in 2022, compared to just 14.6% in 2019. This widening gap highlights the ongoing advantages enjoyed by those from more affluent backgrounds when it comes to accessing higher education. The figures, released by the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service (UCAS), show that the proportion of private school pupils accepted into university has increased by 1.8 percentage points since 2019, while the proportion of state school pupils has fallen by 0.6 percentage points. This means that private school pupils are now more than twice as likely to go to university as state school pupils. The gap is particularly pronounced in the most selective universities, with 43.5% of private school pupils accepted into Russell Group universities in 2022, compared to just 18.9% of state school pupils. This means that private school pupils are now more than twice as likely to go to a Russell Group university as state school pupils. There are a number of factors that contribute to this gap, including: Funding: Private schools have significantly more funding than state schools, which allows them to provide smaller class sizes, better facilities, and more extracurricular activities. This can give private school pupils a significant advantage in terms of academic achievement. Selection: Private schools are able to select their pupils, which means that they can admit pupils who are more likely to succeed academically. This can also contribute to the gap in university entrance rates. Culture: Private schools often have a culture of academic achievement, which can motivate pupils to work harder and achieve better grades. This can also contribute to the gap in university entrance rates. The widening gap in university entrance rates is a concern, as it means that pupils from less affluent backgrounds are less likely to have the opportunity to access higher education. This can have a significant impact on their future life chances. There are a number of things that can be done to address this gap, including: Increasing funding for state schools: State schools need to be given more funding so that they can provide the same quality of education as private schools. This would help to level the playing field for pupils from all backgrounds. Reforming school admissions: The school admissions system needs to be reformed so that it is fairer to pupils from all backgrounds. This could involve abolishing private school selection or introducing a system of quotas for state school pupils in selective schools. Changing the culture of schools: Schools need to change their culture so that they value academic achievement for all pupils, regardless of their background. This could involve setting higher expectations for all pupils and providing more support for pupils who are struggling. By addressing the factors that contribute to the gap in university entrance rates, we can help to create a more level playing field for pupils from all backgrounds and ensure that everyone has the opportunity to succeed in higher education.

title: Groupe Eurotunnel bid to run French ports
text: Groupe Eurotunnel Eyes French Port Expansion Groupe Eurotunnel, the operator of the Channel Tunnel, has submitted a bid to acquire a long-term concession to manage a cluster of French ports in the English Channel region. The bid, which is for a 50-year concession, includes the ports of Calais, Boulogne-sur-Mer, and Dunkerque. If successful, Groupe Eurotunnel would become the largest port operator in Northern France, with an annual traffic volume of approximately 25 million passengers and 6 million tonnes of freight. The company believes that the acquisition would allow it to optimize operations, improve efficiency, and enhance services for customers. The French government has launched a tender process for the concession, which is expected to close in the coming months. Groupe Eurotunnel faces competition from several other international port operators, including DP World, PSA International, and Bolloré Ports. The acquisition of the French ports would be a major strategic move for Groupe Eurotunnel, which has been seeking to diversify its revenue streams and expand its presence in the European port market. The company currently operates ports in the United Kingdom, Dover, and Folkestone, and has been exploring opportunities to expand its operations in France for several years. Analysts believe that the French ports offer significant growth potential, particularly in the areas of freight and logistics. The ports are well-positioned to serve the growing trade between the United Kingdom and the European continent, and they have the potential to develop into major hubs for the distribution of goods. Groupe Eurotunnel has a strong track record in port management and operations, and it is well-respected in the industry. The company has a proven ability to deliver high-quality services and to innovate in order to improve efficiency and customer satisfaction. The French government is expected to announce the outcome of the tender process in the coming months. If Groupe Eurotunnel is successful in its bid, it will have the opportunity to make a significant investment in the French ports and to transform them into major gateways for trade and tourism. The acquisition of the French ports would be a major boost for Groupe Eurotunnel, and it would allow the company to further solidify its position as a leading player in the European transport sector.

title: Coronavirus: Ecuador sees massive surge in deaths in April
text: Ecuador has seen a massive surge in deaths in April, with the country's official death toll from the coronavirus pandemic more than doubling in the space of a month. According to the country's health ministry, there were 3,095 confirmed deaths from Covid-19 as of 30 April - up from 1,424 at the end of March. The vast majority of the deaths have been in the coastal province of Guayas, which includes the city of Guayaquil. The province has been the epicentre of the outbreak in Ecuador, and has accounted for more than half of the country's total deaths. The surge in deaths has overwhelmed the healthcare system in Guayas, with hospitals struggling to cope with the influx of patients. Many people have died at home or in the streets, as they were unable to get access to medical care. The Ecuadorian government has imposed a nationwide lockdown in an attempt to contain the virus, but the measures have been difficult to enforce in Guayas. The province is home to many poor and informal workers, who have been unable to stay home and lose income. The government has also been criticised for its handling of the crisis, with many accusing it of being slow to react to the outbreak. The surge in deaths in Ecuador is a reminder of the devastating impact that the coronavirus pandemic can have. It is also a warning to other countries that are still struggling to contain the virus. Analysis The surge in deaths in Ecuador is a major concern, and it is likely to put a strain on the country's healthcare system. The government is facing a difficult challenge in trying to contain the virus, as it is difficult to enforce lockdown measures in a poor and densely populated country. The international community should provide assistance to Ecuador, as it is struggling to cope with the crisis. This assistance could include financial aid, medical supplies, and technical expertise. It is also important to learn from the mistakes that have been made in Ecuador. Other countries should take steps to ensure that they have a robust healthcare system in place, and that they are prepared to respond to a major outbreak of the virus.

title: Historic annual mop fair returns to Cirencester market place
text: Amidst the bustling streets of Cirencester, Gloucestershire, the historic Mop Fair makes its long-awaited return, bringing with it a vibrant tapestry of tradition, entertainment, and community spirit. This annual extravaganza, dating back to the 17th century, is a testament to the town's rich past as a wool-trading center. The fair's origins lie in the hiring of farm laborers, known as "mops," who would congregate in the market square to seek employment. Over time, Mop Fair has evolved into a much-loved festival that celebrates Cirencester's heritage and offers a plethora of attractions for visitors of all ages. The heart of the fair remains the lively market stalls, where traders from far and wide showcase their wares, from handmade crafts to delectable local produce. But there's much more to Mop Fair than just shopping. The streets are alive with the sound of music, with live performances taking place on multiple stages throughout the day. Traditional fairground rides, such as the iconic carousel and helter-skelter, add an element of nostalgia and childhood wonder. A highlight of the fair is the grand parade, which winds its way through the town center on the Saturday afternoon. Local groups, marching bands, and colorful floats participate in this vibrant procession, showcasing the diversity and creativity of Cirencester's community. In the evenings, the fair transforms into a magical nighttime spectacle. The market square is illuminated by twinkling lights, and the rides take on a surreal glow. Live music continues late into the night, providing a soundtrack for the revelry and merriments. Mop Fair is more than just a fair; it's a celebration of community and a reminder of Cirencester's rich history. It's a chance for locals and visitors alike to come together, enjoy the entertainment, and embrace the spirit of this time-honored tradition. As the sun sets on Mop Fair, the memories created will linger long after the rides have stopped and the stalls have closed. It's a testament to the enduring power of tradition and the importance of preserving our cultural heritage.

title: Covid-19: Facebook rejects businessman's jab advert
text: Covid-19: Facebook rejects businessman's jab advert Facebook has rejected an advert from a businessman offering cash to encourage people to get vaccinated against COVID-19. Ben Francis, the chief executive of Gymshark, said he was "disappointed" that the advert was not allowed to run, and offered to pay for a billboard campaign instead. The social media giant said its policy prohibited ads "that promote the sale or use of vaccines". It comes as the government launches a new campaign to encourage people to get vaccinated. Mr Francis, whose sportswear company has 1.2 million followers on Facebook, said he had offered £10 to anyone who showed proof of having had the vaccine. He said he was "frustrated" that Facebook would not allow him to run the advert, and said it was "not in the spirit of helping the UK out of this mess". A Facebook spokesperson said: "Our policy prohibits ads that promote the sale or use of vaccines, including ads that offer financial incentives for people to get vaccinated. "We understand that people are passionate about getting vaccinated, but we need to ensure that our platform is not used to promote the sale or use of vaccines. "We will continue to review our policies and make updates as necessary." The government has launched a new campaign to encourage people to get vaccinated, with the slogan "Every vaccination gives us hope". The campaign includes TV, radio and online adverts, and will see famous faces such as Sir Captain Tom Moore, Dolly Parton and Michael Sheen encouraging people to get jabbed. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said: "I am delighted that so many people have already come forward to get their vaccine. "But we need to do more to encourage those who haven't yet been vaccinated to do so. "This new campaign will help us to reach more people and give them the information they need to make an informed decision about getting vaccinated." The government has set a target of vaccinating all adults by the end of July.

title: Newcastle cancer patients helped on road to recovery
text: Newcastle cancer patients helped on road to recovery People in Newcastle battling cancer are getting help with their recovery through a new service that tackles transport challenges. The service, provided by Macmillan Cancer Support and the British Red Cross, helps patients get to and from hospital for treatment, as well as to other appointments and activities that support their recovery. Cancer treatment can often cause side effects that make it difficult to travel, such as fatigue, nausea, and pain. The service provides a range of support, including: Transport to and from hospital appointments Transport to other appointments, such as support groups and counseling Help with planning and coordinating travel Assistance with getting on and off public transport The service is available to people who are receiving cancer treatment at the Freeman Hospital in Newcastle. It is funded by Macmillan Cancer Support and the British Red Cross, and is delivered in partnership with local transport providers. Since the service launched in April 2023, it has helped over 100 people with cancer in Newcastle. One person who has benefited from the service is 65-year-old John Smith. John was diagnosed with lung cancer in 2022 and has been receiving treatment at the Freeman Hospital. "The transport service has been a lifeline for me," said John. "I live on my own and don't have any family nearby, so getting to and from hospital appointments was a real challenge. The service has taken away that stress and allowed me to focus on my recovery." Another person who has benefited from the service is 42-year-old Sarah Jones. Sarah was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2021 and has been receiving treatment at the Freeman Hospital. "The transport service has been a huge help to me," said Sarah. "I have young children and I need to be able to get to and from hospital appointments without having to worry about how I'm going to get there. The service has given me peace of mind and allowed me to focus on getting better." The Macmillan Cancer Support and British Red Cross transport service is a vital service for people with cancer in Newcastle. It provides practical support that helps people with cancer to access the treatment and support they need to recover. If you are receiving cancer treatment at the Freeman Hospital in Newcastle and would like to access the transport service, please contact the Macmillan Cancer Support team on 0191 213 7323.

title: Redcar SSI: Two men killed in explosion near gas pipes at former steelworks site
text: Two men have died following an explosion near gas pipes at the former steelworks site in Redcar, north-east England. Cleveland Police said the incident happened at about 11:15 BST on Tuesday off the Trunk Road, near the former SSI steelworks. The area, which includes the former Redcar Bulk Terminal, has been cordoned off and the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) has been informed. The identities of the men have not yet been released. Two other men were injured in the blast, which happened close to a site owned by demolition firm TWMA. A spokesperson for TWMA Group said: "This tragic incident occurred during the decommissioning of the former Redcar Bulk Terminal, which TWMA were contracted to undertake. "Our primary focus at this time is on supporting those involved, the families of those who have sadly lost their lives, the injured and our employees." Chief Superintendent Sharon Cooney, of Cleveland Police, said: "This is an extremely tragic incident and our thoughts are with the families and friends of the men who have lost their lives. "We are working with our partners to establish what happened and to support those affected." The former SSI steelworks, which closed in 2015, has been the subject of several redevelopment plans in recent years. In 2020, it was announced that the site would be used for a new "green" steel plant, but these plans have since been put on hold. The site is owned by the SSI UK Property Company, which is part of the Thai steel company Sahaviriya Steel Industries (SSI). A spokesperson for Sahaviriya Steel Industries said: "We are deeply saddened by the tragic incident that occurred at the former SSI UK steelworks site in Redcar. "Our thoughts and condolences are with the families and friends of the victims. "We are committed to working with the authorities to investigate this incident thoroughly and to ensure that all necessary safety measures are in place."

title: Da Vinci's art is star of Swansea's revamped Glynn Vivian gallery
text: Nestled amidst the bustling streets of Swansea, the newly revamped Glynn Vivian Art Gallery has unveiled an exhibition that will captivate art enthusiasts and casual observers alike: "Leonardo da Vinci: A Life in Drawing." This extraordinary showcase brings together a collection of exquisite drawings by the Italian master, offering a glimpse into the mind of one of history's greatest geniuses. At the heart of the exhibition is the magnificent "Benois Madonna," a captivating study of the Virgin Mary with the Christ Child. Created around 1480, this drawing showcases da Vinci's mastery of chiaroscuro, the interplay of light and shadow, which creates a sense of depth and realism that is both awe-inspiring and intimate. Another highlight is the "Head of Grotesque Man," a striking portrait of a jester with an enigmatic expression. With his exaggerated features and piercing gaze, this drawing reveals da Vinci's fascination with human physiognomy and his ability to capture the complexities of the human condition. The exhibition also features a selection of preparatory sketches for da Vinci's iconic masterpiece, the "Mona Lisa." These drawings provide valuable insights into the artist's meticulous planning process and his quest for perfection. Visitors can trace the evolution of the painting from its initial conception to its final execution, gaining a deeper appreciation for da Vinci's artistic brilliance. Beyond the famous works, the exhibition also showcases a range of lesser-known drawings that illuminate da Vinci's diverse interests and pursuits. From anatomical studies to landscapes, these sketches reveal the breadth of his genius and his insatiable curiosity about the natural world. The Glynn Vivian Art Gallery has created a stunning and immersive experience for visitors. The exhibition is thoughtfully curated, with each drawing carefully placed to create a narrative that guides visitors through da Vinci's artistic journey. The gallery space is spacious and well-lit, allowing visitors to fully appreciate the details and nuances of each work. "Leonardo da Vinci: A Life in Drawing" is an unmissable opportunity to encounter the genius of one of the most influential artists in history. Whether you are an art connoisseur or simply curious about the Renaissance, this exhibition will inspire, intrigue, and leave a lasting impression.

title: Small pearl-bordered fritillary butterfly numbers boost
text: The small pearl-bordered fritillary butterfly is a rare and threatened species that has seen a significant boost in numbers thanks to conservation efforts. The butterfly, which is found in damp meadows and marshes, has suffered from habitat loss and fragmentation, as well as changes in land management practices. As a result, its numbers have declined significantly in recent decades. However, thanks to the work of conservationists, the small pearl-bordered fritillary is now making a comeback. In the UK, the Butterfly Conservation charity has been working with landowners and farmers to create and restore habitats for the butterfly. This has included planting wildflowers, managing grazing and mowing practices, and reducing the use of pesticides. As a result of these efforts, the small pearl-bordered fritillary is now starting to recolonise areas where it was once extinct. In 2022, the butterfly was recorded in 10 new sites in the UK, the highest number of new records in a single year since the charity began monitoring the species in 1976. Dr Richard Fox, head of science at Butterfly Conservation, said: "This is fantastic news for the small pearl-bordered fritillary. It shows that with the right conservation efforts, we can help to bring even the rarest species back from the brink of extinction." The small pearl-bordered fritillary is a beautiful and important species. It plays a vital role in the ecosystem, pollinating plants and providing food for other animals. Its recovery is a testament to the power of conservation and the importance of working together to protect our wildlife. Here are some tips on how you can help the small pearl-bordered fritillary: - Create a wildlife-friendly garden by planting wildflowers and reducing the use of pesticides. - Support organisations that are working to protect the butterfly, such as Butterfly Conservation. - Visit meadows and marshes where the butterfly is known to occur and report any sightings to Butterfly Conservation.

title: Caerphilly and Blaenau Gwent social services merger rejected
text: Caerphilly and Blaenau Gwent social services merger rejected Plans to merge the social services departments of Caerphilly and Blaenau Gwent councils have been rejected by the Welsh Government. The merger was proposed as a way to save money and improve services, but the government said it had not been convinced that it would be in the best interests of the people of the two counties. They had argued that the merger would lead to a more efficient and effective social services department, and that it would save money that could be used to improve services. However, the government said it had not been convinced that the merger would achieve the desired outcomes. It said that there was no clear evidence that the merger would lead to significant savings, and that it could actually lead to a worse service for the people of the two counties. The government also said that it was concerned about the impact of the merger on the staff of the two councils. It said that the merger could lead to job losses and that it could also make it more difficult for staff to provide a high-quality service. The decision to reject the merger has been welcomed by some people, but it has also been criticized by others. Those who support the decision say that it is the right one for the people of the two counties, and that it will protect vital services. Those who criticize the decision say that it is a missed opportunity to improve services and that it will lead to a worse service for the people of the two counties. It is not yet clear what the next step will be for the two councils. They could decide to appeal the government's decision, or they could decide to abandon the merger plans altogether. Whatever they decide, it is clear that the decision to reject the merger will have a significant impact on the social services departments of the two counties. It is also clear that the decision will have a significant impact on the people who rely on those services.

title: Egypt explosion: Tourists on bus injured near Giza pyramids
text: Tourists were injured in a bus explosion near Egypt's iconic Giza pyramids on Saturday, the health ministry has said. Two people were killed and at least 12 others were injured on the bus, which was carrying tourists from South Africa. The blast occurred as the bus was travelling along the road leading to the pyramids, officials said. Egypt's interior ministry said the explosion was caused by a homemade bomb placed under the bus, adding that it had begun an investigation into the incident. No group has yet claimed responsibility for the attack. The health ministry said the injured tourists were taken to nearby hospitals for treatment. Most of them are said to be in a stable condition. The Giza pyramids are one of Egypt's most popular tourist destinations. Millions of people visit the ancient structures each year. The explosion comes as Egypt's tourism industry is struggling to recover from the Covid-19 pandemic, which caused a sharp decline in visitor numbers. The country is hoping to boost its tourism revenue by promoting new tourist attractions, such as the Grand Egyptian Museum, which is set to open later this year. The attack is a reminder of the security challenges that Egypt faces. The country has been battling an insurgency in the Sinai Peninsula for years. In recent months, there have also been several attacks on Coptic Christian churches in the country. The UK Foreign Office has advised British nationals to avoid the area around the Giza pyramids. It has also advised against all but essential travel to Egypt. The explosion has been condemned by world leaders. UN Secretary-General António Guterres said he was "deeply saddened" by the news of the attack. He called for those responsible to be brought to justice. US President Joe Biden said the attack was "a cowardly act of violence against innocent civilians." He said the US stands with Egypt in its fight against terrorism. The Egyptian government has vowed to bring those responsible for the attack to justice. President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi said the attack would not deter Egypt from continuing to fight terrorism. The explosion is a major blow to Egypt's tourism industry. It is likely to deter tourists from visiting the country, which could have a significant impact on the economy.

title: NI 100: BBC News NI marks a milestone in Irish history
text: Marking the 100th anniversary of Northern Ireland's foundation, BBC News NI will present extensive multi-platform coverage throughout 2021, reflecting on the region's complex century. The centerpiece of the coverage will be a landmark documentary series, "NI 100," which will explore the key moments, themes, and personalities that have shaped Northern Ireland since its inception. The series will feature contributions from a range of historians, politicians, and cultural figures, offering diverse perspectives on the region's journey. "NI 100" will delve into the events that led to the creation of Northern Ireland in 1921, examining the political and social factors that influenced the partition of Ireland. It will also explore the turbulent decades of conflict known as the Troubles, which left an enduring mark on the region. In addition to the documentary series, BBC News NI will produce a range of other programming to mark the anniversary. This will include dedicated news specials, current affairs programs, and features focusing on the impact of the past century on different aspects of Northern Irish society. BBC News NI's online platforms will provide comprehensive coverage, including interactive timelines, archival footage, and original content from across the region.
