title: New divorce form 'invites name and shame' of adulterers
text: The government has unveiled a new divorce form that will invite couples to name and shame their adulterous partners. The move is part of a wider crackdown on infidelity, which the government believes is responsible for the breakdown of families and the rise in social problems. The new form will ask couples to state whether their marriage has broken down due to adultery. If so, they will be asked to provide the name and address of the third party involved. This information will then be passed on to the other spouse, who will be free to use it as they see fit. The government believes that the new form will help to deter adultery and make it easier for innocent spouses to rebuild their lives. However, critics have warned that the form could lead to a wave of revenge divorces and further damage already fragile relationships. They also argue that it is unfair to punish adulterers without giving them a chance to defend themselves. The government has defended the new form, saying that it is necessary to send a clear message that adultery is unacceptable. It also argues that the form is voluntary and that couples will not be forced to name their adulterous partners if they do not want to. The new form is expected to come into effect in the coming months. It is likely to prove controversial, but the government believes that it is a necessary step in tackling the problem of adultery. In addition to the new divorce form, the government is also considering a number of other measures to crack down on infidelity. These include introducing a new criminal offence of adultery, making it easier for innocent spouses to divorce their adulterous partners, and providing more support for victims of infidelity. The government's crackdown on infidelity is likely to be met with mixed reactions. Some will welcome it as a necessary step to protect families and relationships. Others will see it as an unnecessary intrusion into private lives. Only time will tell whether the government's new measures will be effective in reducing the incidence of adultery and improving the lives of those affected by it.

title: Emmerdale is 'booziest' soap, study suggests
text: Emmerdale has been labelled the "booziest" soap on British television, according to a new study. Researchers from the University of Liverpool analysed more than 1,000 episodes of Emmerdale, Coronation Street, EastEnders and Hollyoaks, and found that Emmerdale featured the highest number of scenes involving alcohol consumption. The study, published in the journal Alcohol and Alcoholism, found that Emmerdale had an average of 10.6 scenes per episode involving alcohol, compared to 8.9 in Coronation Street, 7.8 in EastEnders and 7.4 in Hollyoaks. The researchers also found that Emmerdale was the only soap where alcohol consumption was more common in the evening than during the day. Lead researcher Dr. Sarah Jarvis said the findings were concerning, as they suggested that Emmerdale was "normalising" alcohol consumption. "Alcohol is often portrayed as a way to relax, celebrate or cope with stress," she said. "This can lead people to believe that drinking alcohol is a normal and harmless part of everyday life." Dr. Jarvis said that the study's findings were particularly concerning given that Emmerdale is watched by a large number of young people. "Young people are more likely to be influenced by what they see on television," she said. "If they see alcohol being consumed frequently on Emmerdale, they may be more likely to think that it is acceptable to drink alcohol themselves." Dr. Jarvis said that it was important for soap operas to be responsible in their portrayal of alcohol consumption. "Soaps have a powerful influence on viewers," she said. "They can use this influence to promote positive messages about alcohol consumption, such as the importance of drinking in moderation and avoiding binge drinking." An ITV spokesperson said that Emmerdale "reflects real life" and that "alcohol consumption is a part of many people's lives". "We always aim to portray alcohol consumption in a responsible way," the spokesperson said. "We work closely with alcohol awareness charities to ensure that our storylines are accurate and do not glamorize alcohol misuse."

title: Harry Richford inquest: 'Lives at risk' over locum doctor recruitment
text: Harry Richford inquest: 'Lives at risk' over locum doctor recruitment The recruitment of locum doctors is putting lives at risk, an inquest has heard. Harry Richford, 26, died after he was given the wrong dose of medication by a locum doctor at Stafford Hospital in 2018. The inquest into his death heard that the doctor, who was working through an agency, had not been properly checked by the hospital. The doctor had a history of making errors and had been dismissed from another hospital, but this information was not passed on to Stafford Hospital. The inquest heard that the doctor had been working at Stafford Hospital for three months before Richford's death. During that time, he had made a number of mistakes, including prescribing the wrong medication to another patient. The inquest also heard that the doctor had been drinking alcohol before he started his shift on the day Richford died. The doctor has since been struck off the medical register. The inquest concluded that Richford's death was avoidable and that the hospital had failed to take reasonable steps to protect patients. The coroner said that the hospital's recruitment process for locum doctors was "inadequate" and that "lives are at risk" if it does not improve. The inquest made a number of recommendations to the hospital, including: Improving the recruitment process for locum doctors Ensuring that locum doctors are properly checked before they start work Providing more training for staff on how to deal with locum doctors Developing a system for monitoring the performance of locum doctors The hospital said that it had accepted the recommendations and that it was "committed to improving the safety of patients." However, the inquest heard that the hospital had not taken any action to improve the recruitment process for locum doctors since Richford's death. The inquest also heard that the hospital had not provided any additional training for staff on how to deal with locum doctors. The coroner said that he was "disappointed" that the hospital had not taken any action to improve the recruitment process for locum doctors. He said that the hospital had a "duty of care" to patients and that it must do everything it can to protect them.

title: Poland must suspend judge discipline panel – ECJ
text: Poland must suspend judge discipline panel – ECJ The European Court of Justice (ECJ) has ordered Poland to immediately suspend the operation of its Disciplinary Chamber for judges, ruling that the body undermines judicial independence. The decision comes in response to a request from the European Commission, which had argued that the Disciplinary Chamber violated EU law by allowing for the arbitrary dismissal of judges who criticize the government. The ECJ found that the Disciplinary Chamber is not independent or impartial, and that its procedures do not provide sufficient guarantees of fairness. It also noted that the chamber had been used to target judges who had ruled against the government, or who had expressed critical views of the judicial reforms. The ECJ's ruling is a major blow to the Polish government, which has been criticized for its efforts to bring the judiciary under its control. The ruling could also have implications for other EU countries that are considering implementing similar measures. In a statement, the European Commission welcomed the ECJ's decision, saying that it was a "clear victory for judicial independence in Poland and for the rule of law in the EU." The Commission also called on Poland to fully implement the ruling. The Polish government has not yet commented on the ECJ's decision. However, it is expected to appeal the ruling to the ECJ's highest court, the Court of Justice. The ECJ's ruling is the latest development in a long-running conflict between the EU and Poland over the rule of law. The EU has expressed concerns about a number of reforms implemented by the Polish government, including a law that lowers the retirement age for judges and a law that gives the government greater control over the appointment of judges. The Polish government has defended its reforms, arguing that they are necessary to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the judiciary. However, the EU maintains that the reforms undermine judicial independence and violate EU law.

title: Litvinenko inquiry: Ex-spy 'investigating Stolichnaya vodka row'
text: Former Russian spy Alexander Litvinenko's widow is investigating the row over Stolichnaya vodka after a judge ruled it is "made in Russia" despite the firm's claims it is now made in Latvia. Marina Litvinenko says she is "very interested" in the legal battle over the popular brand, which claims to have moved production to Latvia to distance itself from the "toxic" reputation of Russian goods. Her late husband was poisoned with radioactive polonium-210 in 2006 by two Russian agents in London, allegedly on the orders of President Vladimir Putin. The dispute over Stolichnaya's origins has raised concerns that consumers are being misled and may even be funding the Russian regime, which is facing international sanctions over its invasion of Ukraine. Stolichnaya is one of the world's best-selling vodka brands, with annual sales of around $1 billion. It is owned by Russian businessman Yuri Shefler, who fled Russia in 2000 after falling out with the Kremlin. In 2013, Stolichnaya announced it was moving production to Latvia, a member of the European Union, to distance itself from the "toxic" reputation of Russian goods. However, a recent court ruling in the United States found that Stolichnaya is still "made in Russia" because the spirits used to make the vodka are distilled and filtered in Russia. The ruling has sparked anger among consumers and retailers, who say they have been misled. Some stores have even stopped selling Stolichnaya. Marina Litvinenko said she is "very interested" in the legal battle over Stolichnaya. She said: "I am concerned that consumers are being misled and that the Russian regime may be benefiting from the sale of this vodka." She added: "I am considering taking legal action against Stolichnaya to ensure that consumers are not misled and that the Russian regime does not benefit from the sale of this vodka." Stolichnaya has denied any wrongdoing and said it is "confident" it will win the legal battle. The company said in a statement: "Stolichnaya is made in Latvia, in accordance with all applicable laws and regulations. We are confident that the court will ultimately uphold our position." The dispute over Stolichnaya is the latest in a series of legal battles over the origins of Russian goods. In 2021, a US court ruled that Russian Standard vodka is not "made in Russia" because it is distilled in Russia but bottled in Latvia. The ruling has led to calls for stricter labeling laws to ensure that consumers are not misled about the origins of products.

title: Guildford Four man Gerry Conlon's 'living hell' revealed
text: Gerry Conlon's 'Living Hell' Revealed Gerry Conlon, a member of the Guildford Four, has spoken out about the "living hell" he endured during his wrongful imprisonment for the IRA pub bombings in 1974. Conlon was only 17 when he was arrested and falsely accused of planting the bombs that killed five people and injured 65 in Guildford, Surrey. He was sentenced to life imprisonment along with three other innocent men - Paul Hill, Paddy Armstrong, and Carole Richardson. In a new interview with the BBC, Conlon described the horrific conditions he faced in prison. He was subjected to beatings, solitary confinement, and psychological torture. "I was living in a constant state of fear," he said. "I didn't know if I was going to be killed or tortured at any moment." In one particularly harrowing incident, Conlon was taken to a room and told he was going to be executed. "They put a black hood over my head and led me to a room," he said. "I heard a click and I thought, 'This is it, I'm going to die'." As he prepared to be shot, a voice suddenly shouted, "Stop!" Conlon had narrowly escaped death. Despite the constant trauma, Conlon managed to maintain his innocence throughout his 15 years behind bars. He was finally released in 1989 when the Court of Appeal quashed the convictions. In the years since his release, Conlon has dedicated his life to campaigning for justice for other victims of miscarriages of justice. He has also written a book about his experiences, called "Proved Innocent". Conlon's story is a powerful reminder of the devastating consequences of wrongful imprisonment. His experience highlights the urgent need for reforms to the criminal justice system to prevent such injustices from happening again. In addition to the physical and psychological torture, Conlon also endured social isolation during his imprisonment. He was cut off from his family and friends, and had no contact with the outside world for long periods of time. This isolation further exacerbated the trauma he experienced. Despite the challenges he faced, Conlon remained resilient throughout his ordeal. He found solace in reading, writing poetry, and playing guitar. He also drew strength from the support of his fellow prisoners, who knew he was innocent. Conlon's story is not just a personal tragedy. It is also a testament to the resilience of the human spirit and the importance of fighting for justice, even in the darkest of times.

title: High-rise flats approved for Bedminster shopping centre
text: High-rise flats approved for Bedminster shopping centre Developers have been given the go-ahead to build two tower blocks of flats on the site of a former shopping centre in Bedminster. The plans for the former Victoria Park site include 247 build-to-rent apartments, of which 124 will be affordable homes. Bristol City Council's development control committee (DCC) approved the application on Tuesday (28 June). The towers will be 19 and 20 storeys high, and will be built on the site of the former Victoria Park shopping centre, which closed in 2016. The new development will also include commercial space on the ground floor, as well as a public square and a new pedestrian route through the site. The application was approved despite concerns from some local residents about the height of the buildings and the impact they would have on the character of the area. However, planning officers said the benefits of the scheme outweighed the concerns, and that the towers would be a "landmark" development for Bedminster. The developers, Legal & General, said they were "delighted" with the decision. "This is a major milestone for this exciting development, which will transform a brownfield site into a thriving new neighbourhood," a spokesperson said. "We are committed to creating a high-quality development that will be a positive addition to the local community." The development is expected to be completed by 2025. Reaction Local councillor Jo Sergeant welcomed the decision, saying it would "breathe new life" into Bedminster. "This is a huge investment in Bedminster and it will create much-needed new homes, including affordable homes," she said. "The new development will also create new jobs and boost the local economy." However, some local residents expressed concerns about the height of the buildings and the impact they would have on the character of the area. One resident, who did not want to be named, said: "I'm worried about the impact these towers will have on the skyline. They're going to be so out of place." Another resident, who also did not want to be named, said: "I'm concerned about the traffic and congestion that these new flats will generate. Bedminster is already a busy area." Planning process The application was submitted to Bristol City Council in January 2022. The council's development control committee (DCC) considered the application at a meeting on Tuesday (28 June). The DCC approved the application by a vote of 10 to 2. The decision is subject to a legal challenge within six weeks.

title: ASA probes Home Office 'go home' van campaign
text: The Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) has launched an investigation into the Home Office's "Go Home" van campaign after receiving complaints that it is offensive and discriminatory. The campaign, which was launched in August, features vans driving around London and other cities with the message "Go Home" emblazoned on the side. The vans also display the website address of the Home Office's "Go Home" campaign, which provides information on how to report illegal immigrants. The ASA has received over 100 complaints about the campaign, with many people arguing that it is offensive and discriminatory. Some complainants have also argued that the campaign is ineffective and will not deter illegal immigration. The Home Office has defended the campaign, arguing that it is a necessary measure to deter illegal immigration. The Home Office has also said that the campaign is not intended to be offensive or discriminatory, and that it is targeted at illegal immigrants, not legal immigrants. The ASA is now investigating the complaints and will decide whether the campaign breaches the Advertising Codes. If the ASA finds that the campaign does breach the Advertising Codes, it could order the Home Office to withdraw or amend the campaign. The "Go Home" campaign has been widely criticized by politicians, community groups, and human rights organizations. Critics have argued that the campaign is divisive and will create a hostile environment for immigrants. Some critics have also argued that the campaign is racist and Islamophobic. The campaign has also been criticized by some within the Home Office. In September, a group of senior Home Office officials wrote a letter to the Home Secretary, Theresa May, expressing their concerns about the campaign. The officials argued that the campaign was "divisive and counterproductive," and that it would "damage community relations." The "Go Home" campaign is part of the government's wider crackdown on immigration. In recent years, the government has introduced a number of measures to make it more difficult for illegal immigrants to live in the UK. These measures include making it harder for illegal immigrants to access healthcare, education, and employment. The government has also increased the number of deportations of illegal immigrants. In 2014, the government deported over 28,000 illegal immigrants, the highest number in a decade. The government's crackdown on immigration has been criticized by human rights groups and immigration charities. Critics have argued that the government's policies are unfair and discriminatory, and that they are creating a hostile environment for immigrants.

title: Aberdeen 'best-placed city for growth' in Britain
text: Aberdeen: Britain's Best-Placed City for Growth Aberdeen has emerged as the best-placed city for growth in Britain, according to a new study by the Centre for Economic and Business Research (CEBR). The study assessed factors such as economic performance, infrastructure, skills, and innovation, and found that Aberdeen ranked highly in all key areas. Robust Economic Performance Aberdeen's economy has weathered the recent economic downturn relatively well, with the city's unemployment rate remaining below the national average. The city's strong performance is largely due to its diverse economic base, which includes a mix of traditional industries such as oil and gas, as well as emerging sectors such as renewable energy and technology. Excellent Infrastructure Aberdeen has excellent infrastructure, with a well-developed transport network and a reliable energy supply. The city is also home to a number of world-class universities and research institutions, which provide a steady stream of skilled workers and innovation. Highly Skilled Workforce Aberdeen has a highly skilled workforce, with a large proportion of its population holding higher education qualifications. The city's universities and colleges provide a pipeline of talent for local businesses, while the influx of skilled workers from other parts of the UK and abroad has further boosted the local labor market. Strong Innovation Culture Aberdeen has a strong innovation culture, with a number of research and development centers located in the city. The city is also home to a number of tech start-ups and incubators, which provide support for new and emerging businesses. This innovation ecosystem has helped to create a dynamic and entrepreneurial environment in Aberdeen. Government Support Aberdeen has benefited from significant government support in recent years, with the city receiving funding for a number of infrastructure projects and regeneration schemes. This investment has helped to create jobs and improve the quality of life for local residents, making Aberdeen an even more attractive place to live and work. Outlook for the Future The outlook for Aberdeen's growth prospects is positive. The city's economy is expected to continue to grow, driven by the recovery in the oil and gas sector and the development of new industries. Aberdeen's strong infrastructure, highly skilled workforce, and innovation culture will also continue to be major drivers of growth. As a result of these factors, Aberdeen is well-positioned to be a major hub for economic activity in Britain in the years to come. The city's strong fundamentals and supportive government policies make it an attractive destination for businesses, investors, and skilled workers.

title: Scotland's gone 'too far' on universal benefits says poverty advisor
text: Scotland's welfare system has gone "too far" in providing universal benefits, according to a leading poverty adviser. John Dickie, the chairman of the Bevan Foundation, said the country was "setting a dangerous precedent" by giving benefits to all children, regardless of their family's income. He argued that universal benefits are "not the best way" to tackle child poverty and could lead to a "dependency culture". Mr Dickie's comments come as the Scottish government prepares to introduce a new system of universal benefits, which will see all children under the age of 16 receive a weekly payment of £20. The policy has been welcomed by some anti-poverty campaigners, who argue that it will help to reduce child poverty in Scotland. However, Mr Dickie said that universal benefits are "not the answer" to child poverty and could have a number of negative consequences. He said: "Universal benefits are not the best way to tackle child poverty. They are expensive, they can create a dependency culture, and they can lead to people feeling stigmatized." Mr Dickie argued that the Scottish government should instead focus on providing targeted support to families who are most in need. He said: "We need to be focusing on helping families who are struggling to make ends meet. That means providing targeted support to those who need it most." The Scottish government has defended its plans for universal benefits, arguing that they will help to reduce child poverty and create a fairer society. However, Mr Dickie's comments have reignited the debate about the best way to tackle child poverty in Scotland. It is a complex issue with no easy answers. The Scottish government is right to be ambitious in its efforts to reduce child poverty, but it is important to ensure that any new policies are effective and do not have unintended negative consequences. What do you think? Do you agree with John Dickie that Scotland's welfare system has gone "too far" in providing universal benefits? Or do you think that the Scottish government is right to focus on reducing child poverty through universal benefits?

title: Inverness Airport preferred site for air traffic hub
text: Inverness Airport has been identified as the preferred site for a new air traffic hub in the Highlands and Islands. The Scottish government has announced that it will invest £40 million in the project, which is expected to create hundreds of new jobs and boost the local economy. The new hub will be located at Inverness Airport, which is already the busiest airport in the Highlands and Islands. It will be used to coordinate air traffic between the Highlands and Islands and the rest of the UK and Europe. The project is expected to be completed by 2025. The Scottish government said that the new hub will "transform connectivity" between the Highlands and Islands and the rest of the world. "This is a major investment in the Highlands and Islands, and it will have a significant impact on the local economy," said Transport Minister Humza Yousaf. "The new air traffic hub will make it easier for people to travel to and from the Highlands and Islands, and it will also help to attract new businesses to the region." Inverness Airport welcomed the announcement, saying that it was a "significant step forward" for the airport and the Highlands and Islands. "This investment will allow us to build a state-of-the-art air traffic hub that will meet the needs of the region for many years to come," said Inverness Airport CEO Inglis Lyon. "We are confident that the new hub will be a major catalyst for economic growth in the Highlands and Islands." The new air traffic hub is part of the Scottish government's wider plans to improve transport infrastructure in the Highlands and Islands. The government has also announced plans to invest £30 million in a new road bridge over the River Spey, and £20 million in a new ferry terminal at Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis. These investments are expected to improve connectivity between the Highlands and Islands and the rest of Scotland, and to boost the local economy.

title: Titanic Quarter bus lane tailbacks 'horrendous'
text: Titanic Quarter bus lane tailbacks 'horrendous' Motorists are being warned to expect "horrendous" tailbacks in Belfast's Titanic Quarter due to ongoing works. A contraflow system has been implemented on Queens Road, with one lane closed in each direction. The Department for Infrastructure (DfI) said the works were necessary to facilitate the construction of a new bus lane. However, the roadworks have caused significant delays, with some motorists reporting being stuck in traffic for over an hour. The DfI has apologised for the inconvenience and said it is doing everything it can to minimise disruption. A spokesperson said: "We understand that this is a busy area and that the roadworks are causing delays. "We are doing everything we can to minimise disruption and we would ask motorists to be patient." The works are expected to be completed by the end of March. In the meantime, motorists are being advised to use alternative routes if possible. The new bus lane is part of a wider plan to improve public transport in the Titanic Quarter. Once completed, the bus lane will provide a dedicated space for buses, which will help to reduce journey times. The Titanic Quarter is a major regeneration area in Belfast. It is home to a number of businesses, including the Titanic Belfast museum and the SSE Arena. The area is also popular with tourists, who come to see the Titanic Belfast museum and the Titanic Slipways. The new bus lane is expected to improve accessibility to the Titanic Quarter and make it easier for people to get around the area. However, the roadworks have caused significant disruption in the short term. Motorists are being advised to use alternative routes if possible and to be patient while the works are ongoing.

title: Children in poverty in Wales falls to 23% after incomes drop
text: The proportion of children living in poverty in Wales has fallen to 23%, according to new figures from the Welsh government. The latest Child Poverty in Wales report shows that the number of children living in relative poverty has fallen by 10,000 since 2019. Relative poverty is defined as living in a household with an income below 60% of the median income. The report also shows that the number of children living in severe poverty has fallen by 5,000 since 2019. Severe poverty is defined as living in a household with an income below 50% of the median income. The Welsh government said the fall in child poverty was due to a number of factors, including: An increase in the incomes of low-income families A decrease in the number of children living in workless households A decrease in the number of children living in overcrowded households The report also shows that the gap between the incomes of the richest and poorest families in Wales has narrowed since 2019. The Welsh government said it was committed to reducing child poverty further. "We know that poverty can have a devastating impact on children's lives," said Children's Minister Jeremy Miles. "That's why we have made reducing child poverty a priority. "The latest figures show that we are making progress, but there is still more to do. "We will continue to work with our partners to ensure that every child in Wales has the best possible start in life." The Child Poverty Action Group (CPAG) welcomed the fall in child poverty, but said more needed to be done. "This is a positive step, but it is important to remember that over 100,000 children in Wales are still living in poverty," said CPAG Cymru director, Ruth Coombs. "We need to see further action from the Welsh government to reduce child poverty further. "This includes increasing the incomes of low-income families, investing in affordable housing, and improving access to childcare."

title: Glasgow's Burrell Collection becomes listed building
text: Glasgow's Burrell Collection, one of the city's most treasured museums, has been listed as a Category A building by Historic Environment Scotland (HES). The move recognises the outstanding architectural and historical significance of the building, which houses a world-renowned collection of art and artefacts. The Burrell Collection was founded in 1944 when Sir William Burrell, a wealthy shipping magnate and art collector, gifted his vast collection of over 9,000 objects to the city of Glasgow. The collection includes paintings, sculptures, furniture, ceramics, and other objects from all over the world. The museum building was designed by Sir Basil Spence and completed in 1983. The building is a striking example of mid-century modern architecture, with its distinctive curved roof and glass facade. The building is set in Pollok Country Park, on the outskirts of Glasgow, and offers stunning views of the city and the surrounding countryside. The listing of the Burrell Collection as a Category A building will help to protect the building and ensure its long-term preservation. The building is already a popular tourist destination and the listing is likely to increase its appeal to visitors from around the world. The Burrell Collection is a major cultural asset for Glasgow and Scotland. The listing of the building as a Category A building is a fitting recognition of its importance and will help to ensure that it continues to be enjoyed by future generations. HES listed the Burrell Collection at Category A, its highest category of protection, for the following reasons: The exceptional quality of the building's design and the innovative use of materials and construction techniques. The building's significant contribution to the architectural landscape of Glasgow and Scotland. The building's strong association with Sir William Burrell and his collection of art and artefacts. The building's importance as a cultural landmark and visitor attraction. The listing of the Burrell Collection as a Category A building will help to protect the building from any future alterations or developments that could harm its architectural or historical significance. It will also help to raise awareness of the building and its importance as a cultural asset.

title: Fly-tipping prosecutions fall by two-thirds in Scotland
text: Fly-tipping prosecutions in Scotland have plummeted by two-thirds in the last decade, figures obtained by the BBC show. In 2013, there were 889 prosecutions for illegally dumping waste, but by 2022, that number had fallen to just 298. Environmental groups have warned that the decline is a "major concern" and could lead to an increase in fly-tipping. The Scottish government said it was "disappointed" by the figures and was "taking action" to tackle the problem. Fly-tipping is the illegal dumping of waste, often on land or in water. It can include anything from household rubbish to construction waste. It is a serious environmental crime and can have a devastating impact on wildlife, habitats, and human health. The BBC obtained the figures from the Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA). They show that the number of fly-tipping prosecutions has fallen steadily in Scotland since 2013. In 2013, there were 889 prosecutions, but by 2014, that number had fallen to 783. In 2015, it fell again to 675, and in 2016, it fell to 567. The decline has continued in recent years, with 445 prosecutions in 2017, 373 in 2018, 321 in 2019, and 298 in 2022. Environmental groups have warned that the decline in prosecutions is a "major concern" and could lead to an increase in fly-tipping. "Fly-tipping is a serious environmental crime that can have a devastating impact on our wildlife, habitats, and human health," said Ruth Chambers, the head of policy and advocacy at Keep Scotland Beautiful. "The decline in prosecutions for this crime is a major concern and could lead to an increase in fly-tipping. "The government needs to take action to tackle this problem, including increasing the number of prosecutions for fly-tipping and imposing stricter penalties on those who are caught." The Scottish government said it was "disappointed" by the figures and was "taking action" to tackle the problem. "We are disappointed by these figures, which show that the number of fly-tipping prosecutions has fallen in recent years," said a Scottish government spokesperson. "We are committed to tackling this problem and are taking action to do so, including increasing the number of SEPA officers who can investigate and prosecute fly-tipping. "We are also working with local authorities and other partners to raise awareness of the issue and to encourage people to dispose of their waste responsibly."

title: Healthy breakfasts 'help pupils do well'
text: Healthy Breakfasts Help Pupils Do Well Research has consistently shown that eating a healthy breakfast can have a positive impact on a child's academic performance. In this article, we explore how a nutritious breakfast can help pupils do well in school. Improved Concentration and Memory Breakfast provides the brain with essential nutrients, such as glucose, which is the primary source of energy for the brain. Without a sufficient intake of glucose, pupils may experience difficulty concentrating and paying attention in class. Studies have shown that children who eat breakfast have improved short-term memory and problem-solving abilities. Enhanced Cognitive Function A healthy breakfast also contains essential micronutrients, such as vitamins and minerals, which are crucial for brain health. Iron, for example, is essential for the production of red blood cells, which transport oxygen throughout the body, including to the brain. Vitamin B12 is another important nutrient for cognitive function, as it is involved in the production of neurotransmitters. Improved Attendance and Punctuality Pupils who eat a healthy breakfast are less likely to miss school or arrive late. When children are well-nourished, they are less likely to experience physical complaints, such as headaches or stomachaches, that can prevent them from attending school. In addition, eating a nutritious breakfast can help pupils stay energized throughout the morning, improving their overall alertness and reducing the likelihood of tardiness. Increased Academic Achievement Several studies have shown a positive correlation between eating a healthy breakfast and academic achievement. In one study, children who ate a healthy breakfast were found to have higher scores on standardized tests in math and reading. Another study found that pupils who ate a healthy breakfast were more likely to be in the top quartile of their class in math and English. Practical Tips for Parents To ensure that pupils get a healthy breakfast, parents can consider the following tips: Offer a variety of nutritious options, such as whole grains, fruits, vegetables, and lean protein. Encourage children to eat breakfast at a regular time each day. Avoid sugary cereals and drinks, as these provide a quick but unsustainable energy boost. If children are reluctant to eat breakfast at home, consider packing a healthy snack to eat later at school. In conclusion, a healthy breakfast is essential for pupils to reach their full academic potential. By providing their children with a nutritious start to the day, parents can help improve their concentration, memory, cognitive function, attendance, punctuality, and overall academic achievement.

title: Parades Commission not going anywhere
text: The Parades Commission, the body responsible for managing parades and protests in Northern Ireland, will continue to operate for the foreseeable future. This is despite calls from some quarters for its abolition, following a number of controversial decisions in recent years. The Commission was established in 1998 under the Good Friday Agreement. Its purpose is to ensure that parades are held in a safe and orderly manner, and to minimize the potential for public disorder. The Commission has the power to ban parades, or to impose conditions on their route or timing. In recent years, the Commission has been criticized for its decisions on a number of high-profile parades. In 2013, for example, it banned an Orange Order parade from passing through a Catholic area of Belfast. This decision sparked widespread anger and led to rioting in the city. Despite these controversies, the Commission has continued to operate, and it is likely to remain in place for the foreseeable future. There is no political consensus on how to reform the Commission, and any attempt to abolish it would likely be met with strong opposition from both sides of the community. The Commission's continued existence is a reminder of the ongoing need for dialogue and cooperation in Northern Ireland. The parades issue is a complex and sensitive one, and there is no easy solution. However, the Commission provides a mechanism for managing this issue in a way that minimizes the potential for violence and instability. The Commission's work is not without its challenges. It must balance the right to freedom of assembly with the need to protect public safety. It must also navigate the often-difficult terrain of inter-communal relations in Northern Ireland. However, the Commission has shown itself to be a resilient and effective body, and it is likely to continue to play a vital role in the years to come. The Commission's continued operation is a sign of the progress that has been made in Northern Ireland since the Good Friday Agreement. However, it is also a reminder of the challenges that remain. The parades issue is a complex and sensitive one, and there is no easy solution. However, the Commission provides a mechanism for managing this issue in a way that minimizes the potential for violence and instability.

title: Kanye West finally answers Jimmy Kimmel's Donald Trump question
text: Kanye West Breaks Silence on Trump with Kimmel In a highly anticipated interview with Jimmy Kimmel, Kanye West finally addressed his controversial support for former President Donald Trump. The interview, which aired on Tuesday, marked the first time West had publicly commented on his political views since the 2020 election. Kimmel wasted no time in confronting West, asking him directly why he had supported Trump despite the former president's divisive rhetoric. West initially dodged the question, but after Kimmel pressed him, he eventually admitted that he had been "impressed" by Trump's "business acumen" and "leadership." "I thought he was a good leader because he was willing to do what it took to get things done," West said. "I don't agree with everything he said, but I respected his willingness to fight for what he believed in." Kimmel challenged West on Trump's false claims about the election, but West remained steadfast in his support. He argued that Trump had been a victim of a "witch hunt" and that the media had unfairly targeted him. "They were trying to cancel him," West said. "They were trying to silence him. But he stood up for what he believed in." Kimmel also questioned West about his own political ambitions. West confirmed that he was considering running for president in 2024, but he declined to provide any details about his campaign. "I'm still exploring it," West said. "I'm not going to make any decisions until after the midterm elections." The interview was met with mixed reactions. Some praised West for speaking his mind, while others criticized him for endorsing Trump. Many viewers expressed frustration at West's unwillingness to fully condemn Trump's actions. Despite the controversy, the interview was a major victory for Jimmy Kimmel. It generated significant buzz and helped to reignite the debate about Kanye West's political views. It also raised questions about the future of West's career and whether he will ultimately decide to run for president.

title: Lyra McKee: New footage released of suspected gunman
text: Lyra McKee: New footage released of suspected gunman The Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) has released new footage of a masked gunman suspected of murdering Lyra McKee in Derry in 2019. The 29-year-old journalist was shot dead during rioting in the Creggan area of the city on April 18, 2019. The new footage, released on Tuesday, shows a masked figure firing a handgun in the direction of police officers. Detective Superintendent Jason Murphy said the footage was "significant" and appealed for the public's help in identifying the gunman. "This footage is of a very high quality and provides a clear view of the gunman," he said. "We believe that someone out there knows who this individual is, and we are appealing for their help in identifying him. "We are determined to bring Lyra's killer to justice and this footage is a key piece of evidence in our investigation." The PSNI has also released a new image of a silver Vauxhall Astra car that was seen in the area at the time of the shooting. Police believe the car was used by the gunman to make his escape. Detective Superintendent Murphy said: "We are asking anyone who may have seen this car in the Creggan area on the evening of April 18, 2019, to contact us. "We are also appealing for anyone who may have dashcam footage from that evening to come forward." Lyra McKee was a promising young journalist who was described as "a rising star" in her field. Her death sent shockwaves through the journalism community and beyond. The investigation into her murder has been ongoing for more than three years, and the PSNI has pledged to continue to pursue all lines of inquiry. Detective Superintendent Murphy said: "We will not rest until we have brought Lyra's killer to justice. "We are determined to get justice for Lyra and her family, and we will not give up until we have achieved that." Anyone with information about the murder of Lyra McKee is asked to contact the PSNI on 101, or Crimestoppers anonymously on 0800 555 111.

title: Channel 4 breached Ofcom code with pre watershed X-Men
text: Channel 4 has been found to have breached the Ofcom code with its pre-watershed broadcast of the film X-Men. The media regulator ruled that the film, which contains scenes of violence and nudity, was unsuitable for children and should not have been shown before the 9pm watershed. Ofcom received 13 complaints about the broadcast, which aired on Channel 4 on February 20th. The regulator said it found that the film "contained frequent scenes of violence which were likely to be harmful to young children". It also said that the film's depiction of female nudity was "gratuitous and unnecessary". Channel 4 said it "regrets" the breach of the Ofcom code and has apologized to viewers. The broadcaster said that it "took into account the film's age rating and the fact that it had been edited for television" when making the decision to broadcast it before the watershed. However, Ofcom said that Channel 4 "failed to take sufficient account of the potential impact of the film on younger viewers". The regulator said that the film's violence was "particularly harmful" because it was "frequent and graphic". It also said that the film's depiction of female nudity was "gratuitous and unnecessary". Ofcom said that it has "taken into account the fact that Channel 4 has a good track record of compliance with the code" and has "not imposed a financial penalty". However, the regulator said that it has "put Channel 4 on notice that it must take steps to ensure that it does not breach the code again". The breach of the Ofcom code is a serious matter and Channel 4 must take steps to ensure that it does not happen again. The broadcaster must take into account the potential impact of its programming on younger viewers and ensure that it does not broadcast material that is likely to be harmful to them.

title: Concert marks 40 years since the Rolling Stones 'nearly' rocked Pembroke
text: In the quaint coastal town of Pembroke, the echoes of a legendary concert that almost took place 40 years ago reverberated through the streets, igniting a nostalgic flame among music enthusiasts. The year was 1982, and the world-renowned Rolling Stones were at the height of their fame. Rumors had swirled that the band was considering adding Pembroke to their European tour itinerary, sending the town into a frenzy of excitement. Local organizers worked tirelessly to secure the venue, the Pembroke Town Hall, and eagerly awaited confirmation from the Stones' management. However, fate had other plans. Just days before the scheduled concert, the tour was abruptly canceled due to unforeseen circumstances. The disappointment was palpable, but the memory of the near-miss concert lived on. To commemorate the 40th anniversary of this almost-event, a special tribute concert was organized at the very venue where the Stones had planned to perform. The 'Stones Nearly Rocked Pembroke' concert featured local bands and musicians paying homage to the legendary band. The evening was a celebration of the enduring legacy of the Rolling Stones and a testament to the enduring spirit of Pembroke. Among the performers was Jake Thomas, a local guitarist who had been a teenager when the Stones were rumored to be coming to town. "It's surreal to think that one of the greatest bands in the world almost played on this stage," he said. "Tonight, we're keeping their spirit alive." As the music filled the air, attendees couldn't help but imagine what it would have been like to witness the Rolling Stones in such an intimate setting. The atmosphere was electric, charged with a sense of both nostalgia and anticipation. The concert closed with a rousing rendition of "Satisfaction," the Stones' timeless anthem. The crowd erupted in thunderous applause, paying tribute to the band that nearly rocked Pembroke but forever left an imprint on the town's musical history. While the Rolling Stones may not have graced the Pembroke Town Hall stage in 1982, the 'Stones Nearly Rocked Pembroke' concert served as a fitting reminder of the power of music to inspire and connect generations. It was a testament to the enduring legacy of the Rolling Stones and the unwavering passion for live music that continues to thrive in small towns across the country.

title: University merger 'conspiracy', says Dr Peter Noyes
text: University Merger 'Conspiracy', Says Dr Peter Noyes Dr Peter Noyes, a former vice-chancellor of the University of Greenwich, has accused the government of "orchestrating a conspiracy" to merge universities. In a blog post, Dr Noyes claims that the government is "bullying" universities into merging in order to create a "handful of mega-universities". He says that this is being done despite the fact that there is no evidence that larger universities are better than smaller ones. "The government's claim that mergers will improve the quality of higher education is simply not supported by the evidence," Dr Noyes writes. He argues that smaller universities are often more innovative and responsive to the needs of students and businesses. "They are also more likely to be embedded in their local communities and to contribute to the local economy," he says. Dr Noyes's claims come as the government is consulting on plans to merge the University of Greenwich with the University of Kent. The government says that the merger will create a "world-leading university" that will be "better able to compete internationally". However, Dr Noyes argues that the merger will actually damage both universities. "The University of Greenwich has a strong track record of innovation and success," he says. "The merger will only serve to stifle this innovation and creativity." Dr Noyes is not the only person to express concerns about the government's merger plans. The National Union of Students (NUS) has also criticized the plans, saying that they will "damage the quality of higher education in the UK". The NUS says that the government's plans are "driven by ideology, not by evidence". "The government is simply trying to create a handful of mega-universities that will be easier to control," the NUS says. The government has defended its merger plans, saying that they are necessary to improve the quality of higher education in the UK. However, Dr Noyes and other critics argue that the government's plans are based on ideology, not on evidence.

title: CBI says leaving EU would have serious consequences for Britain
text: The UK's Serious Fraud Office (SFO) has warned of "significant consequences" for the country's criminal justice and anti-corruption systems if it leaves the European Union without a deal. In a letter to the Home Office, the SFO said that its cross-border operations would be "severely disrupted" in the event of a no-deal Brexit, as it would lose access to key EU tools such as the European Arrest Warrant (EAW) and the EU Directive on Mutual Legal Assistance (MLAT). The SFO also expressed concern about the potential impact of Brexit on its ability to recover stolen assets from overseas, as well as its cooperation with European partners on transnational crime investigations. The SFO's warning comes as Parliament prepares to vote on the government's proposed Brexit deal. If the deal is rejected, the UK will leave the EU without a deal on 29 March 2019. The SFO is not the only law enforcement agency to express concerns about the impact of Brexit. The National Crime Agency (NCA) has also warned of "significant risks" to the UK's national security if it leaves the EU without a deal. The NCA said that Brexit would make it more difficult to track and prosecute organized crime gangs, as well as share intelligence with European partners. The EU has also warned of the consequences of a no-deal Brexit. The European Commission has said that the UK would lose access to a number of EU law enforcement and judicial cooperation mechanisms, including the EAW and MLAT. The Commission has also said that the UK would no longer be party to a number of international agreements on law enforcement and judicial cooperation, such as the Council of Europe Convention on Human Rights. The UK government has said that it is committed to maintaining its high levels of law enforcement and judicial cooperation with the EU after Brexit. However, it is unclear how the UK will be able to maintain these levels of cooperation if it leaves the EU without a deal. The SFO's warning is a reminder of the potential consequences of a no-deal Brexit. The UK government must take urgent action to address the concerns of law enforcement agencies and ensure that the country's criminal justice and anti-corruption systems are not weakened after Brexit. A no-deal Brexit would also have a significant impact on the UK's economy. The SFO estimated that the UK economy would lose up to £100 billion over the next 10 years if it leaves the EU without a deal. The SFO also warned that Brexit would make it more difficult for UK businesses to trade with the EU, as they would face new tariffs and regulations.

title: Honduras protests: Buildings burn during clashes over reforms
text: Amidst a deepening social and political crisis, Honduras has erupted in widespread protests over proposed constitutional reforms. The demonstrations, marked by violence and destruction, have cast a shadow over the country's fragile democracy. Thousands of protesters took to the streets of Tegucigalpa, the capital, and other cities on Sunday, expressing their anger against the government's plan to establish new electoral courts. They fear that the reforms, if implemented, would undermine the integrity of future elections and consolidate the power of the ruling National Party. As the protests intensified, clashes erupted between demonstrators and security forces. Protesters hurled rocks and Molotov cocktails, setting fire to government buildings, including the headquarters of the National Electoral Institute (TSE). Police responded with tear gas, water cannons, and live ammunition, leaving several people injured. Amidst the chaos, President Juan Orlando Hernández declared a state of emergency, suspending constitutional guarantees for 10 days. This move has been widely criticized as an attempt to stifle dissent and suppress the legitimate grievances of the Honduran people. The protests have exposed deep-rooted divisions within Honduran society. Many citizens are disillusioned with the government, accusing it of corruption, authoritarianism, and economic mismanagement. They demand free and fair elections, the rule of law, and the end of what they see as a corrupt and repressive regime. However, the government maintains that the constitutional reforms are necessary to improve the electoral system and strengthen democracy. It accuses the opposition of inciting violence and seeking to destabilize the country. The international community has expressed concern over the situation in Honduras. The United States, a close ally, has urged the government to respect the right to peaceful protest and to engage in dialogue with the opposition. The Organization of American States (OAS) has also called for calm and restraint. The protests have highlighted the challenges facing Honduras. The country has been plagued by poverty, inequality, and violence for decades. The current crisis has deepened these problems, leaving the future of the nation in doubt. It remains unclear how the situation will unfold. The government has vowed to restore order, while protesters remain determined to fight for their demands. The outcome of this confrontation will have a profound impact on the future of Honduran democracy.

title: Duterte pulls police off controversial drugs crackdown
text: Duterte pulls police off controversial drugs crackdown Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has ordered police to stand down from his controversial anti-drugs campaign, which has been criticized for widespread human rights abuses. The move comes after a report by the Philippine National Police (PNP) revealed that more than 6,600 people had been killed in police anti-drug operations since Duterte took office in 2016. The report also found that many of the killings were extrajudicial, meaning they were carried out without due process of law. Duterte has defended the crackdown, saying it is necessary to rid the country of the drug menace. However, the United Nations and other human rights groups have condemned the killings, saying they amount to a "war on the poor." In a televised address on Thursday, Duterte said he was withdrawing the police from the anti-drugs campaign because he did not want them to be "scapegoats" for the killings. He said the campaign would now be led by the Philippine Drug Enforcement Agency (PDEA). "I am giving them the last chance to prove themselves," Duterte said of the police. "If they continue to abuse their authority, I will not hesitate to fire all of them." The PNP welcomed Duterte's decision, saying it would allow them to focus on their other duties. The PDEA, however, has said it is not ready to take over the anti-drugs campaign. It is unclear what impact Duterte's decision will have on the drug problem in the Philippines. Some experts believe that the crackdown has actually made the problem worse, by driving drug users deeper into the shadows. Others believe that the crackdown has been effective in reducing crime and drug use. Only time will tell whether Duterte's decision to withdraw the police from the anti-drugs campaign will have a positive or negative impact on the Philippines.

title: The Men Who Own Scotland: Land reform on 'radical journey'
text: In the heart of the Scottish Highlands, amidst rolling hills and shimmering lochs, lies a vast and contested landscape. It is a land owned by a privileged few, a legacy of centuries-old feudalism that has left deep scars on the social fabric of Scotland. But now, a wave of land reform is sweeping across the country, promising to redistribute power and give communities a greater say in how their land is used. At the forefront of this movement are organizations like Community Land Scotland (CLS), which supports community buyouts of land from private landowners. Since its inception in 2003, CLS has helped over 200 communities across Scotland acquire ownership of their land, totaling over 600,000 acres. One of the most successful community buyouts was the Knoydart Peninsula, a remote and rugged area in the northwest Highlands. In 1999, the community raised over £2 million to purchase the peninsula from a private estate. Since then, they have transformed the area, creating a thriving community-owned enterprise that includes sustainable forestry, tourism, and crofting. The land reform movement is not without its challenges. Landowners have resisted community buyouts, arguing that they will lead to a loss of investment and economic decline. However, supporters of land reform argue that community ownership can actually boost local economies by empowering communities to create jobs and develop sustainable businesses. The Scottish government has been supportive of land reform, passing legislation in 2015 that gives communities a "right to buy" abandoned or neglected land. This has led to a surge in community buyouts, as communities seize the opportunity to take control of their land. One of the most recent examples of this is the buyout of the Isle of Gigha, a small island off the west coast of Scotland. In 2022, the community raised £4.5 million to purchase the island from its private owner. They plan to use the land to develop sustainable agriculture, tourism, and renewable energy projects. The land reform movement in Scotland is still in its early stages, but it has already made a significant impact. It is a radical journey that is challenging centuries-old power structures and giving communities a greater say in their future. As the movement continues to grow, it has the potential to transform the landscape of Scotland, both physically and politically.

title: Motorway lessons proposed for learner drivers
text: Motorway Lessons Proposed for Learner Drivers In a bid to improve road safety and reduce the number of accidents involving novice drivers, the government has proposed introducing mandatory motorway lessons for learner drivers. The lessons would be an addition to the current driving test and would focus on teaching drivers how to safely navigate motorways. According to the Department for Transport, around 20% of all road deaths involve drivers who have held a driving license for less than two years. Motorways are particularly hazardous for inexperienced drivers, as they are often unfamiliar with the high speeds and complex traffic patterns. The proposed motorway lessons would be delivered by qualified driving instructors and would cover a range of topics, including: Motorway lane discipline Safe overtaking and merging Emergency procedures Using motorway signs and signals Safe speed management The lessons would be designed to give learner drivers the confidence and skills they need to drive safely on motorways. They would also help to reduce the number of accidents caused by inexperienced drivers. The government's proposal has been welcomed by road safety campaigners. The RAC Foundation said that the lessons would be a "positive step" towards improving road safety. However, some driving instructors have expressed concerns about the cost of the lessons and the potential impact on learner drivers' confidence. The cost of the motorway lessons has not yet been determined, but it is likely to be in the region of £50-£100. The lessons would be optional, but learner drivers would be strongly encouraged to take them. The government is considering a number of options for delivering the motorway lessons. One option is to make them a compulsory part of the driving test. Another option is to offer the lessons as an additional service by driving instructors. The government is also considering whether to extend the motorway lessons to all new drivers, regardless of their age or experience. This would help to ensure that all drivers have the skills and knowledge they need to drive safely on motorways. The government's consultation on the proposed motorway lessons is now open. The consultation will close on 28th February 2023. The government will then consider the feedback received and make a decision on whether to implement the lessons.

title: Dalian Atkinson: Ex-footballer 'staggered' towards accused PC
text: Dalian Atkinson's widow has told a court she saw her husband "staggering" towards a police officer moments before he was Tasered and kicked in the head. Elaine Atkinson said the former Aston Villa and Sheffield Wednesday striker was "incoherent" and "not making sense" at the time. PC Benjamin Monk, 43, denies murder and manslaughter. The jury at Birmingham Crown Court was shown body-worn camera footage of the incident in Telford, Shropshire, in August 2016. Monk and another officer, PC Mary Ellen Bettley-Smith, were called after Atkinson was reported to have been banging on the door of his father's home. The court heard that Atkinson had mental health problems and had been drinking heavily. His widow said she arrived at the house shortly after the police and saw her husband staggering towards PC Monk. "He seemed very unsteady on his feet," she said. "He was stumbling and incoherent. I didn't know what to think. I was worried about his safety." She said she thought her husband was asking for help and called out to him to go back to the house. "He didn't respond," she said. "He was too far away by then." The court was shown footage from PC Monk's body-worn camera which showed Atkinson stumbling towards him. PC Monk drew his Taser and ordered Atkinson to stop, but he continued to approach. Monk then fired the Taser and Atkinson fell to the ground. As Atkinson lay on the ground, Monk kicked him three times in the head. Atkinson died in hospital the following day. Monk has admitted kicking Atkinson, but said he did so in self-defence because he believed Atkinson was trying to grab his Taser. The trial continues.

title: New marine zone plans scrapped by minister
text: New marine zone plans scrapped by minister Environment Minister Rebecca Pow has scrapped plans to create a network of marine conservation zones in English waters, a move that has been met with anger from environmental groups. The plans, which were first proposed in 2018, would have seen 127 areas of the sea designated as marine conservation zones (MCZs). These areas would have been protected from damaging activities such as fishing, dredging and seabed mining. However, Pow has now announced that the government will not be proceeding with the plans. She said that the decision was made after a "careful review" of the evidence, and that the government believes that the existing network of marine protected areas is sufficient to protect the marine environment. Environmental groups have condemned the decision, arguing that it will damage marine life and habitats. They say that the proposed MCZs would have protected important areas for wildlife, such as coral reefs and seagrass beds. "This is a devastating blow for our seas," said Richard Benyon, chairman of the Marine Conservation Society. "The government has failed to stand up for our marine environment and has put our seas at risk." The Wildlife Trusts also criticized the decision, saying that it was a "betrayal" of the government's promise to protect the environment. "The government has ignored the overwhelming scientific evidence that shows that marine conservation zones are essential for protecting our seas," said Rob Cunningham, chief executive of the Wildlife Trusts. The decision to scrap the marine zone plans comes at a time when the government is facing growing pressure to protect the environment. The government has pledged to reach net zero emissions by 2050, and has set out a number of policies to reduce pollution and protect wildlife. However, environmental groups say that the government's actions do not match its rhetoric. They say that the decision to scrap the marine zone plans shows that the government is not serious about protecting the environment. The government has defended its decision, saying that it is committed to protecting the marine environment. However, environmental groups say that the government needs to do more to show that it is serious about this commitment.

title: Devon and Cornwall police officers tasked with call centre work
text: Devon and Cornwall Police officers are now taking on call centre work amid concerns that staff shortages are affecting the force's ability to respond to 999 calls. The move comes after a report found that the force had the longest average waiting time for 999 calls in England and Wales. According to the report, the average time it took for Devon and Cornwall Police to answer a 999 call was 14 minutes and 24 seconds. This was the longest waiting time of any force in England and Wales, and more than double the national average of six minutes and 35 seconds. The report also found that the force had the second-lowest number of call handlers per 100,000 people. In response to the report, Devon and Cornwall Police has said that it is taking a number of steps to improve its call handling performance. These steps include: - Recruiting more call handlers - Investing in new technology - Introducing a new call handling system - Working with other agencies to reduce demand on the 999 service The force has also said that it is working to reduce the number of calls that are abandoned before they are answered. In the meantime, officers from across the force are being asked to work in the call centre to help answer 999 calls. A spokesman for the force said: "We are aware of the concerns that have been raised about our call handling performance. "We are taking these concerns very seriously and are taking a number of steps to improve our performance. "We would like to thank the public for their patience and understanding during this time." The move to have officers take on call centre work has been met with mixed reactions. Some people have welcomed the move, saying that it will help to improve the force's response times to 999 calls. Others have questioned whether it is the best use of police officers' time, arguing that they should be out on the streets fighting crime. The Police Federation, which represents rank-and-file officers, has said that it is concerned about the move. A spokesman for the federation said: "We are concerned that the use of police officers to answer 999 calls will lead to a reduction in the number of officers available to respond to incidents on the streets. "We believe that this could have a negative impact on public safety."

title: Pawnbroker warns probe could spark loan shark rush
text: Pawnbrokers have warned that a government probe into the industry could lead to a rise in illegal lending by loan sharks. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has launched an investigation into the sector, amid concerns over high interest rates and hidden charges. But pawnbrokers say the probe could deter legitimate businesses from operating, leaving a vacuum that could be filled by unregulated lenders. "If the CMA makes it too difficult for pawnbrokers to operate, then loan sharks will step in to fill the void," said Michael Anscombe, chief executive of the National Pawnbrokers Association. "Loan sharks charge extortionate rates of interest and use intimidation and violence to collect debts. This is a real danger to vulnerable people." The CMA is investigating whether pawnbrokers are breaking competition law by charging excessive interest rates and failing to provide customers with clear information about the terms of their loans. The investigation was launched after the CMA received a number of complaints from consumers about the industry. Some consumers have complained that they have been charged interest rates of up to 1,500% APR on pawn loans. Others have said that they have been misled about the terms of their loans, and have ended up losing their valuables. The CMA has said that it is too early to say what the outcome of the investigation will be. But it has warned that it could take action against pawnbrokers who are found to be breaking the law. "We are concerned about the potential impact of the CMA investigation on the pawnbroking industry," said Anscombe. "We believe that pawnbrokers provide a valuable service to many people, particularly those who are on low incomes or who have poor credit histories. We urge the CMA to take into account the impact of its investigation on the whole industry, and not just on a few bad apples." The pawnbroking industry is regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA). The FCA has a number of rules in place to protect consumers, including a cap on interest rates and a requirement for pawnbrokers to provide customers with clear information about the terms of their loans. However, the FCA has been criticized for not doing enough to protect consumers from loan sharks. In 2016, the FCA was fined £10.5 million for failing to properly supervise the payday lending industry. The CMA investigation is likely to take several months to complete. It is unclear what the outcome of the investigation will be, but it is possible that the CMA could take action against pawnbrokers who are found to be breaking the law.

title: Vauxhall: Crunch talks to save Ellesmere Port plant continue
text: Vauxhall: Crunch talks to save Ellesmere Port plant continue Discussions are continuing between Vauxhall's parent company Stellantis and the UK government in a bid to save the carmaker's Ellesmere Port plant. The future of the factory, which employs around 1,000 people, has been in doubt since Vauxhall announced in July that it would be closing the site in 2022. The government has since offered a £30m grant to help secure the plant's future, but Stellantis has said that it needs more financial support in order to make the investment necessary to convert the factory to electric vehicle production. Talks between the two sides have been ongoing for several weeks, but no agreement has yet been reached. A source close to the negotiations told the BBC that the talks were "very difficult" and that there was no guarantee that a deal would be reached. "Stellantis is asking for a lot of money, and the government is reluctant to give it to them," the source said. "There is a real risk that the plant will close if a deal cannot be reached." The Ellesmere Port plant is one of the UK's largest car factories, and its closure would be a major blow to the local economy. The plant has been producing cars since the 1960s, and it has played a key role in the development of the UK's automotive industry. The closure of the plant would also be a major blow to the UK's efforts to become a leader in the production of electric vehicles. The government has pledged to ban the sale of new petrol and diesel cars by 2030, and it is hoping to encourage the development of a thriving electric vehicle industry in the UK. The Ellesmere Port plant is well-suited to the production of electric vehicles, and its closure would be a major setback to the government's plans. The talks between Stellantis and the government are expected to continue in the coming days. It is hoped that a deal can be reached that will save the Ellesmere Port plant and secure its future as a major center for the production of electric vehicles.

title: Chinese investment in the US falls sharply in 2017
text: Chinese investment in the US plummeted by 35% in 2017 to $29 billion, according to new figures released by the Rhodium Group and the National Committee on US-China Relations. This is the first annual decline in Chinese investment in the US since 2009, and the lowest level since 2009. The fall in Chinese investment was driven by a number of factors, including the Trump administration's tough stance on trade and investment, as well as the Chinese government's efforts to reduce capital outflows. The Trump administration has taken a number of steps to restrict Chinese investment in the US, including increasing scrutiny of foreign investment deals and tightening export controls. The Chinese government has also taken steps to reduce capital outflows, including imposing new restrictions on foreign exchange transactions. The decline in Chinese investment in the US is likely to have a significant impact on the US economy. Chinese investment has been a major source of job creation and economic growth in the US in recent years. The fall in Chinese investment is likely to lead to job losses and slower economic growth in the US. The decline in Chinese investment in the US is also likely to have a significant impact on US-China relations. The Trump administration has accused China of unfair trade practices, and the decline in Chinese investment is likely to further strain relations between the two countries. The fall in Chinese investment in the US is a major development with significant implications for the US economy and US-China relations. It is important to understand the causes of this decline and to assess its potential impact. In addition to the factors mentioned above, there are a number of other factors that may have contributed to the decline in Chinese investment in the US. These include the rising cost of labor in China, the increasing availability of investment opportunities in other countries, and the uncertainty surrounding the future of US-China relations. title: Venezuela elections neither 'free nor fair', says US
text: Venezuela Elections Declared 'Neither Free Nor Fair' by US The United States has denounced the recent Venezuelan presidential elections as "neither free nor fair," citing widespread irregularities and the imprisonment of political opponents. In a statement, Secretary of State Antony Blinken said the elections "were not conducted in a free and fair manner." He pointed to the jailing of opposition candidates, the lack of independent election observers, and the reports of voter fraud. "The United States does not recognize the results of these elections," Blinken said. "We stand with the Venezuelan people and their desire for democracy, freedom, and the rule of law." The elections, held on November 21, saw incumbent President Nicolás Maduro claiming victory with over 82% of the vote. However, the opposition and international observers have widely criticized the results, alleging that they were rigged in favor of Maduro. The US statement echoed the concerns of the Organization of American States (OAS), which issued a report last week saying that the elections "did not meet minimum standards for a democratic process." The OAS also called for new elections to be held. The Venezuelan government has rejected the criticisms, accusing the US and the OAS of interfering in its internal affairs. Maduro has vowed to remain in office and has called for the opposition to recognize his victory. The international condemnation of the elections has put further pressure on Maduro, who is already facing economic sanctions and a campaign of diplomatic isolation. The US and other countries have imposed sanctions on Venezuela's oil industry, which is the country's main source of revenue. The Venezuelan election crisis comes amid a broader political and economic crisis in the country. The country has been plagued by hyperinflation, food shortages, and a lack of basic necessities. The crisis has led to a mass exodus of Venezuelans, many of whom have fled to neighboring countries. The US statement said the Venezuelan people "deserve the right to freely choose their own leaders and their own future." It called on the Venezuelan government to release political prisoners, respect the rule of law, and allow for new elections. "The United States will continue to work with the international community to support the Venezuelan people and their aspiration for a better future," the statement concluded.

title: Edwin Poots: Arlene Foster's exit is 'rough and tumble' of politics
text: Edwin Poots: Arlene Foster's exit is 'rough and tumble' of politics Edwin Poots has said the ousting of Arlene Foster as DUP leader is part of the "rough and tumble" of politics. title: Abandoned BBC Gardeners' World plot an 'urban veg hub'
text: In the verdant heart of Bristol, an abandoned plot from BBC's iconic 'Gardeners' World' has found a vibrant new purpose as an urban veg hub, offering a lifeline to the community and promoting sustainable living. Residents can participate in workshops, learn about gardening techniques, and connect with like-minded individuals. The project has also been instrumental in addressing food insecurity in the area. By providing affordable produce, the hub helps reduce the financial burden on families and ensures that everyone has access to healthy and nutritious food. Moreover, the hub promotes sustainable practices, reducing food miles and fostering environmental awareness. The plot uses compost from local sources, collects rainwater for irrigation, and employs natural pest control methods. By demonstrating these principles, the hub encourages residents to adopt sustainable habits in their own gardens. The urban veg hub has become an integral part of the community, transforming a forgotten space into a hub of life and sustainability. It serves as a testament to the enduring legacy of 'Gardeners' World' and the power of community to create positive change. As the sun sets over Bristol, casting a warm glow upon the verdant plot, the urban veg hub stands as a beacon of hope, nourishment, and community spirit. Its success is a reminder that even in abandoned spaces, the seeds of resilience and renewal can take root and flourish.
