title: Snowdon motorists 'towed' if they park illegally at Pen-y-Pass
text: Snowdon motorists face being 'towed' if they park illegally at Pen-y-Pass Motorists who park illegally at the popular Snowdon beauty spot Pen-y-Pass could be towed away this summer, the authorities have warned. Vehicles parked on double yellow lines, in lay-bys, or on grass verges will be targeted by the scheme. Motorists who have their vehicles towed away will have to pay a release fee of £150, plus any additional storage charges. A spokesperson for the National Park Authority said: "Illegal parking at Pen-y-Pass is a major problem which we are determined to tackle. title: Why charities are counting the costs of council cuts

title: Fifa indictment: What's in it

FIFA has said it will cooperate with the US investigation and has appointed an independent ethics committee to look into the allegations. The scandal has cast a shadow over FIFA and has led to calls for reform of the organisation. Background FIFA is the international governing body of association football. It was founded in 1904 and is based in Zurich, Switzerland. FIFA is responsible for organising the World Cup, the Confederations Cup, and other international football tournaments. title: UK diesel car sales fall by nearly a third in October
text: UK diesel car sales fall by nearly a third in October Sales of new diesel cars in the UK have fallen by nearly a third in October, according to figures from the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT). Just 9.1% of new cars sold in October were diesel, down from 13.4% in the same month last year. This is the lowest market share for diesel cars since records began in 1997. The decline in diesel sales has been driven by a number of factors, including concerns about air pollution and the rising cost of fuel. In recent years, a number of cities have introduced or expanded clean air zones, which charge drivers of older, more polluting vehicles. The government has also announced plans to ban the sale of new petrol and diesel cars by 2030. This has led many consumers to delay buying a new diesel car, in anticipation of the ban. The decline in diesel sales has been welcomed by environmental campaigners. They argue that diesel cars are a major source of air pollution, which can contribute to respiratory problems and other health issues. However, the decline in diesel sales has also raised concerns about the future of the UK automotive industry. Diesel cars have traditionally been popular with British drivers, and their decline could lead to job losses in the manufacturing sector. The SMMT has called on the government to provide more support for the automotive industry, including investment in research and development of new technologies. "The UK automotive industry is facing a perfect storm of challenges, including the decline in diesel sales, the global chip shortage, and the rising cost of raw materials," said SMMT chief executive Mike Hawes. "The government must provide more support for the industry if we are to maintain our position as a global leader in automotive manufacturing." The decline in diesel sales is likely to continue in the coming months. In November, the government is due to introduce a new Vehicle Excise Duty (VED) system, which will increase the tax on diesel cars. This is likely to further deter consumers from buying diesel vehicles.

title: Budget 2017: Tax on takeaway boxes to be considered
text: Chancellor Philip Hammond is considering introducing a tax on takeaway food and drink containers as part of plans to tackle plastic waste. The levy could be applied to single-use items such as plastic cups, straws, and food boxes, and would be similar to the 5p charge on plastic bags introduced in 2015. The Treasury is understood to be looking at a range of options, including a flat rate levy on all takeaway containers or a higher charge on items made from non-recyclable materials. The move is part of a wider government drive to reduce plastic pollution, which has been linked to a range of environmental problems, including damage to marine life and the release of harmful chemicals into the food chain. A Treasury spokesperson said: "We are committed to taking action to reduce plastic waste and we are considering a range of options, including a levy on takeaway food and drink containers." The proposal has been welcomed by environmental groups, who say it could help to reduce the amount of plastic waste generated by the hospitality industry. Hugo Tagholm, chief executive of the Surfers Against Sewage campaign group, said: "A tax on takeaway containers is a positive step towards reducing the amount of plastic pollution in our oceans and on our beaches." "We hope that the government will introduce a levy that is both ambitious and effective in reducing the use of single-use plastics," he added. The hospitality industry has expressed concern about the potential impact of a tax on takeaway containers, warning that it could lead to increased costs for businesses and consumers. title: Ofwat blamed for high water bills by committee of MPs
text: A committee of MPs has accused the water regulator Ofwat of failing to prevent high water bills for customers. The report concludes by saying that Ofwat needs to "take a more proactive approach to regulation" and that it needs to "do more to protect consumers from unfair charges". Ofwat has said that it accepts the findings of the report and that it will "take action to address the concerns raised". However, the committee has said that it will continue to monitor Ofwat's progress and that it will "hold the regulator to account" if it does not make the necessary improvements. title: Shark nations failing on conservation pledges
text: Shark nations failing on conservation pledges Conservation commitments made by governments to safeguard shark populations are falling short, according to a new report by the wildlife trade monitoring network Traffic. The report, published on Tuesday, assesses the progress made by 23 countries that have signed up to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES). It found that while some nations have made significant strides in implementing their pledges, many are lagging behind. The report found that only five of the 23 countries have fully implemented their CITES commitments. These countries are Australia, Canada, India, Mexico, and the United States. The report found that some countries are failing to implement their CITES commitments due to a lack of resources or political will. The report also found that illegal fishing is a major threat to sharks. The report found that illegal fishing is responsible for the deaths of an estimated 100 million sharks each year. The report calls on governments to do more to combat illegal fishing and to implement their CITES commitments. The report comes as the world's shark populations face a number of threats, including overfishing, habitat loss, and climate change. According to the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), one-quarter of all shark species are now threatened with extinction. The report from Traffic highlights the need for urgent action to protect sharks. Governments must do more to implement their CITES commitments and to combat illegal fishing. The report also calls on consumers to make sustainable seafood choices. Consumers can help to protect sharks by choosing to buy seafood from fisheries that use sustainable practices. Sharks play a vital role in marine ecosystems. They help to keep populations of other fish in check and they play a role in nutrient cycling. The loss of sharks would have a devastating impact on marine ecosystems and on the livelihoods of people who depend on the ocean.

title: Sudan death penalty reignites Islam apostasy debate
text: Sudan's Death Penalty Reignites Islam Apostasy Debate The execution of a Sudanese woman convicted of apostasy has sparked a fierce debate about the role of religion in the country's legal system. Noura Hussein was found guilty of renouncing Islam in May 2022 and sentenced to death by hanging. Her execution on Wednesday has drawn widespread condemnation from human rights groups and cast a spotlight on Sudan's controversial apostasy laws. Apostasy, the act of renouncing one's religion, is a serious crime in many Muslim-majority countries, including Sudan. While the Quran does not explicitly prescribe a punishment for apostasy, some Islamic scholars argue that it is punishable by death. In Sudan, apostasy is a capital offense under Article 126 of the penal code. Noura Hussein's case has brought the issue of apostasy to the forefront of public discourse in Sudan. Her supporters argue that her conviction and execution were unjust and violate her fundamental rights to freedom of religion and belief. They point out that she was reportedly forced to marry at a young age and that she had never renounced Islam. Opponents of apostasy laws, both within Sudan and internationally, argue that they are archaic and discriminatory. They argue that people should be free to choose their own religion without fear of persecution. They also point out that apostasy laws are often used to target religious minorities or dissenters. The debate over apostasy in Sudan is a complex one, with strong arguments on both sides. Supporters of apostasy laws argue that they are necessary to protect the integrity of Islam and prevent religious strife. Opponents argue that they are a violation of human rights and that they serve only to suppress dissent. The execution of Noura Hussein has reignited the debate over apostasy and is likely to continue to be a source of controversy in Sudan and beyond. The case has raised important questions about the role of religion in the legal system, the rights of religious minorities, and the limits of freedom of expression. It is important to note that different interpretations exist within Islamic jurisprudence regarding the punishment for apostasy, ranging from death to imprisonment or no punishment at all. The specific interpretation adopted in a particular country is often influenced by cultural, historical, and political factors. The debate over apostasy in Sudan is a reminder of the complex and often conflicting relationship between religion and the law. It is a debate that is likely to continue for many years to come.

title: Restricted embryo growth 'predicts miscarriage risk'
text: Restricted embryo growth 'predicts miscarriage risk' Embryos that fail to grow properly in the early stages of pregnancy are at increased risk of miscarriage, research suggests. Scientists found that the size of the embryo at six weeks was linked to the likelihood of it surviving to birth. Embryos that were in the smallest 25% for their gestational age were 10 times more likely to miscarry than those in the largest 25%, the study found. The findings, published in the journal JAMA Internal Medicine, could help doctors identify women at high risk of miscarriage and provide them with closer monitoring. Around 15-20% of pregnancies end in miscarriage, with most occurring in the first trimester. The exact cause of miscarriage is often unknown, although it is thought to be due to a combination of factors, including genetic abnormalities, hormonal imbalances and infections. The new study involved over 10,000 women who had early pregnancy scans at six weeks. The researchers measured the size of the embryo and followed the women until they gave birth or miscarried. They found that the risk of miscarriage was significantly higher in women whose embryos were in the smallest 25% for their gestational age. For example, the miscarriage rate was 5.4% in women whose embryos were in the smallest 25%, compared to 0.5% in women whose embryos were in the largest 25%. The researchers also found that the link between embryo size and miscarriage risk was independent of other factors known to increase the risk of miscarriage, such as maternal age, smoking and obesity. This suggests that embryo size is an important independent predictor of miscarriage risk. The researchers say their findings could help doctors identify women at high risk of miscarriage and provide them with closer monitoring. They believe that this could lead to a reduction in the number of miscarriages. Dr Alexander Heazell, from the University of Manchester, who led the study, said: "Our findings suggest that embryo size at six weeks is a strong predictor of miscarriage risk. "This could help us to identify women at high risk of miscarriage and provide them with closer monitoring. "This could lead to a reduction in the number of miscarriages." Dr Pat O'Brien, a consultant gynecologist at Tommy's, a charity that funds research into miscarriage, premature birth and stillbirth, said: "This is a very important study that adds to our understanding of the causes of miscarriage. "The findings suggest that embryo size at six weeks is an important independent predictor of miscarriage risk. "This could help us to identify women at high risk of miscarriage and provide them with closer monitoring. "This could lead to a reduction in the number of miscarriages."

title: Elections 2021: Tory Giles Orpen-Smellie wins Norfolk PCC election
text: Tory Giles Orpen-Smellie wins Norfolk PCC election Conservative candidate Giles Orpen-Smellie has been elected as Norfolk's Police and Crime Commissioner (PCC) in a closely fought contest. Orpen-Smellie, a former RAF pilot and businessman, secured 83,365 votes, or 35.8% of the total, in Thursday's election. He defeated Labour's James Wright, who received 73,550 votes (31.5%), and Liberal Democrat Liz Boor, who came third with 54,425 votes (23.3%). Turnout was 31.2%, down from 35.2% in the previous PCC election in 2016. Orpen-Smellie said he was "honoured and humbled" to be elected. "I want to thank the people of Norfolk for putting their trust in me," he said. "I will work tirelessly to deliver on my promises to make Norfolk safer and to protect the most vulnerable in our communities." Orpen-Smellie's victory marks the first time that the Conservatives have held the PCC role in Norfolk. The previous PCC, Lorne Green, a former Labour MP, did not seek re-election. Orpen-Smellie is a former RAF pilot who served in the Gulf War. He is also a businessman and has worked in the private sector for over 20 years. He has pledged to increase the number of police officers in Norfolk, to focus on tackling drug-related crime, and to improve support for victims of domestic abuse. Labour's James Wright said he was "disappointed" to have lost the election but congratulated Orpen-Smellie on his victory. The discovery of pork DNA in halal meat products has raised concerns about the safety of halal meat products. Halal meat is meat that has been prepared in accordance with Islamic law. title: Young 'to be poorer than parents at every stage of life'
text: Young people in the UK are on course to be poorer than their parents at every stage of life, according to a major new study. The research, published by the Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS), found that young people born in the 1980s and 1990s are likely to have lower incomes, own fewer assets, and save less for retirement than their parents did at the same age. The study found that the average income of young people in the UK has fallen by 10% since the 1980s, while the average wealth of young people has fallen by 25%. The IFS said that the decline in young people's incomes and wealth is due to a number of factors, including: Rising inequality: The gap between the rich and the poor has widened in recent decades, and young people are more likely to be at the bottom of the income distribution. Stagnant wages: Wages have not kept pace with inflation in recent years, which has made it harder for young people to afford housing and other essential expenses. Rising housing costs: The cost of housing has risen sharply in recent years, making it harder for young people to save for a deposit. A lack of affordable childcare: The cost of childcare is a major barrier to young people who want to work. The IFS said that the decline in young people's incomes and wealth is a major concern, as it will have a negative impact on their future financial security. The study found that young people who are born into poverty are more likely to remain in poverty as adults. The IFS said that this is because poverty can have a negative impact on children's education, health, and development. The IFS said that the government needs to take action to address the decline in young people's incomes and wealth. The study recommended that the government should: Increase the minimum wage Build more affordable housing Reduce the cost of childcare Invest in early childhood education The IFS said that these measures would help to improve the financial security of young people and give them a better chance of success in life.

title: Pro-Putin social media campaign hijacked by critics
text: Pro-Putin Social Media Campaign Backfires A Russian social media campaign aimed at boosting support for President Vladimir Putin inadvertently backfired, as critics hijacked the hashtag and flooded it with anti-war and anti-Putin messages. The campaign, launched on the popular social media platform Telegram, involved the use of the hashtag #WeAreTogether and featured positive messages about Putin's leadership. However, critics quickly seized the opportunity to turn the hashtag against the Kremlin. Using the #WeAreTogether hashtag, they posted videos of Russian soldiers being killed or captured in Ukraine, as well as images of the devastation caused by the war. They also shared messages criticizing Putin's policies and calling for an end to the conflict. The campaign quickly went viral, with the hashtag #WeAreTogether becoming one of the top trending topics on Telegram. The Kremlin was forced to react, with officials accusing critics of "spreading fake news" and "undermining the morale" of Russian troops. However, the damage had already been done. title: Step down now, David Cameron urges President Assad
text: British Prime Minister David Cameron has called on Syrian President Bashar al-Assad to step down "immediately" for the sake of his country. Speaking in the House of Commons, Mr. Cameron said that President Assad had lost all legitimacy and that his continued presence in power was making it impossible to find a peaceful solution to the Syrian crisis. "He has lost the support of his own people and the respect of the international community," Mr. Cameron said. "He can no longer be a part of Syria's future." Mr. Cameron's comments came after a suspected chemical weapons attack in the Damascus suburb of Ghouta, which killed hundreds of people. The Syrian government has denied responsibility for the attack, but the United States and other Western powers have blamed the regime. Mr. Cameron said that the chemical weapons attack was "a crime against humanity" and that President Assad must be held accountable. He said that the United Kingdom was working with its allies to build an international consensus on a response to the attack. "We will not stand idly by while innocent people are being killed," Mr. Cameron said. "We must act to stop this barbaric regime." President Assad has been in power since 2000, following the death of his father, Hafez al-Assad. He has faced widespread opposition to his rule, particularly since the start of the Syrian uprising in 2011. The Syrian civil war has killed more than 100,000 people and displaced millions more. The conflict has also created a humanitarian crisis, with millions of people in need of food, water, and shelter. title: 'Lack of evidence' holding back cannabis medicines
text: Lack of evidence' holding back cannabis medicines Despite growing interest in the potential therapeutic benefits of cannabis, a lack of high-quality clinical evidence is hindering the development and approval of cannabis-based medicines. "There is a lot of anecdotal evidence and some small studies suggesting that cannabis may be helpful for a variety of conditions, such as chronic pain, multiple sclerosis, and epilepsy," said Dr. David Nutt, a neuropsychopharmacologist at Imperial College London. "But we need more rigorous research to confirm these findings and to determine the optimal doses and formulations for different conditions." One of the biggest challenges in conducting clinical trials on cannabis is the difficulty in obtaining a standardized product. Cannabis is a complex plant that contains hundreds of different compounds, and the relative proportions of these compounds can vary depending on the strain, growing conditions, and extraction method. This makes it difficult to compare results from different studies and to determine the specific compounds responsible for any therapeutic effects. Another challenge is the stigma surrounding cannabis use. In many countries, cannabis is still classified as an illegal drug, which makes it difficult for researchers to obtain funding and approval for clinical trials. This stigma also discourages some patients from participating in research studies. Despite these challenges, there is growing interest in the potential therapeutic benefits of cannabis. In recent years, several countries have legalized medical cannabis, and the number of clinical trials is increasing. "We are starting to see more high-quality research on cannabis," said Dr. Nutt. "This research is helping us to better understand the potential benefits and risks of cannabis use, and it is paving the way for the development of new cannabis-based medicines." One area where cannabis has shown promise is in the treatment of chronic pain. A number of studies have found that cannabis can be effective in reducing pain intensity and improving function in patients with conditions such as fibromyalgia, multiple sclerosis, and cancer pain. Cannabis has also shown promise in the treatment of epilepsy. A number of studies have found that cannabis can reduce the frequency and severity of seizures in children and adults with epilepsy. In addition to its potential therapeutic benefits, cannabis also has a number of potential side effects. These side effects can include dry mouth, dizziness, impaired coordination, and anxiety. In some cases, cannabis use can also lead to more serious side effects, such as psychosis and cardiovascular problems. It is important to note that cannabis is not a cure-all for any condition. It is also important to be aware of the potential side effects of cannabis use. If you are considering using cannabis for medical purposes, it is important to talk to your doctor first.

title: Legacy inquests: Families launch legal bid over funding
text: Families bereaved by the 7/7 London bombings are launching a legal bid to force the government to properly fund legacy inquests into the atrocity. The inquests, which are due to start in September, will examine the events leading up to the attacks, the emergency response and the long-term impact on the victims' families. However, the government has allocated just £3.5 million to cover the costs of the inquests, which are expected to last for at least two years. The families argue that this is not enough money to ensure that the inquests are properly conducted and that all the necessary evidence is heard. They are seeking a judicial review of the government's funding decision, arguing that it is irrational and unlawful. The legal challenge is being supported by the charity Inquest, which provides legal advice and support to bereaved families. Inquest's director, Deborah Coles, said: "The government's decision to allocate just £3.5 million to cover the costs of the 7/7 inquests is a disgrace. "These inquests are of vital importance to the families of the victims. They need to know what happened, why it happened and what can be done to prevent it from happening again. "The government's funding decision is an insult to the families and to the memory of their loved ones." The families' legal challenge is the latest in a series of disputes over the funding of legacy inquests. In 2019, the government agreed to pay £10 million to cover the costs of the inquests into the Hillsborough disaster. However, the government has refused to provide similar funding for the inquests into other historical events, such as the Bloody Sunday killings and the Birmingham pub bombings. The families argue that the government's failure to properly fund legacy inquests is a denial of justice. They say that the inquests are an essential part of the process of healing and reconciliation, and that they should not be denied the opportunity to find out the truth about what happened to their loved ones. The government has said that it is committed to ensuring that legacy inquests are properly funded. However, it has also said that it must balance the need for justice with the need to be fiscally responsible. The legal challenge brought by the 7/7 families is likely to be a test case for the government's approach to funding legacy inquests. If the families are successful, it could set a precedent for other families seeking to force the government to provide more funding for legacy inquests.

title: Disabled man's holiday prize 'not wheelchair friendly'
text: A disabled man has canceled his holiday prize after the hotel he was supposed to stay at was not wheelchair friendly. John Dickinson, 61, from Wigan, won an all-expenses-paid trip to the Woodlands Hotel in Worsley, Greater Manchester, in a radio competition. However, when he checked the hotel's website, he realized that there were no accessible rooms available. "I was really disappointed," said John, who has muscular dystrophy. "I've been looking forward to this holiday for months." The hotel has since apologized and offered John a full refund. But John says he is still angry that he was not told about the lack of accessible rooms before he booked the trip. "I feel like I've been discriminated against," he said. "I should have been told about this upfront." The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) says that businesses must make reasonable adjustments for disabled people. This includes providing accessible rooms in hotels and other public places. A spokesperson for the EHRC said: "We are concerned to hear about Mr. Dickinson's experience. Businesses have a legal duty to make reasonable adjustments for disabled people. This includes providing accessible rooms in hotels." John's case highlights the importance of businesses being aware of their obligations under the Equality Act. It also shows that disabled people are still facing discrimination when it comes to accessing public places. In a statement, the Woodlands Hotel said: "We sincerely apologize for the inconvenience caused to Mr. Dickinson. We are committed to providing accessible facilities for all our guests and we are currently reviewing our website to ensure that all information is clear and up-to-date." The hotel added that it has since refunded Mr. Dickinson's prize and offered him a free stay in an accessible room in the future. John has accepted the hotel's apology and says he is willing to give them another chance. "I'm still disappointed that I had to cancel my holiday," he said. "But I'm grateful to the hotel for apologizing and offering me a free stay in the future."

title: Spinal muscular atrophy: Families plead for drug to slow disease
text: In a heart-wrenching plea, families affected by spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) are urging the government to provide access to a life-changing drug that could slow the progression of the debilitating condition. SMA is a rare, genetic disorder that affects the motor neurons in the spinal cord, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy. It primarily affects infants and young children, and its severity can vary widely. In its most severe form, SMA can be fatal within the first two years of life. There is currently no cure for SMA, but there are treatments available that can help to manage the symptoms and improve the quality of life for patients. However, these treatments are often very expensive and can have significant side effects. Nusinersen, a drug that has been shown to be effective in slowing the progression of SMA, is not currently funded by the National Health Service (NHS). This means that families who want to access the drug have to pay for it privately, which can cost tens of thousands of pounds per year. The families of children with SMA are now calling on the government to make nusinersen available on the NHS. They say that the drug could make a huge difference to the lives of their loved ones, giving them the chance to live longer, more fulfilling lives. "My son, Oscar, was diagnosed with SMA when he was just a few months old," said Sarah Harrison, Oscar's mother. "He's now four years old and he's doing really well, but I know that without nusinersen, his condition would be much worse. I can't bear to think about what would happen to him if we couldn't afford to pay for his treatment." Another family, the Smiths, have set up a petition calling on the government to fund nusinersen on the NHS. The petition has already gained over 100,000 signatures. title: Fruit-shaped sensor 'can improve freshness'
text: Fruit-shaped sensor can improve freshness A new fruit-shaped sensor can help to improve the freshness of fruit and vegetables. The sensor, which is about the size of a grape, can be inserted into the fruit or vegetable and will monitor its ripeness. When the fruit or vegetable is ripe, the sensor will send a signal to a smartphone app, which will notify the user. The sensor is made of a biodegradable material and is powered by a small battery. It can be used to monitor a variety of fruits and vegetables, including apples, bananas, avocados, and tomatoes. The sensor was developed by a team of researchers at the University of California, Davis. The researchers say that the sensor can help to reduce food waste by allowing consumers to know when their fruits and vegetables are at their peak ripeness. "We wanted to create a sensor that was affordable, easy to use, and could provide consumers with real-time information about the freshness of their produce," said lead researcher Dr. Changying Li. The sensor is still in the early stages of development, but the researchers are hopeful that it will be commercially available within the next few years. In addition to helping consumers to reduce food waste, the sensor could also be used to improve the quality of food. By monitoring the ripeness of fruits and vegetables, farmers and retailers can ensure that they are harvested and sold at the optimal time. The sensor could also be used to develop new food products. For example, it could be used to create a self-ripening fruit bowl that would automatically adjust the temperature and humidity to keep the fruit fresh. The possibilities for the fruit-shaped sensor are endless. It is a simple but effective tool that could have a major impact on the way we grow, store, and consume food. Benefits of the fruit-shaped sensor: Helps to reduce food waste Improves the quality of food Can be used to develop new food products Is affordable, easy to use, and provides real-time information about the freshness of produce

title: Dental surgeons urge England's schools to go sugar-free
text: Dental surgeons in England are urging schools to implement sugar-free policies in an effort to combat the alarming rise in childhood tooth decay. According to the British Dental Association (BDA), tooth decay is the most common chronic disease in children, with nearly one in three five-year-olds experiencing the condition. The BDA attributes this surge in decay to the high consumption of sugary foods and drinks, particularly in school settings. Research has shown that children who have sugary snacks and drinks during the school day are at an increased risk of developing cavities. This is because the sugar in these products provides a food source for bacteria that live on the teeth. These bacteria produce acids that erode the tooth enamel, leading to decay. In response to this growing concern, the BDA is calling on schools across England to adopt sugar-free policies. These policies would prohibit the sale and consumption of all sugary foods and drinks on school premises, including in vending machines, canteens, and packed lunches. The BDA believes that sugar-free schools would play a crucial role in reducing tooth decay among children. By eliminating sugary temptations from the school environment, children would be less likely to snack on these unhealthy products and develop cavities. In addition to reducing tooth decay, sugar-free policies would also have a number of other benefits for children. For example, they would help children to develop healthy eating habits, which would benefit their overall health and wellbeing. Sugar-free policies would also reduce the risk of obesity, type 2 diabetes, and other chronic diseases that are linked to excessive sugar consumption. The BDA's call for sugar-free schools has been supported by a number of organizations, including the National Health Service (NHS), Public Health England (PHE), and the British Heart Foundation (BHF). These organizations all recognize the importance of reducing sugar consumption among children and believe that sugar-free schools are an effective way to achieve this. The BDA is urging schools to adopt sugar-free policies as soon as possible. The organization has developed a toolkit to help schools to implement these policies effectively. The toolkit includes resources such as sample policies, lesson plans, and posters. The BDA believes that sugar-free schools are a vital step towards improving the oral health of children in England. By eliminating sugary temptations from the school environment, children can be given the best chance of developing healthy teeth and gums.

title: New whisky distillery built at historic Lindores Abbey
text: In a nod to Scotland's rich distilling heritage, a new whisky distillery has been built on the grounds of the historic Lindores Abbey in Fife. The abbey, founded in 1191, is believed to be the birthplace of Scotch whisky, with records indicating that monks there were distilling a spirit known as "aqua vitae" in the 15th century. The new distillery, named Lindores Abbey Distillery, is the first to be built on the site in over 500 years. It has been constructed using traditional methods and materials, including locally sourced stone and reclaimed wood from the original abbey buildings. The distillery will produce a single malt Scotch whisky, which will be matured in oak casks for a minimum of three years. The project has been spearheaded by Drew McKenzie Smith, a direct descendant of the monks who first distilled whisky at Lindores Abbey. McKenzie Smith said he was inspired to create the distillery after discovering a reference to the abbey's whisky-making past in a 15th-century manuscript. "I was fascinated by the idea that Scotch whisky may have originated here at Lindores Abbey," said McKenzie Smith. "I wanted to recreate that spirit and share it with the world." The distillery has been designed to be as sustainable as possible, with a focus on reducing water and energy consumption. The spent grain from the distilling process will be used to feed cattle on a nearby farm, and the heat generated by the distillery will be used to warm the abbey's visitor center. The Lindores Abbey Distillery is expected to produce around 100,000 liters of whisky per year. The first batch of whisky is expected to be released in 2023. The distillery has been welcomed by the local community and the Scotch whisky industry. The Scotch Whisky Association said it was "delighted" to see a new distillery being built on such a historic site. "Lindores Abbey is a key part of the story of Scotch whisky," said Karen Betts, the Scotch Whisky Association's chief executive. "The new distillery will help to keep that story alive and inspire future generations." The Lindores Abbey Distillery is open to the public for tours and tastings. Visitors can learn about the history of whisky making at the abbey and see the distilling process in action.

title: Gay marriage ban 'step too far' says Archbishop of Wales
text: The Archbishop of Wales has said that the Church in Wales' decision to ban same-sex marriage is a "step too far". John Davies, who is also the Bishop of Swansea and Brecon, said he was "deeply disappointed" by the vote, which was passed by the Church's governing body, the Governing Body, on Tuesday. "I believe that the decision to ban same-sex marriage is a step too far," he said. "I believe that the Church should be a place of welcome and inclusion for all people, regardless of their sexual orientation." Davies is one of a number of senior figures within the Church in Wales who have spoken out against the ban. The Bishop of St Asaph, Gregory Cameron, said he was "deeply saddened" by the decision, while the Bishop of Bangor, Andy John, said it was a "missed opportunity" for the Church to show its love and compassion for all people. The Church in Wales is the third branch of the Anglican Communion to ban same-sex marriage, after the Church of England and the Episcopal Church in the United States. However, it is the first branch of the Anglican Communion to do so since the Scottish Episcopal Church voted in favor of same-sex marriage in 2017. The decision is likely to further divide the Anglican Communion, which is already split on the issue of same-sex marriage. The Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, has said that he "deeply regrets" the decision, and that it will make it "harder for us to walk together as a Communion". The ban is also likely to lead to further calls for the Church in Wales to leave the Anglican Communion. The Bishop of Monmouth, Richard Pain, has said that he believes the Church in Wales is now "out of step" with the rest of the Anglican Communion, and that it may need to consider leaving. The decision to ban same-sex marriage is a significant moment in the history of the Church in Wales. It is a decision that will have far-reaching consequences for the Church, both in Wales and internationally.

title: Australia growth rate falls short of forecasts
text: Australia's economic growth rate has slowed more than expected in the final quarter of 2022, falling short of forecasts and raising concerns about the impact of rising interest rates and global economic headwinds. The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) reported on Wednesday that the economy grew by 0.5% in the December quarter, down from 0.8% in the September quarter and below the market consensus forecast of 0.7%. The slowdown was broad-based, with growth in household spending, business investment, and government spending all slowing. Household spending, which accounts for about two-thirds of economic activity, grew by just 0.3% in the December quarter, down from 0.9% in the September quarter. Business investment also slowed, with spending on new machinery and equipment declining by 0.8% in the December quarter. Government spending grew by just 0.2%, the slowest pace in a year. The slowdown in growth is a concern for policymakers, who are trying to balance the need to control inflation with the need to support economic growth. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has raised interest rates nine times since May 2022 in an effort to curb inflation, which hit a 33-year high of 7.8% in the December quarter. The RBA has warned that further interest rate hikes are likely to be needed in the coming months, which could put further pressure on economic growth. Economists said the December quarter GDP figures were disappointing and raised concerns about the strength of the economy in the coming months. "The slowdown in growth in the December quarter was more pronounced than expected and suggests that the economy is starting to feel the impact of higher interest rates and the global economic slowdown," said Shane Oliver, chief economist at AMP Capital. "The RBA is likely to remain focused on bringing inflation under control, which suggests that further interest rate hikes are likely in the coming months," he added. The Australian dollar fell against the US dollar after the release of the GDP figures, as investors weighed the implications of the slowdown in growth for the RBA's interest rate policy.

title: Motorola phone 'brazen copy' of iPhone X
text: Motorola Phone Accused of Blatant iPhone X Rip-Off Motorola's latest smartphone, the Moto G8, has sparked controversy for its striking resemblance to Apple's flagship iPhone X. Critics have accused the company of blatantly copying Apple's design, raising questions about originality and innovation within the smartphone industry. The Moto G8 features a near-identical notch display, which Apple introduced with the iPhone X in 2017. This distinctive design element houses the front-facing camera and sensors, providing a more immersive viewing experience. However, Motorola's implementation on the Moto G8 appears to be a direct copy, lacking any significant differentiation. Furthermore, the overall shape and layout of the Moto G8 also bear a striking similarity to the iPhone X. The device has a sleek, rectangular body with curved edges and a glass back. The rear-mounted fingerprint sensor and camera module are also positioned in nearly the same locations. Critics argue that Motorola's brazen imitation is a cheap attempt to capitalize on the success of Apple's design. They contend that it stifles innovation and prevents consumers from having access to truly unique smartphones. Motorola has not directly addressed the accusations, but it did release a statement emphasizing the "competitive" nature of the smartphone market. The company also highlighted the Moto G8's affordability as a key selling point. However, industry experts question whether Motorola's justification is sufficient. They argue that even in a crowded market, originality and differentiation are essential for long-term success. The controversy surrounding the Moto G8 highlights the complex relationship between inspiration and imitation in the tech industry. While it is natural for companies to draw inspiration from successful products, outright copying raises concerns about intellectual property rights and consumer choice. As the smartphone market continues to evolve, it remains to be seen whether Motorola and other manufacturers will prioritize originality or seek to emulate the success of established brands. Additional Observations: The Moto G8 is significantly cheaper than the iPhone X, retailing for around £200 against the iPhone X's original price of £999. Some consumers may appreciate the more affordable option provided by the Moto G8, even if it resembles an existing design. Motorola's decision to copy Apple's design may have been a strategic move to appeal to consumers who desire the iPhone X aesthetic without paying a premium price.

title: State school numbers rise at Cambridge
text: State school numbers rise at Cambridge Data released by the University of Cambridge has shown that the number of students from state schools accepted into the university has increased for the eighth consecutive year. In the 2023 admissions cycle, 60.7% of UK undergraduates admitted to Cambridge were from state schools, up from 59.9% the previous year. This is the highest proportion of state school students admitted to the university since records began in 2004. The increase has been driven by a number of factors, including the university's outreach work in state schools, its contextual admissions policy, and the increasing number of students from disadvantaged backgrounds applying to Cambridge. The university's outreach work includes a range of activities designed to encourage and support students from underrepresented backgrounds to apply to Cambridge. These activities include summer schools, masterclasses, and mentoring programs. The university's contextual admissions policy takes into account a range of factors when making admissions decisions, including a student's school type, family income, and whether they have been in care. This policy helps to ensure that students from all backgrounds have a fair chance of being admitted to Cambridge. The increasing number of students from disadvantaged backgrounds applying to Cambridge is a reflection of the growing awareness of the university's commitment to widening access. The university has a number of initiatives in place to support students from disadvantaged backgrounds, including the Cambridge Bursary Scheme, which provides financial support to students from low-income families. The increase in the number of state school students admitted to Cambridge is a positive development. It shows that the university is making progress in its efforts to widen access and ensure that students from all backgrounds have the opportunity to study at Cambridge. However, there is still more to be done. The university is committed to continuing its outreach work and to developing new initiatives to support students from underrepresented backgrounds. The university also believes that the government must do more to support students from disadvantaged backgrounds, including increasing funding for schools and universities. Only by working together can we ensure that all students have the opportunity to succeed in higher education.

title: Criticism over lack of detail on Lake Vyrnwy estate future
text: Concerns have been raised over the lack of detail provided by Severn Trent about the future of the Lake Vyrnwy estate. The water company, which owns the 24,000-acre estate in Powys, has said it is considering options for its future, including selling it. But critics say Severn Trent has been too vague about its plans and have called for more information to be made public. The Lake Vyrnwy estate is a popular tourist destination and is home to a number of businesses and organisations, including the RSPB and the National Trust. Any sale of the estate could have a significant impact on the local economy and environment. Powys County Council leader Rosemarie Harris said: "We are concerned about the lack of detail that has been provided by Severn Trent so far. "The estate is a major asset to Powys and we need to know what the company's plans are for its future." Severn Trent has said it is committed to "working closely with the local community" to develop a plan for the estate. But critics say the company needs to be more specific about its plans. Montgomeryshire MP Craig Williams said: "Severn Trent needs to come clean about what its plans are for the estate. "The local community deserves to know what the future holds for this important asset." A Severn Trent spokesperson said: "We are currently considering a number of options for the future of the Lake Vyrnwy estate. "We are committed to working closely with the local community to develop a plan that is in the best interests of all stakeholders." The company said it would be holding a public consultation on its plans later this year. The Lake Vyrnwy estate was created in the 1880s to provide water for Liverpool. It is now one of the largest reservoirs in the UK and supplies water to around 2 million people. The estate is also a popular tourist destination, with visitors coming to enjoy the scenery, wildlife and outdoor activities.

title: Apple design chief Jonathan Ive is knighted
text: Sir Jonathan Ive, Apple's design chief who was instrumental in creating iconic products like the iPhone and iPad, has been knighted by the Queen. Ive was born in London in 1967 and studied industrial design at Newcastle Polytechnic. He joined Apple in 1992 and quickly rose through the ranks, becoming head of design in 1997. Under Ive's leadership, Apple's design language has become synonymous with simplicity, elegance, and user-friendliness. He has overseen the design of some of the company's most successful products, including the iMac, iPod, iPhone, iPad, and Apple Watch. Ive's work has been praised by critics and consumers alike. He has received numerous awards, including the Royal Society of Arts Albert Medal and the Time 100 Most Influential People in the World. In 2012, Ive was awarded a CBE for his services to design. He is now one of only a handful of people to have been knighted for their work in the field of design. The knighthood is a fitting recognition of Ive's outstanding contribution to British design. He is a true pioneer who has helped to shape the way we live and work. In a statement, Apple CEO Tim Cook said: "Jony is one of the most talented and influential designers of our time. His work has transformed Apple and the world we live in. We are incredibly fortunate to have him as a member of our team." Ive said he was "honored and humbled" to receive the knighthood. He said: "I am grateful for the recognition, but I am most proud of the work that I have done with my colleagues at Apple. We have been able to create products that have made a difference in people's lives, and that is what drives me every day." Ive is a role model for aspiring designers around the world. His knighthood is a testament to his talent, hard work, and dedication.

title: Paul Heaton and Jacqui Abbott to play free NHS concert
text: Paul Heaton and Jacqui Abbott will play a free concert for NHS workers and their families to thank them for their hard work during the pandemic. The concert will take place at Manchester's AO Arena on Tuesday, 21 September, and will be open to all NHS staff, their families and friends. Heaton and Abbott said they were "honoured" to be able to perform for NHS workers. "We've all seen the incredible work that they've done over the last year and a half, and we wanted to find a way to say thank you," Heaton said. "We hope this concert will be a way for them to let their hair down and have some fun." The concert will be free to attend, but tickets must be booked in advance. Tickets will be available from the AO Arena website from 9am on Thursday, 19 August. Heaton and Abbott are best known for their work with the Beautiful South. They have released six albums together, including the number one hit albums "Welcome to the Beautiful South" and "Carry On Up the Charts". They have also had a number of successful singles, including "A Little Time", "Don't Marry Her" and "Perfect 10". In recent years, Heaton and Abbott have been performing as a duo. They have released two albums together, "What Have We Become?" and "Manchester Calling". They have also toured extensively, including a sold-out show at the Royal Albert Hall in 2019. The concert for NHS workers is part of a series of free concerts that Heaton and Abbott are playing this year. They have already played concerts for homeless people and refugees. Heaton said he and Abbott were committed to using their music to make a positive difference in the world. "We believe that music has the power to heal and unite people," he said. "We hope that this concert will be a way for us to show our appreciation for the NHS and all the amazing work that they do."

title: Jersey pair in 30-year search for Iron Age coins
text: In the verdant fields of Jersey, a tenacious husband-and-wife duo has embarked on a remarkable 30-year quest to uncover the secrets of their beloved island's Iron Age past. Tony and Heather Everett, both archaeology enthusiasts, have dedicated countless hours combing the landscape, meticulously searching for elusive Iron Age coins. Their unwavering determination stems from a profound passion for history and a desire to unravel the hidden stories of their ancestral home. "It's like putting together a giant jigsaw puzzle," Tony explained. "Each coin we find adds another piece to the picture of our ancient ancestors." Their initial discovery of an Iron Age coin set the stage for their lifelong pursuit. "It was a thrill that made all the searching worthwhile," Heather recalled. Inspired by that moment, they vowed to uncover more of Jersey's Iron Age heritage, one coin at a time. Over the years, they have scoured fields, beaches, and even the island's iconic coastal paths, their eyes peeled for any sign of these ancient artifacts. Metal detectors have become their trusted companions, aiding them in their relentless search. "The Jersey climate is a double-edged sword," Tony said. "While it preserves the coins remarkably well, it also makes the ground very difficult to dig." Undeterred, they have developed a keen eye for spotting the telltale signs of buried treasure. Their dedication has borne fruit, as they have amassed a collection of over 50 Iron Age coins, each with its own unique story to tell. Some bear intricate Celtic designs, while others feature the faces of ancient rulers. "These coins are not merely objects; they are tangible links to our past," Heather said. "They provide us with invaluable insights into the lives, beliefs, and commerce of our ancestors." The couple's findings have not only enriched their own knowledge but have also contributed significantly to the understanding of Jersey's Iron Age period. Their collection has been featured in local exhibitions and publications, inspiring a new generation of history enthusiasts. Tony and Heather's tireless search has not only unearthed hidden treasures but has also forged an unbreakable bond between them. "We share a passion for history and a love for our island," Tony said. "This is more than just a hobby; it's a way of life." Their journey is a testament to the enduring power of curiosity and the transformative nature of discovery. As they continue their quest, they hope to uncover even more secrets of Jersey's Iron Age, preserving its legacy for generations to come.

title: Britain First leader and deputy leader jailed for hate crimes
text: Britain First Leader and Deputy Leader Jailed for Hate Crimes Former Britain First leader Paul Golding and deputy leader Jayda Fransen have been jailed for 16 months and two years respectively for religiously aggravated harassment. The charges stemmed from an incident in March 2018, in which the pair distributed leaflets and made abusive comments outside a mosque in Luton, Bedfordshire. Witnesses reported that Golding and Fransen shouted at Muslims and called them "rapists" and "child abusers." The convictions follow a lengthy trial at the Old Bailey, where jurors heard how the pair's actions had caused significant distress to the Muslim community in Luton. Judge Colin Durman said that the pair had "crossed the line" and that their comments were "offensive, inflammatory, and intended to stir up hatred." Golding, who previously served as a police officer, was found guilty of three counts of religiously aggravated harassment. Fransen, who has a history of making anti-Muslim statements, was convicted of one count of the same offense. During the trial, the defense argued that the pair were exercising their right to freedom of speech. However, the judge rejected this argument, stating that their comments had gone beyond legitimate criticism and incited hatred. Prosecuting attorney Mark Heywood described Golding and Fransen as "dangerous" and "poisonous." He said that their actions had "caused significant harm to the Muslim community in Luton." The convictions have been welcomed by anti-racism campaigners, who have long condemned Britain First as a far-right extremist group. Shahid Malik, the former MP for Dewsbury, called the sentences "a victory for justice" and said that they "send a strong message that hate crimes will not be tolerated." However, Britain First supporters have condemned the convictions as an "attack on free speech." In a statement, the group said that Golding and Fransen were "innocent of any crime" and that they had been "unfairly targeted." The convictions come at a time of growing concern about far-right extremism in the UK. In recent years, there have been several high-profile incidents of hate crimes against Muslims, including the murder of Jo Cox MP in 2016. The government has been criticized for its handling of far-right extremism, and there are calls for more to be done to tackle the problem.

title: Barclays reviewing currency trades
text: Barclays, one of the world's largest banks, is reviewing its currency trading operations in light of recent market volatility. The bank is examining its trading strategies, risk management practices, and technology systems to ensure they are robust and effective. The review comes as currency markets have been roiled by a number of factors, including the ongoing trade war between the United States and China, the uncertainty surrounding Brexit, and the global economic slowdown. These factors have led to increased volatility and a sharp decline in trading volumes. Barclays is not the only bank to review its currency trading operations in recent months. Other banks, including Citigroup, Deutsche Bank, and UBS, have also taken steps to strengthen their risk management practices and improve their trading systems. The increased scrutiny of currency trading operations comes as regulators around the world are stepping up their oversight of the foreign exchange market. In recent years, there have been a number of high-profile cases of currency manipulation and other misconduct in the market. In 2014, for example, five major banks were fined a total of $4.3 billion by regulators in the United States, the United Kingdom, and Switzerland for manipulating currency rates. The banks were found to have colluded to fix the prices of currencies, such as the euro and the yen, in order to profit from their trading. The increased regulatory scrutiny and the recent market volatility have led to a number of changes in the way that banks trade currencies. Banks are now required to hold more capital against their currency trading operations and to have more robust risk management systems in place. They are also under pressure to improve their trading technology and to be more transparent about their trading activities. These changes are likely to make it more difficult for banks to profit from currency trading in the future. Despite the challenges, currency trading remains an important part of the global financial system. Currencies are used to facilitate trade and investment, and they play a key role in the global economy. Banks will need to continue to adapt their currency trading operations to meet the challenges of the changing regulatory environment and the evolving market landscape.

title: Coronavirus: Belfast's Lyric Theatre rules out 2020 reopening
text: The Lyric Theatre in Belfast has ruled out reopening in 2020 due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The theatre had hoped to reopen in September with a socially distanced audience, but has now said it is not possible to do so safely. In a statement, the Lyric said: "We have taken the difficult decision not to reopen the Lyric Theatre in 2020. This decision was not made lightly and we are deeply disappointed to have to take this step. "However, the health and safety of our audiences, staff and artists must be our priority. We do not believe that we can reopen safely under the current circumstances." The Lyric is one of the leading theatres in Northern Ireland and its closure will be a major blow to the local arts scene. The theatre had been due to stage a number of productions in the autumn, including a new play by Marie Jones and a revival of the classic musical Cabaret. The Lyric said it is now working on plans to reopen in 2021 and will announce its new season in due course. In the meantime, the theatre will continue to offer online content, including live-streamed performances and workshops. The Lyric's decision to close for the rest of the year follows similar announcements from other theatres across the UK, including the National Theatre in London and the Royal Shakespeare Company in Stratford-upon-Avon. The coronavirus pandemic has had a devastating impact on the arts sector, with theatres, cinemas and music venues forced to close for months. Many theatres are now struggling to survive and are facing an uncertain future. The Lyric Theatre is a vital part of the Belfast arts scene and its closure will be a major loss to the city. However, the theatre's decision to put safety first is understandable and it is hoped that it will be able to reopen in 2021 with a full and vibrant programme of events.

title: Views sought on Gatwick and London 'airspace motorway'
text: Views sought on Gatwick and London 'airspace motorway' A public consultation has been launched on plans to create an 'airspace motorway' linking Gatwick and London's Heathrow airports. The proposals, from air traffic control company NATS, would see a dedicated route for aircraft flying between the two airports, in a bid to reduce delays and carbon emissions. The consultation will run until 29 October and will seek views from the public, airlines, and other stakeholders. NATS says the airspace motorway would "revolutionise" air travel in the south-east of England, and would "deliver significant benefits" for passengers, airlines, and the environment. The company claims that the motorway would reduce delays by up to 20 minutes per flight, and would cut carbon emissions by up to 10%. It would also free up airspace for other flights, allowing for more capacity and flexibility. However, some environmental groups have expressed concerns about the plans, arguing that they could lead to increased noise pollution for communities living near the flight paths. The consultation will seek to address these concerns, and NATS says it is committed to working with local communities to mitigate any potential impacts. If the plans are approved, the airspace motorway could be in operation by 2029. Key benefits of the airspace motorway: Reduced delays for passengers Lower carbon emissions Increased capacity and flexibility Improved air quality Potential concerns: Increased noise pollution for communities near flight paths Visual impact of aircraft flying overhead How to have your say: The public consultation on the airspace motorway is open until 29 October. You can have your say by completing the online questionnaire at the following link: [Consultation link] You can also write to NATS at the following address: NATS FREEPOST Consultation London SW1W 8ZJ Your views will help to inform the decision-making process.

title: RHI scandal: Boiler owners opposed to being publicly named
text: RHI scandal: Boiler owners opposed to being publicly named A number of boiler owners have expressed their opposition to being publicly named as part of the ongoing public inquiry into the Renewable Heat Incentive (RHI) scandal. The RHI scheme, which was introduced in Northern Ireland in 2012, was designed to encourage the uptake of renewable energy technologies by providing financial incentives to businesses and individuals who installed biomass boilers. However, the scheme was found to have been poorly designed and implemented, leading to widespread abuse and overpayments. As a result, the Northern Ireland Executive has been ordered to pay back more than £500 million to the UK Treasury. The public inquiry into the RHI scandal is currently underway, and part of its remit is to identify those who benefited financially from the scheme. However, a number of boiler owners have objected to their names being made public, arguing that it would damage their privacy and reputation. In a letter to the inquiry, one boiler owner said that he had "done nothing wrong" and that his name should not be "dragged through the mud" for simply participating in a government scheme. Another boiler owner said that she was "afraid of being targeted by vigilantes" if her name was made public. The inquiry panel has said that it is "sympathetic" to the concerns of boiler owners, but that it is important to ensure that the public has a full understanding of the RHI scandal. "We believe that it is in the public interest for the names of those who benefited financially from the scheme to be made public," the panel said. "However, we will consider the privacy concerns of individual boiler owners on a case-by-case basis." The inquiry panel has also said that it will not name any boiler owners who have repaid the overpayments they received under the scheme. The RHI scandal has had a significant impact on Northern Ireland, both financially and politically. The public inquiry is expected to last for several months, and it is likely that further revelations about the scandal will emerge.

title: Japan ninja student gets top marks for writing essay in invisible ink
text: In an extraordinary feat of stealth and academic prowess, a ninja student in Japan has astounded educators by receiving top marks for writing an essay in invisible ink. The student, whose identity remains a closely guarded secret, attends the prestigious Ninja Academy in Iga, Mie Prefecture. It was written entirely in an invisible ink made from a secret blend of natural ingredients, including lemon juice and vinegar. To reveal the hidden text, the examiner had to use a special chemical solution, which caused the ink to become visible. The essay itself was a scholarly investigation into the history and techniques of ninja warfare. The student demonstrated an encyclopedic knowledge of the subject, showcasing their mastery of both ancient and modern ninja arts. The examiner was particularly impressed by the student's analysis of the use of invisible ink in ninja operations throughout history. "This essay is an exceptional example of the skills and knowledge that our students develop at the Ninja Academy," said a spokesperson for the academy. "To achieve such a high level of mastery in both writing and stealth is a testament to the student's dedication and hard work." The student's achievement has sparked a renewed interest in the ancient art of invisible ink. Historians and scholars are now exploring the potential applications of this technology in modern espionage and counterintelligence. Some experts believe that invisible ink could play a significant role in future conflicts, allowing agents to communicate securely and leave behind undetectable messages. Others argue that the technology is outdated and easily detectable by modern surveillance techniques. Regardless of its potential military applications, the student's achievement serves as a reminder of the enduring power of stealth and the importance of mastering the art of deception. As the world becomes increasingly digital and transparent, the ability to hide in plain sight will become an invaluable asset for those seeking to achieve their goals, whether they be political, military, or personal.

title: Pacific castaway Jose Salvador Alvarenga's health worsens
text: The health of Pacific castaway Jose Salvador Alvarenga has worsened since his return to El Salvador, according to his family. Alvarenga, 37, spent more than 13 months adrift in the Pacific Ocean after his fishing boat capsized in 2012. He was rescued in January 2014 and returned to El Salvador, where he received medical treatment. However, his family says that his health has deteriorated in recent months. He has lost weight, is suffering from muscle pain, and has difficulty sleeping. Alvarenga's family has taken him to several doctors, but they have been unable to diagnose his condition. They are now appealing for help from the government and international medical experts. "We don't know what's wrong with him," said Alvarenga's mother, Maria Julia Alvarenga. "He's in a lot of pain and we don't know how to help him." Alvarenga's ordeal began in December 2012, when his fishing boat capsized off the coast of Mexico. He was stranded at sea with a 15-year-old boy, who died after a few weeks. Alvarenga survived by eating fish, turtles, and birds. He also drank his own urine and seawater. He was finally rescued by a cargo ship in January 2014, after drifting more than 6,000 miles across the Pacific Ocean. Upon his return to El Salvador, Alvarenga was hailed as a hero. He was given a ticker-tape parade and met with President Salvador Sanchez Ceren. However, Alvarenga's health has since declined. He has been suffering from muscle pain, headaches, and fatigue. He has also lost a significant amount of weight. Alvarenga's family is worried that his health problems may be related to his time at sea. title: London Bridge terrorist-hiring head teacher struck off
text: London Bridge terrorist-hiring head teacher struck off A head teacher who hired an assistant later convicted of plotting the London Bridge terror attack has been struck off the teaching register. Suzette Lampkin was the head of the Westminster Academy when she hired Nicky Reilly. Reilly had previously worked at several other schools and had been investigated for inappropriate behaviour. In 2017, Reilly was jailed for life for helping plan the attack in which eight people were killed and 48 injured. Lampkin was found guilty of unacceptable professional conduct by a National College for Teaching and Leadership (NCTL) panel. The panel heard that Lampkin had failed to take reasonable steps to ensure the suitability of Reilly before hiring him. It also found that she had failed to follow up on concerns raised by staff about Reilly's behaviour. Lampkin has been prohibited from teaching indefinitely. The NCTL said in a statement: "The panel found that Mrs Lampkin's actions fell significantly short of the standards expected of the profession. "The panel was particularly concerned that Mrs Lampkin had failed to take reasonable steps to ensure the suitability of Mr Reilly before appointing him, and that she had failed to follow up on concerns raised by staff about his behaviour. "The panel considered that Mrs Lampkin's actions had the potential to put children at risk of harm, and that she had shown a disregard for the welfare of her pupils." Westminster Academy is a secondary school in the London Borough of Westminster. It is a co-educational academy with a sixth form. The school was rated "good" by Ofsted in its most recent inspection in 2019. Lampkin has the right to appeal the NCTL's decision.

title: Wylfa: Last day for Anglesey nuclear plant
text: The last day of operations for the Wylfa nuclear power plant on the Isle of Anglesey has arrived, marking the end of an era for the island and the UK's nuclear industry. For over 40 years, Wylfa has been a major employer and a significant contributor to the UK's energy supply, generating enough electricity to power millions of homes across the country. As the sun sets on Wylfa's final day, a palpable sense of nostalgia hangs in the air. Former employees, local residents, and energy experts gather to bid farewell to the iconic plant. The mood is bittersweet, as people reflect on the plant's history and its role in shaping the region. Commissioned in 1971, Wylfa was one of the first nuclear power plants built in the UK. It has operated safely and reliably throughout its lifetime, providing a steady and low-carbon source of energy. However, the plant has also faced its share of challenges, including a major fire in 1982 and a series of safety concerns in recent years. Despite these challenges, Wylfa has remained a vital part of the UK's energy mix. It has employed thousands of people over the years, providing jobs and economic benefits to the local community. The plant has also played a key role in reducing the UK's reliance on fossil fuels and mitigating climate change. As Wylfa enters its final hours, the focus shifts to the future. The UK government has pledged to invest in new nuclear power stations, recognizing the importance of this technology in meeting the country's future energy needs. However, the debate over nuclear power continues, with some arguing that it is too expensive and risky, while others maintain that it is essential for a secure and low-carbon energy future. The closure of Wylfa marks a significant milestone in the UK's energy history. It is a reminder of the complex challenges and opportunities that come with nuclear power and the importance of balancing the need for reliable energy with environmental and safety concerns. As the last reactor at Wylfa is shut down, a new chapter begins for the Isle of Anglesey and the UK's nuclear industry. The future of nuclear power in the UK remains uncertain, but the legacy of Wylfa will undoubtedly continue to shape the debate for years to come.

title: Germany's Jews urged not to wear kippahs after attacks
text: Germany's Jews urged not to wear kippahs after attacks German police have urged Jews not to wear kippahs in public after a spate of attacks on people wearing the Jewish skullcap. The Central Council of Jews in Germany said there had been 10 anti-Semitic attacks in the Berlin area in recent weeks, including several in which people wearing kippahs were assaulted or verbally abused. The German government has said that it is committed to fighting anti-Semitism and has pledged to take action to reduce anti-Semitic attitudes in Germany. title: Wiseman agrees to Muller takeover
text: Sir Martin Wiseman, the long-standing chairman of defence company Muller, has agreed a takeover by US giant General Dynamics. title: Poland hosts landmark European gay pride
text: In a historic moment for Poland, the nation played host to its first ever European Pride event, drawing a vibrant and enthusiastic crowd to the streets of Warsaw. The event marked a significant milestone in the country's journey towards greater acceptance and inclusivity for the LGBTQ+ community. The march took place on Saturday, July 23, under the theme "Together for Equality." It commenced with a rally at the bustling Plac Zamkowy, where speeches were delivered by Polish and European LGBTQ+ activists, politicians, and allies. The crowd waved rainbow flags, held up placards advocating for equality, and chanted slogans calling for an end to discrimination. As the march made its way through the heart of Warsaw, participants were greeted with cheers, applause, and messages of support from onlookers. The route passed by iconic landmarks such as the Palace of Culture and Science and the Old Town, showcasing the LGBTQ+ community's presence and visibility in the heart of Polish society. Alongside the march, a vibrant cultural program took place throughout the week, featuring concerts, exhibitions, and workshops. These events provided a platform for LGBTQ+ artists, performers, and speakers to share their stories and perspectives. The successful hosting of European Pride in Poland is a testament to the growing acceptance and visibility of the LGBTQ+ community in the country. While Poland still faces challenges in terms of LGBTQ+ rights, the event demonstrated a strong movement for equality and a growing demand for change. The European Pride Organisers Association (EPOA), which coordinated the event, expressed their gratitude to Poland for hosting the Pride and their commitment to continue working towards equality and inclusivity for LGBTQ+ people across the continent. "Warsaw Pride has been a powerful display of unity and resilience, sending a clear message that LGBTQ+ people deserve equal rights and respect," said EPOA President Kristine Garina. "We commend the Polish LGBTQ+ community and their allies for their tireless efforts in making this event a success." The Polish government has been criticized by human rights groups for its stance on LGBTQ+ issues, including a controversial law that bans the "promotion" of homosexuality in schools. However, the government has stated that it supports the right to peaceful assembly and that it would ensure the safety of participants at European Pride. The event has been met with mixed reactions from the Polish public. Some conservative groups have condemned the march, but many Poles have expressed their support for the LGBTQ+ community and their right to celebrate their identities.

title: David Brickwood murder: Northampton silence 'spineless' says son
text: The family of murdered Northampton man David Brickwood have condemned the "spineless" silence from the local community, as his son appeals for information on the 15th anniversary of the case. David Brickwood was found stabbed to death in his home in Rectory Farm on January 19, 2008. Despite a £50,000 reward offered and repeated appeals, his killer has never been caught. His son, also called David, who was 20 at the time of his father's death, said the family deserve justice and are desperate to know who killed their "loving husband and father". "It's hard to believe it's been 15 years. It feels like yesterday and a lifetime ago," he said. "The last 15 years have been a living nightmare for my family. Not knowing who killed my dad has turned our lives upside down. We deserve justice and we need closure." "The support we've had from the police has been amazing, but we're so frustrated by the silence from the community," he added. "People must have seen or heard something that could help solve this case. But they're too scared to come forward." "It's spineless and cowardly. How can you live with yourself knowing that you've allowed a killer to get away with murder?" David Snr was a well-known figure in the community, having worked as a builder, part-time taxi driver, and football coach for the local youth team. He was described as a "gentle giant" and a "loving husband and father". Police have made several arrests in connection with his murder, but no one has ever been charged. Detective Inspector Stuart Hitchon, who is leading the investigation, said he is "determined" to catch David Brickwood's killer. "This was a brutal and senseless murder that has had a devastating impact on David's family," he said. "We are determined to find the person responsible and bring them to justice." Det Insp Hitchon said he believes there are people in the community who know who killed David Brickwood. "We know that people are reluctant to come forward for a variety of reasons," he said. You could help us solve this case and give David's family the justice they deserve."

title: Rowley Regis dog attack: Woman, 85, killed by dogs that got through fence hole

title: Primark fire: Cordon leads to £152k loss for Translink
