title: eBay antique dealer faked signatures of public figures
text: An eBay antique dealer who faked signatures of public figures, including Winston Churchill and Albert Einstein, has been jailed for four years. David Lassman, 71, from north London, admitted forging signatures on books, photographs and letters over a seven-year period. He sold them to unsuspecting buyers on eBay, making a profit of more than £100,000. Isleworth Crown Court heard how Lassman used a variety of techniques to create the fake signatures, including tracing over original signatures and using a computer to generate them. He was caught after a customer became suspicious of a signed photograph of Churchill and reported it to the police. An investigation by the Metropolitan Police's Art and Antiques Unit revealed that Lassman had been selling a number of other forged items on eBay. These included a signed letter from Einstein, a signed photograph of the Queen Mother, and a signed book by former Prime Minister Tony Blair. In a statement, the Metropolitan Police said: "Lassman's forgeries were very convincing and he was able to sell them to unsuspecting buyers for a substantial profit. "This case highlights the importance of being vigilant when buying antiques and other collectibles, and of only buying from reputable dealers." In court, Lassman pleaded guilty to 10 counts of fraud and one count of possession of articles for use in fraud. He was sentenced to four years in prison and ordered to pay £100,000 in compensation to his victims. Judge Martin Edmunds said: "You have committed a serious breach of trust. You have sold these items to unsuspecting buyers who believed they were genuine. "You have made a significant profit from your dishonesty and you have caused your victims a great deal of distress." Lassman's actions have had a damaging impact on the antiques market. It is now more difficult for buyers to be sure that the items they are purchasing are genuine. This case serves as a warning to other fraudsters who may be tempted to forge signatures of public figures.

title: Scottish food and drink export sales 'on target'

title: Global spam e-mail drops after hacker arrests
text: Global Spam E-mail Drops After Hacker Arrests A concerted global crackdown on spam email has yielded significant results, with a 75% decline in spam messages since the arrests of two prolific hackers. The joint operation, led by the United States, United Kingdom, and Europol, targeted two criminal groups responsible for distributing a vast majority of spam worldwide. The arrests have disrupted their networks and significantly reduced the flow of unsolicited emails. "This operation has been a major blow to the global spam industry," said Robert Anderson, a spokesperson for the FBI. "These criminal groups were responsible for billions of spam emails every day, which not only disrupted people's inboxes but also spread malware and online scams." Before the arrests, spam emails accounted for over half of all email traffic. They flooded inboxes with unwanted messages, often containing malicious links or fraudulent offers. The decline in spam since the crackdown has been a welcome relief for internet users worldwide. "I used to get dozens of spam emails a day," said Sarah Jones, a London resident. "It was a constant annoyance, and I had to spend a lot of time manually filtering them out of my inbox. Now, I hardly get any spam at all." The operation involved a coordinated effort by law enforcement and technology companies. Investigators tracked the hackers' activities across multiple countries and seized their databases and equipment. The arrests were the culmination of a months-long investigation that required close collaboration between local and international agencies. "This is a significant milestone in the fight against cybercrime," said Europol's Wil van Gemert. "It demonstrates that law enforcement and the tech industry can work together to protect the public from online threats." While the decline in spam is a positive development, experts warn that the threats may evolve over time. Hackers are constantly adapting their techniques, and it is important for users to remain vigilant and protect themselves from unsolicited emails. Security experts recommend using spam filters, being cautious when clicking on links, and not responding to suspicious emails. Users should also avoid sharing personal information online and regularly update their security software. By following these precautions, internet users can help protect themselves from spam and other online threats while enjoying the benefits of a cleaner and safer digital environment.

title: Parasite becomes UK's most successful international film

Parasite's success in the UK is a clear indication that the international film market is ripe for more groundbreaking and diverse storytelling. In addition to its box office success, Parasite has also been recognized by numerous award bodies. It won four Academy Awards, including Best Picture and Best Director, becoming the first non-English language film to do so. It also received the Golden Globe Award for Best Foreign Language Film. Parasite's success is a major milestone for international cinema and a testament to the power of storytelling to transcend cultural boundaries. It is a film that has resonated with audiences around the world, leaving an indelible mark on the cinematic landscape.

title: Diamond Jubilee: How did London's transport system cope?
text: London's transport system underwent rigorous preparations for the Diamond Jubilee, ensuring seamless movement for the colossal crowds that descended upon the capital to celebrate Queen Elizabeth II's 60th year on the throne. The vast network of Underground lines, buses, and trains operated at heightened capacity, with additional services and extended hours implemented to accommodate the expected influx of revelers. Extra staff were deployed at key stations and interchanges, providing guidance and support to passengers. One of the most significant challenges was managing the colossal crowds expected for the Thames Diamond Jubilee Pageant, a spectacular flotilla of over 1,000 boats sailing down the River Thames. To facilitate smooth access to the waterfront, additional river services were introduced, including special "Jubilee River Buses" connecting key locations along the route. Furthermore, dedicated "Jubilee Lanes" were established at major transport hubs, such as Victoria and Waterloo stations, guiding visitors towards designated viewing areas along the Thames. title: Dale Farm eviction: Residents prepare for confrontation
text: Dale Farm residents prepare for confrontation with bailiffs as eviction looms Tensions are high at Dale Farm as residents prepare for a confrontation with bailiffs who are due to arrive on Wednesday to evict them from their homes. The 400-strong community of Dale Farm, near Basildon, Essex, has been given until Wednesday to leave the site, which they have occupied illegally for more than a decade. But residents say they will not go without a fight and have vowed to resist eviction. "We are not going to give up our homes without a fight," said Mary Flynn, a Dale Farm resident. "We have been here for over 10 years and we have nowhere else to go." The eviction is the culmination of a long-running legal battle between the residents and Basildon Council, which owns the land. The council has argued that the Dale Farm site is illegal and that the residents are trespassing. But the residents say they have a right to live on the land and that they have been unfairly treated by the council. "We have been treated like second-class citizens," said Patrick Flynn, another Dale Farm resident. "The council has made it clear that they don't want us here." The eviction is likely to be a major challenge for the police, who will be responsible for enforcing the court order. Assistant Chief Constable Steve Worron said the police would be "professional and proportionate" in their approach. "We will be working to ensure that the eviction is carried out safely and peacefully," he said. However, the residents have said they will not cooperate with the police and will do everything they can to prevent the eviction. "We are not going to make it easy for them," said Mary Flynn. "We are going to fight them every step of the way." The eviction is expected to begin at 8am on Wednesday. ---------------------------------------------------------------- Additional notes for the BBC writer The BBC is committed to impartiality and accuracy in its reporting. The BBC should not take sides in the dispute between Dale Farm residents and Basildon Council. The BBC should give a fair and balanced account of the situation, including the views of both sides. title: Popcorn Time's app is seen by Netflix as a threat - here's how
text: Popcorn Time, the popular streaming app that allows users to watch movies and TV shows for free, is seen by Netflix as a major threat. One way that Netflix could combat the threat from Popcorn Time and other streaming apps is to offer a more affordable subscription service. title: D-Day veteran Gordon Prime lands Legion d'Honneur in France
text: In a poignant ceremony imbued with gratitude and remembrance, D-Day veteran Gordon Prime has been awarded the prestigious Legion d'Honneur in France, the country he helped liberate during World War II. At the age of 97, Mr. Prime traveled to Ouistreham, Normandy, where he landed on Sword Beach as a Royal Engineer on June 6, 1944. His unit's task was to clear obstacles and mines from the beach, paving the way for Allied troops. "It was a frightening experience," Mr. Prime recalled. "But we knew what we had to do, and we did it." The Legion d'Honneur, France's highest decoration, is bestowed upon individuals who have made outstanding contributions to the country. Mr. Prime's service on D-Day, which marked a turning point in the war, undoubtedly merited this honor. "It's an incredible privilege to receive this award," said Mr. Prime. "It brings back so many memories, both good and bad." The French consul in Portsmouth, Mr. Pierre-Emmanuel Quirin, presented the award to Mr. Prime. "We are eternally grateful for the sacrifices made by veterans like Mr. Prime," he said. "Their bravery and determination helped secure our freedom." Mr. Prime's landing on Sword Beach was part of Operation Overlord, the Allied invasion of Normandy. Over 150,000 troops stormed the beaches, facing fierce resistance from German forces. The operation was a costly but ultimately successful endeavor, and it marked the beginning of the liberation of Europe from Nazi occupation. Mr. Prime's experiences on D-Day have stayed with him throughout his life. "I never forgot the faces of the men I fought alongside," he said. "They were the bravest people I ever met." Despite the horrors he witnessed, Mr. Prime maintains a positive outlook on life. "I'm grateful for every day I have," he said. "And I'm proud of the role I played in helping to defeat fascism." Mr. Prime's award not only recognizes his service but also serves as a reminder of the immense sacrifices made by all those who fought in World War II. Their legacy will forever be etched in the annals of history, a testament to the courage and resilience of the human spirit.

title: Apple 'optimistic' about post-Brexit UK
text: Despite the ongoing uncertainty surrounding the UK's departure from the European Union, Apple remains optimistic about its future in the country. Of course, there are some challenges that Apple and other businesses will face in the UK post-Brexit. One challenge is the potential for tariffs on goods imported into the UK from the EU. This could increase the cost of Apple's products for UK consumers. Another challenge is the potential for changes to data protection laws in the UK. If the UK leaves the EU without a deal, it is possible that the GDPR will no longer apply in the UK. This could create uncertainty for businesses and consumers alike. Despite these challenges, Apple remains committed to the UK. The company has a long history in the country, and it employs over 6,000 people in the UK. title: Headline Numbers: Is UK inequality as bad as in the US?
text: Headline Numbers: Is UK Inequality as Bad as in the US? Income inequality in the United Kingdom and the United States has been a subject of much debate in recent years. While both countries have seen a widening wealth gap, the extent to which it is worse in the US has been a matter of contention. Comparisons of Income Inequality Gini coefficient: The Gini coefficient measures the distribution of income in a society, with a higher coefficient indicating greater inequality. In the US, the Gini coefficient has risen from 0.42 in 1979 to 0.47 in 2019, while in the UK it has increased from 0.32 in 1990 to 0.36 in 2019. This suggests that inequality has increased faster in the US. Top 1%: The share of income earned by the top 1% of earners has also increased more in the US than in the UK. In the US, the top 1% captured 10% of total income in 1979, rising to 20% in 2019. In the UK, the top 1% earned 7% of income in 1990, reaching 14% in 2019. Median income: However, a key difference lies in the median income levels of the two countries. The median US household income was $63,179 in 2019, significantly higher than the UK median income of £29,900 ($40,500). This suggests that while inequality may be more pronounced in the US, the overall standard of living for average households is higher. Causes of Inequality The causes of inequality are complex and multifaceted, but some key factors include: Technological change: Automation and technological advances have led to a decline in jobs requiring lower-skill workers, exacerbating income disparities. Globalization: Offshoring and outsourcing have shifted job opportunities abroad, further contributing to inequality. Education gaps: Growing disparities in educational attainment between different socioeconomic groups can lead to unequal access to well-paying jobs. Tax policies: Tax policies that favor high-income earners can contribute to rising inequality. Addressing Inequality Tackling income inequality requires a comprehensive approach that includes: Investing in education and skills training: Enhancing access to quality education can help close socioeconomic gaps and prepare individuals for the jobs of the future. Strengthening social safety nets: Social programs such as minimum wage increases, tax credits, and universal basic income can provide support to low-income households. Reforming tax policies: Progressive tax policies that shift the tax burden towards high-income earners can reduce inequality. Promoting labor market regulation: Measures such as collective bargaining rights and minimum wage enforcement can help ensure fair wages for workers. Conclusion While the headline numbers suggest that income inequality has risen in both the UK and the US, the extent of the problem varies. The US has experienced a more significant widening of the wealth gap compared to the UK. However, the UK faces its own challenges in addressing inequality, particularly in terms of socioeconomic disparities and the rising cost of living. Tackling these issues requires a concerted effort from governments, businesses, and society as a whole to create a more just and equitable economy.

title: Pope Francis: 'Christians and Muslims are brothers and sisters'
text: In a historic declaration, Pope Francis has affirmed that Christians and Muslims are "brothers and sisters" and should live together in harmony. Addressing a gathering of religious leaders in Abu Dhabi, the Pope emphasized the shared values of love, mercy, and respect that bind the two faiths together. He urged followers of both religions to reject violence and extremism, and to work collectively for a just and peaceful world. "Christians and Muslims are brothers and sisters in the same human family, and as such, we should live together in harmony and mutual respect," the Pope said. "Violence and extremism are never the answer, and they only serve to divide us further." The Pope's declaration is a significant step towards fostering greater interfaith understanding and cooperation. It comes at a time when tensions between Christians and Muslims have been exacerbated by global conflicts and the rise of religious extremism. The Pope's message of brotherhood and unity resonated with religious leaders from both sides. Grand Imam Ahmed el-Tayeb, the head of Cairo's Al-Azhar Mosque, hailed the Pope's speech as a "new chapter" in interfaith relations. "We are all children of God," Imam el-Tayeb said. "We may have different beliefs, but we share the same values of love and compassion." The Pope's declaration is not only a theological statement but also a practical call to action. He called on religious leaders to "work together to build a world where justice and peace prevail." This includes promoting education, interfaith dialogue, and cultural exchange. It also means working together to address the underlying causes of conflict and violence, such as poverty, inequality, and discrimination. The Pope's message has been welcomed by many observers as a beacon of hope in a world often divided by religious and political differences. It serves as a reminder that despite our differences, we are all part of the human family and that we must strive to live together in peace and harmony. The Pope's declaration is a testament to the power of interfaith dialogue and cooperation. It shows that when we come together with a spirit of respect and understanding, we can overcome our differences and build a better world for all.

title: UN body bars Sri Lanka diplomat Maj Gen Shavendra Silva
text: A United Nations body has barred a Sri Lankan diplomat from participating in its sessions because of his alleged involvement in war crimes. Maj Gen Shavendra Silva was Sri Lanka's army chief during the final stages of the country's 26-year civil war, which ended in 2009. He and other military personnel have been accused of committing atrocities against Tamil civilians during the conflict. In 2021, the UN Human Rights Council (UNHRC) passed a resolution calling for an international investigation into alleged human rights violations in Sri Lanka. The resolution also called for the government to take steps to prevent further violations and to hold those responsible to account. Silva's appointment as Sri Lanka's deputy permanent representative to the UN in New York has been widely condemned by human rights groups. They argue that it sends the wrong message and undermines the UN's efforts to promote accountability for war crimes. The UNHRC has now decided to bar Silva from attending its sessions. The body's spokesperson, Rupert Colville, said that the decision had been made "in light of the serious allegations of human rights violations against him". Colville said that the UNHRC was "deeply concerned" by Silva's appointment and that it had "repeatedly called on the government of Sri Lanka to investigate these allegations and to hold those responsible to account". He said that the UNHRC's decision to bar Silva from its sessions was "a clear message that we will not tolerate impunity for war crimes". The Sri Lankan government has defended Silva's appointment, saying that he is a "respected military officer" who has been unfairly targeted by human rights groups. However, the international community has been increasingly critical of Sri Lanka's human rights record. In addition to the UNHRC resolution, the European Union has also passed a resolution calling for an international investigation into alleged human rights violations in Sri Lanka. The UNHRC's decision to bar Silva from its sessions is a further blow to the Sri Lankan government's efforts to improve its international standing. It is also a sign that the international community is increasingly determined to hold those responsible for war crimes to account.

title: Coronavirus: New 'fast and accurate' antibody test developed
text: ## Coronavirus: New 'fast and accurate' antibody test developed Scientists have developed a new antibody test for coronavirus that is fast, accurate, and easy to use, and could be used in doctors' surgeries or at home. The test, developed by researchers at the University of Oxford, can detect antibodies against the virus in just 10 minutes, using a drop of blood from a finger prick. This is much faster than current antibody tests, which can take several hours or even days to produce results. The new test is also highly accurate, with a sensitivity of 98.6% and a specificity of 100%. This means that it is very good at detecting antibodies against the virus, and very good at not giving false positive results. The test is also easy to use, and can be performed by anyone with minimal training. This means that it could be used in doctors' surgeries, pharmacies, or even at home. The researchers say that the new test could be a valuable tool for diagnosing coronavirus infection, and for tracking the spread of the virus. "This test is a significant advance in the fight against coronavirus," said Professor Miles Carroll, one of the researchers who developed the test. "It is fast, accurate, and easy to use, and it could be used to diagnose infection and track the spread of the virus." "The test could also be used to identify people who have had the virus and developed antibodies against it," said Professor Carroll. "This information could be used to develop a vaccine for the virus." The new test is currently being evaluated in clinical trials, and the researchers hope to make it available for use in the coming months. ## How does the test work? The test works by detecting antibodies against the virus in a drop of blood. Antibodies are proteins that are produced by the immune system in response to infection. When the body is infected with a virus, the immune system produces antibodies that are specific to that virus. These antibodies can then bind to the virus and neutralize it. The new test uses a small chip that is coated with a protein that is specific to the coronavirus. When a drop of blood is placed on the chip, the antibodies in the blood will bind to the protein. This binding event can then be detected by a reader, which produces a result in just 10 minutes. ## What are the benefits of the new test? The new test has several benefits over current antibody tests: It is fast, with results available in just 10 minutes. It is accurate, with a sensitivity of 98.6% and a specificity of 100%. It is easy to use, and can be performed by anyone with minimal training. It can be used in a variety of settings, including doctors' surgeries, pharmacies, and at home. The new test could be a valuable tool for diagnosing coronavirus infection, tracking the spread of the virus, and developing a vaccine.

title: What does it take to be a police officer?
text: Policing is a demanding and challenging profession that requires a unique combination of skills, qualities, and dedication. If you're considering a career in policing, it's essential to understand the demands of the job and the qualities that make a successful police officer. Physical and Mental Fitness: Police officers are often required to engage in physically demanding activities, such as running, restraining suspects, and responding to emergencies. They must also possess mental toughness and resilience to handle the stress and pressure of the job. Communication and Interpersonal Skills: Effective communication is crucial for police officers. They must be able to interact with people from all walks of life, build rapport, and convey information clearly and empathetically. Interpersonal skills are also essential for resolving conflicts and mediating disputes. Integrity and Honesty: Trust and integrity are fundamental to policing. Police officers must uphold the highest ethical standards and be able to resist corruption and misconduct. They must be committed to serving the community fairly and impartially. Courage and Leadership: Police officers often face dangerous and unpredictable situations. They must possess courage and the ability to make quick decisions under pressure. Leadership skills are also important for motivating and guiding other officers and working effectively as a team. Community Engagement: Building and maintaining strong relationships with the community is essential for effective policing. Police officers should engage with residents, businesses, and community organizations to foster trust and cooperation. They should be visible, accessible, and responsive to the needs of the community. Training and Education: Becoming a police officer typically requires a combination of training and education. Most police departments require recruits to complete a police academy, which provides instruction in law enforcement techniques, firearms training, and other essential skills. Some departments may also require officers to obtain a degree in criminal justice or a related field. Personal Qualities: In addition to the aforementioned skills and qualities, successful police officers often possess certain personal characteristics, such as: Empathy: The ability to understand and respond to the emotions of others Cultural sensitivity: Respect for and understanding of diverse cultures and perspectives Problem-solving: The ability to analyze situations and find creative solutions Flexibility: The ability to adapt to changing priorities and demands Stress management: The ability to manage and cope with high levels of stress While these qualities and skills are essential for success in policing, it's important to note that policing is a constantly evolving profession. Officers must be willing to adapt to new technologies, best practices, and community needs. Ongoing training and professional development are crucial for staying up-to-date and providing the best possible service to the public.

title: Geraint Thomas gold in team pursuit: Congratulations for cyclist
text: Geraint Thomas etched his name into the Olympic history books once more as he helped Great Britain to gold in the men's team pursuit on Wednesday. The Welshman, who won the Tour de France in 2018, was part of the quartet that stormed to victory at the Izu Velodrome, setting a new Olympic record in the process. Thomas, Ethan Hayter, Ethan Vernon and Ollie Wood clocked a time of 3:45.636 to beat Denmark by more than a second, with Australia taking bronze. It is Thomas's second Olympic gold medal, having also triumphed in the team pursuit at the 2012 Games in London. Speaking after the race, Thomas said: "It's amazing. I can't believe we've done it. "We came here with a plan and we executed it perfectly. We rode our hearts out and we're so happy to have won." Thomas's victory is a fitting reward for years of hard work and dedication. His success is also a boost for British cycling, which has been struggling in recent years. Thomas's victory will inspire a new generation of cyclists and help to restore the nation's dominance in the sport. Thomas's gold medal is a moment to savor for British fans. It is a reminder of the country's rich cycling heritage and the talent that exists within the British team. Thomas's victory is also a testament to the power of teamwork. The four riders worked together seamlessly to achieve their goal, and their success is a reminder that anything is possible when people work together. Thomas and his teammates are now national heroes, and their victory will be celebrated for years to come. They have made history, and they have inspired a nation.

title: Indonesia post-election protests leave six dead in Jakarta
text: Indonesia Post-Election Protests Leave Six Dead in Jakarta Violent protests erupted in the Indonesian capital, Jakarta, after the announcement of the presidential election results, leaving at least six people dead and over 200 injured. The clashes began on Wednesday night, hours after the Electoral Commission declared incumbent President Joko Widodo the winner over his challenger, Prabowo Subianto. Subianto, a former general, has repeatedly rejected the results, alleging widespread fraud. Protesters set fire to vehicles and property in central Jakarta and clashed with security forces. Police fired tear gas and water cannons to disperse the crowds. Six people have been confirmed dead in the violence, including a police officer. Over 200 people have been injured, many of them suffering from breathing problems due to tear gas inhalation. The government has deployed additional security forces to restore order and imposed a temporary ban on public gatherings. President Widodo has called for calm and has urged protesters to respect the election results. "I urge the public to remain calm and not be provoked by any party that wants to create chaos," Widodo said in a televised address. "We must protect our democracy and uphold the rule of law." Subianto has not yet conceded defeat but has called for his supporters to refrain from violence. However, he has continued to allege irregularities in the election process. "We will continue to fight to defend the people's votes," Subianto said. "We will not give up until the truth is revealed." The protests are a reminder of Indonesia's troubled history with elections. In 1998, widespread protests led to the resignation of President Suharto after 32 years in power. International observers have expressed concern over the violence in Jakarta and have called on both sides to resolve their differences peacefully. "We urge all parties to exercise restraint and avoid further violence," a statement from the European Union said. "Indonesia has a long history of peaceful elections, and we hope that this will continue." The protests have also raised questions about the strength of Indonesia's democracy and the country's ability to manage its political differences peacefully.

title: Extinction Rebellion: Central London targeted despite ban
text: Central London was once again targeted by climate activists from Extinction Rebellion on Monday, despite a ban on demonstrations in the area. The group blocked several roads, including Waterloo Bridge, Oxford Circus, and Marble Arch, causing major disruption to traffic. The Metropolitan Police said they had arrested 14 people in connection with the protests. Extinction Rebellion said it was targeting central London because it is "the heart of the system that is destroying the planet." The group is calling for urgent action to tackle the climate crisis, including a shift to renewable energy and a reduction in meat consumption. "We are here to demand that the government take action on the climate crisis," said Extinction Rebellion spokesperson Zion Lights. "We are facing a climate emergency and we need to act now." The protests come just days after the government announced a new plan to tackle climate change. The plan includes measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, increase renewable energy use, and protect forests. However, Extinction Rebellion said the plan does not go far enough and that more needs to be done. "The government's plan is too little, too late," said Lights. "We need to see real action now, not more empty promises." The protests have been met with mixed reactions from the public. Some people support the activists' demands for action on climate change, while others believe that the protests are causing unnecessary disruption. The Metropolitan Police said they are "committed to facilitating peaceful protest while ensuring the safety of the public." The force said it will continue to monitor the protests and take action against anyone who breaks the law. Extinction Rebellion has said it plans to continue its protests until the government takes action on climate change. The group has said it is prepared to face arrest and imprisonment in order to get its message across. The climate crisis is one of the most pressing issues facing the world today. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has warned that we have only a few years left to take action to avoid the worst effects of climate change. The IPCC has said that we need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 45% by 2030 and reach net zero by 2050 in order to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius. The government's new plan to tackle climate change is a step in the right direction, but it does not go far enough. We need to see more ambitious action from the government and from all of us.

title: London 2012: Unauthorised Olympic branded goods seized
text: London 2012: Unauthorised Olympic branded goods seized More than £100,000 worth of unauthorised London 2012 Olympic branded goods have been seized by Trading Standards officers. The goods, which included t-shirts, mugs, key rings and other souvenirs, were found on sale at markets and shops across the UK. The London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games (LOCOG) said the goods were "unauthorised" and "infringed its intellectual property rights". LOCOG said it was working with Trading Standards to "protect the integrity" of the Olympic brand. A spokesman for LOCOG said: "We are very disappointed that people are trying to profit from the Olympic Games by selling unauthorised goods. "These goods are not only illegal, but they are also often of poor quality and do not meet the high standards that we expect for Olympic products." The spokesman said LOCOG was "determined to take action" against those who were selling unauthorised goods. "We will continue to work with Trading Standards to seize these goods and we will also be taking legal action against the sellers," he said. Trading Standards officers have been carrying out raids on markets and shops across the UK in recent weeks. In one raid in London, officers seized more than £50,000 worth of unauthorised Olympic goods. The goods were found on sale at a market stall in East London. The stallholder was arrested and charged with selling counterfeit goods. He is due to appear in court later this month. Trading Standards officers have also seized unauthorised Olympic goods in other parts of the UK, including Birmingham, Manchester and Glasgow. The officers are working with LOCOG to identify the source of the goods and to take action against those who are manufacturing and selling them. The sale of unauthorised Olympic goods is a criminal offence. Those who are caught selling these goods could face a fine or even a prison sentence. LOCOG has urged the public to be vigilant and to only buy Olympic goods from authorised retailers. The official London 2012 Olympic Games website has a list of authorised retailers.

title: Coronavirus: New mortgage holiday should affect credit record, says Nationwide boss
text: Coronavirus: New mortgage holiday should affect credit record, says Nationwide boss The boss of Nationwide has said he believes the new mortgage holiday introduced by the government should affect people's credit records. Joe Garner said that while the holiday was "the right thing to do", it was important to ensure that people did not take advantage of the situation. "We need to make sure that people who are genuinely struggling are able to get the help they need," he said. "But we also need to make sure that people who can afford to pay their mortgage don't take advantage of the situation." Under the new scheme, borrowers will be able to apply for a three-month mortgage holiday, which will be automatically approved by lenders. The government has said that this will not affect people's credit records. However, Garner said that he believes this is a mistake. "I think it's important that people understand that taking a mortgage holiday is a serious decision," he said. "It's not something that people should do lightly." He added that he was concerned that some people might take advantage of the holiday to stop paying their mortgage, even if they could afford to do so. "This could have a negative impact on their credit record and make it more difficult for them to get credit in the future," he said. Garner's comments come as the government is facing pressure to extend the mortgage holiday scheme. The current scheme is due to end on 31 October, but some campaigners are calling for it to be extended for a further six months. The government has said that it will keep the situation under review, but has not yet made a decision on whether to extend the scheme. The Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) has also said that it believes the mortgage holiday should affect people's credit records. "We believe that it is important to ensure that people who take advantage of the mortgage holiday are not disadvantaged in the future," the CML said in a statement. The CML said that it was working with lenders to develop a system that would allow them to track borrowers who had taken a mortgage holiday. This information would then be shared with credit reference agencies. The CML said that it believed this system would help to ensure that people who took advantage of the mortgage holiday did not have their credit records unfairly affected.

title: Russell Bishop trial: Jurors hear how bodies were found
text: In the ongoing Russell Bishop trial, jurors were presented with chilling details of the discovery of the bodies of Karen Hadaway and Nicola Fellows, the two young girls who were murdered in Brighton in 1986. Detective Constable Julian Oakes, a member of the team that responded to the scene, described how he found the girls' bodies in Wild Park, a secluded woodland area. He recalled that Karen's body was submerged in a stream, while Nicola's body was lying nearby on the bank. DC Oakes said that Karen's body had multiple stab wounds, including a fatal wound to the heart. Nicola's body had also been stabbed numerous times, and she had also suffered a head injury. The court heard that a forensic pathologist, Dr. Derek James, determined that both girls had died from "penetrating chest injuries caused by a sharp instrument." He testified that the injuries were consistent with those caused by a knife. Dr. James also noted that Karen's body had traces of semen, which suggested that she had been sexually assaulted. However, he said that there was no evidence of sexual assault on Nicola's body. The prosecution alleges that Bishop, who is now 54, killed the girls after sexually assaulting them. Bishop has denied both charges of murder and two charges of indecent assault. During cross-examination, Bishop's defense lawyer, Joel Bennathan QC, suggested that someone else could have killed the girls. He pointed out that there were no eyewitnesses to the murders and that the DNA evidence against Bishop was weak. However, the prosecution maintains that Bishop was responsible for the girls' deaths. They argue that he was the last person seen with the victims before they disappeared, and that his DNA was found on Karen's body. The trial, which is expected to last several weeks, continues at Hove Crown Court.

title: Mars probe returns first pictures
text: Mars Probe Returns First Pictures NASA's latest Mars probe, Perseverance, has returned its first images from the Red Planet, offering stunning views of the rugged Martian landscape. The probe landed successfully in Jezero Crater on Thursday, after a perilous journey of seven months and 300 million miles. Its mission is to search for signs of ancient life on Mars, a planet that scientists believe may once have harbored microbial organisms. The first images, transmitted back to Earth via NASA's Deep Space Network, show a desolate but intriguing landscape. The probe's landing site is located in a dried-up river delta, where scientists hope to find evidence of past water activity. One of the most striking features of the images is the sheer size and scale of the Martian terrain. The probe's landing site is surrounded by towering cliffs and canyons, suggesting a once-active and dynamic environment. NASA scientists are particularly interested in the presence of dark, layered rocks near the probe's landing site. These rocks are thought to have been formed by the deposition of sediments over time, potentially preserving traces of ancient life. The probe is equipped with a variety of scientific instruments, including cameras, spectrometers, and a rock-drilling system. Scientists will use these tools to analyze the surface composition, atmosphere, and geology of Mars. "These first images are a testament to the incredible precision and capabilities of Perseverance," said Thomas Zurbuchen, NASA's associate administrator for science. "They provide a tantalizing glimpse into the scientific treasures that await us on Mars." The probe's mission is expected to last at least two years. During that time, it will explore Jezero Crater, collect samples of rocks and soil, and search for signs of ancient life. Scientists hope that the probe's findings will shed new light on the history of Mars and its potential for habitability. The return of the first images from Perseverance marks a significant milestone in the exploration of Mars. It is the first time that a probe has been sent to the planet since the successful landing of NASA's Curiosity rover in 2012. The images have captured the imagination of scientists and the public alike, and they promise to provide valuable insights into the Red Planet and its potential for harboring life.

title: Luke Durbin disappearance: Police search Suffolk woods
text: Police officers and specialist search teams are scouring woodland in Suffolk after a man was reported missing. Luke Durbin, 28, was last seen in the Rickinghall area at around 9.15pm on Friday. title: Iraqi detainees beaten, inquiry told
text: Former Iraqi detainees have told a public inquiry that they were subjected to serious beatings and ill-treatment while in the custody of British troops. The allegations were made at the public inquiry into the death of Baha Mousa, a hotel receptionist who died in British custody in Basra in September 2003. The inquiry has heard that Mousa was beaten and subjected to other forms of abuse while in the custody of the Queen's Lancashire Regiment. The latest allegations came from two other Iraqi detainees who were held by British troops at the same time as Mousa. One of the detainees, Ahmed Jabbar Kareem, told the inquiry that he was beaten on the soles of his feet with a metal rod and that he was also punched and kicked in the face. He said that the beatings were carried out by British soldiers who were wearing balaclavas. Kareem said that he was also subjected to other forms of ill-treatment, including being forced to stand for long periods of time and being deprived of sleep. Another detainee, Hassan Said, told the inquiry that he was beaten on the head and body with a metal rod. He said that he was also punched and kicked in the face and that he was subjected to electric shocks. Said said that the beatings were carried out by British soldiers who were wearing balaclavas. The inquiry has heard that the British troops who were responsible for Mousa's death were part of a unit that had been involved in a number of other incidents of abuse. The inquiry is also investigating allegations that the British government covered up the extent of the abuse. The Ministry of Defence has admitted that there was a "catalogue of failures" in the way that Mousa was treated, but it has denied that there was a cover-up. The inquiry is expected to continue for several months.

title: Managers are heavier drinkers than manual workers
text: Managers More Likely than Manual Workers to Drink Heavily A new study has found that managers are more likely to drink heavily than manual workers, even after taking into account factors such as age, income, and education. The study, published in the journalAddiction*, surveyed over 1,000 working adults in the United Kingdom. The study found that managers were 1.5 times more likely to drink heavily than manual workers. Heavy drinking was defined as drinking more than 14 units of alcohol per week for men and more than seven units per week for women. The study also found that managers were more likely to binge drink, or have five or more drinks on a single occasion. Managers were 1.8 times more likely to binge drink than manual workers. The authors of the study say that the findings are concerning, given that heavy drinking is associated with a number of health problems, including liver disease, heart disease, and cancer. They also say that the findings suggest that managers may be under more stress than manual workers, which may be leading them to drink more heavily. "Managers have a higher prevalence of heavy drinking and binge drinking than manual workers, even after accounting for age, income, and education," said lead author Dr. Richard Stephens of the University of Sheffield. "This suggests that there may be something about the work environment of managers that is contributing to their increased risk of heavy drinking." Dr. Stephens and his colleagues say that further research is needed to investigate the factors that are contributing to the increased risk of heavy drinking among managers. They also say that interventions should be developed to help managers reduce their drinking. "Heavy drinking is a serious problem that can have a devastating impact on the health of individuals and their families," said Dr. Stephens. "We need to do more to understand the factors that are contributing to heavy drinking among managers and to develop interventions to help them reduce their drinking." In the meantime, Dr. Stephens recommends that managers who are concerned about their drinking should talk to their doctor or a mental health professional. Help is available, and there is no shame in seeking help.

title: Alton Towers Smiler crash: Park closed for weekend
text: Alton Towers Smiler crash: Park closed for weekend Alton Towers has closed for the weekend after a rollercoaster crash that left four people seriously injured. title: Retail: Chain shop closures outweigh new stores opening
text: Chain Shop Closures Outweigh New Store Openings The number of UK chain store closures has outstripped the number of new store openings for the first time since records began in 2010. Figures from the Local Data Company show that there were 7,814 store closures in 2022, compared to just 4,290 new openings. This represents a net loss of 3,524 stores, the highest level of net closures on record. The retail sector has been hit hard by a number of factors in recent years, including the rise of online shopping, the COVID-19 pandemic, and the cost-of-living crisis. These factors have made it increasingly difficult for bricks-and-mortar stores to compete, leading to a wave of closures. Some of the most high-profile store closures in recent months include M&S, John Lewis, and Debenhams. These closures have left large gaps in shopping centers and high streets across the UK, and have had a significant impact on local economies. The rise of online shopping has been a major factor in the decline of the high street. Consumers are increasingly choosing to shop online for convenience, choice, and price. This has led to a decline in footfall in shopping centers and high streets, making it more difficult for bricks-and-mortar stores to survive. The COVID-19 pandemic has also had a major impact on the retail sector. Lockdowns and social distancing measures forced many stores to close, and even when they were allowed to reopen, footfall was significantly reduced. This led to a sharp decline in sales for many retailers, and many were unable to recover. The cost-of-living crisis is another factor that has contributed to the decline of the high street. With inflation rising and consumers facing higher energy and food bills, they are cutting back on non-essential spending. This has led to a further decline in sales for many retailers. The decline of the high street is a major concern for local authorities and policymakers. Retail is a major source of employment and economic activity, and the closure of stores can have a significant impact on local communities. There are a number of things that can be done to support the high street, including: Investing in regeneration projects to make shopping centers and high streets more attractive to shoppers Providing financial support to retailers, such as business rates relief and grants Encouraging the development of mixed-use developments that combine retail with other uses, such as housing or leisure Promoting local businesses and independent retailers It is important to remember that the high street is not dead. There are still many people who enjoy shopping in physical stores, and there are many retailers who are adapting to the changing retail landscape. By supporting the high street, we can help to create vibrant and sustainable local communities.

title: Sir Quentin Thomas retires from BBFC after 10 years
text: After a decade of dedicated service, Sir Quentin Thomas has announced his retirement as the Director of the British Board of Film Classification (BBFC). During his tenure, he has overseen significant changes in the film classification landscape, guided by his unwavering commitment to protecting children and empowering audiences. Under his leadership, the board has embraced the evolving digital landscape, adapting its classification system to address the challenges and opportunities presented by online streaming platforms. One of Sir Quentin's key initiatives has been the introduction of the "12A" classification, which allows children aged 12 and over to watch certain films accompanied by an adult. This has provided greater flexibility for families, while ensuring that appropriate safeguards are in place. He has also championed transparency and accountability within the classification process. The BBFC has introduced a new online platform where members of the public can engage with the board's decisions and provide input. Sir Quentin's commitment to protecting children has been unwavering. He has strengthened the board's collaboration with law enforcement agencies and industry partners to combat the illegal distribution of harmful content. Beyond his work at the BBFC, Sir Quentin has made significant contributions to the broader field of media regulation. He has served as the President of the International Federation of Film Classification, representing the UK alongside other key classification bodies worldwide. As he steps down from his role, Sir Quentin leaves behind a legacy of innovation and dedication. He has played a crucial role in ensuring that the BBFC remains a trusted and respected institution, protecting children and supporting the UK's vibrant film industry. The BBFC has paid tribute to Sir Quentin's leadership, stating that he "will be greatly missed." title: PC Semple murder: Witness heard 'someone throwing up on the carpet'

title: Dermot O'Leary returns 'home' to The X Factor
text: In a nostalgic homecoming, Dermot O'Leary is set to make his triumphant return as the host of The X Factor, the show that catapulted him to fame two decades ago. O'Leary's appointment marks a full-circle moment for both the presenter and the talent competition, which is undergoing a major revamp for its 16th season. His familiar face and infectious enthusiasm promise to bring a sense of familiarity and warmth to a show that is embracing both the past and the future. As the longest-serving presenter of The X Factor, O'Leary's departure in 2015 left a void that fans struggled to fill. His rapport with the contestants, his witty banter, and his ability to connect with viewers on a personal level made him an indispensable part of the show's DNA. Now, with The X Factor returning to its original broadcaster, ITV, O'Leary's return coincides with a renewed sense of optimism for the show. The upcoming season will feature a revamped judging panel, including Simon Cowell, Nicole Scherzinger, and new additions Robbie Williams and Ayda Field. O'Leary's return is also a testament to his enduring popularity as one of the UK's most beloved TV personalities. Since leaving The X Factor, he has hosted a string of successful shows, including The Nightly Show and This Morning. His versatility and charisma have made him a sought-after presenter, and his return to The X Factor is a clear indication of his enduring appeal. For O'Leary, the opportunity to reconnect with the show that first brought him into the public eye is a chance to revisit his roots and share his infectious energy with a new generation of contestants and viewers. As he steps back into the X Factor spotlight, O'Leary will undoubtedly bring with him a wealth of experience and a deep understanding of what makes the show so special. His return is a symbol of change and continuity, a reminder of the show's enduring legacy while embracing the fresh possibilities that lie ahead. With Dermot O'Leary at the helm once again, The X Factor is set for a season that promises to be filled with nostalgia, excitement, and unforgettable moments. His return is not merely a homecoming; it is a celebration of the show's past, present, and future.

title: Coronavirus: Middlesbrough school 'hit hard' by 40 bereavements
text: Coronavirus: Middlesbrough school 'hit hard' by 40 bereavements A school in Middlesbrough has been "hit hard" by the coronavirus pandemic, with 40 members of its community having died. Head teacher of St Mary's Catholic College, John Foley, said the school was "devastated" by the loss of so many lives. He said the school had been "doing everything we can" to support students and staff during the difficult time. "We have had a number of bereavements in our school community due to Covid-19," he said. "It has been a very difficult time for everyone, and we are all still coming to terms with the losses. "We have been doing everything we can to support our students and staff during this difficult time." The school has set up a memorial garden in memory of those who have died. Mr Foley said the garden was a "place of peace and reflection" for the school community. "The memorial garden is a place where we can remember those who have died and celebrate their lives," he said. "It is also a place where we can come together as a community and support each other." The school has also set up a support group for students and staff who have been affected by the pandemic. The group meets regularly to share their experiences and offer each other support. Mr Foley said the support group had been a "valuable" resource for the school community. "The support group has been a great way for our students and staff to come together and share their experiences," he said. "It has been a valuable resource for our school community during this difficult time." The school has also been working with local organizations to provide support to the wider community. The school has been working with the local food bank to provide food to families in need. The school has also been working with the local mental health charity to provide support to people who are struggling with their mental health. Mr Foley said the school was committed to supporting the local community during the pandemic. "We are committed to supporting our local community during this difficult time," he said. "We are working with local organizations to provide support to those who need it. "We are all in this together, and we will get through this together."

title: Danny Jones sword killing: Oswestry man Richard Reece jailed
text: An Oswestry man has been jailed for killing his neighbor, Danny Jones, with a samurai sword in 2021. Richard Reece, 49, admitted to the manslaughter of Mr. Jones following a late-night confrontation outside their homes in Maesbury Road, Oswestry, on 28 July 2021. Mold Crown Court heard on Friday, May 6, 2023, that Reece had gone next door to Mr. Jones' house just before midnight, armed with a samurai sword, after he had been drinking heavily and taking cocaine. The pair, who had been neighbors for around 20 years, had an ongoing dispute. Prosecuting barrister Elen Owen said that CCTV footage from that night captured Mr. Jones coming to his door where he was met by Reece. "Words were exchanged before Reece swung the sword and it struck Mr. Jones to the left side of his neck. He managed to return to his house and raised the alarm. Paramedics rushed to the scene and Mr. Jones was taken to the Royal Shrewsbury Hospital, but he tragically died in the early hours of the following morning," Ms. Owen said. The jury heard that Reece had initially denied any involvement in Mr. Jones' death but later admitted manslaughter. The court heard that there had been "significant animosity" between the two men, with Mr. Jones having called the police to Reece's house on four occasions in the two years leading up to his death. Ms. Owen said that the dispute had been "trivial," but it had "escalated out of all proportion." "There had been complaints about loud music and DIY noise, and a boundary dispute," she said. In his defense, Reece told the court that Mr. Jones had come at him with a knife that night and that he had struck out with the sword in self-defense. "I didn't mean to kill him," he said. The jury rejected Reece's version of events and convicted him of manslaughter. Sentencing Reece, Judge Niclas Parry said that the defendant had "taken an innocent man's life in drink-fueled rage." "You armed yourself with a deadly weapon and you went next door to confront a man who posed no threat to you. "You have deprived a family of a much-loved husband and father, and a community of a respected member," Judge Parry said. Reece was sentenced to nine years in prison.

title: Toy firm VTech fined $650,000 over data breach
text: Toy firm VTech fined $650,000 over data breach VTech, a Hong Kong-based toy company, has been fined $650,000 by the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) for failing to protect the personal information of children. The FTC found that VTech had collected and stored the personal information of more than 6 million children, including their names, addresses, birthdates, and genders, without properly securing it. This information was later accessed by hackers in a 2015 data breach. The FTC also found that VTech had not taken reasonable steps to protect the security of its network, which allowed the hackers to gain access to the children's personal information. The FTC's complaint alleges that VTech violated the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA), which requires companies that collect personal information from children under the age of 13 to obtain parental consent and to protect the security of that information. In addition to the fine, the FTC has ordered VTech to implement a comprehensive security program to protect the personal information of children. This program must include measures to: Secure VTech's network and systems Train VTech employees on data security best practices Regularly monitor VTech's systems for security vulnerabilities Respond to security incidents quickly and effectively The FTC's action against VTech is a reminder that companies that collect personal information from children have a legal obligation to protect that information. Companies that fail to do so may face significant penalties. Parents should be aware of the risks of sharing their children's personal information online. They should only share this information with companies that they trust to protect it. Parents should also talk to their children about the importance of protecting their personal information online. Here are some tips for parents to help protect their children's personal information online: Only share your child's personal information with companies that you trust to protect it. Talk to your child about the importance of protecting their personal information online. Teach your child to be careful about what information they share online. Monitor your child's online activity. title: New 'revenge porn' law comes into force in Scotland

title: More UK students consider study abroad, poll suggests
text: More UK students are considering studying abroad, according to a new poll. title: Clegg - A very botched coup
text: In the annals of political blunders, the botched coup of Nick Clegg will be remembered as a masterclass in self-inflicted harm. Elected as Deputy Prime Minister in 2010 as part of the coalition government with the Conservative Party, Clegg's popularity soared. He was seen as a fresh face in politics, articulating the concerns of the Liberal Democrats, a party of social justice and environmentalism. However, Clegg's star began to wane as the coalition government made unpopular decisions in response to the financial crisis. The Liberal Democrats became increasingly marginalized, and Clegg's own credibility took a hit. In an attempt to revive his dwindling fortunes, Clegg announced in 2015 that he would step down as leader of the Liberal Democrats. The move was widely seen as an attempt to distance himself from the unpopular coalition government and position himself as a potential future Prime Minister. But Clegg's plan backfired spectacularly. His resignation triggered a leadership contest in which he was defeated by Tim Farron, a backbencher with no government experience. Farron's victory exposed the deep divisions within the Liberal Democrats and further damaged Clegg's reputation. Undeterred, Clegg remained in Parliament and continued to voice his opinions. However, his interventions were increasingly ignored, and his influence dwindled to the point where he became a political irrelevance. In 2017, Clegg announced that he would not be standing for re-election. His parliamentary career ended with a whimper, a far cry from the glory days of 2010. The botched coup of Nick Clegg serves as a cautionary tale about the dangers of hubris and the importance of staying true to one's beliefs. Clegg's attempt to reinvent himself as a potential Prime Minister failed because it was based on a fundamental misreading of the political landscape. By compromising his principles and alienating his base, Clegg ultimately destroyed his own political career. He became a cautionary tale about the perils of forgetting one's roots and chasing after the false promises of power.

title: US government set to give up net oversight powers
text: The United States government is preparing to relinquish its oversight authority over the internet's addressing system, a move that could have significant implications for the way the web is governed. For decades, the US government has played a central role in managing the internet's domain name system (DNS), which translates website addresses into numerical IP addresses that computers can understand. This has given the US a significant degree of control over the internet's infrastructure and has allowed it to set policies for how the DNS is used. However, in recent years, there have been growing calls for the US to give up its oversight of the DNS. Critics argue that the US government's control over the internet is outdated and that it gives the US too much power to censor and control online content. In response to these concerns, the US government has announced that it will begin to transition oversight of the DNS to a new, international organization. The new organization, which is still being formed, will be responsible for managing the DNS and setting policies for its use. The US government's decision to give up its oversight of the DNS is a significant development that could have far-reaching implications for the way the internet is governed. It is still unclear how the new organization will operate and what policies it will set, but the move is likely to lead to a more decentralized and less US-centric internet. Here are some of the potential implications of the US government's decision to give up its oversight of the DNS: Increased competition and innovation. A more decentralized internet could lead to increased competition and innovation in the DNS market. New companies could emerge to offer alternative DNS services, and existing companies could be forced to improve their services in order to compete. Reduced government control. A more decentralized internet would reduce the US government's control over the internet. This could make it more difficult for the government to censor or control online content. Increased security risks. A more decentralized internet could also increase security risks. With multiple organizations managing the DNS, it could become more difficult to identify and mitigate security threats. The US government's decision to give up its oversight of the DNS is a complex issue with far-reaching implications. It is still too early to say what the full impact of this decision will be, but it is clear that the internet is entering a new era of governance.

title: Walsall Acorns children's hospice to close

title: Autism is largely down to genes, twins study suggests
text: Autism is largely down to genes, twins study suggests Autism is a complex developmental condition that affects an individual's ability to communicate and interact with others. Now, new research suggests that genetics plays a major role in determining whether someone will develop the condition. The study, published in the journal Nature Genetics, looked at data from more than 2,000 pairs of twins. Half of the twin pairs were identical, meaning that they shared 100% of their genes, while the other half were fraternal, meaning that they shared only 50% of their genes. The researchers found that identical twins were much more likely to both have autism than fraternal twins. This suggests that there is a strong genetic component to autism. The study also found that the genetic risk of autism is higher in males than in females. This is consistent with previous research that has shown that autism is more common in boys than in girls. The researchers say that their findings could help to identify new genes that are involved in autism. This could lead to the development of new treatments for the condition. Dr. James Cusick, who led the study, said: "Our findings provide strong evidence that genetics plays a major role in the development of autism. "This is an important step forward in our understanding of the condition, and it could lead to new treatments for autism." The study was funded by the National Institute of Mental Health. What is autism? Autism is a complex developmental condition that affects an individual's ability to communicate and interact with others. Symptoms of autism can include: Difficulty with social interactions Difficulty with communication Repetitive behaviors Restricted interests Autism is a spectrum disorder, meaning that the symptoms can vary from mild to severe. There is no cure for autism, but there are treatments that can help to improve the symptoms. These treatments may include: Speech therapy Occupational therapy Physical therapy Behavioral therapy Medication What causes autism? The exact cause of autism is unknown, but it is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. The new study suggests that genetics plays a major role in the development of autism. This is consistent with previous research that has shown that autism is more common in families with a history of the condition. However, it is important to note that genetics are not the only factor that contributes to autism. Environmental factors, such as exposure to toxins, may also play a role. How is autism diagnosed? Autism is typically diagnosed by a healthcare professional, such as a pediatrician or child psychiatrist. The diagnosis is based on the child's behavior and development. There is no single test for autism, but there are a number of screening tools that can help to identify children who may be at risk for the condition. What is the treatment for autism? There is no cure for autism, but there are treatments that can help to improve the symptoms. These treatments may include: Speech therapy Occupational therapy Physical therapy Behavioral therapy Medication The type of treatment that is recommended for a child with autism will depend on the child's individual needs.

text: Another Cardiff Bay private flat block has failed its cladding test, raising concerns about the safety of residents. Cardiff council said the building's cladding had been tested and found to be combustible, meaning it could catch fire easily. The council said it was working with the building's management company to ensure that the cladding was replaced as quickly as possible. The news comes as a blow to residents of the Infinity building, who are now facing the prospect of having to pay for the cost of replacing the cladding. The cost of replacing the cladding on the Grenfell Tower was estimated to be £10m. One resident, who did not want to be named, said: "This is really worrying news. I'm concerned about the safety of my family and I'm also worried about the cost of replacing the cladding. I don't know how I'm going to afford it." The Infinity building is the fourth private block in Cardiff Bay to fail cladding tests. The council also said it was urging the government to take action to ensure that all buildings with combustible cladding were made safe. A spokesman for the council said: "We are doing everything we can to ensure that all buildings in Cardiff Bay are safe. title: Killer Brett Rogers' mum had 'no choice' in having him back home
text: In a shocking turn of events, the mother of convicted killer Brett Rogers has revealed that she had "no choice" but to let her son move back into her home upon his release from prison. Rogers, 34, was convicted of murdering his girlfriend, Sarah Payne, in 2000. He was sentenced to life in prison but was released on parole in 2021 after serving 21 years. His mother, Julie, said she had been forced to take him in as he had nowhere else to go. She told the BBC: "I didn't want him back here. I was terrified of what he might do. But I had no choice. He's my son and I couldn't just leave him on the streets." Julie admitted that she was scared of her son, but said she was determined to help him reintegrate into society. "I know he did a terrible thing," she said. "But he's paid his debt to society. He deserves a second chance." Rogers' release has sparked outrage among the public, with many people calling for Julie to be prosecuted for aiding a known criminal. However, Julie insists that she is not condoning her son's actions. "I'm not saying what he did was right," she said. "But I believe that everyone deserves a second chance." Julie's decision to take Rogers in has raised important questions about the role of family in the rehabilitation of offenders. Is it ever right to let a known criminal back into your home? And what does it say about our society that we are so quick to condemn those who have committed crimes, even when they have served their time? Experts say that it is important to remember that not all offenders are the same. Some are genuinely remorseful for their actions and are committed to changing their ways. Others, however, are more likely to reoffend. It is up to each individual family to decide whether or not they are willing to take the risk of letting a convicted criminal back into their home. There is no easy answer, and there is no right or wrong decision. In the case of Brett Rogers, it is clear that his mother loves him unconditionally. She is willing to put her own fears aside in order to give him a second chance. Whether or not this is the right decision, only time will tell.

title: Nigel Farage says Labour has 'abandoned' its pro-Brexit voters
text: Nigel Farage has accused the Labour party of "abandoning" its pro-Brexit voters after the party announced it would back a second referendum on the UK's membership of the European Union. Speaking to the BBC, Mr Farage said that Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn had "completely betrayed" the working-class voters who had supported the party in the last election. "Labour has always been the party of the working class," he said. "But now they've abandoned them in favour of the metropolitan elite." Mr Farage's comments come after Labour announced that it would support a second referendum on Brexit, even if it meant campaigning to remain in the EU. The decision has been met with anger from some Labour MPs, who argue that it will alienate the party's traditional working-class voters. However, Mr Corbyn has defended the decision, saying that it is the only way to "break the Brexit deadlock" and give the public a say on their future. "We have to respect the result of the referendum," he said. "But we also have to give people a chance to have their say on the final deal." The Labour party is now facing a difficult choice. If it goes ahead with its plan to support a second referendum, it risks alienating its traditional working-class voters. However, if it does not support a second referendum, it risks losing the support of its younger, more pro-European voters. The decision is likely to have a major impact on the outcome of the next general election. In response to Mr Farage's comments, a Labour spokesperson said: "The Labour party is committed to delivering Brexit. We will respect the result of the referendum, but we will also give people a say on the final deal." The spokesperson added that the party was "determined to build a country that works for everyone, not just the privileged few." The decision by Labour to support a second referendum has been welcomed by some, but it has also been met with criticism. Those who support the decision argue that it is the only way to break the Brexit deadlock and give the public a say on their future. However, those who oppose the decision argue that it will alienate the party's traditional working-class voters and make it more difficult to deliver Brexit. The decision is likely to have a major impact on the outcome of the next general election.

title: Sri Lanka clashes hit peace hopes
text: In Sri Lanka, violent clashes between security forces and protesters have cast a shadow over hopes for lasting peace. The unrest, sparked by an unprecedented economic crisis, has raised fears of a return to the country's bloody past. For decades, Sri Lanka has been plagued by a bitter ethnic conflict between the majority Sinhalese and the minority Tamils. The civil war, which lasted from 1983 to 2009, claimed the lives of tens of thousands of people. After the war ended, the government promised to address the grievances of the Tamil community and promote reconciliation. However, progress has been slow, and many Tamils feel that they have been marginalized and discriminated against. The current economic crisis has exacerbated these tensions. The country is facing soaring inflation, a shortage of essential goods, and a massive increase in unemployment. The government has been unable to stem the crisis, and public anger has been growing. In recent weeks, protests have erupted across the country, demanding the resignation of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa and his government. The protests have been largely peaceful, but there have been some violent incidents. On July 13, security forces opened fire on protesters in Colombo, killing at least eight people and injuring hundreds more. The shooting has sparked outrage and condemnation both within Sri Lanka and internationally. The violence has raised fears that Sri Lanka could be on the verge of another civil war. The country is deeply divided, and there is a lack of trust between the government and the Tamil community. The international community is watching the situation in Sri Lanka with growing concern. The United Nations has called for an independent investigation into the July 13 shooting, and the United States has expressed its "grave concern" about the violence. Sri Lanka's future is uncertain. The country has a long history of conflict, and the current economic crisis has only made things worse. It is essential that the government takes steps to address the grievances of the Tamil community and to promote reconciliation. Without these steps, Sri Lanka's hopes for lasting peace will remain elusive.

title: 'Kylie Jenner, wow, being in a wheelchair is so fun and fashionable!'
text: Kylie Jenner, the youngest billionaire in the world, has sparked controversy after posting a series of photos on Instagram showing her posing in a wheelchair. The photos, which have since been deleted, were met with mixed reactions, with some people praising Jenner for raising awareness of disability and others criticizing her for glamorizing it. In the photos, Jenner is seen wearing a black crop top and matching sweatpants, along with a pair of high heels. She is sitting in a wheelchair with her legs crossed, and she is looking at the camera with a smile. The caption on the photos reads, "Wow, being in a wheelchair is so fun and fashionable!" The photos quickly went viral, and they were met with a range of reactions. Some people praised Jenner for raising awareness of disability, while others criticized her for glamorizing it. "I think it's great that Kylie Jenner is using her platform to raise awareness of disability," said one commenter. "She's showing people that people with disabilities can be just as stylish and fashionable as anyone else." "I'm not sure how I feel about these photos," said another commenter. "On the one hand, I think it's great that Kylie Jenner is showing people that people with disabilities can be just as stylish and fashionable as anyone else. On the other hand, I worry that she's glamorizing disability and making it seem like something that's fun and trendy." Jenner has not responded to the controversy, but she has since deleted the photos from her Instagram account. The debate over Jenner's photos highlights the complex and often contradictory ways that disability is portrayed in the media. On the one hand, there is a growing movement of people with disabilities who are working to challenge stereotypes and promote a more inclusive view of disability. On the other hand, there are still many instances of people with disabilities being portrayed in a way that is demeaning or disrespectful. It is important to remember that disability is not a fashion statement. It is a complex and multifaceted aspect of human experience, and it should be treated with respect and understanding.

title: New Aberdeen FC Kingsford stadium plans approved
text: New Aberdeen FC Kingsford Stadium Plans Approved Aberdeen City Council has approved plans for a new stadium for Aberdeen Football Club, to be built on the site of the former Kingsford industrial estate. The new stadium, which will have a capacity of around 20,000, will replace the club's current home at Pittodrie Stadium. The new stadium is expected to cost around £100 million and will be funded by a combination of private investment, public funding, and a loan from the Scottish Government. Aberdeen FC chairman Dave Cormack said: "This is a historic day for Aberdeen Football Club. We have been working on this project for many years and we are delighted that it has finally been approved.
