Aberdeen City Council leader Jenny Laing said: "This is a significant investment in Aberdeen and we are confident that the new stadium will be a major asset to the city. "It will not only provide a new home for Aberdeen FC, but it will also create jobs and boost the local economy. We are delighted to have played a part in making this project a reality." The new stadium is expected to be completed by 2025. It will be located on the site of the former Kingsford industrial estate, which is next to the A90 Aberdeen Western Peripheral Route. The stadium will be designed by Populous, the architects behind the London Stadium and the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium. It will feature a state-of-the-art pitch, modern seating, and a range of hospitality facilities. The new stadium will be a major boost for Aberdeen FC, who have ambitious plans to return to the top flight of Scottish football. It will also be a major benefit to the city, providing a new focal point for the community and attracting visitors from all over the world.

title: South Georgia whaling: Antarctic art marks a dark past
text: Amidst the pristine glaciers and abundant wildlife of South Georgia, a poignant reminder of a dark past lingers in the form of whaling art. These haunting images, etched into the fabric of the island's history, bear witness to an industry that once threatened the very existence of the majestic creatures that inhabit these icy waters. In the late 18th century, South Georgia became a hub for whalers seeking the lucrative spoils of the Southern Ocean. As the industry boomed, whaling stations sprang up along the island's coastline, processing vast quantities of whale oil and baleen. This relentless pursuit of profit exacted a devastating toll on whale populations, pushing some species to the brink of extinction. To document their macabre trade, whalers commissioned artists to capture the gruesome spectacle of the hunt. These paintings and sketches offer a chilling glimpse into the industrial-scale killing that occurred on South Georgia. Whaleboats, their occupants armed with harpoons and lances, swarm around colossal whales, blood staining the icy waters red. The colossal carcasses, their bodies flayed and blubber stripped, lie frozen on the decks of whaling ships, a testament to the industry's relentless greed. Beyond their historical value, these works also reveal the artistry and craftsmanship of the whalers themselves. Despite their involvement in a brutal trade, many of these men were skilled scrimshaw carvers and amateur painters. Their intricate carvings on whalebone and ivory depict scenes from daily life at the whaling stations, capturing both the camaraderie and the hardships endured by the crews. Today, these haunting artworks serve as a powerful reminder of the devastating impact of human exploitation on the natural world. They stand as a testament to the fragility of marine ecosystems and the importance of conservation. As visitors explore South Georgia, these images confront them with the dark legacy of the whaling era, encouraging reflection on the need to protect and preserve the island's pristine environment for generations to come. While whaling has long ceased on South Georgia, its legacy continues to shape the island's identity. The abandoned whaling stations, now crumbling ruins, serve as poignant reminders of an era that left an indelible mark on both the landscape and the hearts of those who witnessed it. And as the island's wildlife thrives once more, these haunting artworks stand as a reminder of the resilience of nature and the importance of learning from the mistakes of the past.

title: Colombia and Farc rebels chart course for peace talks
text: Colombia and Farc Rebels Chart Course for Peace Talks After decades of armed conflict, Colombia and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc) are poised to embark on a fresh round of peace negotiations. Representatives from both sides have met in Oslo, Norway, to lay the groundwork for talks that they hope will end one of the longest-running civil wars in the world. The conflict between the Colombian government and the Farc has claimed the lives of hundreds of thousands of people and displaced millions more. In recent years, the fighting has subsided somewhat, but violence continues to flare up in parts of the country. The new peace talks come at a time when both sides are facing pressure to end the conflict. The Colombian government is under pressure from its citizens to achieve a lasting peace, while the Farc is facing pressure from its own members to lay down its arms. The talks are expected to be complex and difficult. The two sides have a long history of mistrust, and there are many issues that need to be resolved, including the future of Farc fighters and the return of land to displaced people. However, there is also a sense of hope that this time could be different. The Colombian government and the Farc have both expressed a commitment to peace, and they have agreed to a set of ground rules for the talks. The talks are being facilitated by Norway and Cuba, which have played a similar role in other peace processes around the world. The two countries will provide a neutral venue for the talks and will help the two sides to overcome obstacles. The peace talks are a major step forward for Colombia. If they are successful, they could bring an end to decades of violence and suffering. However, it is important to remember that the talks are just the beginning of a long and difficult process. There will be setbacks and disappointments along the way, but both sides are committed to achieving a lasting peace. The following are some of the key issues that will be discussed in the peace talks: The future of Farc fighters: The Farc is a guerrilla army with an estimated 8,000 fighters. The government wants the Farc to disarm and demobilize, while the Farc wants guarantees that its members will not be prosecuted for their crimes. The return of land to displaced people: Millions of Colombians have been displaced from their homes due to the conflict. The government wants to return land to these people, but the Farc wants to ensure that the land is not used for illegal activities. The political participation of the Farc: The Farc wants to be able to participate in politics after the conflict is over. The government is willing to consider this, but it wants to ensure that the Farc does not use its political power to promote violence.

title: Coronavirus: Court action threatened over school meal vouchers
text: Coronavirus: Court action threatened over school meal vouchers Campaigners are threatening legal action against the government over its failure to provide free school meals over the summer holidays. The voucher scheme, which was introduced during the first lockdown, was not extended over the summer by the government, despite calls from charities and teaching unions. A group of parents and food poverty campaigners are now seeking a judicial review of the government's decision, arguing that it is unlawful and discriminatory. The group is being supported by the Good Law Project, a not-for-profit organisation that uses the law to protect the public interest. Jo Maugham, the director of the Good Law Project, said: "The government's decision to end free school meals over the summer holidays is a disgrace. It is unlawful and discriminatory, and it will have a devastating impact on the poorest families in our society." The campaigners argue that the government's decision is unlawful because it breaches the Equality Act 2010. The act prohibits discrimination on the grounds of race, gender, disability, religion or belief, sexual orientation, age, or socio-economic status. The campaigners also argue that the government's decision is discriminatory because it will have a disproportionate impact on children from low-income families. A Department for Education spokesperson said: "We understand that many families are facing financial challenges at this time, which is why we have provided a range of support, including increasing Universal Credit by £20 a week and providing local authorities with £63 million to support families with food and essential items." The government has also said that it will provide £120 million to councils to help them provide food support to vulnerable families over the summer holidays. However, the campaigners argue that this is not enough and that the government should reinstate the free school meals voucher scheme. The judicial review is expected to be heard in the High Court in the coming weeks. Impact of the decision The government's decision to end free school meals over the summer holidays has been met with widespread criticism. Charities and teaching unions have warned that it will have a devastating impact on the poorest families in our society. A survey by the Food Foundation found that 44% of parents said that they would struggle to feed their children over the summer holidays without free school meals. The government's decision has also been condemned by the United Nations. The UN's Special Rapporteur on extreme poverty and human rights, Olivier De Schutter, said that the decision was "a violation of the right to food of children living in poverty".

title: Arrests as fracking gets green light at Preston New Road site
text: Police make arrests as fracking gets green light at Preston New Road site Lancashire Police have made a number of arrests as protesters gathered at the Preston New Road fracking site following the government's decision to approve the project. Energy firm Cuadrilla has been given the go-ahead to start exploratory drilling at the site near Blackpool, despite strong opposition from local residents and environmental campaigners. Protesters have been camped out at the site for several months, and on Monday they blocked access to the site in an attempt to prevent Cuadrilla from starting work. Police were called to the scene and made a number of arrests. It is understood that the arrests were for offences including obstruction of the highway and public order offences. Cuadrilla said it was "disappointed" by the protests and said it was "committed to working with the community to address any concerns". The company said it had "taken all necessary steps to ensure that our operations are safe and environmentally responsible". However, opponents of fracking say the process is dangerous and could cause environmental damage. They also say that Cuadrilla has not properly consulted with the local community. The government has said that fracking is a "safe and necessary" way to extract gas from the UK's shale rock formations. However, the decision to approve the Preston New Road project has been met with widespread criticism. Environmental campaigners say the government is "ignoring the will of the people" and that fracking will damage the environment and harm human health. Local residents say they are concerned about the noise, pollution and traffic that fracking will bring to their area. The Preston New Road project is the first fracking project to be approved in the UK since 2019. The government has said that it hopes fracking will help to reduce the UK's reliance on imported gas. However, opponents of fracking say that the process is not economically viable and that it will not reduce the UK's carbon emissions. The Preston New Road project is expected to start drilling in the coming weeks. It is not yet clear how long the drilling will take or whether Cuadrilla will be successful in finding commercially viable quantities of gas.

title: Poorer seven-year-old pupils' improvement short of target
text: The progress of disadvantaged pupils in England has fallen well short of the government's target, figures suggest. The gap between the poorest and richest seven-year-olds in English and maths has narrowed since 2011, but not by as much as the government had hoped. Ministers said they were "disappointed" but that progress was being made. The figures come amid criticism that the government's focus on grammar and phonics is failing to improve standards in the long term. The data, published by the Department for Education, shows that the gap between pupils from poorer homes and their wealthier peers has narrowed by 7% in reading, 5% in writing and 10% in maths since 2011. This means that, on average, a child from the poorest fifth of homes is now about eight months behind a wealthier peer in reading and writing, and six months behind in maths. But the government's ambition was to narrow the gap by 12% in reading, writing and maths by 2020. Education Secretary Damian Hinds said: "I am disappointed that the gap between disadvantaged pupils and their peers has not narrowed as much as we would have liked. "But we are making progress and will continue to work tirelessly to give every child, regardless of their background, the best possible start in life." Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said the figures showed that the government's focus on grammar and phonics was "not enough on its own to improve standards in the long term". "We need a broader curriculum that develops children's critical thinking and problem-solving skills," he said. The Sutton Trust, an education charity, said the figures were "a wake-up call for the government". "The gap between rich and poor pupils is still far too wide," said its chief executive, James Turner. "We need to see a step change in the government's approach if we are going to close this gap and give all children the opportunity to succeed." The National Education Union said the figures were "a damning indictment of the government's education policies". "Ministers have focused on narrow measures such as phonics and grammar, and neglected other essential areas such as creativity and critical thinking," said its joint general secretary, Kevin Courtney. "This has failed our poorest children and left them even further behind."

title: Medicine supply chains to change post Brexit, MPs told
text: Medicine supply chains to change post-Brexit, MPs told The UK's departure from the EU will necessitate significant changes to the way medicines are supplied to the UK, members of Parliament have been told. The Health and Social Care Committee heard from experts that the current system, which relies heavily on imports from the EU, is unsustainable in the long term. The committee was told that the UK needs to develop its own manufacturing capacity and diversify its supply chains to ensure that it is not reliant on any one country for its medicines. The UK government has said that it is committed to ensuring that the supply of medicines is not disrupted after Brexit. However, the committee heard that there are a number of challenges that need to be addressed, including: The need to secure new trade deals with other countries The need to increase the UK's manufacturing capacity The need to develop new supply chains The committee was told that the UK government is working on a number of initiatives to address these challenges, including: The establishment of a new Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) The launch of a new £200 million fund to support the development of new medicines manufacturing facilities in the UK The development of a new trade policy that will give the UK greater flexibility to negotiate new trade deals The committee welcomed these initiatives, but said that more needs to be done to ensure that the UK is prepared for Brexit. The committee's chair, Jeremy Hunt, said: "The UK's departure from the EU will have a significant impact on the way medicines are supplied to the UK. It is essential that the government takes steps now to ensure that there is no disruption to the supply of medicines after Brexit." The committee's report makes a number of recommendations to the government, including: The government should develop a comprehensive strategy for ensuring the supply of medicines after Brexit The government should increase the UK's manufacturing capacity for medicines The government should diversify the UK's supply chains for medicines The government should work with other countries to secure new trade deals The government has said that it will consider the committee's recommendations carefully.

title: In the media: Obama endorses gay marriage
text: In the Media: Obama Endorses Gay Marriage Former President Barack Obama has made history by endorsing same-sex marriage, becoming the first sitting U.S. president to publicly support the practice. In an interview with ABC News, Obama declared, "I believe that committed and loving same-sex couples should be able to marry." Obama's endorsement is a significant milestone in the fight for LGBTQ+ rights. It comes at a time when public opinion in the United States is rapidly shifting in favor of same-sex marriage. According to a 2013 Gallup poll, 55% of Americans support same-sex marriage, compared to only 27% in 1996. Obama's decision to endorse same-sex marriage was met with mixed reactions. Supporters hailed it as a courageous and necessary step towards equality. Opponents condemned it as a betrayal of traditional values. The issue of same-sex marriage has been a subject of fierce debate in the United States for decades. In 2008, California voters approved Proposition 8, which banned same-sex marriage in the state. However, in 2013, the Supreme Court struck down Proposition 8, ruling that it was unconstitutional. Despite the Supreme Court ruling, same-sex marriage remains banned in several states. However, the fight for full marriage equality continues, and Obama's endorsement is likely to give the movement a major boost. Obama's endorsement of same-sex marriage is not only a personal declaration of his beliefs but also a reflection of the changing social landscape in the United States. As public opinion continues to shift in favor of LGBTQ+ rights, it is likely that more and more political leaders will follow in Obama's footsteps and endorse same-sex marriage. The issue of same-sex marriage is complex and multifaceted. There are strong arguments on both sides of the debate. However, one thing is clear: the endorsement of same-sex marriage by former President Barack Obama is a significant step forward in the fight for LGBTQ+ equality.

title: Wild parakeets take roost in Birmingham's Shard End
text: In a surprising turn of events, wild parakeets have taken up residence in the Shard End area of Birmingham. These vibrant birds, once native to warmer climates, have adapted to the urban environment and are now thriving in the city's parks and streets. The parakeets, with their unmistakable emerald green plumage and distinctive calls, have become a familiar sight in Shard End. They nest in trees in the area's green spaces, including the popular Kingfisher Country Park, and often gather in large flocks, creating a lively spectacle. Experts believe that the parakeets may have escaped from captivity or been brought to the area as pets that were later released. They have proven to be resilient birds, able to withstand the colder temperatures of Birmingham's winters. The arrival of the parakeets has been met with mixed reactions from local residents. Some have embraced the birds, enjoying their vibrant presence and the cheerful sounds they bring to the neighborhood. Others have raised concerns about the potential impact on native wildlife, particularly smaller birds. Ornithologists have acknowledged the potential challenges posed by the non-native parakeets. Like other invasive species, they can compete with native birds for resources such as food and nesting sites. However, it is too early to say with certainty what the long-term impact will be. For now, the parakeets remain a curious addition to Birmingham's urban landscape. Their distinctive calls and flashes of green plumage add a touch of the exotic to the city's streets and parks. While their presence raises questions about the impact on the local environment, these remarkable birds have undoubtedly become a part of Shard End's unique character. In addition to the potential ecological implications, the arrival of the parakeets has also sparked discussions about human-wildlife interactions in urban environments. The birds' ability to thrive in close proximity to humans highlights the challenges and opportunities associated with managing wildlife in densely populated areas. As the parakeets continue to make Shard End their home, it remains to be seen how they will interact with the area's diverse bird population and whether their presence will have a lasting impact on the local ecosystem.

title: Elon Musk accused of stealing farting unicorn image
text: Elon Musk has been accused of stealing an image of a farting unicorn from a small artist. The artist, who goes by the name of "Stable Diffusion", posted the image on Twitter in January 2023. Musk then tweeted the same image a few days later, without giving credit to Stable Diffusion. Stable Diffusion was understandably upset, and called out Musk on Twitter. "Hey @elonmusk," they wrote. "This is my art. You didn't ask permission to use it. You didn't credit me. This is theft." Musk initially apologized on Twitter, and said that he would give credit to Stable Diffusion in the future. However, he later deleted the tweet, and has not given credit to Stable Diffusion for the image. This is not the first time that Musk has been accused of stealing other people's work. In 2018, he was accused of stealing the idea for the Tesla Cybertruck from a small design firm. He has also been accused of stealing ideas from other companies, such as SpaceX and SolarCity. Musk's behavior has led some to question his ethics. They argue that he is willing to take credit for other people's work, and that he does not respect the rights of artists. Others, however, defend Musk, arguing that he is a visionary who is not afraid to take risks. They say that he is not interested in stealing other people's work, but rather in using it to create something new and innovative. The debate over Musk's ethics is likely to continue. However, one thing is for sure: he is a complex and controversial figure. He is a brilliant inventor and entrepreneur, but he is also a ruthless businessman. It remains to be seen whether he will be able to use his talents for good, or whether he will ultimately self-destruct. In the meantime, Stable Diffusion is still waiting for Musk to give them credit for their work.

title: Firefighters back industrial action in pensions row
text: Firefighters Back Industrial Action in Pensions Row Firefighters have voted overwhelmingly in favor of industrial action in a long-running dispute over pensions. The Fire Brigades Union (FBU) said 88% of its members who voted backed industrial action. The turnout was 73%. The FBU said firefighters were "angry and frustrated" at government plans to increase their pension contributions and raise the retirement age. The union said it would now consider what form of industrial action to take. The government said it was "disappointed" with the result of the ballot and urged the FBU to reconsider. The dispute centers on plans by the government to increase firefighters' pension contributions from 11% to 14% of their salary. The government also wants to raise the retirement age for firefighters from 60 to 65. The FBU said the government's plans would "decimate" firefighters' pensions and make it impossible for many to retire before they are too old to do their job safely. The union said it was "not prepared to accept" the government's plans and would take whatever action necessary to protect firefighters' pensions. The government said it was "committed to ensuring that firefighters have a fair and sustainable pension scheme." The government said it had made "significant concessions" in an attempt to reach a deal with the FBU, but that the union had rejected these. The government said it was "disappointed" that the FBU had voted in favor of industrial action and urged the union to reconsider. The FBU said it would now consider what form of industrial action to take. The union said it would not rule out strikes, but that it would also consider other forms of action, such as work-to-rule or overtime bans. The government said it hoped that the FBU would reconsider its decision to take industrial action and that the two sides could reach a deal that was fair to both firefighters and taxpayers.

title: US firm RiverOak renews bid to reopen Manston Airport
text: US firm RiverOak renews bid to reopen Manston Airport US firm RiverOak Strategic Partners has renewed its bid to reopen Manston Airport in Kent, south-east England. The company submitted a revised planning application to Thanet District Council on Friday, after its original proposal was rejected in 2021. RiverOak says the airport could create up to 2,500 jobs and boost the local economy by £1bn over the next 10 years. But opponents say the plans are unrealistic and would damage the environment. Manston Airport closed in 2014 after its owner, Ann Gloag, withdrew funding. RiverOak first submitted a planning application to reopen the airport in 2020, but it was rejected by Thanet District Council in May 2021. The council said the plans were "not in accordance with the development plan" and would have "significant adverse impacts" on the environment. RiverOak has now submitted a revised planning application, which it says addresses the concerns raised by the council. The new plans include a smaller terminal building and a reduced number of flights. RiverOak says the airport would operate up to 25 flights per day, with a focus on budget airlines and cargo services. The company says the airport would create up to 2,500 jobs and boost the local economy by £1bn over the next 10 years. But opponents say the plans are unrealistic and would damage the environment. The Manston Airport Action Group (MAAG) says the airport would generate too much noise and pollution, and would have a negative impact on local wildlife. MAAG also says the plans are unrealistic, and that there is no demand for an airport in Manston. The group is calling on Thanet District Council to reject RiverOak's planning application. The council is expected to make a decision on the application later this year.

title: Labour leadership ballot closes
text: Labour leadership ballot closes, result due on Monday The contest to replace Sir Keir Starmer as leader of the Labour Party has closed, with the result set to be announced on Monday. The ballot of Labour members and registered supporters closed at midday on Thursday, with the winner set to be announced at a special conference in London on Monday afternoon. Sir Keir is the only candidate to have put themselves forward for the role, and is widely expected to be re-elected unopposed. However, some Labour members have expressed concerns about the lack of a contest, arguing that it is undemocratic and will lead to a lack of accountability. One Labour MP, who did not want to be named, said: "I think it's a shame that there's not a contest. It would have been good to have a proper debate about the future of the party." Another Labour MP said: "I understand why Keir is unopposed, but I think it's important to have a contest. It's the only way to ensure that the leader is accountable to the membership." However, other Labour members have defended the lack of a contest, arguing that it is a sign of unity within the party. One Labour member said: "I think it's a good thing that Keir is unopposed. It shows that the party is united behind him." Another Labour member said: "I don't think it's necessary to have a contest. Keir has done a good job and I'm happy to support him." The Labour leadership ballot is the first to be held under the party's new rules, which require candidates to secure the support of at least 20% of Labour MPs and MEPs in order to stand. The new rules were introduced in an attempt to prevent the party from being led by someone who does not have the support of the parliamentary party. The Labour Party is currently the largest opposition party in the House of Commons, with 202 MPs. The party is led by Sir Keir Starmer, who was elected in 2020.

title: Amazon readies Android app store
text: Amazon is developing its own app store for Android devices, according to a report from Bloomberg. The move would mark a significant challenge to Google's Play Store, which is currently the dominant app store for Android devices. Amazon has been working on the project for several months and is in talks with developers about distributing their apps through its store, Bloomberg reported. The new store is expected to launch later this year. Amazon's entry into the Android app market could have a major impact on the industry. Amazon has a vast customer base and a well-developed e-commerce platform. It could use these advantages to attract developers and users to its new app store. If Amazon is successful in launching a successful Android app store, it could force Google to lower its fees for developers and improve the quality of its Play Store. It could also give developers more choice in how they distribute their apps. Google has not yet commented on Amazon's plans. However, the company is likely to view Amazon's entry into the Android app market as a major threat. Google has invested heavily in its Play Store and it is a key part of its Android ecosystem. Amazon's move into the Android app market is a sign of the growing competition in the mobile ecosystem. Apple and Google currently dominate the market, but Amazon is now looking to challenge their dominance. It remains to be seen whether Amazon can be successful in launching a successful Android app store. However, the company has a track record of success in e-commerce and it has the resources to invest in the project. If Amazon is successful, it could have a major impact on the Android app market. In addition to the potential impact on the Android app market, Amazon's move could also have implications for the broader mobile ecosystem. Amazon is already a major player in the e-commerce market and it has ambitions to become a major player in the mobile market. If Amazon is successful in launching a successful Android app store, it could give the company a significant advantage in the mobile market.

title: Clashes as Ethiopian Israelis protest over police shooting
text: Ethiopian Israelis took to the streets of Tel Aviv on Sunday to protest the fatal police shooting of a 19-year-old man. Yehuda Biadga was shot dead by police on Saturday night after he allegedly stabbed an officer during a traffic stop in the Israeli city of Bat Yam. Police said Biadga had been driving a stolen vehicle and had tried to flee when pulled over. Biadga's family and friends dispute the police account, saying he was unarmed and was shot in the back. The protest in Tel Aviv began peacefully but turned violent when demonstrators clashed with police. Police fired stun grenades and water cannon to disperse the crowd, while protesters threw stones and bottles. At least 11 people were arrested and several others were injured in the clashes. The protest is the latest in a series of demonstrations by Ethiopian Israelis over police violence. In 2015, a video of two police officers beating an Ethiopian-Israeli soldier sparked widespread outrage and led to protests across the country. Ethiopian Israelis say they are regularly subjected to discrimination and violence by the police. They also complain of being treated as second-class citizens and of being denied equal opportunities in education, employment, and housing. The Israeli government has been criticized for its handling of the protests. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has called for calm and has promised to investigate the shooting of Biadga. But protesters say the government has not done enough to address their concerns. The protests are a sign of the growing frustration and anger among Ethiopian Israelis. They are demanding an end to police violence and discrimination, and they are calling for equal rights and opportunities. The Israeli government must take their demands seriously and work to build a more just and equitable society for all its citizens.

title: Christmas ad spend 'to hit record high'
text: Christmas ad spend to hit record high UK businesses are set to spend a record £7.1bn on Christmas advertising this year, according to a new report. The Advertising Association/Warc Expenditure Report forecasts that ad spending will increase by 5.6% compared to last year. This is the highest level of growth since 2007. The report says that the increase in ad spending is being driven by a number of factors, including the strong economy, the growth of online advertising, and the increasing popularity of video content. The biggest spenders on Christmas advertising will be the retail sector, which is expected to account for 38% of all ad spend. This is followed by the food and drink sector (21%), the automotive sector (11%), and the travel and leisure sector (9%). The report also predicts that online advertising will account for 57% of all Christmas ad spend this year, up from 53% last year. This is being driven by the increasing use of smartphones and tablets, as well as the growing popularity of social media platforms. Video content is also becoming increasingly important for Christmas advertisers. The report says that 63% of all Christmas ad spend will be on video this year, up from 59% last year. This is being driven by the popularity of video-sharing platforms such as YouTube and TikTok. The Advertising Association's chief executive, Stephen Woodford, said: "The Christmas advertising market is set to hit a new record high this year, with businesses looking to make the most of the festive period. The growth in online advertising and video content is particularly notable, and reflects the changing way that consumers are engaging with advertising." The report also found that the average UK household will see around 15 Christmas adverts per day in the run-up to the big day. This is up from 13 adverts per day last year. The most popular Christmas advertising slots are on ITV, Channel 4, and Sky. These slots are typically booked up months in advance, and can cost millions of pounds. Some of the most iconic Christmas adverts in recent years have included: The John Lewis Christmas advert, which has become a festive tradition in the UK. The Coca-Cola Christmas advert, which has featured a variety of different themes over the years. The Sainsbury's Christmas advert, which has often featured heartwarming stories. Christmas advertising is a major part of the festive period in the UK. It helps to create a sense of excitement and anticipation, and it can also be a source of nostalgia for many people.

title: Jenna Coleman 'leaving' Doctor Who
text: Jenna Coleman's Departure from Doctor Who British actress Jenna Coleman is set to leave the long-running sci-fi series Doctor Who at the end of the upcoming tenth season. Coleman has played the character of Clara Oswald, a companion to the Doctor, since 2012. Her exit was announced in a statement from the BBC, which said that "Jenna has been a fantastic addition to the show and we are very grateful for all she has contributed." Coleman expressed her gratitude to the show's fans and crew, saying in a statement: "I have loved playing Clara and I will always be grateful for the opportunity to have worked on Doctor Who." She added that "it's been an incredible journey and I've made lifelong friends." Coleman's departure comes at a time of change for Doctor Who. The show is set to undergo a major revamp next year, with Peter Capaldi stepping down as the Doctor and being replaced by Jodie Whittaker, the first female actress to play the role. Russell T Davies, who was the showrunner of Doctor Who from 2005 to 2010, is also set to return as the show's executive producer in 2018. Coleman's departure is a major loss for Doctor Who. She has been a popular and well-received companion, and her chemistry with Capaldi has been praised by fans and critics alike. However, her exit also provides an opportunity for the show to refresh itself and explore new directions. With Whittaker as the Doctor and Davies at the helm, Doctor Who is set to enter an exciting new era. Possible Reasons for Coleman's Departure There are several possible reasons why Coleman has decided to leave Doctor Who. One possibility is that she simply wants to pursue other projects. Coleman is a talented actress with a wide range of abilities, and she may feel that she has outgrown the role of Clara Oswald. Another possibility is that she is unhappy with the direction that the show is taking. Davies has already hinted that he plans to make some significant changes to the show, and Coleman may not be comfortable with those changes. Finally, it is also possible that Coleman simply wants to spend more time with her family and friends. She has been working on Doctor Who for four years, and she may be ready for a break. Whatever the reason, Coleman's departure is a significant event for Doctor Who. She has been an important part of the show for the past four years, and she will be missed by fans and cast members alike.

title: Pringles tube tries to wake from 'recycling nightmare'
text: In the depths of a recycling plant, amidst a cacophony of clanking machinery and the pungent aroma of discarded materials, an unlikely protagonist stirs from its slumber. A Pringles tube, once a symbol of culinary delight, now finds itself trapped in a recycling nightmare. Its sleek cylindrical form, once a beacon of innovation, now lies crumpled and forlorn. The once-vibrant colors have faded, replaced by a dull, ashen hue. Encrusted with a sticky residue of its former contents, it bears the scars of countless meals enjoyed and discarded. As the conveyor belt grinds beneath its weight, the tube struggles to regain consciousness. Its thin walls creak and groan under the pressure, threatening to shatter into a thousand pieces. The constant jostling and bumping against its fellow recyclables sends shockwaves through its fragile frame. In a desperate attempt to escape its torturous prison, the tube rolls and slides, seeking an opening through which it can slip. But its efforts are in vain. It is trapped, ensnared by a labyrinth of metal and plastic. As darkness descends upon it, the tube resigns itself to its fate. It has become a mere husk of its former glory, destined to end its days as recycled material. But amidst the despair, a flicker of hope remains. For in the heart of the recycling plant, there works a man named George. A seasoned employee with a keen eye for the unusual, George has always had a soft spot for discarded objects. As he surveys the conveyor belt, his gaze falls upon the struggling Pringles tube. Intrigued by its resilience, George carefully plucks it from the torrent of recyclables. He examines it with a mixture of awe and pity, marveling at its tenacity in the face of adversity. Inspired by its plight, George vows to give the tube a second chance at life. He takes it home and washes away the residue of its past. With meticulous care, he repairs its damaged walls and restores its vibrant colors. And so, the Pringles tube is reborn, emerging from its recycling nightmare transformed into a symbol of hope and resilience. It proudly stands on a shelf in George's home, a testament to the power of second chances and the human spirit that refuses to give up.

title: The case for a non-white Spider-Man
text: Spider-Man: A Cultural Icon with an Evolving Identity Spider-Man, the iconic superhero created by Stan Lee and Steve Ditko in 1962, has become an integral part of popular culture. However, the traditional depiction of Spider-Man as a young, white male has raised questions about the relevance of the character in a society that is increasingly diverse. Advocates for a non-white Spider-Man argue that it would provide much-needed representation for communities that have historically been underrepresented in superhero narratives. The character's iconic suit and web-slinging abilities transcend racial boundaries, making it possible to envision a Spider-Man who reflects the diversity of the real world. Furthermore, a non-white Spider-Man could serve as an inspirational role model for children and young adults, demonstrating that heroism is not confined to a particular racial or ethnic background. By breaking down stereotypes and showcasing the universality of the superhero concept, Spider-Man can help foster a more inclusive and equitable society. However, some traditionalists argue that altering the character's race would undermine his established iconography and the nostalgic appeal of the original comics. They maintain that Spider-Man's core identity is inextricably linked to his white skin and that any change would be disrespectful to the character's creators and loyal fans. Proponents of a non-white Spider-Man counter that the character has already undergone significant changes over the years, including different costumes, backstories, and love interests. They argue that a change in race would be just another evolution in the character's long history, ensuring its relevance to a new generation of fans. Ultimately, the decision of whether or not to introduce a non-white Spider-Man is a complex one that requires careful consideration. While respecting the character's legacy is important, so too is the need for representation and inclusivity in modern storytelling. As the world continues to evolve, it is inevitable that the characters we identify with will reflect that change. Whether it takes the form of a new character, an alternate universe version, or a reimagined classic, the introduction of a non-white Spider-Man would be a significant step towards creating a more diverse and representative superhero landscape. By embracing change and evolving with the times, Spider-Man can continue to be an enduring icon for generations to come.

title: Personal travel agents boost holiday bookings
text: Personal Travel Agents Boost Holiday Bookings Amidst the surge in online travel booking platforms, personal travel agents have emerged as a formidable force, revitalizing the industry with their personalized services and expertise. Despite the convenience and accessibility of digital channels, travelers are increasingly turning to human touch and bespoke guidance for their vacation planning. According to a recent survey by the American Society of Travel Advisors (ASTA), 65% of Americans prefer booking their holidays through travel agents. This resurgence in demand highlights the value that personal agents bring to the travel experience. They act as trusted advisors, leveraging their industry knowledge and connections to curate tailored itineraries that meet clients' specific needs. Personalized Planning and Expertise Unlike online platforms that offer a generic range of options, travel agents take the time to understand their clients' travel aspirations, preferences, and budget. They delve into the nuances of destinations, recommending hidden gems, exclusive experiences, and insider tips that enhance the overall vacation experience. Their expertise extends to niche markets, such as luxury travel, adventure expeditions, and tailor-made family holidays. Human Connection and Flexibility In the digital age, personal connection has become a sought-after commodity. Travel agents provide a human touch that online booking engines lack. They are available to answer queries, resolve issues promptly, and offer continuous support throughout the planning process. This personalized approach instills confidence and peace of mind, especially for first-time travelers or those navigating complex itineraries. Moreover, travel agents offer flexibility and adaptability. They can accommodate last-minute changes, upgrade bookings, and negotiate special deals on behalf of their clients. Their understanding of the industry allows them to navigate unforeseen circumstances, ensuring that travelers have a smooth and stress-free vacation. Cost Savings and Exclusive Perks Contrary to popular belief, personal travel agents can often secure more competitive deals than online booking platforms. They have established relationships with airlines, hotels, and tour operators, enabling them to negotiate exclusive discounts and added value benefits. These partnerships also allow them to secure upgrades, priority boarding, and access to VIP airport lounges. The Future of Travel Agents While online booking platforms will continue to appeal to tech-savvy travelers seeking convenience, the demand for personal travel agents is expected to remain strong. Their personalized services, expertise, and human touch cater to a growing segment of travelers who value authentic experiences and hassle-free planning. As the travel industry evolves, personal agents will continue to play a crucial role in shaping the future of holidays, empowering travelers to create unforgettable memories that surpass mere itineraries.

title: Covid: EU starts mass vaccination in 'touching moment of unity'
text: In a poignant moment of unity, the European Union has commenced its mass Covid-19 vaccination campaign, marking a significant turning point in the fight against the pandemic that has ravaged the continent. The first doses were administered across the bloc on Sunday, as countries from Portugal to Hungary rolled out their vaccination programs. In a symbolic gesture of solidarity, several European leaders received their vaccinations publicly, underscoring the importance of the campaign and reassuring their citizens of the vaccine's safety. German Chancellor Angela Merkel, French President Emmanuel Macron, and Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte were among those who rolled up their sleeves. The EU's mass vaccination drive is a logistical undertaking of unprecedented scale, involving the coordination of vaccine procurement, distribution, and administration across 27 member states. The European Medicines Agency (EMA) has authorized the use of two vaccines so far – Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna – and more are expected to be approved in the coming months. The rollout of the vaccines has been met with cautious optimism by many Europeans, who have endured months of lockdowns, travel restrictions, and economic hardship. While some expressed concerns about the potential side effects of the vaccines, the vast majority recognized the urgency of protecting themselves and their communities from the virus. Health experts have emphasized the importance of achieving herd immunity, which occurs when a large proportion of the population has developed antibodies against a disease, making it more difficult for the virus to spread. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that between 60-70% of the population needs to be vaccinated to achieve herd immunity against Covid-19. The EU is aiming to vaccinate 70% of its adult population by the end of summer 2021. The campaign will prioritize healthcare workers, the elderly, and those with underlying health conditions, who are at higher risk of severe illness from Covid-19. The mass vaccination drive is a testament to the power of science and cooperation in the face of a global crisis. As the vaccines continue to roll out across the EU and beyond, there is renewed hope that the end of the pandemic is in sight.

title: Everest avalanche: Sherpas discuss boycott
text: On April 18, 2014, an avalanche hit a group of Sherpas who were preparing the route for climbers on Mount Everest, resulting in 16 fatalities. The tragic incident sparked outrage among Sherpa communities, leading to a movement calling for a boycott of the mountain. Kaji Sherpa, President of the Nepal Mountaineering Association, spoke to the BBC about the reasons behind the boycott. "The Sherpas are the backbone of the Everest climbing industry," he said. "They risk their lives every day to make it possible for others to reach the summit. But they are not treated with the respect and recognition they deserve." Sherpas have long complained of being underpaid and overworked by Western expedition companies. They also say that they are often ignored in decision-making processes related to climbing on Everest. "We are not just porters," said Kaji Sherpa. "We are highly skilled mountaineers who deserve to be treated as equals." The boycott movement has gained widespread support within the Sherpa community. Many Sherpas have vowed not to work on Everest until their demands are met. This has put expedition companies in a difficult position, as it is impossible to climb Everest without Sherpa support. The companies have met with Sherpa representatives to try to resolve the issue. However, no agreement has yet been reached. The Sherpas are demanding a number of changes, including increased pay, better insurance, and a greater say in decision-making. The boycott has had a significant impact on the Everest climbing industry. The number of expeditions has dropped sharply, and many climbers have canceled their plans to climb the mountain. This has resulted in a loss of revenue for expedition companies and the Nepalese government. It remains to be seen whether the boycott will achieve its goals. However, it has certainly raised awareness of the plight of Sherpas and has forced the climbing industry to confront the issue of their treatment.

title: Ed Balls: Labour would back mansion tax to fund tax credits
text: Labour would back a mansion tax to fund tax credits for the poorest families, Ed Balls has said. The shadow chancellor told the BBC that a tax on homes worth more than £2m could raise £1.5bn a year, enough to cover the cost of reinstating the tax breaks to their previous level. The government cut tax credits by an average of £1,200 a year in April, sparking protests from charities and opposition politicians. The chancellor, George Osborne, has said he cannot afford to reverse the cuts without raising other taxes or cutting spending elsewhere. But Mr Balls said Labour would introduce a "modest" mansion tax to raise the revenue needed. He told the BBC's Andrew Marr Show: "Let's just get this straight: £1.5bn would reinstate tax credits in full. A mansion tax on homes worth over £2m would raise that. "So that's an additional tax on the top 0.5% of properties, raising £1.5bn to reinstate tax credits for the poorest families." Mr Balls said the tax would be "fair" and would not hit people who had worked hard to buy their homes. He said: "A mansion tax would be fair because it would be paid by those who can afford it, and it would not affect the vast majority of homes in this country. "It's a modest proposal on the top 0.5% of homes, the most expensive homes, to raise money to reverse the tax credit cuts that have hit the poorest families." The government has said it will not introduce a mansion tax, arguing that it would be unfair to people who have worked hard to buy their homes. But Labour argues that the tax would be a fair way to raise revenue to help the poorest families. The party has pledged to reinstate tax credits to their previous level if it wins the next election. The Liberal Democrats have also pledged to support a mansion tax, but the Conservatives have ruled it out.

title: Boardrooms 'need more ethnic diversity'
text: The stark absence of ethnic diversity in British boardrooms remains an enduring problem that stifles progress and undermines the fair representation of our society. Despite persistent efforts to promote inclusion, the latest figures reveal a dismal picture that calls for urgent action. According to a recent study by the Parker Review, ethnic minorities hold a mere 14.1% of board positions in FTSE 100 companies, a figure that has remained virtually unchanged in the past five years. The situation is even more dire in other sectors, with ethnic minorities accounting for just 8.5% of board members in the FTSE 250 and a mere 5.7% in the public sector. This lack of diversity has profound implications for decision-making and corporate governance. Studies have consistently shown that diverse boards lead to better financial performance, enhanced innovation, and increased employee engagement. By excluding ethnic minorities from the highest echelons of decision-making, we are depriving our businesses and our society as a whole of valuable perspectives and insights. The reasons for the lack of ethnic diversity in boardrooms are complex and multifaceted. However, one key factor is the prevalence of unconscious bias in recruitment and selection processes. Unconscious bias refers to the automatic, often subconscious, stereotypes and attitudes that can influence our decision-making without us even realizing it. To address this issue, businesses must adopt proactive measures to eliminate unconscious bias from their recruitment practices. This includes implementing blind hiring processes, conducting diversity training for hiring managers, and actively seeking out candidates from underrepresented groups. Another barrier to ethnic diversity in boardrooms is the lack of role models and mentorship opportunities for ethnic minorities. Many talented individuals from ethnic minority backgrounds feel underrepresented and undervalued in the business world. By creating mentorship programs and providing opportunities for ethnic minorities to shadow senior leaders, we can inspire future generations and break down the barriers to progression. Government policy can also play a significant role in promoting ethnic diversity in boardrooms. The introduction of mandatory diversity targets for FTSE 100 companies has been met with mixed reactions. Some argue that it is an essential step to accelerate progress, while others fear it could lead to tokenism. Regardless of one's views on mandatory targets, it is clear that government intervention is necessary to create a level playing field and address the systemic barriers that prevent ethnic minorities from reaching boardroom positions. Ultimately, achieving true ethnic diversity in British boardrooms is not simply a matter of ticking boxes. It is about creating a fair and inclusive workplace where everyone has the opportunity to succeed regardless of their background. By challenging unconscious bias, providing mentorship opportunities, and implementing targeted policies, we can unlock the full potential of our businesses and create a society that truly reflects the diversity of its people.

title: No SNP applause on Cameron's legacy at final PMQs
text: In the final Prime Minister's Questions (PMQs) session of his premiership, David Cameron faced a barrage of criticism from opposition leaders, including Scottish National Party (SNP) leader Nicola Sturgeon. Sturgeon took particular issue with Cameron's legacy on Scotland, accusing him of "failing to keep his promises" on devolving more powers to the Scottish Parliament. She also criticized his handling of the Brexit referendum, which resulted in a majority of Scots voting to remain in the European Union. "The Prime Minister has presided over a decade of broken promises and missed opportunities for Scotland," Sturgeon said. "He promised to give Scotland a say on its own future, but he has broken that promise." Cameron defended his record on Scotland, arguing that he had delivered on his commitment to devolve more powers to Holyrood. title: Brexit: PSNI 'won't police customs checkpoints', says chief constable
text: The Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) will not police any customs checkpoints that may be erected on the Irish border after Brexit, its chief constable has said. Byrne's comments come amid growing concerns about the potential impact of Brexit on the Irish border. The UK is due to leave the European Union on March 29, 2019, and there is still no agreement on how the border will operate after that date. The EU has insisted that there must be no hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, but the UK government has said that it is prepared to leave the EU without a deal, which could lead to the imposition of tariffs and other barriers to trade. Byrne said that the PSNI was "ready for all eventualities" but that he hoped a deal could be reached that would avoid a hard border. "We are working closely with our partners in the Republic of Ireland and with the UK government to ensure that we are prepared for all eventualities," he said. "But we hope that a deal can be reached that will avoid a hard border." The PSNI's decision not to police customs checkpoints is likely to add to the pressure on the UK government to reach a deal with the EU. The Irish government has said that it will not allow any customs checkpoints on the border, and the PSNI's refusal to police them means that the UK government would have to find another way to enforce them. title: Sisi gives Egypt military new powers after Sinai attack
text: Sisi grants Egypt's military sweeping new powers following Sinai attack Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi has expanded the military's powers to combat terrorism following a deadly attack on a mosque in the Sinai Peninsula. The new measures, approved by parliament on Monday, grant the military sweeping powers, including the authority to arrest and detain suspects without a warrant. The move has been met with criticism from human rights groups, who warn that it could lead to abuses. Details of the new law The new law grants the military the following powers: To arrest and detain suspects for up to 30 days without a warrant. To search and seize property without a warrant. To use deadly force to disperse protests. To establish military courts to try civilians. The law also creates a new National Anti-Terrorism Authority, which will be responsible for coordinating the government's counterterrorism efforts. Government's justification The government has defended the new law as necessary to combat the threat of terrorism. "We are facing a war against terrorism," Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly said. "We need to give the military the tools it needs to protect our country." Criticism from human rights groups Human rights groups have condemned the new law as a "blank check" for the military. "This law will give the military free rein to commit human rights abuses," said Amnesty International's Egypt researcher. The Egyptian Initiative for Personal Rights, another human rights group, called the law "a major setback for human rights in Egypt." Background The new law was approved in the wake of a deadly attack on a mosque in the Sinai Peninsula on Friday. The attack, which killed at least 305 people, was the deadliest terrorist attack in Egypt's recent history. The attack was claimed by the Islamic State group, which has been waging an insurgency in the Sinai since 2013. Implications The new law is likely to have a significant impact on Egypt's human rights record. The military has long been accused of human rights abuses, including arbitrary detentions, torture, and extrajudicial killings. The new law could give the military even greater impunity for such abuses. The law could also have a chilling effect on dissent. The military's authority to use deadly force to disperse protests could make it more difficult for people to exercise their right to free assembly.

title: 'Failing leadership' at Shrewsbury and Telford Hospital Trust
text: Failing Leadership at Shrewsbury and Telford Hospital Trust An independent inquiry has concluded that "failures of leadership and management" at Shrewsbury and Telford Hospital Trust (SaTH) led to hundreds of baby deaths and avoidable brain damage in mothers over two decades. The inquiry found that the trust had a "defensive and adversarial" culture and failed to properly investigate concerns raised by families. Ockenden said that the trust had "failed to learn and improve" from its mistakes, and that there was a "lack of openness and transparency" at the trust. She said that the trust had "lost the trust of the families it serves." The inquiry made a number of recommendations to improve maternity services at SaTH, including: Establishing a new, independent maternity board Improving training for staff Increasing staffing levels Creating a new complaints procedure The Department of Health and Social Care (DHSC) has said that it will accept all of the inquiry's recommendations. The DHSC has also announced that it will be setting up a new independent body to oversee maternity services in England. Many families have said that they feel let down by the trust and that they have lost faith in the NHS. The inquiry's findings are a damning indictment of the leadership and management at SaTH. The DHSC must now act on the inquiry's recommendations and ensure that the trust is held accountable for its failings. The inquiry's findings are also a reminder of the importance of patient safety.
