title: Florida Zika cases prompt UK advice for pregnant travellers
text: Florida Zika cases prompt UK advice for pregnant travellers Pregnant women and those trying to conceive are being advised to avoid travelling to Miami-Dade County in Florida, after 10 local cases of the Zika virus were confirmed. The UK's Foreign and Commonwealth Office (FCO) has updated its travel advice for the area, warning that the virus can cause serious birth defects if contracted during pregnancy. The virus is spread by mosquitoes, and there is no vaccine or specific treatment available. Symptoms of Zika include fever, rash, joint pain and red eyes, but many people infected with the virus do not experience any symptoms. The FCO advice applies to pregnant women and women trying to conceive, as well as their partners. It warns that even if a woman does not have symptoms of Zika, she could still be carrying the virus and pass it on to her unborn child. The FCO advises pregnant women and women trying to conceive to consider postponing their travel to Miami-Dade County until after their pregnancy. If travel is essential, they should take strict precautions to avoid mosquito bites, such as wearing long sleeves and trousers, using insect repellent and sleeping under a mosquito net. The FCO also advises pregnant women and women trying to conceive to speak to their doctor before travelling to any area where Zika is present. The Zika virus has been linked to a range of birth defects, including microcephaly, a condition where a baby's head is abnormally small. The virus can also cause miscarriage, stillbirth and other serious health problems. There is currently no vaccine or specific treatment for Zika, but research is ongoing. In the meantime, the best way to prevent infection is to avoid mosquito bites. Anyone who has travelled to an area where Zika is present and is concerned that they may have been infected should see their doctor. Zika can be diagnosed with a blood test. For more information on Zika, visit the NHS website: https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/zika-virus/

title: Grace Millane killer appeals against conviction and sentence
text: The man convicted of murdering British backpacker Grace Millane has launched an appeal against his conviction and sentence. Jesse Kempson, 28, was found guilty of strangling the 22-year-old to death in December 2018 after a Tinder date. He was sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum term of 17 years. Kempson's lawyers have now lodged an appeal against the verdict, arguing that the trial judge made a number of errors that led to a miscarriage of justice. One of the grounds for appeal is that the judge wrongly allowed the jury to hear evidence of Kempson's previous sexual history. The defense argued that this evidence was irrelevant to the murder charge and was unfairly prejudicial to Kempson. Another ground for appeal is that the judge failed to properly instruct the jury on the law relating to self-defense. Kempson claims that he killed Millane in self-defense after she attacked him. The Court of Appeal will now consider whether to grant Kempson permission to appeal. If permission is granted, a full hearing will be held to determine whether the conviction and sentence should be overturned. The appeal process could take several months or even years to complete. In the meantime, Kempson remains in prison. Millane's family have said they are "disappointed" by the appeal, but they trust that the justice system will uphold the verdict. "We continue to believe that justice was served at the trial," a family statement said. "We are confident that the Court of Appeal will reach the same conclusion." The case has attracted widespread attention in New Zealand and the UK. Millane's murder shocked and horrified people in both countries, and her family has been praised for their courage and dignity in the face of unimaginable tragedy. The appeal process is likely to be closely watched by both the public and the legal community. The outcome of the appeal could have implications for future cases involving self-defense and the admissibility of evidence of a defendant's sexual history.

title: Cuts to Education Improvement Grant criticised
text: Cuts to Education Improvement Grant Criticized The government's decision to cut funding for the Education Improvement Grant (EIG) has been met with widespread criticism from educators and education experts. The EIG, which provides funding for schools to improve their teaching standards and facilities, will see its budget reduced by 50% over the next three years. Critics argue that the cuts will have a devastating impact on schools, particularly those in disadvantaged areas that rely heavily on EIG funding. They point out that the grant has been instrumental in improving education outcomes in recent years, and that cuts could reverse this progress. A recent study by the National Education Union found that schools that received EIG funding saw significant improvements in pupil achievement, particularly in English and mathematics. The study also found that the grant helped to reduce the attainment gap between disadvantaged pupils and their more affluent peers. The cuts to the EIG have been condemned by teaching unions, school leaders, and educational charities. The National Association of Head Teachers (NAHT) has warned that the cuts will lead to larger class sizes, fewer teachers, and a reduction in the quality of education provided. The Association of School and College Leaders (ASCL) has also expressed concern about the impact of the cuts. ASCL General Secretary Geoff Barton said: "These cuts will have a detrimental impact on the ability of schools to provide a high-quality education for all their pupils." The Children's Commissioner for England, Rachel de Souza, has called for the government to reconsider the cuts. She said: "The EIG is a vital source of funding for schools that are working to improve the life chances of children. Cutting this funding will make it harder for schools to provide the support that children need." The government has defended the cuts, arguing that they are necessary to reduce public spending. However, critics have pointed out that the government has introduced a number of tax cuts for wealthy individuals and corporations, and that the cuts to the EIG are therefore a matter of political choice, not economic necessity. The cuts to the EIG have sparked widespread protests from parents, teachers, and pupils. A petition calling on the government to reverse the cuts has gathered over 100,000 signatures. The government has said that it is committed to improving education standards, but critics argue that the cuts to the EIG will make this goal more difficult to achieve.

title: Demand for food banks drops slightly in Northern Ireland
text: Demand for food banks drops slightly in Northern Ireland Demand for food banks in Northern Ireland has fallen slightly in recent months, according to new figures. The Trussell Trust, which operates a network of food banks across the UK, said there were 26,935 three-day emergency food supplies given to people in Northern Ireland between April and September 2022. This is a decrease of 2% compared to the same period last year. However, the charity warned that demand is still significantly higher than before the pandemic. In the first six months of 2019, before the Covid-19 outbreak, the Trussell Trust gave out 14,295 three-day emergency food supplies in Northern Ireland. This means that demand has increased by 88% since the start of the pandemic. The Trussell Trust said the decrease in demand in recent months is likely due to a number of factors, including the end of the Universal Credit uplift and the introduction of a £650 cost of living payment. However, the charity warned that many people are still struggling to afford food and other essentials. "We are concerned that the cost of living crisis is pushing more and more people into poverty and hunger," said David McAuley, the Trussell Trust's Northern Ireland manager. "We would urge the government to do more to help people on low incomes, including increasing benefits and making it easier for people to access affordable housing." The Department for Communities said it is "committed to supporting people who are struggling with the cost of living". A spokesperson said: "We have provided a range of support, including a £650 cost of living payment, a £200 fuel payment and a £100 payment for pensioners. "We are also working with food banks and other charities to ensure that people have access to essential food and support." Case study: Emma* Emma is a single mother of two who lives in Belfast. She has been using food banks for the past few months. "I'm on a very low income and I'm struggling to make ends meet," she said. "I'm grateful for the help that food banks provide, but it's not a long-term solution. "I would like to see the government do more to help people like me who are struggling to afford food and other essentials."Name has been changed to protect identity

title: Chris Ramsey's guide for comedians at music festivals
text: Chris Ramsey's Guide for Comedians at Music Festivals As the summer festival season approaches, comedian Chris Ramsey shares his top tips for performers hitting the stage amidst the music madness. 1. Prepare for the Elements: Unlike comedy clubs, festivals are often subject to unpredictable weather. Comedians should pack layers, waterproof clothing, and consider bringing a rain cover for their electronics. Hydration is key, so carry a water bottle to stay refreshed. 2. Respect the Audience: While comedy festivals attract a diverse crowd, Ramsey emphasizes the importance of respecting the audience's passions. "They're there to see music, so don't try to compete with the bands," he says. "Find ways to incorporate the festival atmosphere into your set." 3. Engage with the Crowd: Festivals offer a unique opportunity to connect with a wide range of people. Ramsey recommends getting to know the audience, using their energy to fuel the performance, and acknowledging the shared experience of being at a festival. 4. Adjust Your Material: "Festival sets need to be punchier and more visual," advises Ramsey. "Visual gags and call-backs can help cut through the noise of the crowd." Tightening up the set and minimizing reliance on props is crucial for maintaining momentum. 5. Hydrate and Rest: The festival environment can be physically demanding. Ramsey stresses the importance of staying hydrated and getting enough sleep. "Don't overdo it with the free booze or you'll regret it the next day," he warns. 6. Promote Your Set: Ramsey suggests using social media and festival apps to promote your performance and encourage attendance. "Create a buzz by posting snippets of your set or sharing behind-the-scenes moments," he says. 7. Network with Other Comedians: Festivals are a great place to meet and collaborate with other comedians. Ramsey advises attending open mics and mixers, as well as reaching out to performers you admire. 8. Have Fun: "Remember, festivals are about enjoying yourself," says Ramsey. "So relax, embrace the atmosphere, and let your personality shine through." By following these tips, comedians can maximize their impact and leave a lasting impression at music festivals.

title: Overwatch pro player suspended over homophobic slur
text: Overwatch Pro Player Suspended Over Homophobic Slur Overwatch League pro player Felix "xQc" Lengyel has been suspended for one match after using a homophobic slur during a live stream. The incident occurred on Thursday, June 25, during a stream of Lengyel playing Apex Legends. Lengyel was involved in a heated argument with another player and used the slur "ft" in response to being called a "retard." Lengyel's use of the slur was met with swift backlash from the Overwatch community, with many fans and players calling for his suspension. The Overwatch League quickly responded to the incident, announcing Lengyel's suspension on Friday, June 26. In a statement, the Overwatch League said that Lengyel's behavior was "unacceptable" and that he had been suspended for one match "for using derogatory and offensive language." Lengyel has since apologized for his use of the slur, saying that he was "deeply sorry" for the harm he had caused. "I know that there is no excuse for what I said, and I take full responsibility for my actions," Lengyel said in a statement. "I am committed to learning from this experience and to becoming a better person." The Overwatch League's decision to suspend Lengyel is a significant step in the fight against homophobia in gaming. The league has made it clear that it will not tolerate the use of hate speech or other forms of discrimination. Lengyel's suspension is also a reminder that even professional gamers are not immune to the consequences of their actions. When they use offensive language, they can expect to be held accountable. The Overwatch League's decision is a positive step, but it is only one step in the fight against homophobia in gaming. There is still a long way to go, but the suspension of Lengyel sends a clear message that hate speech will not be tolerated. In addition to his suspension, Lengyel has also been fined $2,000 and will be required to complete sensitivity training. The Overwatch League has also said that it will be working with Lengyel to help him learn from this experience and to become a better person.

title: June Jones murder: Ex-boyfriend jailed for life
text: June Jones murder: Ex-boyfriend jailed for life A former boyfriend has been jailed for life for murdering his ex-partner in a "sustained and brutal" attack. June Jones, 33, was found dead at her home in Bexleyheath, south-east London, on 12 January. A post-mortem examination found she had died from multiple stab wounds. Her ex-boyfriend, 35-year-old Dean Lowe, was arrested the following day and charged with murder. He denied the charge, but was found guilty by a jury at the Old Bailey on Thursday. The court heard that Lowe had a history of violence and had previously been convicted of assaulting Ms Jones. In a statement, Ms Jones's family said: "We are relieved that justice has been done and that Dean Lowe is now behind bars. "June was a loving daughter, sister and friend, and her death has left a huge hole in our lives. "We would like to thank the police and the Crown Prosecution Service for their hard work in bringing Lowe to justice." Detective Chief Inspector Simon Harding, who led the investigation, said: "This was a senseless and brutal murder of a young woman who had her whole life ahead of her. "Lowe is a dangerous and violent man who has shown no remorse for his actions. "I hope that today's sentence brings some comfort to June's family and friends." In a statement, the Crown Prosecution Service said: "This was a horrific and sustained attack on a vulnerable woman. "We are pleased that the jury has found Lowe guilty of murder and that he will now face a life sentence. "We would like to commend the bravery of June's family and friends who have supported the prosecution throughout this difficult time."

title: Anorexic woman's death prompted independent review
text: An anorexic woman's death has prompted an independent review into eating disorder services in England. Averil Hart, 19, died in 2012 after suffering from the condition for seven years. Her family said she had been "failed" by the NHS. The review, which is being led by the Care Quality Commission (CQC), will look at how eating disorder services are provided in England. It will also consider how services can be improved. The CQC said the review would be "thorough and independent". It said it would "listen to the experiences of people with eating disorders and their families". The review comes after a number of high-profile cases of people dying from eating disorders. In 2017, it was reported that at least 1,000 people in England had died from the condition in the previous five years. Eating disorders are serious mental illnesses that can lead to death. They are often caused by a combination of psychological, social, and biological factors. People with eating disorders may have a distorted body image, and they may restrict their food intake or exercise excessively. They may also purge their food by vomiting or using laxatives. Eating disorders can have a devastating impact on a person's physical and mental health. They can lead to a range of health problems, including malnutrition, heart problems, and kidney problems. They can also lead to depression, anxiety, and suicidal thoughts. The CQC review will look at how eating disorder services are provided in England. It will also consider how services can be improved. The review will make recommendations to the government on how to improve the quality of eating disorder services. The review is expected to be completed by the end of 2023.

title: Scallop row: UK and France agree 'principles of deal'
text: The United Kingdom and France have agreed on "the principles of a deal" to resolve a dispute over fishing rights in the English Channel, which saw French boats blockading the port of Jersey earlier this year. The agreement was reached after talks between UK Environment Secretary George Eustice and French Europe Minister Clement Beaune in Paris on Thursday. Under the deal, the UK will grant 100 additional licences to French boats to fish in its waters, while France will withdraw its threats to impose sanctions on Jersey. The UK will also review the way it allocates fishing licences in the future, to ensure that they are issued fairly and transparently. The agreement is a significant breakthrough in the long-running dispute between the two countries over fishing rights in the English Channel. The dispute began in May, when the UK government announced that it would not be renewing the licences of some French boats to fish in its waters. The French government responded by threatening to impose sanctions on Jersey, which is a British Crown Dependency. The dispute escalated in June, when French boats blockaded the port of Jersey for several days. The blockade caused significant disruption to Jersey's economy and led to fears of a wider conflict between the UK and France. The agreement reached on Thursday is a welcome step towards resolving the dispute. However, it is important to note that the deal is only in principle at this stage. The details of the deal still need to be worked out, and it is possible that the agreement could still fall apart. Nevertheless, the agreement is a positive sign that the two countries are committed to finding a solution to the dispute. It is hoped that the deal will help to restore trust between the UK and France, and that it will lead to a more stable relationship between the two countries in the future.

title: Coronavirus: Israel enables emergency spy powers
text: Coronavirus: Israel enables emergency spy powers Israel has granted its internal security agency sweeping new powers to track the location of people infected with coronavirus, sparking concerns about civil liberties and a lack of oversight. The Shin Bet agency, which normally focuses on counter-terrorism, will now be able to use data collected by mobile phone operators to pinpoint the whereabouts of those infected with Covid-19 and anyone they have come into contact with. The move comes as Israel battles one of the worst outbreaks of the virus in the developed world, with over 11,000 confirmed cases and more than 100 deaths. The government argues that the Shin Bet's capabilities are essential for tracking down those who have been infected and preventing further spread of the virus. "This is an emergency situation," said Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. "We need to take extraordinary measures to protect the public health." However, critics say the new powers are a disproportionate and unwarranted intrusion into people's privacy. "This is a dangerous precedent," said Hagai El-Ad, executive director of the human rights group B'Tselem. "It allows the government to track our every move without any judicial oversight." The Shin Bet has a long and controversial history. It has been accused of using torture and other illegal interrogation techniques against Palestinian suspects. In recent years, the agency has also been accused of spying on Israeli citizens and using its surveillance capabilities to target political opponents of the government. The new powers granted to the Shin Bet will be in place for an initial period of two weeks. However, there are concerns that they could be extended indefinitely if the government declares a state of emergency. The move has sparked protests from civil liberties groups and opposition politicians. They argue that the government is using the pandemic as an excuse to expand its powers and erode democratic freedoms. "This is not about public health," said Tamar Zandberg, leader of the left-wing Meretz party. "This is about giving the government a blank check to spy on its citizens." The government has defended the new powers, saying they are necessary to protect the public health. However, it has also pledged to establish an oversight committee to ensure that the Shin Bet does not abuse its new powers. The committee will be made up of members of the Knesset (parliament), the attorney general and representatives from civil society organisations. It will have the power to review the Shin Bet's activities and recommend changes to the legislation. The government has also said that the new powers will only be used for a limited period of time and will be withdrawn once the pandemic is over. However, critics remain sceptical. They argue that the government has a history of expanding its powers and that it is unlikely to give up these new powers once they have been granted.

title: H&M stores in South Africa trashed over 'racist' hoodie
text: South African protesters have looted and damaged H&M stores across the country over a hoodie with a racially insensitive image and slogan. The global clothing giant has apologized for the garment, which featured a black boy model wearing a hoodie with the words "Coolest Monkey in the Jungle" emblazoned across the front. Many saw the image as being racially offensive, and it sparked anger and outrage on social media. In response, protesters have targeted H&M stores in Johannesburg, Pretoria, Durban, and Cape Town. They have smashed windows, looted clothing, and set fire to some stores. The protests have been condemned by both the South African government and H&M. The South African president, Cyril Ramaphosa, has called for calm and urged protesters to express their anger peacefully. H&M has also issued a statement apologizing for the hoodie and saying that it has been removed from sale. The company has also announced that it will be donating 1 million euros to organizations working to combat racism. Despite the apology and the donation, the protests have continued. This is a sign of the deep-seated anger that many South Africans feel over the issue of racism. Racism is a serious problem in South Africa. The country has a long history of racial discrimination, and many black South Africans still face prejudice and discrimination today. The "Coolest Monkey in the Jungle" hoodie is just one example of the kind of racism that many black South Africans experience on a daily basis. The protests over the hoodie are a sign of the frustration and anger that many black South Africans feel. It is important to remember that racism is not just about individual acts of discrimination. It is also about the systemic racism that exists in many societies. This systemic racism can be seen in the way that black people are often treated differently from white people in areas such as education, employment, and housing. The protests over the H&M hoodie are a reminder that racism is a problem that needs to be addressed on both an individual and a systemic level. We need to work together to create a more just and equitable society for all.

title: Boris Johnson's 'union adviser' Oliver Lewis quits after two weeks
text: Oliver Lewis, Boris Johnson's newly appointed "union adviser," has resigned after just two weeks in the role. The resignation comes amid a wave of criticism over Lewis's lack of experience in trade unions and his previous comments about workers. Lewis was appointed to the post on July 25, but his tenure has been dogged by controversy. He has been criticized for his lack of experience in trade unions, having previously worked as a journalist and political adviser. He has also been criticized for his previous comments about workers, including a 2013 article in which he described striking workers as "militant trade unionists" who were "holding the country to ransom." Lewis's resignation is a blow to Johnson, who has made strengthening the union between the UK's four nations a key part of his agenda. It also raises questions about the government's commitment to working with trade unions, which have been critical of Johnson's policies on issues such as Brexit and public sector pay. In a statement, Lewis said that he had decided to resign after "careful consideration." He said that he had "always believed that the government should work closely with trade unions" and that he had "hoped to be able to make a positive contribution in this role." However, he said that he had "come to the conclusion that I will not be able to do so effectively." The government has said that it will now begin the process of recruiting a new union adviser. It is unclear who will be appointed to the role, but it is likely that the government will be looking for someone with more experience in trade unions and who is less likely to make controversial comments. Lewis's resignation is the latest in a series of setbacks for Johnson. In recent weeks, he has been criticized for his handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, his decision to prorogue Parliament, and his relationship with his former aide Dominic Cummings. The resignation of his union adviser will only add to the pressure on Johnson, who is now facing calls to resign from some members of his own party. It remains to be seen whether Lewis's resignation will have a long-term impact on Johnson's government. However, it is clear that the government is now under increasing pressure to address the concerns of trade unions and to improve its relationship with them.

title: PM Narendra Modi says India will extend coronavirus lockdown until 3 May
text: PM Narendra Modi says India will extend coronavirus lockdown until 3 May Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has announced that the country's coronavirus lockdown will be extended until 3 May. The lockdown was originally due to end on 14 April, but Modi said that it was necessary to extend it in order to contain the spread of the virus. "The extension of the lockdown is a difficult decision, but it is necessary to save lives," Modi said in a televised address to the nation. "We cannot afford to let our guard down now." India has reported over 10,000 cases of coronavirus and more than 300 deaths. The vast majority of cases are in the country's major cities, including Mumbai, Delhi and Bengaluru. The lockdown has had a significant impact on the Indian economy. Many businesses have been forced to close, and millions of people have lost their jobs. The government has announced a number of measures to support businesses and workers, but it is unclear how long the economic impact will last. Modi said that the government would continue to monitor the situation and make decisions about the lockdown based on the latest scientific advice. He urged people to cooperate with the lockdown measures and to follow the government's guidelines on social distancing and hygiene. "This is a time for all of us to come together and fight this virus," Modi said. "We will overcome this challenge if we work together." The extension of the lockdown has been met with mixed reactions. Some people have welcomed the decision, saying that it is necessary to save lives. Others have expressed concern about the economic impact of the lockdown and the impact it will have on their livelihoods. The Indian government has said that it will provide financial assistance to people who have been affected by the lockdown. The government has also announced a number of measures to support businesses, including tax relief and loan guarantees. It is unclear how long the lockdown will last. Modi said that the government would continue to monitor the situation and make decisions based on the latest scientific advice.

title: China seeks to combat hi-tech crimewave
text: China has intensified its crackdown on high-tech crime, as the country grapples with a surge in sophisticated digital offenses. The government has launched a nationwide campaign, deploying cutting-edge technologies and enhancing collaboration among law enforcement agencies. Cybercrimes have become increasingly prevalent in China, fueled by advancements in artificial intelligence (AI), blockchain, and the internet of things (IoT). Criminals are exploiting these technologies to commit a wide range of offenses, including identity theft, financial fraud, and intellectual property infringement. In response, the Chinese government has established a dedicated task force, the National Anti-Telecom Network Fraud Center, to coordinate efforts against hi-tech crime. The task force is equipped with advanced analytical tools and a database of known criminal patterns to identify and disrupt these offenses. Law enforcement agencies are also leveraging AI and big data to enhance their crime-fighting capabilities. By analyzing vast amounts of data, they can detect suspicious activities and identify potential targets. Facial recognition systems and surveillance cameras are being deployed to track down suspects and prevent crimes from occurring. The government has also implemented stricter regulations on the sale and use of mobile phone cards, which are often used by criminals to register anonymous accounts and evade detection. Real-name registration and facial recognition are now required when purchasing a new SIM card, making it more difficult for criminals to operate anonymously. Furthermore, China is promoting international cooperation in the fight against hi-tech crime. The country has entered into agreements with other nations to share intelligence, extradite suspects, and develop joint strategies to address emerging threats. Despite these efforts, hi-tech crime remains a significant challenge for China. The rapid pace of technological advancement and the interconnectedness of the global internet provide criminals with new opportunities to commit offenses. The government and law enforcement agencies must continuously adapt and evolve their strategies to stay ahead of the evolving threat landscape. Alongside the government's efforts, the Chinese public is also playing a vital role in combating hi-tech crime. Citizens are encouraged to report suspicious activities and to be vigilant about protecting their personal information online. By working together, the government, law enforcement, and the public can create a safer and more secure digital environment for all.

title: Natalie Hemming murder: Jealous partner jailed for life
text: Natalie Hemming, 28, was strangled to death by her jealous partner, Aliaksei Litvinau, 33. Litvinau, a bodybuilder, was sentenced to life in prison at the Old Bailey on Wednesday. The court heard that Litvinau had been controlling and abusive towards Hemming throughout their relationship. He had accused her of cheating on him and had threatened to kill her on several occasions. On the day of the murder, Litvinau had gone to Hemming's flat in Fulham, west London. He found her in bed with another man and flew into a rage. He strangled her to death and then fled the scene. Hemming's body was discovered by her friend the following day. Litvinau was arrested a few days later. In a statement, Hemming's family said: "Natalie was a loving and devoted daughter, sister and friend. She was full of life and had so much to live for. Her brutal and senseless murder has left a huge hole in our lives." Detective Chief Inspector Helen Rance, who led the investigation, said: "This was a brutal and cowardly murder. Litvinau is a dangerous and possessive man who deserves to spend the rest of his life in prison." Domestic violence is a serious issue that affects millions of people every year. If you are in a relationship with someone who is controlling or abusive, it is important to seek help. There are many organizations that can provide support and advice. You can find more information on domestic violence on the BBC website: https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-45408567 The following are some of the signs of domestic violence: Physical abuse, such as hitting, punching, or kicking Emotional abuse, such as name-calling, belittling, or threatening Sexual abuse, such as rape or sexual assault Controlling behavior, such as isolating you from friends and family or monitoring your movements Financial abuse, such as controlling your money or preventing you from working If you are experiencing any of these signs, it is important to seek help. You can call the National Domestic Violence Hotline at 1-800-799-SAFE (7233) or visit their website at https://www.thehotline.org/.

title: Crash for cash: Five more guilty over insurance scam
text: Crash for Cash: Five More Guilty over Insurance Scam Five more people have been convicted in connection with a multi-million-pound insurance scam that involved staging car crashes. The group, aged between 24 and 48, were found guilty at St Albans Crown Court of conspiracy to commit fraud. The scam, which operated between 2012 and 2014, involved arranging for innocent drivers to be involved in crashes with vehicles driven by members of the gang. The gang would then file fraudulent insurance claims for injuries sustained in the crashes. The investigation into the scam was carried out by the City of London Police's Insurance Fraud Enforcement Department (IFED). Detective Inspector Steve Wilson, from IFED, said: "This was a highly organized and sophisticated scam that defrauded innocent drivers and insurance companies out of millions of pounds." "The investigation was complex and challenging, but we were determined to bring those responsible to justice. We hope that today's convictions will send a clear message that insurance fraud will not be tolerated." The five defendants were arrested in a series of dawn raids in 2016. They were charged with conspiracy to commit fraud and money laundering. During the trial, the court heard that the gang used a variety of methods to stage the crashes. In some cases, they would drive their vehicles into the back of innocent drivers' cars. In other cases, they would brake suddenly, causing the innocent driver to crash into them. The gang also used cloned license plates and fake insurance policies. This made it difficult for insurance companies to investigate the claims and identify the fraud. The court heard that the gang made more than £5 million from the scam. The money was used to fund a lavish lifestyle, including luxury cars, designer clothes, and holidays abroad. The five defendants were sentenced to a total of 16 years and 9 months in prison. The sentences range from 2 years and 9 months to 5 years and 6 months. Detective Inspector Wilson said: "These sentences reflect the seriousness of the crimes committed by these defendants. They showed a complete disregard for the welfare of innocent drivers and the integrity of the insurance industry." "We will continue to work with our partners to investigate and prosecute insurance fraud. We are determined to protect innocent drivers and insurance companies from this type of criminal activity."

title: Wiltshire Police chief Mike Veale accused of misconduct
text: Wiltshire Police Chief Mike Veale Accused of Misconduct The Chief Constable of Wiltshire Police, Mike Veale, is facing allegations of misconduct. The Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC) has launched an investigation into his conduct. The allegations against Veale relate to his handling of a complaint made against him by a member of the public. The complaint is understood to relate to an incident that occurred in 2020. Veale has denied any wrongdoing and has said that he will cooperate fully with the IOPC investigation. The IOPC is an independent body that investigates complaints against the police. It has the power to recommend disciplinary action against officers who are found to have breached the police code of conduct. The investigation into Veale is ongoing and it is not yet known when it will be concluded. Veale has been Chief Constable of Wiltshire Police since 2016. He previously served as Deputy Chief Constable of Avon and Somerset Police. He is a controversial figure who has been criticized for his handling of a number of high-profile cases. He was also criticized for his decision to purchase a £40,000 Range Rover for his personal use. The allegations against Veale have raised questions about his suitability to continue as Chief Constable of Wiltshire Police. The IOPC investigation will determine whether he has breached the police code of conduct and whether he should face any disciplinary action. Update: The IOPC has concluded its investigation into the allegations against Mike Veale. The IOPC found that Veale had breached the police code of conduct and recommended that he be dismissed from his post. Wiltshire Police has accepted the IOPC's recommendation and Veale has been dismissed from his post.

title: Young Tamils in Sri Lanka 'being held without charge'
text: In the aftermath of the Sri Lankan civil war, thousands of young Tamils have been detained by the government without charge. Many of these detainees have been held for months or even years, without access to lawyers or their families. The Sri Lankan government claims that these detainees are being held for their own safety, but human rights groups say that they are being held arbitrarily and that their detention is a violation of their human rights. The situation of these young Tamils is a source of great concern for the Tamil community in Sri Lanka. The families of the detainees are desperate for news of their loved ones, and they are calling on the government to release them immediately. The government has been accused of using the arrests of these young Tamils as a way to suppress dissent within the Tamil community. The government has denied these allegations, but the fact that so many young Tamils have been detained without charge has raised concerns about the government's commitment to human rights. The United Nations has called on the Sri Lankan government to release these detainees immediately. The UN has also called on the government to investigate the allegations of arbitrary detention and torture. The government has said that it is committed to human rights, but it has not yet taken any steps to release the detainees or to investigate the allegations of torture. title: The four-year spread of bubble tea across the UK
text: Bubble Tea Craze Sweeps Across the UK In the bustling streets of London, the tantalizing aroma of bubble tea fills the air. This refreshing Taiwanese beverage has taken the UK by storm, captivating taste buds and becoming a social media sensation. Within a mere four years, bubble tea has established a formidable presence in the British culinary landscape. Origins and Introduction Bubble tea, known as pearl milk tea in Taiwan, originated in the 1980s. The drink consists of brewed tea, milk, and tapioca balls (pearls), which give it its characteristic chewy texture. In 2018, bubble tea made its debut in the UK, initially gaining popularity among East Asian students. Rapid Expansion and Popularity Surge As the drink's allure spread beyond the Asian community, bubble tea shops began to mushroom across the country. Chinese supermarkets, shopping malls, and even high streets became hotspots for bubble tea enthusiasts. The unique taste and aesthetic appeal made it an instant hit, particularly among young people and social media influencers. Regional Variations and Adaptations While traditional bubble tea remains a favorite, UK-based vendors have introduced imaginative variations. From classic flavors like strawberry and mango to unconventional options like matcha and lavender, there is a bubble tea to suit every palate. The popularity of veganism has also led to the creation of plant-based milk options. Customization and Instagrammability One of the key factors that has fueled bubble tea's success is its high level of customization. Customers can choose their tea base, milk type, sweetness level, and pearl size. This allows for endless possibilities and creates a personalized experience. Moreover, the vibrant colors and playful textures of bubble tea make it highly Instagrammable, contributing to its viral spread on social media. Wider Cultural Impact Beyond its taste appeal, bubble tea has also become a symbol of youthful culture and social connection. Bubble tea shops have become popular meeting places and backdrops for content creators. The drink's success has also spurred the emergence of bubble tea-themed merchandise and events. Conclusion In just four short years, bubble tea has become a ubiquitous and beloved beverage in the UK. Its unique flavor profile, high level of customization, and Instagrammable aesthetic have all contributed to its widespread appeal. As bubble tea continues to evolve and adapt to British tastes, it is poised to remain a popular and vibrant addition to the culinary scene for years to come.

title: EA games web server hacked to host phishing website now fixed
text: EA Games Web Server Breach: Phishing Website Removed Electronic Arts (EA), a leading video game publisher, has confirmed that its web server was recently compromised by hackers. The breach allowed the attackers to host a phishing website on EA's servers, designed to steal personal and financial information from users. According to EA, the phishing website was hosted on a subdomain of the EA Help website. It was disguised as a legitimate EA login page and prompted users to enter their EA account credentials, including their username, password, and security questions. The breach was first discovered by security researcher Chad Seaman, who reported it to EA on Monday. EA immediately took down the phishing website and launched an investigation into the incident. "We are aware of a recent attempt to phish EA players through a fake website," EA said in a statement. "This website was not hosted on EA's servers, but it was able to spoof EA's login page." "We have taken down the phishing website and are continuing to investigate the incident. We recommend that players be cautious when entering their personal information online, and only use official EA websites and channels." It is unclear at this time how many users may have been affected by the phishing scam. EA has advised users to change their EA account passwords immediately and be wary of any suspicious emails or websites that claim to be from EA. The breach is a reminder of the importance of online security and the need for users to be vigilant when entering personal information online. It is also a reminder for companies to invest in robust security measures to protect their data and their customers' privacy. EA has not disclosed any further details about the breach, including how the hackers gained access to its web server or what measures it is taking to prevent similar incidents in the future. title: WW2's 'Spitfire Women': Eleanor Wadsworth, one of last female pilots, dies
text: Eleanor Wadsworth, One of the Last Female Spitfire Pilots of World War II, Dies Eleanor Wadsworth, one of the last surviving female pilots who flew Spitfires during World War II, has passed away at the age of 100. Wadsworth, who hailed from Ulverston, Cumbria, joined the Air Transport Auxiliary (ATA) in 1943. The ATA was responsible for ferrying aircraft from factories to operational units, a vital role in supporting the war effort. Despite facing prejudice and skepticism as a woman in a male-dominated field, Wadsworth proved to be an exceptional pilot. She flew over 900 aircraft during her time with the ATA, including Spitfires, Hurricanes, and Wellingtons. Her fearless spirit and unwavering determination earned her the admiration of her colleagues. "She was one of the finest and most courageous pilots I ever flew with," said John Hemingway, a fellow ATA pilot. After the war, Wadsworth continued to fly, working as an instructor and test pilot. She also became an advocate for women in aviation, sharing her experiences and encouraging others to pursue their dreams. In 2018, she was awarded the MBE for her services to aviation. At the ceremony, she met Prince Charles, who praised her as an "inspiration to us all." Eleanor Wadsworth's passing marks the end of an era. She was one of the pioneers who paved the way for women in aviation, demonstrating that they could excel in even the most challenging of fields. Her legacy lives on in the countless women who have followed in her footsteps, inspired by her courage, determination, and unwavering passion for flying. In a tribute to her life, the RAF said: "Eleanor was a remarkable woman who made a significant contribution to our country during and after the war. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her." Eleanor Wadsworth's memory will continue to inspire generations of aviators to come, reminding us of the indomitable spirit that can overcome any obstacle.

title: Fonseka political prisoner - former CJ
text: In the annals of Sri Lankan history, the saga of Sarath Fonseka, the former Chief of Defence Staff and one-time political prisoner, remains a tale of intrigue, conflict, and societal upheaval. Fonseka's rise to prominence came during the final stages of the Sri Lankan Civil War, where he played a pivotal role in defeating the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) in 2009. As a venerated military figure, he enjoyed widespread public support and was hailed as a war hero. However, his political aspirations would soon set him on a collision course with the government. In 2010, Fonseka challenged incumbent President Mahinda Rajapaksa in the presidential election. The campaign was fiercely contested, with allegations of voter fraud and intimidation. After a narrow defeat, Fonseka found himself the target of political persecution. He was arrested on fabricated charges of conspiring against the government and sentenced to two and a half years in prison. Fonseka's imprisonment sparked international condemnation and raised concerns about the state of democracy in Sri Lanka. The former war hero became a symbol of political oppression, with his supporters organizing protests and demanding his release. After serving his sentence, Fonseka was released in 2012, but he remained under restrictions and surveillance. Following the electoral defeat of Rajapaksa in 2015, Fonseka's political fortunes took a turn. He was elected to parliament in 2016 and joined the government of President Maithripala Sirisena. However, his tenure was marked by controversy, with allegations of corruption and a strained relationship with the ruling party. Fonseka's legacy remains a complex and contested one. His military accomplishments are undeniable, yet his political actions have been divisive. His arrest and imprisonment cast a shadow over Sri Lanka's post-war transition and raised questions about the government's commitment to democratic principles. Today, Fonseka is a vocal critic of the Rajapaksa regime, which has returned to power. He remains a symbol of both the triumph and the tribulations of a nation grappling with its past and present. The story of Sarath Fonseka is a reminder of the often-fragile nature of democracy and the price paid by those who dare to challenge the powerful.

title: Amazonian groups sue French supermarket chain over deforestation
text: Amazonian Groups Sue French Supermarket Chain over Deforestation Indigenous groups from the Amazon rainforest have filed a lawsuit against a French supermarket chain, accusing it of contributing to deforestation in the region. The lawsuit, filed with the French courts, alleges that the supermarket chain has been sourcing products from suppliers linked to the destruction of the Amazon rainforest. The lawsuit was filed by the Coordination of Indigenous Organizations of the Brazilian Amazon (COIAB) and the Amazon Environmental Research Institute (IPAM). The groups claim that the supermarket chain has been sourcing products such as beef, soy, and palm oil from suppliers who have cleared large areas of rainforest to make way for agriculture. The lawsuit alleges that the supermarket chain has failed to take adequate steps to ensure that its products are not contributing to deforestation. The groups claim that the supermarket chain has not conducted proper due diligence on its suppliers and has not taken steps to reduce the risk of sourcing products from deforested areas. The lawsuit is seeking an injunction to prevent the supermarket chain from sourcing products from suppliers linked to deforestation. The groups are also seeking damages for the environmental damage caused by the deforestation. The lawsuit is the latest in a series of legal actions brought against companies accused of contributing to deforestation in the Amazon rainforest. In recent years, a number of companies have been sued by investors, environmental groups, and indigenous communities. The Amazon rainforest is one of the most important ecosystems on Earth. It is home to an estimated 10% of the world's known species and plays a vital role in regulating the global climate. However, the rainforest is under threat from deforestation, which is driven by the demand for commodities such as beef, soy, and palm oil. Deforestation is a major problem in the Amazon rainforest. In 2020, an area of rainforest the size of Portugal was cleared. This deforestation is having a devastating impact on the environment and on the indigenous communities who live in the rainforest. The lawsuit against the supermarket chain is an important step towards holding companies accountable for their role in deforestation. The lawsuit could set a precedent for future legal actions against companies that are linked to deforestation.

title: Chinese police uncover huge fake jellyfish 'scam'
text: In a shocking bust, Chinese authorities have uncovered a massive counterfeit jellyfish operation, seizing over 160 tons of artificial jellyfish destined for dinner tables around the country. The operation, which spanned multiple provinces, involved the production and sale of fake jellyfish made from a mixture of industrial gelatin, salt, and alum, posing serious health risks to unsuspecting consumers. Jellyfish, a popular delicacy in China, is harvested from the ocean or farmed in coastal areas. However, the high demand and lucrative prices have led to a surge in counterfeiting, with fraudulent products flooding the market. The fake jellyfish were manufactured in clandestine workshops, where cheap ingredients were combined to create a semblance of the real thing. The artificial jellyfish were then sold to restaurants and seafood markets, often mixed in with genuine jellyfish to maximize profits. The scam was exposed following a tip-off to police in the eastern city of Taizhou, Zhejiang Province. A preliminary investigation revealed a network of suppliers, manufacturers, and distributors involved in the illicit trade. Raids conducted across several provinces uncovered numerous production facilities, where hundreds of workers were busy manufacturing the fake jellyfish. Tons of raw materials and finished products were confiscated, along with equipment used in the production process. Police arrested over 50 suspects, including the alleged mastermind behind the operation. The suspects face charges ranging from fraud to producing and selling harmful food products. The seizure of the fake jellyfish is a major victory for food safety regulators in China, who have been cracking down on counterfeit and adulterated food products in recent years. The case has also highlighted the need for increased vigilance in the seafood industry, where counterfeiting remains a persistent problem. Experts warn that consuming fake jellyfish can have severe consequences for health. Industrial gelatin, a primary component in the counterfeit products, is not intended for human consumption and can contain toxic substances. Alum, another ingredient used in the fake jellyfish, can cause gastrointestinal problems and kidney damage. Consumers are urged to be wary of suspiciously low prices for jellyfish and to purchase seafood from reputable sources. Restaurants and seafood markets should also be vigilant and ensure that their suppliers are legitimate. The authorities are continuing to investigate the case and have vowed to prosecute all those involved in the counterfeit jellyfish operation to the fullest extent of the law.

title: Covid: Minister rules out vaccine passports in UK
text: Covid: Minister rules out vaccine passports in UK The UK government has ruled out introducing vaccine passports for domestic use, following a review of their potential benefits and risks. Health Minister Sajid Javid said on Monday that the government had "carefully considered" the use of vaccine passports, but had concluded that they "are not a proportionate way" to tackle the spread of Covid-19. He said that the government was "confident" that the current measures in place, such as the vaccination programme and the NHS Covid Pass, were sufficient to "manage the risks" of the virus. The decision comes after a six-week consultation on the potential use of vaccine passports, which received more than 150,000 responses. The consultation found that there was "no consensus" on the use of vaccine passports, with some people supporting their use and others strongly opposed. The government also considered the potential impact of vaccine passports on civil liberties and the economy, and concluded that they would "have a significant and disproportionate impact on certain groups in society". The government's decision has been welcomed by some, who argue that vaccine passports are discriminatory and could lead to a "two-tier" society. However, others have expressed disappointment, arguing that vaccine passports could be an effective way to reduce the spread of the virus and protect the NHS. The government has said that it will continue to monitor the situation and will "not hesitate" to introduce vaccine passports if they become necessary in the future. In the meantime, the government is urging people to get vaccinated and to follow the current Covid-19 restrictions. It reflects the government's view that the current measures in place are sufficient to manage the risks of the virus, and that vaccine passports would be disproportionate and discriminatory. The decision is likely to be welcomed by some, but it may also lead to disappointment from others who believe that vaccine passports could be an effective way to reduce the spread of the virus. title: Trade talks 'must include healthcare'
text: Trade talks 'must include healthcare' Trade deals should not be negotiated without addressing the impact on healthcare systems, a leading health charity has warned. Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) said it was "deeply concerned" about the secrecy surrounding trade talks, which it said could "undermine access to affordable medicines". The charity is calling for trade deals to be transparent and to include clear safeguards to protect public health. It comes as the UK government prepares to negotiate a trade deal with the US. The US has been pushing for changes to the NHS that could lead to higher drug prices and reduced access to healthcare. MSF said it was "essential" that the UK government resisted these demands and put the protection of the NHS first. "Trade deals can have a huge impact on our health, but they are often negotiated in secret, with little or no input from the public," said Rachel Kiddell-Monroe, MSF's UK director. "We are deeply concerned that trade talks could undermine access to affordable medicines and other essential healthcare services. We are calling for trade deals to be transparent and to include clear safeguards to protect public health." MSF's concerns are echoed by other health organisations. The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that trade deals can lead to "higher prices, reduced access to medicines, and weakened health systems". The European Public Health Alliance (EPHA) has also called for trade deals to be transparent and to include safeguards to protect public health. "Trade deals are not just about economics. They can have a profound impact on our health and well-being," said EPHA director Johanna Hanefeld. "We need to make sure that trade deals are negotiated in the interests of public health, not just the interests of big business." The UK government has said it is committed to protecting the NHS in trade talks. However, it has also said that it is willing to consider changes to the NHS if they are "in the best interests of the UK". MSF said it was "essential" that the UK government resisted US demands to change the NHS. "The NHS is one of the UK's most cherished institutions. It provides high-quality healthcare to all, regardless of their ability to pay," said Kiddell-Monroe. "We must not allow trade deals to undermine the NHS and its commitment to universal healthcare."

title: Loughborough University student died from drugs mix
text: A Loughborough University student has died after taking a fatal combination of drugs, an inquest has heard. Megan Pollitt, 19, was found unresponsive in her flat on 10 November 2021. Paramedics were called but were unable to revive her. An inquest into her death at Loughborough Coroners' Court heard that Ms Pollitt had taken a combination of cocaine, ketamine and alcohol. The medical cause of death was given as mixed drug toxicity. The inquest heard that Ms Pollitt had been out with friends on the evening of 9 November. She returned to her flat in the early hours of the morning and took the drugs. Her flatmates found her unresponsive later that day and called for help. title: Lowest ever winter deaths recorded
text: The number of deaths in England during the winter months has fallen to its lowest level on record, according to new figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS). Between December 2022 and March 2023, there were 113,600 deaths in England, which is 15.6% lower than the average number of deaths during the same period over the last five years. The ONS said that the decrease in winter deaths is likely to be due to a number of factors, including the success of the Covid-19 vaccination program and the mild winter weather. Dr. Julie Stanborough, head of mortality analysis at the ONS, said: "The decrease in winter deaths is good news and is likely to be due to a number of factors, including the success of the Covid-19 vaccination program and the mild winter weather. "However, it is important to note that the number of deaths in England is still higher than it was before the pandemic, and we are still seeing excess deaths among people aged 65 and over." The ONS figures also show that the number of deaths from Covid-19 in England during the winter months fell by 86% compared to the previous year. This is likely to be due to the success of the vaccination program, which has reduced the number of people who are becoming seriously ill from the virus. The decrease in winter deaths is a positive sign, but it is important to remember that the number of deaths in England is still higher than it was before the pandemic. title: Amazon told to answer Deliveroo deal concerns in five days
text: Amazon has been given five days to address competition concerns over its proposed deal to buy food delivery service Deliveroo. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) said its initial probe had raised issues about the tie-up, which it fears could lead to higher prices, less choice, and reduced innovation in the sector. The CMA said it had "reasonable grounds for believing that the merger may result in a substantial lessening of competition." It has now launched a Phase 2 investigation, which will give Amazon and Deliveroo the chance to respond to the concerns. The CMA said its concerns center on the following areas: The combined market share of Amazon and Deliveroo: Amazon is already a major player in the online grocery market, while Deliveroo is one of the UK's leading food delivery services. The CMA is worried that the tie-up could give the combined company too much control over the market, leading to higher prices for consumers. The potential for Amazon to use its data to gain an unfair advantage: Amazon has vast amounts of data on its customers' shopping habits. The CMA is concerned that it could use this data to give Deliveroo an unfair advantage over its rivals, for example, by offering exclusive discounts or promotions to Amazon Prime members. The impact on innovation: The CMA is concerned that the tie-up could stifle innovation in the food delivery sector. Amazon and Deliveroo are both large companies with a strong track record of innovation. However, the CMA is worried that the deal could lead to less competition and less investment in new products and services. The CMA has given Amazon and Deliveroo five working days to submit their responses to these concerns. The companies will then have the opportunity to make further representations before the CMA makes a final decision on whether to block the deal. If the CMA does decide to block the deal, it would be a major setback for Amazon's ambitions in the UK grocery market. It would also be a blow to Deliveroo, which is currently facing intense competition from Uber Eats and other rivals. The CMA's investigation is expected to conclude by the end of the year.

title: China quake: Rescue teams blast roads amid aftershocks
text: Amid the devastation wrought by Monday's deadly earthquake in China, rescue teams are working tirelessly to reach survivors trapped under the rubble. title: The spying game: China's global network
text: In the shadowy realm of international espionage, China has emerged as a formidable player. Its sprawling global network of spies operates with stealth and precision, seeking to gather intelligence, influence foreign governments, and advance its own geopolitical agenda. China's intelligence apparatus is vast and well-resourced. The Ministry of State Security (MSS) is responsible for internal and external intelligence operations, while the People's Liberation Army (PLA) has a significant intelligence arm known as the General Staff Department. These agencies employ a wide range of methods, from traditional human intelligence to sophisticated cyberwarfare techniques. China's spying network extends far beyond its borders. It has been accused of operating covert operations in over 100 countries, targeting foreign governments, businesses, and dissidents. In the United States, for example, the FBI has investigated numerous cases of Chinese espionage, including the hacking of government computer systems and the theft of trade secrets. One of the key tactics employed by China's spies is the use of "honeypots" – individuals who are recruited to provide information or access to sensitive targets. These honeypots can be found in a variety of settings, from academic institutions to diplomatic functions. They are often well-educated and well-connected, making them ideal for gathering information on political, economic, and military matters. China's spying activities have raised concerns among Western governments, who see it as a threat to their national security. In 2018, the United States expelled dozens of Chinese diplomats suspected of spying, and the European Union has also expressed concerns about China's intelligence operations. However, China has defended its spying activities as necessary for protecting its national interests. It argues that other countries, including the United States, also engage in espionage, and that its own activities are no more aggressive or intrusive. The spying game between China and other countries is likely to continue for the foreseeable future. As China's global power and influence grows, so too will the need for it to maintain a robust intelligence network. Western governments will need to remain vigilant and develop effective counterintelligence measures to protect their own national security while also seeking to engage with China in a constructive and cooperative manner.

title: Egypt arrests: UN condemns detention of human rights advocates
text: The United Nations has condemned the detention of human rights advocates in Egypt, calling for their immediate release. Three prominent activists were arrested on 29 November 2022, during a raid on the Egyptian Commission for Rights and Freedoms (ECRF), a leading human rights organization. The activists, ECRF director Mohamed Zaree, researcher Haytham Mohamedain, and lawyer Abdelrahman Tarek, were taken to an unknown location and have since been held incommunicado. The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Volker Türk, expressed deep concern about the arrests and called for the activists' immediate release. "The detention of human rights defenders in Egypt is a deeply troubling development," Türk said. "These individuals are playing a vital role in promoting and protecting human rights in the country, and their work should be supported, not criminalized." The UN Human Rights Office (OHCHR) said that the arrests appear to be part of a broader crackdown on civil society in Egypt. "We have received reports of numerous other human rights defenders being subjected to arbitrary arrests, detention, and harassment in recent months," said OHCHR spokesperson Jeremy Laurence. "These actions are a violation of Egypt's international obligations and must stop." The Egyptian government has not commented publicly on the arrests of the three ECRF activists. However, the government has a history of cracking down on dissent and human rights activism. In recent years, the Egyptian government has imprisoned dozens of human rights activists, journalists, and political dissidents. Many of these individuals have been held for months or even years without charge or trial. The crackdown on dissent has been particularly severe since the 2013 military coup that brought President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi to power. Sisi has overseen a wide-ranging crackdown on civil society, media, and political opposition. The international community has repeatedly condemned the Egyptian government's crackdown on dissent. In 2021, the UN Human Rights Council passed a resolution calling on Egypt to release all political prisoners and to respect the rights of human rights defenders. However, the Egyptian government has ignored the international community's calls for reform. The arrests of the three ECRF activists are a further indication that the government is not willing to tolerate any form of dissent.

title: Paddy Armstrong in offer to help Guildford Four inquest

title: RNLI 'float' advice after 18 deaths off Welsh coast
text: RNLI ‘Float’ Advice After 18 Deaths Off Welsh Coast Following the tragic loss of 18 lives in the Bristol Channel in recent weeks, the RNLI has issued an urgent reminder about the importance of wearing a life jacket or buoyancy aid when on or near the water. The warning comes as the organization released statistics showing that there have been 18 accidental drownings in the Welsh coastal region this year, compared to 10 in the same period last year. The RNLI's 'Float to Live' campaign aims to raise awareness of the risks associated with cold water shock and the importance of staying afloat in the event of an accident. Cold water shock is a sudden and potentially fatal involuntary gasp for air caused by the body's reaction to being immersed in cold water. It can lead to drowning even in shallow water. The RNLI's Water Safety Lead, Chris Cousens, said: "We cannot stress enough how vital it is to wear a life jacket or buoyancy aid when on or near the water, especially during the colder months. Cold water shock is a real and serious risk, and it can affect anyone, regardless of their swimming ability." The RNLI recommends that anyone going on or near the water should: Wear a life jacket or buoyancy aid that is the correct size and fit. Tell someone where you are going and when you expect to be back. Check the weather forecast and tide times before you set off. Carry a means of communication, such as a mobile phone in a waterproof case. Cousens added: "We urge everyone to take heed of our advice and to always put safety first. By following these simple steps, we can all help to reduce the risk of drowning and save lives." The RNLI also offers free Float to Live leaflets and resources for anyone who wants to learn more about water safety. These can be downloaded from the RNLI website or obtained from RNLI lifeboat stations. Remember, if you see someone in trouble in the water, call 999 or 112 immediately.

title: Inca success in Peruvian Andes 'thanks to llama dung'
text: Inca Success in Peruvian Andes 'Thanks to Llama Dung' In the unforgiving environment of the Peruvian Andes, the Incas flourished for centuries thanks in part to their clever use of llama dung. It was used to cook food, warm homes, and light public spaces. The Incas even developed a specialized type of stove, known as a "fogón," that was designed to burn llama dung optimally. But llama dung's value extended far beyond fuel. The Incas discovered that it was also an excellent fertilizer. When mixed with soil, llama dung provided essential nutrients for crops. This allowed the Incas to cultivate a wide variety of plants at high altitudes, where farming would otherwise have been impossible. Inca farmers used llama dung to build raised fields, known as "andenes." These elevated platforms created a microclimate that was more conducive to plant growth. By terracing the slopes of the Andes, the Incas were able to maximize agricultural productivity and feed their growing population. Llama dung also played a role in Inca construction. The Incas used it to make mortar, which was used to build walls, temples, and palaces. The dung was mixed with clay and other materials to create a strong and durable adhesive. This enabled the Incas to build impressive structures that have withstood the test of time. In addition to its practical applications, llama dung also had cultural significance for the Incas. It was used in religious ceremonies and festivals. The smoke from burning llama dung was believed to have purifying properties. It was also used to create ceremonial fires, which were used to communicate with the gods. The Inca civilization is a testament to the ingenuity and adaptability of human societies. By harnessing the unique properties of llama dung, the Incas were able to thrive in a challenging environment. title: Saudi Arabia profile - overview
text: Saudi Arabia: A Land of Contrasts Saudi Arabia, the birthplace of Islam and custodian of its holiest sites, is a land of ancient traditions and modern ambitions. Spanning a vast and arid desert landscape, the kingdom is an enigma, a land of paradoxes and contradictions. With its vast oil reserves and an authoritarian monarchy, Saudi Arabia is a wealthy nation and a major player on the world stage. Yet, it also faces significant social and economic challenges, including high youth unemployment and a strict adherence to Islamic law. Geography and Population: Saudi Arabia occupies the vast Arabian Peninsula, bordered by Jordan and Iraq to the north, Kuwait to the northeast, Qatar, Bahrain, and the United Arab Emirates to the east, Yemen to the south, and Oman to the southeast. With a land area of over 2 million square kilometers, it is the largest country in the Middle East and the fifth largest in the world. The population of Saudi Arabia is estimated to be around 36 million, including a large expatriate workforce. The majority of the population are Muslims, with a small Christian minority. The official language is Arabic, and the capital city is Riyadh. History and Politics: Saudi Arabia was founded in 1932 by King Abdulaziz Ibn Saud, who unified the various tribes of the Arabian Peninsula under a single monarchy. The kingdom has been ruled by the House of Saud ever since. Saudi Arabia is an absolute monarchy, with the king wielding ultimate authority over all aspects of government and society. The king is advised by a Council of Ministers, appointed by him. There is no elected parliament or political parties. Economy: Saudi Arabia has one of the largest and most diversified economies in the Middle East. However, it is heavily dependent on oil, which accounts for the majority of its exports and government revenue. In recent years, the government has implemented reforms to reduce its reliance on oil and promote economic diversification. These include investments in renewable energy, tourism, and other non-oil sectors. Culture and Society: Saudi Arabia is a deeply conservative society, shaped by Islamic law and tradition. Women face significant restrictions, including legal limitations on their movement, education, and employment. However, there have been some signs of social liberalization in recent years. In 2018, women were granted the right to drive, and there have been increased efforts to promote female empowerment. Challenges and Future Outlook: Saudi Arabia faces a number of challenges, including high youth unemployment, income inequality, and environmental degradation. The country also faces geopolitical risks, including the ongoing conflict in Yemen and tensions with Iran. The future of Saudi Arabia depends on its ability to address these challenges and adapt to a changing global economy. The kingdom's ambitious Vision 2030 plan aims to diversify the economy, create new jobs, and improve the quality of life for its citizens. The success of this plan will shape the destiny of Saudi Arabia for decades to come.

title: Pangbourne sprays to kill oak processionary caterpillar 'dangerous'
