The remains of an ancient fort, perched on a rugged clifftop, are believed to have been the stronghold of Scaithach and her formidable daughters. Beyond Eigg, the other Small Isles hold their own enchanting stories. On the Isle of Muck, the legend of "The Red Lady of Muck" persists. She is said to haunt the island's ancient ruins, a spectral figure guarding hidden treasures and secrets. On the Isle of Rùm, tales of a giant race of people, known as the "Fomorians," are still whispered among locals. These mythical beings are said to have ruled the island in prehistoric times, leaving behind enigmatic stone structures and legends of their immense strength. As the sun sets over the Small Isles, casting long shadows across the landscape, the echoes of warrior women, legendary figures, and otherworldly tales continue to reverberate. These islands hold within their embrace a rich seam of history, myth, and folklore, inviting us to delve into a world where the boundaries between reality and imagination blur.

title: Evan Lloyd Evans jailed after 'appalling' horses case
text: Evan Lloyd Evans, 39, of Glandyfi, near Machynlleth, Powys, admitted 15 offences relating to the poor treatment of animals. Evans had been warned previously about the poor condition of the animals, and an RSPCA inspector found horses in "appalling" condition during a visit in March 2021. Evans was sentenced to 16 weeks in prison and was banned from keeping equines for life. The RSPCA said 18 horses were removed from the land, with five needing immediate veterinary treatment. Prosecutor Helen Tench said witnesses described the condition of the land as "a quagmire". She said Evans had been given advice from vets and the RSPCA on how to improve the horses' condition but had failed to act on it. "The photographs show the appalling condition that these horses were kept in," Ms Tench said. "They were standing in deep mud and their hooves were overgrown." Defending, Nia Lloyd said her client had not intended to cause the animals suffering. She said he had taken on more horses than he could cope with and had been struggling to pay for their feed and care. "He is not a cruel man and he is deeply remorseful for any suffering caused," Ms Lloyd said. Sentencing, Judge Timothy Petts said the case was "a sorry tale of neglect". He said Evans had "failed abjectly" to meet the needs of the animals in his care. "It's clear you were totally out of your depth," Judge Petts said. "You were keeping far too many horses and were simply unable to cope." The judge said the prison sentence and ban on keeping horses were necessary to protect animals from further suffering. Speaking after the case, RSPCA inspector Keith Hogben said: "This is one of the worst cases of neglect I have ever seen. "The horses were in appalling condition and were suffering unnecessarily. "We are pleased that Evans has been banned from keeping horses for life and hope that this sends out a clear message that animal cruelty will not be tolerated."

title: Euro 2016: Wales' Belarusian fan travels from New York
text: In the heart of Lyon, amidst the vibrant tapestry of Euro 2016, an unlikely figure emerged from the crowd, his passion for football transcending borders and oceans. Aliaksandr Hleb, a Belarusian native residing in New York, had embarked on an extraordinary journey to witness his beloved Wales take on Slovakia in the group stages. Hleb's love for Wales began during his time as a player for Arsenal, where he developed close friendships with Welsh stalwarts such as Aaron Ramsey and Gareth Bale. Inspired by their unwavering spirit and camaraderie, he adopted the Welsh cause as his own. Despite the vast distance, Hleb's determination to experience the thrill of Euro 2016 firsthand was unwavering. He booked flights, arranged accommodation, and meticulously planned his itinerary. As the day of the match approached, he boarded a transatlantic flight, his heart pounding with anticipation. Upon arriving in Lyon, Hleb immersed himself in the electric atmosphere surrounding the stadium. He donned his Wales jersey, proudly displaying his adopted nation's colors. As he made his way to his seat, he was greeted with warm smiles and words of encouragement from fellow Welsh fans. The match itself was a rollercoaster of emotions. Wales took an early lead, only to concede an equalizer shortly after. Hleb's nerves frayed as the tension mounted. But in the dying minutes of the match, Hal Robson-Kanu struck a magnificent goal to secure a memorable victory for Wales. Hleb erupted in jubilation, his voice hoarse from cheering. He hugged the strangers around him, sharing in their collective joy. At that moment, he felt an unbreakable bond with the Welsh people and their resilient spirit. After the match, Hleb had the opportunity to meet some of his Welsh heroes, including Ramsey and Bale. They thanked him for his unwavering support and shared their thoughts on the tournament. Hleb left the stadium that night with a heart filled with gratitude and memories that would last a lifetime. Hleb's journey to Euro 2016 was not merely about supporting a football team. It was a testament to the power of passion, friendship, and the indomitable spirit of human connection. His story serves as a reminder that despite differences in nationality, language, or distance, the love of sport can unite people from all walks of life.

title: Rural communities being ignored and underrated, say peers
text: Amidst the bustling metropolises and technological advancements, rural communities often find themselves overlooked and undervalued. Yet, the vital role they play in shaping our society and economy cannot be understated. A recent report from the House of Lords has highlighted the urgent need to address the growing disparity between urban and rural areas. Rural communities face unique challenges that are often overlooked by policymakers. The decline of traditional industries, such as farming and mining, has led to economic stagnation in many regions. Lack of access to essential services, including healthcare, education, and transportation, further compounds the challenges faced by rural residents. The report emphasizes that the neglect of rural communities has profound consequences not only for those living in these areas but for the nation as a whole. Rural areas provide vital ecosystem services, such as clean air and water, that benefit everyone. They also serve as important centers for food production, tourism, and cultural heritage. Furthermore, rural communities play a crucial role in maintaining social cohesion and stability. The close-knit nature of these communities fosters strong bonds and a sense of belonging, which are essential for a thriving society. Ignoring the needs of rural communities not only undermines their well-being but also weakens the fabric of our nation. The report calls for a comprehensive approach to tackling the challenges facing rural communities. This includes investing in infrastructure, such as broadband internet and transportation networks, to improve connectivity and economic opportunities. It also emphasizes the need for tailored support for businesses and industries that are specific to rural areas. Moreover, the report highlights the importance of empowering rural communities to have a voice in decision-making that affects them. This can be achieved through greater representation in government and local authorities, as well as the establishment of community-led organizations that can advocate for their needs. By recognizing the value of rural communities and addressing the challenges they face, we can create a more balanced and prosperous society. The neglect of rural areas is a national issue that requires urgent attention. It is time for policymakers and all stakeholders to prioritize the needs of these communities and ensure that they are given the opportunities they deserve to thrive and contribute to the well-being of our nation.

title: Tories would scrap stamp duty on £250,000 homes
text: The Conservative Party has pledged to scrap stamp duty on all homes worth up to £250,000 in England and Northern Ireland if it wins the next general election. The policy, which would come into effect from April 2025, is designed to help first-time buyers and those moving up the property ladder. Stamp duty is a tax on the purchase of property in England and Northern Ireland. The amount of tax you pay depends on the value of the property and whether you are a first-time buyer. First-time buyers currently pay no stamp duty on properties up to £300,000, and 5% on the portion of the property price between £300,000 and £500,000. Under the Conservative Party's proposals, first-time buyers would pay no stamp duty on properties up to £250,000, and 5% on the portion of the property price between £250,000 and £500,000. This would mean that first-time buyers would save up to £2,500 on the purchase of a £250,000 home. The Conservative Party has also pledged to increase the threshold at which people start paying stamp duty on their main home from £125,000 to £250,000. This would mean that people would not have to pay any stamp duty on the first £250,000 of their home's value, regardless of whether they were a first-time buyer or not. The Conservative Party says that its stamp duty cuts would help to boost the housing market and make it easier for people to buy a home. The policy has been welcomed by the property industry, but critics have argued that it will benefit wealthy homeowners more than first-time buyers. The Liberal Democrats have pledged to scrap stamp duty for first-time buyers on all homes under £500,000, while Labour has pledged to scrap stamp duty for all first-time buyers on homes under £250,000. The next general election is due to be held in 2024.

title: Protests against train fare rises held at more than 100 stations
text: In a widespread display of discontent, protesters took to over 100 railway stations across the United Kingdom on Saturday to voice their opposition to impending train fare increases. The demonstrations, organized by the pressure group Action for Rail, were intended to send a clear message to the government and train operating companies that the proposed fare hikes are unacceptable. The protests, which saw participation from commuters, trade unions, and political organizations, were marked by a lively atmosphere. At London's Euston station, hundreds of demonstrators gathered, waving placards and chanting slogans such as "Stop the fare rises" and "Rail for all, not just the rich." Similar scenes unfolded at stations in Manchester, Birmingham, Glasgow, and Edinburgh, among others. The planned fare increases, which are expected to take effect in March, have been widely criticized for placing an undue burden on commuters already struggling with the rising cost of living. Action for Rail estimates that the average commuter will face an increase of £100 per year, a figure that many find excessive. "These fare increases are a disgrace," declared Sarah, a commuter from Leeds. "The government and train companies are out of touch with the reality of people's lives. We can't afford these hikes, and we're not going to stand for them." The protests have received support from several Labour Party politicians, including leader Keir Starmer, who has pledged to freeze fares if elected. The government, however, has defended the increases, arguing that they are necessary to maintain and improve rail services. "We understand that people are facing financial pressures, but these fare rises are essential to ensure we have a safe and reliable railway system," said a spokesperson for the Department for Transport. Despite the government's stance, protesters remain determined to fight the fare increases. Action for Rail has vowed to continue organizing demonstrations and campaigning for affordable rail travel. "We won't give up," said Mark, a spokesperson for the group. "These fare rises are unfair, and we're going to keep fighting until they're scrapped." The protests have sparked a wider debate about the future of rail travel in the UK. Many argue that the current system, which is heavily reliant on fare revenue, is unsustainable and needs to be reformed. Alternative funding models, such as a tax on road use or increased government subsidies, have been proposed. As the government prepares to implement the fare increases, it faces growing pressure to reconsider. The protests have shown that public anger is running high, and it remains to be seen whether the government will be able to weather the storm.

title: Sir Philip Green drops 'gagging' legal action
text: Sir Philip Green drops 'gagging' legal action Sir Philip Green has dropped his legal action against the Daily Telegraph newspaper over an article that accused him of sexual harassment and racial abuse. The billionaire businessman had taken legal action against the newspaper and one of its journalists over the article, which was published in October 2018. But on Monday, Green's lawyers told the High Court in London that he was discontinuing the action. The Telegraph had reported that Green had been accused of sexual harassment and racial abuse by five women. The newspaper also alleged that Green had used non-disclosure agreements (NDAs) to silence his accusers. Green has denied the allegations and said that he will not be silenced. In a statement, Green's lawyers said: "Sir Philip Green has decided to discontinue his claim against the Telegraph and its journalist. "Sir Philip maintains that the allegations made against him are untrue and that he has not engaged in any wrongdoing. "However, Sir Philip has taken the decision to discontinue his claim in order to focus on his business and his family." The Telegraph said in a statement: "We are pleased that Sir Philip Green has dropped his legal action. "We stand by our story and we are confident that we would have been successful in defending our case in court." The decision to drop the legal action comes after a number of high-profile cases involving NDAs. In 2018, the former head of Harvey Weinstein's film studio, Harvey Weinstein, was accused of sexual harassment and assault by dozens of women. Weinstein has denied the allegations but has since been charged with rape and sexual assault. In the wake of the Weinstein scandal, a number of Hollywood actresses have spoken out about the use of NDAs to silence victims of sexual harassment and assault. In the UK, the government has launched a review of NDAs and their use in cases of sexual harassment and discrimination. The review is being led by the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and is due to report back in early 2020. The EHRC has said that it will consider whether NDAs are being used to prevent victims of sexual harassment and discrimination from speaking out. The review will also consider whether NDAs are being used to protect the reputations of powerful individuals and organisations.

title: Bombardier ruling: Q&A
text: Bombardier ruling: Q&A What is the Bombardier ruling? The Bombardier ruling is a decision by the World Trade Organization (WTO) that Canada provided illegal subsidies to Bombardier, a Canadian aircraft manufacturer. The ruling allows Boeing, an American aircraft manufacturer, to impose tariffs on Bombardier's planes. What is the background to the ruling? Boeing filed a complaint with the WTO in 2017, alleging that Canada had provided Bombardier with illegal subsidies. Canada denied the allegations, but the WTO ruled in Boeing's favor in 2020. What are the consequences of the ruling? The ruling allows Boeing to impose tariffs of up to 219% on Bombardier's C Series planes. This could make it very difficult for Bombardier to sell its planes in the United States. What is the Canadian government's response to the ruling? The Canadian government has said that it is "deeply disappointed" by the ruling. The government is considering appealing the ruling to the WTO's appellate body. What is the impact of the ruling on the Canadian aerospace industry? The ruling is a major blow to the Canadian aerospace industry. Bombardier is one of Canada's largest aerospace companies, and the tariffs could make it difficult for the company to compete with its rivals. What is the impact of the ruling on the US aerospace industry? The ruling could benefit the US aerospace industry. Boeing is one of the world's largest aircraft manufacturers, and the tariffs could make it more difficult for Bombardier to compete with Boeing in the US market. What is the likely next step? The Canadian government is likely to appeal the ruling to the WTO's appellate body. The appellate body is the highest court in the WTO, and its decision will be final. What is the broader impact of the ruling? The ruling could have a broader impact on the global aerospace industry. It could make it more difficult for governments to provide subsidies to their aerospace companies. This could lead to a more level playing field for aircraft manufacturers around the world.

title: Severn Trent 'used Uber drivers to look at water leaks'
text: Severn Trent Uses Uber Drivers to Detect Water Leaks Severn Trent, one of the UK's largest water companies, has implemented an innovative approach to identifying water leaks by collaborating with Uber drivers. This unique initiative leverages the vast network of Uber vehicles to efficiently survey streets and roads, using technology to locate potential leakages. The partnership between Severn Trent and Uber involves equipping Uber drivers with smartphones that are integrated with a specialized leak detection app. As they drive around, the app constantly monitors water pressure and other indicators, alerting drivers to any abnormalities that may suggest a leak. When a potential leak is identified, the Uber driver marks its location using the app and reports it to Severn Trent. The company then dispatches repair teams to investigate and address the issue promptly. This process allows for early detection and intervention, minimizing water loss and potential damage to properties. "We're always looking for innovative ways to improve our service to customers," said Stuart Jackson, Severn Trent's Director of Leakage. "Our partnership with Uber is a great example of how we can use technology to make our operations more efficient and effective." The use of Uber drivers for leak detection has several advantages over traditional methods. Firstly, it provides a widespread network of sensors across the company's operating area. Secondly, it enables real-time monitoring, meaning that leaks can be identified and reported as soon as they occur. Thirdly, it reduces the need for manual surveys and door-to-door inspections, saving time and resources. "We're delighted to be working with Severn Trent on this innovative project," said Tom Elvidge, Uber's Head of Business Development UK. "Our network of drivers is perfectly placed to help identify leaks in the water network, and we're confident that this partnership will make a real difference in reducing water loss and improving the quality of service for Severn Trent's customers." The collaboration between Severn Trent and Uber is expected to significantly enhance the company's ability to detect and repair leaks, delivering tangible benefits to both customers and the environment. As the initiative expands, it has the potential to become a model for other utility companies seeking to optimize their operations.

title: Websites told to ensure cookies comply with UK law
text: Websites told to ensure cookies comply with UK law The UK's data protection watchdog has told websites to ensure that their use of cookies complies with the law. The Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) has issued new guidance for website operators on how to make sure that their use of cookies is compliant with the UK's Privacy and Electronic Communications Regulations (PECR). The ICO's guidance states that website operators must obtain users' consent before using cookies, unless the cookies are strictly necessary for the website to function properly. The guidance also states that website operators must provide users with clear and concise information about the cookies they use, and must allow users to easily withdraw their consent. The ICO's new guidance follows a recent investigation into the use of cookies by several UK websites. The investigation found that many websites were not obtaining users' consent before using cookies, and were not providing users with clear and concise information about the cookies they were using. The ICO has warned that it will take enforcement action against website operators who fail to comply with the new guidance. The ICO has the power to impose fines of up to £500,000 on website operators who breach the PECR. The ICO's new guidance is a welcome step towards protecting users' privacy online. Cookies are small files that are stored on users' computers when they visit a website. Cookies can be used to track users' online activity, and to target them with advertising. The ICO's new guidance will help to ensure that website operators obtain users' consent before using cookies, and that users are provided with clear and concise information about the cookies that are being used. This will help to protect users' privacy and give them more control over their online experience. What are cookies? Cookies are small files that are stored on your computer or other device when you visit a website. They are used to store information about your visit, such as your language preferences, login details, and shopping cart contents. Why are cookies used? Cookies are used for a variety of purposes, including: To improve the user experience by remembering your preferences To track your browsing activity and target you with advertising To collect data about website usage and traffic patterns How can I control cookies? You can control the use of cookies through your browser settings. Most browsers allow you to block or delete cookies, or to only accept cookies from certain websites. What are the risks of cookies? Cookies can pose a privacy risk if they are used to track your online activity without your consent. They can also be used to store malicious software on your computer. How can I protect myself from the risks of cookies? You can protect yourself from the risks of cookies by: Using a browser that blocks or deletes cookies Only accepting cookies from websites that you trust Deleting cookies after you have visited a website

title: Extra £50m to reduce Welsh NHS waiting times announced
text: Extra £50m to reduce Welsh NHS waiting times announced Welsh Health Minister Eluned Morgan has announced an extra £50m of funding to reduce waiting times for NHS treatment in Wales. The money will be used to increase the number of operations and outpatient appointments, and to recruit more staff. The announcement comes as the latest NHS performance figures show that waiting times for planned care in Wales are at their highest level since records began. In the year to March 2023, the median waiting time for a planned operation in Wales was 36 weeks. This is up from 26 weeks in the previous year. The median waiting time for an outpatient appointment was 18 weeks, up from 12 weeks in the previous year. The Welsh government said the extra funding will help to reduce waiting times and improve patient care. Health Minister Eluned Morgan said: "I am committed to reducing waiting times for NHS treatment in Wales. "This extra funding will help us to do that by increasing the number of operations and outpatient appointments, and by recruiting more staff. "I know that waiting times are a major concern for patients and I am determined to do everything I can to improve the situation." The Welsh NHS Confederation welcomed the extra funding. Director Darren Hughes said: "This is a significant investment in the NHS in Wales and it is very much welcomed. "It will help us to reduce waiting times and improve patient care. "We will work with the Welsh government to ensure that this money is used effectively and to make a real difference to patients." The Royal College of Nursing (RCN) in Wales also welcomed the extra funding, but said that more needs to be done to address the underlying causes of long waiting times. RCN Wales Director Helen Whyley said: "This extra funding is welcome, but it is only a short-term solution. "We need to address the underlying causes of long waiting times, such as the shortage of nurses and other NHS staff. "The Welsh government needs to invest in training and retaining more NHS staff to ensure that we have a sustainable health service for the future."

title: Yemen war: UN agrees to send war crime experts
text: The United Nations has agreed to send a team of war crime experts to Yemen to investigate alleged atrocities committed during the country's seven-year conflict. The decision was made at a meeting of the UN Human Rights Council in Geneva on Thursday. The resolution was passed with 22 votes in favor, 11 against, and 14 abstentions. The team of experts will be tasked with investigating allegations of war crimes and crimes against humanity committed by all parties to the conflict. They will also provide recommendations on how to ensure accountability for these crimes. The UN has been calling for an independent investigation into the Yemen conflict for several years. In 2019, the UN Human Rights Council established a Group of Eminent Experts to investigate alleged human rights violations in Yemen. However, the group was unable to deploy to Yemen due to a lack of cooperation from the parties to the conflict. The decision to send a team of war crime experts to Yemen is a significant step forward in the fight for accountability in the country. The team will be able to gather evidence of war crimes and crimes against humanity, and their findings could be used to prosecute those responsible. The conflict in Yemen has been ongoing since 2015, when the Houthi rebel group seized control of the capital, Sanaa. The Saudi-led coalition intervened in the conflict in 2015, and the fighting has since resulted in the deaths of tens of thousands of civilians. The conflict has also caused a humanitarian crisis in Yemen, with millions of people displaced and facing food insecurity. The UN has called for a ceasefire in Yemen, but the fighting continues. The decision to send a team of war crime experts to Yemen is a welcome step forward in the fight for accountability in the country. The team will be able to gather evidence of war crimes and crimes against humanity, and their findings could be used to prosecute those responsible.

title: Lord Heseltine defends decision to vote for Lib Dems
text: Lord Heseltine has defended his decision to vote Liberal Democrat in the upcoming general election, saying that it is the "only way" to stop Brexit. The former Conservative minister said that he had "agonised" over his decision, but that he ultimately believes that it is the "right thing to do". "I have always been a Conservative, but I believe that Brexit is the wrong thing for our country," he said. "I have come to the conclusion that the only way to stop Brexit is to vote Liberal Democrat." Lord Heseltine's decision to vote Liberal Democrat is a significant blow to the Conservative Party. He is a highly respected figure in the party, and his decision is likely to sway other voters who are considering voting Liberal Democrat. The Liberal Democrats have welcomed Lord Heseltine's decision, saying that it is a "sign that the tide is turning" against Brexit. "We are delighted that Lord Heseltine has decided to join us in the fight against Brexit," said Liberal Democrat leader Vince Cable. "His decision is a sign that the tide is turning against Brexit, and that people are starting to realise that it is the wrong thing for our country." The Conservative Party has criticised Lord Heseltine's decision, saying that it is "a betrayal of the people who voted for him". "Lord Heseltine has betrayed the people who voted for him," said Conservative Party chairman Brandon Lewis. "He is putting his own personal views ahead of the interests of his constituents." Lord Heseltine's decision to vote Liberal Democrat is a further sign of the divisions within the Conservative Party over Brexit. The party is split between those who support Brexit and those who oppose it, and this division is likely to make it difficult for the party to win the next election. The Liberal Democrats are hoping to capitalise on the divisions within the Conservative Party and win the next election. The party is promising to hold a second referendum on Brexit, and this is likely to appeal to voters who are opposed to Brexit.

title: Wales Bill 'being rammed through' Parliament, says academic
text: The Wales Bill, which will devolve further powers to the Welsh government, has been "rammed through" Parliament, an academic has claimed. Professor Richard Wyn Jones, from Cardiff University, said the bill had been "rushed" through the legislative process without proper scrutiny. He said the UK government had "failed to engage" with the Welsh government and other stakeholders, and had "ignored" concerns about the bill's impact on devolution. "This is a deeply flawed bill that will have a negative impact on devolution in Wales," Prof Jones said. "It has been rushed through Parliament without proper scrutiny, and the UK government has failed to engage with the Welsh government and other stakeholders. "The bill will create a two-tier system of devolution in the UK, with Wales having less power than Scotland and Northern Ireland. This is a betrayal of the people of Wales." The Wales Bill was introduced to Parliament in July 2022, and was passed by the House of Commons in March 2023. It is currently being considered by the House of Lords. The bill devolves a number of powers to the Welsh government, including responsibility for health, education, and economic development. However, critics have argued that the bill does not go far enough, and that it will not give Wales the powers it needs to meet the challenges of the 21st century. Prof Jones said the bill was a "missed opportunity" to strengthen devolution in Wales. "This bill could have been a landmark piece of legislation that would have given Wales the powers it needs to thrive," he said. "But instead, it is a deeply flawed bill that will have a negative impact on devolution. "The UK government needs to think again about this bill, and to work with the Welsh government and other stakeholders to develop a bill that will truly strengthen devolution in Wales." The UK government has defended the Wales Bill, saying it will give Wales "more powers than ever before". A UK government spokesperson said: "The Wales Bill is a historic piece of legislation that will give Wales more powers than ever before. "It will give the Welsh government the power to make decisions on a wide range of issues that affect the people of Wales, including health, education, and economic development. "This bill is a testament to the UK government's commitment to devolution, and we believe it will make a real difference to the lives of people in Wales."

title: Girl guides call for airbrushed photos to be labelled
text: Girl Guides Call for Airbrushed Photos to Be Labelled The Girl Guides association has issued an urgent call for airbrushed photos to be clearly labelled, as part of its ongoing campaign to promote positive body image among young people. Research conducted by the organization revealed that 95% of girls surveyed have come across airbrushed photos, with 70% reporting that these images have led them to feel negatively about their own bodies. The Guides believe that the lack of transparency surrounding airbrushed photos is contributing to unrealistic beauty expectations and fueling body dissatisfaction. "We want young people to have access to honest and authentic images," said Angela Salt, Chief Executive of Girlguiding. "By labelling airbrushed photos, we can challenge the idea that these images are the norm and help girls understand that they are not alone in their experiences of body image struggles." The Guides' campaign echoes the growing concern among health experts about the impact of unrealistic body ideals on young people. Studies have shown that exposure to airbrushed images can lead to body dissatisfaction, eating disorders, and low self-esteem. The call for labelling builds on the Guides' existing work in this area. The organization has developed a toolkit for parents and educators to help them talk to young people about body image, as well as a series of resources for girls to explore positive body acceptance. The Guides are urging media companies, advertising agencies, and social media platforms to take responsibility for the images they share. They suggest using a simple label, such as "altered," to indicate when photos have been significantly edited. "We believe that by labelling airbrushed photos, we can create a more honest and transparent media landscape," said Salt. "This will help young people develop a healthier relationship with their bodies and promote a more inclusive society." The campaign has received widespread support from organizations working in the field of body image. The National Eating Disorders Association (NEDA) praised the move as a "step in the right direction." "We applaud the Girl Guides for taking a stand against the harmful practice of airbrushing," said Claire Mysko, CEO of NEDA. "Labelling these images is essential for helping young people understand that they are seeing an altered version of reality." The BBC has reached out to several media companies for comment. A spokesperson for one of the UK's largest newspapers said that the company is considering its stance on labelling airbrushed photos. A social media company representative declined to comment.

title: Coronavirus: Nurses' leaders urge 'care for those who caring'
text: Nurses' leaders have urged the public to show their support for healthcare workers by staying at home during the coronavirus pandemic. The Royal College of Nursing (RCN) said nurses and other healthcare professionals were "putting their lives on the line" to care for patients. The college is calling on the public to show their appreciation by following government advice on social distancing and self-isolation. RCN chief executive and general secretary Dame Donna Kinnair said: "Our nurses and nursing support workers are putting their lives on the line to care for patients during this pandemic. "They are working long hours in difficult and often frightening conditions. They are putting their own health at risk to protect others. "We are asking the public to show their support for our nurses and other healthcare professionals by staying at home. "By following government advice on social distancing and self-isolation, you can help to protect our NHS and save lives." The RCN's call comes as the number of confirmed cases of coronavirus in the UK continues to rise. As of 9am on 25 March 2020, there were 9,529 confirmed cases of coronavirus in the UK, and 465 people had died. The government has advised people to stay at home as much as possible, and to only leave their homes for essential reasons, such as to buy food or to go to work. The RCN is also calling on the government to do more to support nurses and other healthcare professionals during the pandemic. The college is calling for the government to provide more personal protective equipment (PPE) for nurses and other healthcare professionals, and to ensure that they have access to testing and treatment. The RCN is also calling for the government to provide financial support for nurses and other healthcare professionals who are unable to work due to the pandemic. Dame Donna Kinnair said: "The government must do more to support our nurses and other healthcare professionals during this pandemic. "They need to provide more PPE, ensure that they have access to testing and treatment, and provide financial support for those who are unable to work. "Our nurses and other healthcare professionals are risking their lives to care for us. We must do everything we can to support them."

title: Crime: Just 1% of magistrates under 30 in Wales
text: Just 1% of magistrates in Wales are under 30, figures show. The latest data from the Ministry of Justice (MoJ) reveals that out of 1,463 magistrates in Wales, only 15 are aged between 18 and 29. This means that just 1% of magistrates in Wales are under 30, a figure that has remained largely unchanged in recent years. The MoJ said it is "aware of the importance of diversity on the magistracy" and is "committed to increasing the representation of under-represented groups, including young people." However, critics say that the lack of young magistrates is a "serious problem" that is "failing to reflect the communities they serve." "It's simply not fair that young people are so underrepresented on the magistracy," said Nerys Evans, a youth worker from Cardiff. "The magistracy is supposed to represent the community, but it's not doing that when it comes to young people." Evans said she believes that the lack of young magistrates is "putting young people off from participating in the justice system." "Young people need to see people like themselves on the magistracy if they're going to believe that the justice system is fair," she said. The Sentencing Council, which sets guidelines for sentencing in England and Wales, has also expressed concerns about the lack of young magistrates. In a report published in 2019, the Sentencing Council said that "the magistracy needs to be more representative of the communities it serves, including in terms of age." The report said that the lack of young magistrates could lead to "sentencing decisions that are out of touch with the needs of young people." The MoJ said it is "working to increase the diversity of the magistracy" and is "encouraging more young people to apply." However, Evans said that more needs to be done to address the issue. "We need to do more to reach out to young people and let them know about the magistracy," she said. "We also need to make it easier for young people to apply to become magistrates." She said that the magistracy is "a great opportunity for young people to make a difference in their communities." "I would encourage any young person who is interested in the justice system to apply to become a magistrate," she said.

title: 'Racism protests do not get to the root of the problem'
text: Racism protests, while well-intentioned, often fail to address the underlying causes of racial inequality. These protests tend to focus on symbolic gestures, such as removing statues or changing street names, which do little to tackle the systemic racism embedded in our institutions. True progress requires a more nuanced approach that addresses the economic, social, and political factors that perpetuate racial disparities. For example, we need to improve education and employment opportunities for marginalized communities, address police brutality and racial profiling, and enact policies that promote equity in housing, healthcare, and other essential services. Moreover, protests often devolve into divisive rhetoric and violence, which further alienates those who do not share the protesters' views. This polarization makes it difficult to engage in constructive dialogue and find common ground. Instead, we need to foster a culture of empathy and understanding, where we listen to each other's experiences and work together to find solutions that benefit all members of society. Another limitation of protests is their limited reach. While they may garner media attention, they often do not translate into meaningful policy changes. To achieve lasting impact, we need to mobilize political action, hold elected officials accountable, and support organizations working on the ground to address racial inequality. Furthermore, protests can sometimes be counterproductive, as they can trigger a backlash from those who feel threatened by the demands for change. This can lead to increased resistance and entrenchment of racist attitudes. In conclusion, while racism protests can raise awareness about the issue, they often fall short of addressing the root causes of racial inequality. Instead, we need to focus on systemic solutions, foster empathy and understanding, and engage in constructive political action. By working together, we can create a more just and equitable society for all.

title: Coronavirus: Male voice choirs face 'existential threat'
text: Coronavirus: Male voice choirs face 'existential threat' Male voice choirs across the UK are facing an "existential threat" due to the coronavirus pandemic, according to a leading singing teacher. David Lawrence, a vocal tutor at the Royal Northern College of Music, said that many choirs have been forced to stop rehearsing and performing, which is having a devastating impact on their finances and morale. "Male voice choirs are particularly vulnerable because they rely on close harmonies, which is not possible to do safely under social distancing rules," he said. "Many choirs are also losing members because people are afraid to sing in close proximity to others, or because they are shielding or self-isolating." Lawrence said that some choirs have tried to adapt by rehearsing online, but this is not a long-term solution. "Singing online is not the same as singing in person," he said. "You lose the physicality, the energy, and the camaraderie that comes from singing together in a group." He added: "If this situation continues for much longer, I fear that many male voice choirs will simply disappear." The threat to male voice choirs is echoed by other singing teachers and choir leaders. Graham Kendrick, a leading choral composer and conductor, said that the pandemic is "a catastrophe" for choirs. "Choirs are all about people coming together to sing and make music," he said. "That's impossible to do under social distancing rules." Kendrick said that he is particularly concerned about the impact on young singers. "Choirs provide a vital opportunity for young people to develop their musical skills and confidence," he said. "If we lose our choirs, we will be losing a vital part of our musical culture." The government has announced a £1.57 billion support package for the arts, but it is unclear how much of this will go to choirs. Lawrence said that he hopes the government will provide specific support for choirs, which are "a vital part of our musical heritage." "Choirs bring people together, they promote mental and physical well-being, and they create a sense of community," he said. "We cannot afford to lose them."

title: Full Sutton 'super prison': Police object to plans
text: Full Sutton 'super prison': Police object to plans Humberside Police have objected to plans to build a 2,000-place "super prison" near Pocklington, East Yorkshire. The force said the new jail, which would be one of the largest in the country, would put a "significant strain" on its resources. The Ministry of Justice (MoJ) said the prison was needed to meet the growing demand for prison places. But Humberside Police said it was "deeply concerned" about the potential impact on its ability to respond to incidents in the area. The force said it was already struggling to cope with the number of prisoners being held at HMP Hull, which is currently operating at over capacity. "A new prison of this size would place a significant strain on our already stretched resources," said Chief Constable Lee Freeman. "We are deeply concerned about the potential impact on our ability to respond to incidents in a timely and effective manner." The MoJ said it was "committed to working with Humberside Police to address their concerns". A spokesperson said: "We understand the concerns raised by Humberside Police and we are committed to working with them to address these concerns. "This includes exploring ways to mitigate the impact of the new prison on the force's resources." The MoJ said the new prison was needed to meet the growing demand for prison places. "The prison population has been rising steadily for a number of years and we need to ensure that we have enough prison places to meet this demand," the spokesperson said. "The new prison at Full Sutton will provide 2,000 additional places, which will help to reduce overcrowding in our prisons and improve conditions for prisoners." The MoJ said it was also committed to working with local communities to ensure that the new prison had a positive impact on the area. "We will be working with the local community to ensure that the new prison has a positive impact on the area," the spokesperson said. "This includes working with local businesses to create jobs and investing in local infrastructure."

title: Lloyds Bank and Pizza Hut cut more than 1,000 jobs
text: Lloyds Bank and Pizza Hut cut more than 1,000 jobs Lloyds Banking Group and Pizza Hut are among the latest companies to cut jobs, as the cost of living crisis continues to bite. Lloyds said it would axe around 900 roles, while Pizza Hut announced plans to close 29 loss-making restaurants and cut 450 jobs. The news comes as a blow to the UK economy, which is already facing a shortage of workers. The unemployment rate is at a record low, and businesses are struggling to fill vacancies. The job cuts at Lloyds are part of a wider cost-cutting drive, which has seen the bank close branches and reduce its workforce in recent years. The bank said the latest job losses were necessary to "simplify" its operations and improve efficiency. Pizza Hut said it was closing restaurants that were "no longer commercially viable". The company has been struggling in recent years, as competition from other pizza chains has intensified. The job cuts come at a time when the cost of living crisis is squeezing household budgets. Inflation is at a 40-year high, and energy prices have soared. This is making it difficult for people to afford food, energy and other essentials. The job cuts are likely to add to the pressure on the government to take action to help people with the cost of living crisis. The government has already announced a number of measures to help people, including a £400 discount on energy bills and a £650 payment to low-income households. However, some economists believe that the government needs to do more. They argue that the government should increase spending on public services and provide more support to low-income households. The job cuts at Lloyds and Pizza Hut are a reminder of the challenges facing the UK economy. The cost of living crisis is putting pressure on businesses and households, and it is likely to lead to further job losses in the coming months.

title: India tobacco firms halt production over health warning
text: India's tobacco companies have temporarily halted production after the government ordered them to carry larger pictorial health warnings on cigarette packets. The new regulations, which came into effect on Saturday, require tobacco companies to cover 85% of the front and back of cigarette packs with graphic images of the harmful effects of smoking. The warnings include images of diseased lungs, mouth cancer, and throat cancer. They also carry messages such as "Smoking kills" and "Tobacco causes painful death." The tobacco industry has criticized the new regulations, arguing that they are too graphic and will discourage smokers from quitting. The industry has also warned that the regulations could lead to job losses in the tobacco sector. However, the government has defended the new regulations, saying that they are necessary to protect public health. The government has also said that it is committed to helping tobacco farmers and workers transition to other industries. The halt in production is expected to last for a few days while tobacco companies reconfigure their packaging to comply with the new regulations. The new regulations are part of the government's efforts to reduce tobacco consumption in India. India is home to one of the largest tobacco markets in the world, with over 250 million adult smokers. Tobacco use is a major public health problem in India, and it is responsible for over 1 million deaths each year. The government's goal is to reduce tobacco consumption by 30% by 2025. The new regulations are a significant step towards achieving this goal. They are likely to make it more difficult for people to start smoking and to encourage smokers to quit. The tobacco industry has been fighting against the new regulations for years. In 2016, the industry challenged the government's decision to increase the size of health warnings on cigarette packs. The industry lost the case, and the Supreme Court upheld the government's decision. The tobacco industry is now facing a new challenge from the government. The government is considering banning the sale of cigarettes in individual packs. This would make it more difficult for people to buy cigarettes, and it would also reduce the attractiveness of cigarettes to young people. The tobacco industry is fighting against this new proposal, but it is clear that the government is determined to reduce tobacco consumption in India. The new regulations are a significant step towards achieving this goal.

title: Bournemouth surf reef boss Tony Williams in chief exec appointment
text: Tony Williams, the driving force behind Bournemouth's world-class surf reef, has been appointed chief executive of Reef Surf, the company behind the groundbreaking project. Williams, a lifelong surfer and passionate advocate for coastal regeneration, played a pivotal role in securing the £1.4m funding for the reef, which opened in 2020 and has since transformed the seaside town's surfing scene. Under Williams' leadership, Reef Surf has ambitious plans to expand its operations, with projects in the pipeline for other UK coastal towns and discussions underway for potential developments overseas. Williams' appointment as chief executive is a testament to his vision and unwavering commitment to harnessing the power of surfing to revitalize coastal communities. "I'm honored and excited to lead Reef Surf into the next chapter of its journey," said Williams. "The Bournemouth reef has proven to be a game-changer, not just for surfers but for the entire town. We're now looking to replicate that success in other coastal areas, creating inclusive, sustainable, and thriving surfing destinations." Williams' appointment has been welcomed by the surfing community and local authorities alike. "Tony is a true pioneer in the world of surfing," said Surf England CEO Steve England. "His passion and expertise have been instrumental in bringing the Bournemouth surf reef to life, and we're confident that he will drive Reef Surf to even greater heights." Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole Council leader Vikki Slade added: "Tony's appointment is a fantastic endorsement of the success of the Bournemouth surf reef. We're delighted that he will continue to lead the charge in bringing the benefits of surfing to more people across the UK and beyond." Reef Surf is a social enterprise that aims to use surfing as a force for good. In addition to building surf reefs, the company runs community outreach programs, educational initiatives, and environmental conservation projects. "We believe that surfing has the power to transform lives," said Williams. "It's a sport that promotes physical and mental well-being, fosters a sense of community, and connects people with the natural world. Our mission is to make the benefits of surfing accessible to everyone." With Williams at the helm, Reef Surf is poised to make a significant contribution to the UK's coastal communities and the global surfing scene.

title: Greene King pub giant snapped up by Hong Kong firm CKA
text: Greene King, Britain's largest pub chain, has been acquired by Hong Kong's CKA Group in a deal worth £2.7 billion ($3.2 billion). CKA, controlled by the billionaire Li Ka-shing, already owns a number of businesses in the UK, including the supermarket chain AS Watson. The deal will see CKA take full control of Greene King, which has more than 2,700 pubs across the UK. Greene King's chairman, Philip Yea, said the deal was "a great outcome for all our stakeholders". He said CKA was "a long-term investor with a proven track record in the UK" and that the deal would "secure the future of Greene King for many years to come". CKA chairman Victor Li said the acquisition was "a significant investment in the UK" and that Greene King was "a great business with a strong management team". He said CKA was "committed to supporting the long-term success of Greene King". The deal has been approved by Greene King's shareholders and is expected to complete in the first half of 2019. Greene King is the latest in a series of UK businesses to be acquired by Chinese companies in recent years. In 2016, China's Fosun International bought the luxury fashion brand Thomas Cook Group. The trend has raised concerns among some that Chinese companies are gaining too much control over the UK economy. However, the UK government has welcomed the investment, saying it is a sign of confidence in the UK economy. Greene King is a well-known and popular pub chain in the UK. It was founded in 1799 and has a strong reputation for quality food and drink. The chain's pubs are often located in historic buildings and are often popular with tourists. The acquisition of Greene King by CKA is a significant development in the UK pub industry. It remains to be seen how CKA will manage the chain and whether it will make any significant changes. However, the deal is likely to have a major impact on the UK pub industry and could lead to further consolidation in the sector.

title: Hundreds of staff injured at Amazon UK warehouses, GMB claims
text: Hundreds of staff at Amazon UK warehouses have been injured in the past year, according to the GMB union. The union said it had received reports of 589 injuries at Amazon warehouses in the UK between July 2021 and June 2022. The GMB said the most common injuries were musculoskeletal disorders, such as back pain and strains, and that these were caused by the high workload and repetitive nature of the work. The union also said that there had been a number of serious injuries, including fractures, dislocations, and amputations. The GMB said that Amazon needed to do more to protect its staff from injury. Amazon said it was committed to the safety of its employees and that it had a number of measures in place to prevent injuries. The company said it had invested in safety training and equipment, and that it had a team of safety professionals who worked to identify and eliminate hazards. Amazon also said that it had a system in place to investigate and learn from any injuries that did occur. The GMB said that it welcomed Amazon's commitment to safety, but that more needed to be done to reduce the number of injuries. The union said that Amazon should reduce the workload and increase the number of breaks for staff. The GMB also said that Amazon should invest in more training and equipment to help staff to avoid injuries. Amazon said that it would continue to work with the GMB and other unions to improve safety at its warehouses. The company said that it was committed to providing a safe and healthy workplace for all of its employees. The GMB's claims come at a time when Amazon is facing increased scrutiny over its working practices. In recent months, there have been a number of reports of worker injuries and deaths at Amazon warehouses in the US and Europe. Amazon has been accused of putting profits ahead of safety, and of failing to provide adequate training and equipment to its staff. The GMB's claims are likely to add to the pressure on Amazon to improve its safety record.

title: India lion cub leads guard to its mother's corpse
text: In a heart-wrenching incident, a young lion cub in India led forest guards to the lifeless body of its mother, highlighting the strong bonds within the animal kingdom. The tragic event unfolded in the Gir National Park, the last abode of the Asiatic lion. The cub, estimated to be around 8-10 months old, was spotted by forest guards on patrol. As they approached, the cub began to cry out and lead them through the dense vegetation. With each step, the guards' hopes dwindled, but the cub persisted, guiding them deeper into the forest. Finally, they reached a clearing where the lifeless body of the mother lion lay. The cause of her death remains unknown, but the guards suspect natural causes. The sight of the young cub mourning its mother was deeply moving. The guards witnessed the cub nuzzling its mother's body, licking her fur, and attempting to rouse her. But the mother was gone, leaving the cub alone and vulnerable. The guards carefully removed the cub from the scene and took it to a nearby rescue center. There, the cub is receiving round-the-clock care and is expected to be rehabilitated and eventually released back into the wild. The incident highlights the strong bonds that exist between mothers and their young in the animal kingdom. Even in the face of adversity, these bonds remain unbreakable. The cub's determination to lead the guards to its mother's body is a testament to its resilience and the deep connection it shared with its parent. The tragic loss of the mother lion is a reminder of the challenges facing wildlife conservation. Asiatic lions are an endangered species, with an estimated population of around 650 individuals. Protecting their habitat and ensuring their well-being is crucial for the survival of this majestic species. The story of the lion cub leading the guards to its mother's corpse is a bittersweet reminder of both the fragility and the resilience of life in the wild. It is a testament to the deep bonds that connect all living creatures and the importance of protecting our natural heritage.

title: Grenfell inquiry: 'My family are all dead', boy told fire officer
text: In the aftermath of the devastating Grenfell Tower fire, a public inquiry has been launched to uncover the truth behind the tragedy. One of the most harrowing testimonies came from a young boy who survived the blaze but lost his entire family. The boy, who was just 12 years old at the time of the fire, told a fire officer that his "family are all dead." His words, etched with grief and despair, sent shockwaves through the inquiry room. The boy's testimony was one of many that painted a picture of the unimaginable horror that unfolded on the night of June 14, 2017. The fire, which started in a faulty refrigerator, rapidly engulfed the 24-storey tower block, trapping hundreds of residents inside. As the flames raged, the boy and his family were trapped on the 23rd floor. They desperately tried to escape, but the smoke and heat were too intense. They were forced to retreat back into their apartment, where they huddled together and waited for help. But help never came. The fire brigade arrived at the scene, but they were unable to reach the upper floors of the tower due to the intense heat and smoke. The boy and his family were left to their fate. As the fire continued to intensify, the boy's mother and sister collapsed from smoke inhalation. The boy tried to save them, but he was too weak. He was forced to watch helplessly as they succumbed to the flames. Eventually, the boy himself began to lose consciousness. He was overcome by the smoke and heat, and he slipped into unconsciousness. When he woke up, he found himself lying in a hospital bed. He had been rescued by firefighters, but his family was gone. The boy's testimony was a powerful reminder of the human cost of the Grenfell Tower fire. It was a story of unimaginable loss and tragedy. It was also a story of resilience and hope. Despite the horrors he had endured, the boy was determined to rebuild his life. The Grenfell Tower inquiry is ongoing, and it is hoped that it will provide answers to the many questions that remain about the fire. It is also hoped that it will help to prevent similar tragedies from happening in the future.

title: 'Six-month delay' for Heathrow decision
text: 'Six-month delay' for Heathrow decision The government has announced a six-month delay to its decision on whether to expand Heathrow Airport. Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said the delay was necessary to give the government more time to consider the environmental impact of a third runway. The decision was welcomed by environmental groups, but was criticized by business leaders who said it would damage the UK's economy. Heathrow is the UK's busiest airport, and has been operating at full capacity for several years. A third runway would increase the airport's capacity by 50%, and would allow it to handle up to 140 million passengers a year. The government has been considering expanding Heathrow for several years, but has been unable to reach a decision due to concerns about the environmental impact. A third runway would require the destruction of hundreds of homes and businesses, and would also increase noise and air pollution. The government has said that it will only approve a third runway if it can be shown that the environmental impact can be minimized. The delay to the decision is likely to give the government more time to consider the environmental impact of a third runway. It will also give the government more time to consult with local residents and businesses. The decision on whether to expand Heathrow is a complex one, and there are strong arguments on both sides. The government will need to weigh the economic benefits of a third runway against the environmental impact before making a decision. Reaction to the delay Environmental groups welcomed the delay to the decision. Friends of the Earth said that the government needed to take more time to consider the environmental impact of a third runway. "This delay is a victory for common sense and for the environment," said Friends of the Earth's aviation campaigner Jenny Bates. "The government must now rule out a third runway at Heathrow once and for all." Business leaders criticized the delay, saying that it would damage the UK's economy. The British Chambers of Commerce said that the delay would "send the wrong message to businesses and investors." "Heathrow is a vital part of the UK's economy, and this delay will only serve to undermine our competitiveness," said BCC director general Adam Marshall. The decision on whether to expand Heathrow is a complex one, and there are strong arguments on both sides. The government will need to weigh the economic benefits of a third runway against the environmental impact before making a decision.

title: Parkinson's stem cell 'breakthrough'
text: Parkinson's stem cell 'breakthrough' Scientists have made a significant breakthrough in the development of a stem cell treatment for Parkinson's disease. The research, published in the journal Nature Medicine, shows that stem cells can be used to repair damaged brain cells in mice with the condition. Parkinson's disease is a progressive neurological disorder that affects movement, balance and coordination. It is caused by the loss of dopamine-producing nerve cells in the brain. There is currently no cure for Parkinson's disease, but treatments can help to manage the symptoms. The new research offers hope that stem cells could one day be used to treat or even cure Parkinson's disease. The study was conducted by a team of scientists from the University of Cambridge and the University of Edinburgh. They used stem cells from human embryos to create dopamine-producing nerve cells. These cells were then transplanted into the brains of mice with Parkinson's disease. The results showed that the transplanted cells survived and integrated into the brain tissue. The mice showed significant improvements in their motor function and coordination. They were able to walk and move more easily, and their tremors were reduced. The researchers say that the findings are a major step forward in the development of a stem cell treatment for Parkinson's disease. "This is the first time that stem cells have been shown to improve motor function in a Parkinson's disease model," said Professor Roger Barker, from the University of Cambridge. "These findings offer hope that stem cells could one day be used to treat or even cure Parkinson's disease." The researchers caution that more research is needed before stem cell treatments can be used in humans. They need to find a way to produce stem cells that are safe and effective for transplantation. They also need to develop a way to deliver the stem cells to the brain without damaging the surrounding tissue. Despite these challenges, the researchers are optimistic that stem cell treatments could one day be a reality for people with Parkinson's disease. "This is a very exciting development," said Professor David Dexter, from the University of Edinburgh. "If we can overcome the challenges, stem cell treatments could offer a new way to treat Parkinson's disease and improve the lives of people with the condition."

title: Facebook facial recognition faces class-action suit
text: Facebook is facing a class-action lawsuit over its use of facial recognition technology. The plaintiffs allege that Facebook violated the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) by collecting and storing their facial scans without their consent. BIPA is a state law that regulates the collection, use, and storage of biometric information, such as fingerprints, voiceprints, and facial scans. The law requires companies to obtain written consent from individuals before collecting their biometric information. Facebook has not publicly commented on the lawsuit. However, the company has previously defended its use of facial recognition technology, arguing that it is a valuable tool for protecting users from fraud and abuse. The lawsuit is one of several that have been filed against Facebook over its use of facial recognition technology. In 2021, the company agreed to pay $650 million to settle a class-action lawsuit that alleged Facebook violated BIPA by collecting and storing facial scans of users without their consent. The latest lawsuit is a sign that legal challenges to Facebook's use of facial recognition technology are likely to continue. If the plaintiffs are successful in their lawsuit, Facebook could be forced to pay billions of dollars in damages. The lawsuit also raises concerns about the broader use of facial recognition technology. As the technology becomes more sophisticated, it is increasingly being used by law enforcement and other government agencies. Critics argue that facial recognition technology can be used to track and identify people without their consent, and that it poses a threat to privacy and civil liberties. The lawsuit against Facebook is a reminder that the use of facial recognition technology is a complex issue with legal, ethical, and privacy implications. As the technology continues to develop, it is important to have a public debate about its potential benefits and risks. In addition to the legal challenges, Facebook is also facing regulatory scrutiny over its use of facial recognition technology. In 2021, the UK's Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) fined Facebook £500,000 for violating the UK's data protection laws by collecting and storing facial scans of users without their consent. The ICO's investigation found that Facebook had collected and stored facial scans of more than 1 million UK users without their knowledge or consent. The ICO also found that Facebook had failed to take adequate steps to protect the facial scans from misuse. The ICO's fine is a significant development in the regulation of facial recognition technology. It is the first time that a regulator has fined a company for violating data protection laws in relation to the use of facial recognition technology. The ICO's decision is a reminder that companies must comply with data protection laws when they collect and store biometric information. Companies must also take adequate steps to protect biometric information from misuse.

title: A Bafta bruising for the Brits?
text: A Bafta Bruising for the Brits? The British Academy Film Awards (Baftas) are widely recognized as the British equivalent of the Oscars, honoring the best of British and international cinema. However, the recent ceremony raised concerns that British films are facing an uphill battle in the face of stiff competition from Hollywood. Out of the 20 award categories, British films only managed to secure five. "All Quiet on the Western Front," a German-language adaptation of a classic anti-war novel, took home seven awards, including Best Film and Best Director. "The Banshees of Inisherin," an Irish black comedy, won Best Original Screenplay and Best Supporting Actor. The lackluster showing for British films has prompted questions about the health of the British film industry. Some have argued that the UK is losing its competitive edge due to a combination of factors, including the dominance of streaming services, the rise of international co-productions, and a perceived lack of investment in homegrown talent. The British film industry has long been a source of pride for the nation, producing iconic films such as "The King's Speech," "Slumdog Millionaire," and "Shakespeare in Love." However, the declining success at the Baftas suggests that the industry may need to adapt to the changing landscape of filmmaking. One of the key challenges facing British filmmakers is the dominance of Hollywood studios. American films have consistently dominated the box office, and their massive budgets and marketing campaigns give them a significant advantage over smaller British productions. Compounding this issue, streaming services often favor Hollywood content due to its global reach and established fan base. Another factor to consider is the increasing popularity of international co-productions. Films like "All Quiet on the Western Front" and "The Banshees of Inisherin" demonstrate that international collaborations can produce highly successful and critically acclaimed films. However, British filmmakers may find themselves competing for funding and resources against larger international partners. Finally, some critics argue that the British film industry has not done enough to nurture and support homegrown talent. They point to the lack of diversity among British nominees and winners at the Baftas as evidence of a systemic issue within the industry. Despite the challenges, there are still reasons to be optimistic about the future of British film. The UK remains a vibrant and creative hub, with a rich history of filmmaking. By investing in homegrown talent, fostering international collaborations, and adapting to the evolving landscape of cinema, the British film industry can continue to produce world-class films that resonate with audiences worldwide.

title: Jordan Begley Taser death: Mother saw 'fear in his face'
text: The mother of Jordan Begley, a 23-year-old man who died after being Tasered by police in Manchester, has spoken of the "fear in his face" as she watched him being restrained. Kami Begley said her son had been "laughing and joking" with her on the phone just minutes before he was Tasered and arrested on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon on July 10, 2022. Speaking to the BBC, she said: "I saw the fear in his face. He was just a kid. He didn't deserve to die." Ms Begley said her son had been Tasered three times by police officers. She said she had seen CCTV footage of the incident and that it showed Jordan being "pinned down" by officers before being Tasered. "I want to know why they Tasered him three times," she said. "He wasn't a threat to anyone." Jordan Begley's death is the subject of an ongoing investigation by the Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC). The IOPC said in a statement that it was "aware of the comments made by Jordan Begley's mother" and that it would "take them into account as part of our ongoing investigation." The statement added: "Our investigators have been in contact with Jordan Begley's family to offer our condolences and to explain our role in investigating his death. We will keep them updated as our investigation progresses." Tasers are conducted electrical weapons (CEWs) that are used by police to incapacitate people by delivering a high-voltage electric shock. The use of Tasers has been controversial, with critics arguing that they can be dangerous and even fatal. In 2017, the United Nations special rapporteur on extrajudicial, summary or arbitrary executions said that Tasers "should not be used except when strictly necessary to save lives, and that their use should be subject to strict standards and independent monitoring." In the United Kingdom, the use of Tasers is governed by the Police Use of Force Manual. The manual states that Tasers should only be used when there is a threat to life or serious injury. The manual also states that officers should only use Tasers for the minimum amount of time necessary to incapacitate the person. The IOPC is investigating Jordan Begley's death to determine whether the use of Tasers was justified in this case.

title: MPs criticise government's railway plan
text: MPs have criticized the government's railway plan, saying it will lead to higher fares and cuts to services. The plan, which was announced by Transport Secretary Grant Shapps last week, includes a number of measures designed to reduce costs and improve efficiency on the railways. These include increasing the use of driverless trains, closing ticket offices, and reducing the number of trains running on some lines. However, critics argue that these measures will lead to a worse service for passengers. They say that driverless trains are less reliable and that closing ticket offices will make it more difficult for people to buy tickets. They also say that reducing the number of trains running on some lines will make it harder for people to get to work or school. The government has defended the plan, saying it is necessary to reduce the cost of running the railways. It says that the measures it is proposing will save £1bn a year, which will be used to invest in other areas of the transport network. The plan has been met with a mixed reaction from the public. Some people have welcomed the government's focus on reducing costs, while others have expressed concern about the impact the changes will have on services. A recent poll by YouGov found that 42% of people support the government's plan, while 35% oppose it. The remaining 23% are unsure. The government is now facing pressure to address the concerns of critics. It is expected to publish a more detailed version of the plan in the coming weeks, which will include more information about how the changes will affect passengers. The government is also facing legal challenges to the plan. A number of groups, including the Rail, Maritime and Transport union (RMT), have announced plans to take legal action to block the changes. The RMT has argued that the government's plan is "unlawful" and that it will lead to "a bonfire of safety standards". The government has said it will "vigorously defend" the plan in court. The row over the government's railway plan is likely to continue for some time. title: In full: Liberal Democrat conference agenda 2014

title: Microsoft moves to disable Zeus botnet
text: Microsoft Moves to Disable Zeus Botnet Microsoft has taken action to disable a widespread botnet network known as Zeus, which has been used to steal personal information and financial data from millions of computers worldwide. The Zeus botnet has been active for over a decade and is estimated to have infected over 3.6 million devices. It typically spreads through phishing emails or malicious websites that trick users into downloading and installing the malware. Once installed, the Zeus botnet can steal sensitive information such as passwords, credit card numbers, and bank account details. It can also control infected computers remotely, allowing attackers to launch DDoS attacks or distribute other malware. To combat the Zeus botnet, Microsoft has released a security update that disables the malware's functionality. The update is available for all supported versions of Windows, including Windows 10, Windows 8.1, and Windows 7. In addition to the security update, Microsoft has also partnered with law enforcement agencies to take down the Zeus botnet's command and control servers. This has disrupted the botnet's operations and made it more difficult for attackers to use it to steal information or launch attacks. Users who suspect their computers have been infected with the Zeus botnet are advised to take the following steps: Install the Microsoft security update. The update is available through Windows Update or the Microsoft Update Catalog. Scan your computer with an antivirus program. This will help detect and remove any remaining Zeus malware. Change your passwords. If you have used the same password on multiple websites, change them immediately to prevent attackers from accessing your accounts. Monitor your financial accounts. Keep an eye on your bank and credit card statements for any unauthorized transactions. By following these steps, users can help protect themselves from the Zeus botnet and other malware threats.
