title: Children 'hid in attic' during Raoul Moat shootings
text: Children 'hid in attic' during Raoul Moat shootings Former Northumbria Police officer Raoul Moat went on a shooting spree in July 2010, killing ex-girlfriend Samantha Stobbart and her new partner Chris Brown, and seriously injuring PC David Rathband. During the manhunt for Moat, three children were forced to hide in an attic for three days as he roamed the area. The youngsters, aged between seven and 12, were terrified after hearing gunshots and seeing armed police in their street. The children's father told the BBC: "We live in a quiet street and we never expected anything like this to happen. It all started when we heard gunshots and saw armed police running down the street. We didn't know what was going on and we were terrified. We told the children to go and hide in the attic and we locked the door. We then spent the next three days huddled together in the attic, listening to the police searching for Moat." He said his children were "traumatized" by the experience. "They were terrified and they didn't understand what was going on. We tried to keep them calm, but it was difficult. They kept asking when it would be safe to come out and we didn't know what to tell them." He said the family was "relieved" when Moat was finally caught and killed. "We knew he was dangerous and we were worried that he would come after us. We're just glad that it's all over now and that we can start to move on with our lives." Moat's rampage began on July 3, 2010, when he shot dead Ms. Stobbart, 22, and Mr. Brown, 29, at their home in Gateshead, Tyne and Wear. He then went on the run and a massive manhunt was launched. During the manhunt, Moat shot and seriously injured PC Rathband in Newcastle city center. He then fled to Rothbury, Northumberland, where he was eventually cornered by police. Following a six-hour stand-off, Moat was shot and killed by a police marksman. The Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC) later concluded that the police shooting was justified.

title: January Tube strike talks end with 'no progress'
text: January Tube strike talks end with 'no progress' Talks between London Underground and the RMT union have ended without agreement, meaning a strike by Tube drivers on the Central and Victoria lines is still set to go ahead on 10 January. The RMT said there had been "no progress" in negotiations over pay, pensions and working conditions. London Underground said it was "disappointed" that the talks had not led to a resolution. The strike will affect the Central and Victoria lines, which are two of the busiest on the Tube network. The RMT said it had been "forced" to call the strike after London Underground "failed to address our concerns". The union said it was seeking a pay increase of 6.5%, a guarantee that there will be no compulsory redundancies, and a 35-hour week. London Underground said it had offered a pay increase of 4.5%, which it said was "fair and reasonable". The company also said it had made a number of other concessions, including a commitment to no compulsory redundancies for the next two years. However, the RMT said these concessions were not enough. The strike will cause significant disruption to travel in London. Passengers are advised to check before they travel and consider using alternative routes. London Underground is running a reduced service on the Central and Victoria lines, but there are severe delays and some stations are closed. The strike is the latest in a series of industrial disputes on the Tube network. In August, there was a 24-hour strike on the Piccadilly line, and in September there was a 48-hour strike on the Central, Northern and Victoria lines. The RMT has also announced plans for a further strike on the Jubilee line on 13 January. The union said it was "disappointed" that London Underground had not been willing to make the necessary concessions to avoid the strike. London Underground said it was "saddened" that the strike was going ahead. The company said it would do everything it could to minimize the disruption to passengers.

title: Charity warns officer cuts leave prison system 'in crisis'
text: Charity warns officer cuts leave prison system 'in crisis' Prisons are facing a "crisis" due to a shortage of staff, a charity has warned. The Prison Reform Trust said the number of prison officers in England and Wales has fallen by 10% since 2010, with further cuts planned. The charity said this is leading to increased violence, disorder and self-harm in prisons. The Ministry of Justice said it was working to recruit more prison officers and that the prison population had fallen by 6% since 2010. However, the Prison Reform Trust said the cuts were having a "devastating impact" on prisons. It said that in some prisons, officers are being asked to work 12-hour shifts with no breaks. This is leading to fatigue and stress, which is increasing the risk of assaults on staff and prisoners. The charity also said that the cuts are making it more difficult to provide rehabilitation for prisoners. This is because officers are having to spend more time on security and less time on working with prisoners. As a result, the charity said, the prison system is "in crisis". Peter Clarke, director of the Prison Reform Trust, said: "The government's cuts to prison officer numbers are having a devastating impact on our prisons. "Prisons are becoming increasingly violent and dangerous, and prisoners are being denied the rehabilitation they need to turn their lives around. "The government needs to act now to recruit more prison officers and to invest in rehabilitation. Otherwise, our prisons will continue to be in crisis." A Ministry of Justice spokesperson said: "We are working to recruit more prison officers and the prison population has fallen by 6% since 2010. "We are also investing in rehabilitation, with £40 million being spent on new and improved resettlement prisons." However, the Prison Reform Trust said that the government's plans to recruit more prison officers were not enough to address the crisis. It said that the government needed to invest in long-term solutions, such as reducing the prison population and providing more rehabilitation for prisoners.

title: 'CNN wrestling' tweet came from extreme Reddit user
text: CNN Wrestling'' Tweet Came from Extreme Reddit User A now-deleted tweet from CNN's official account, which showed a photo of a wrestling match with the caption "CNN Wrestling," has sparked a wave of confusion and amusement online. The tweet, which was quickly removed, has been attributed to an extreme Reddit user who gained access to CNN's account through a phishing scam. The user, known as "u/AbusiveAccount," is known for their history of posting inflammatory and offensive comments on Reddit. They have been banned from the platform multiple times but have continued to create new accounts. In a statement, CNN confirmed that their account had been compromised and that the "CNN Wrestling" tweet was not authorized. The network said it was investigating the incident and taking steps to secure its accounts. The incident has raised concerns about the security of social media accounts and the potential for malicious actors to gain access to them. It also highlights the importance of using strong passwords and being aware of phishing scams. Phishing is a type of online fraud in which scammers send emails or text messages that appear to be from legitimate organizations. These messages often contain links to fake websites that look like the real thing. If you click on the link and enter your login information, the scammers will be able to access your account. There are a number of things you can do to protect yourself from phishing scams: Never click on links in emails or text messages from people you don't know. Be wary of emails or text messages that ask you to provide personal information, such as your password or credit card number. If you're not sure whether an email or text message is legitimate, contact the organization directly. In the case of the CNN Wrestling tweet, it is unclear how the user gained access to the network's account. However, it is possible that they used a phishing scam to obtain the login information. CNN has since taken steps to secure its accounts and has advised its followers to be aware of phishing scams. The network also said it would be working with law enforcement to investigate the incident. The incident serves as a reminder of the importance of online security and the need to be vigilant against phishing scams. By taking simple precautions, you can help protect yourself from becoming a victim of online fraud.

title: Hillsborough memorials unveiled in Liverpool
text: Hillsborough memorials unveiled in Liverpool Two new memorials have been unveiled in Liverpool to commemorate the 97 victims of the Hillsborough disaster. The memorials are located at the Anfield and Goodison Park football stadiums, the homes of Liverpool and Everton football clubs respectively. The Anfield memorial is a bronze statue of the Shankly Gates, which were the entrance to the stadium at the time of the disaster. The statue is inscribed with the names of the 97 victims. The Goodison Park memorial is a stone plinth with a bronze plaque inscribed with the names of the 97 victims. The plinth is located in the Gwladys Street Stand, which was where many of the victims were standing when the disaster happened. The memorials were unveiled by Liverpool and Everton players, as well as family members of the victims. The Hillsborough disaster was a tragic event that occurred on 15 April 1989, when a crowd crush at the Hillsborough Stadium in Sheffield resulted in the deaths of 97 Liverpool fans. The disaster was caused by a combination of factors, including overcrowding and a lack of police control. The Taylor Report, which was commissioned by the government in the wake of the disaster, found that the police had been negligent in their handling of the crowd. The report also recommended a number of changes to the way that football matches were organized, including the introduction of all-seater stadiums. The Hillsborough disaster had a profound impact on the city of Liverpool. The memorials that have been unveiled today will serve as a permanent reminder of the tragedy and the lives that were lost. The memorials will also be a place for families and friends of the victims to come and remember their loved ones. The unveiling of the memorials is a significant moment in the history of Liverpool. It is a day for remembrance, reflection, and hope.

title: Donald Trump hails South Korea trade deal
text: Donald Trump Hails South Korea Trade Deal President Donald Trump has hailed a new trade deal with South Korea, saying it will "create thousands of new jobs" in the United States. The agreement, which was signed on Tuesday, is the first major trade deal to be negotiated by the Trump administration. It replaces a previous deal that was signed in 2012. Trump said the new deal is a "win-win" for both countries. He said it will boost exports of American goods to South Korea, while also reducing the US trade deficit with the country. "This is a great deal for the United States," Trump said. "It's a fair deal, and it's a reciprocal deal." The new trade deal includes a number of provisions that are designed to benefit US businesses. These include: Reducing tariffs on American goods exported to South Korea Increasing access to the South Korean market for American companies Protecting American intellectual property rights The deal also includes a number of provisions that are designed to address the concerns of South Korea. The US Chamber of Commerce said the deal is a "positive step" that will "boost economic growth and create jobs." The Korean Chamber of Commerce and Industry said the deal is a "balanced and mutually beneficial" agreement that will "strengthen the economic partnership between the two countries." The new trade deal is a significant achievement for the Trump administration. It is the first major trade deal to be negotiated by the administration, and it is expected to boost the US economy. The deal is also a sign of the Trump administration's commitment to renegotiating trade deals that it believes are unfair to the United States. The administration has already renegotiated trade deals with Mexico and Canada, and it is currently in talks with China and the European Union about renegotiating their trade deals. The new trade deal with South Korea is a positive step for the US economy. It is expected to boost exports, create jobs, and reduce the US trade deficit. The deal is also a sign of the Trump administration's commitment to renegotiating trade deals that it believes are unfair to the United States.

title: Ikea founder Ingvar Kamprad's Nazi ties 'went deeper'
text: Ikea Founder Ingvar Kamprad's Nazi Ties 'Went Deeper' Swedish furniture giant Ikea's late founder Ingvar Kamprad had deeper ties to the Nazi Party than previously known, according to a new book. Kamprad, who died in 2018, joined the fascist New Swedish Movement at the age of 18 and remained a member for two years. He also wrote letters praising Nazi leader Adolf Hitler, who he described as "a great man". The extent of Kamprad's Nazi sympathies has been the subject of scrutiny for decades. In 1994, he apologized for his past actions, saying he had been "naive" and "stupid". However, a new book by Swedish author Elisabeth Åsbrink claims that Kamprad's Nazi ties went further than previously believed. Åsbrink alleges that Kamprad was not only a member of the New Swedish Movement, but also a member of the Nazi Party itself. She also claims that Kamprad helped to smuggle Nazi propaganda into Sweden during World War II. Ikea has not commented on the allegations made in Åsbrink's book. However, the company has previously acknowledged Kamprad's Nazi past and expressed regret for his actions. The revelations about Kamprad's Nazi ties have come as a shock to many. Ikea is a global brand that is known for its affordable and stylish furniture. The company's association with Nazism has raised questions about its corporate culture and values. Some critics have called for Ikea to take steps to distance itself from its founder's past. Others have argued that the company should focus on its present and future, rather than dwelling on its history. The debate over Ikea's Nazi past is likely to continue for some time. It remains to be seen how Ikea will respond to these challenges and whether it will be able to move forward from its founder's dark legacy.

title: Global executions fall to lowest level in a decade, Amnesty says
text: Global executions have fallen to the lowest level in a decade, with a significant decline in countries like Iran and Saudi Arabia, according to Amnesty International. The organization's annual report on the death penalty found that at least 483 people were executed in 18 countries in 2022, down from 539 in the previous year. This represents a 10.4% decrease and the lowest number of executions recorded by Amnesty since 2013. "This decline is a welcome step forward in the global fight to end the use of the death penalty," said Agnès Callamard, Amnesty International's Secretary General. "It shows that even the most repressive governments are beginning to realize that the death penalty is not a solution, but a violation of human rights." The report highlights several factors that have contributed to the decline in executions. One is the growing international consensus against the death penalty. In recent years, several countries have abolished capital punishment, including Sierra Leone, Chad, and Kazakhstan. Additionally, international bodies like the United Nations and the European Union have repeatedly called for an end to executions. Another factor is the increasing availability of DNA testing and other forensic technologies. These advances have led to a number of wrongful convictions being overturned, which has raised concerns about the reliability of the death penalty. In addition to the overall decline in executions, the report also found that some countries have made significant progress in reducing their use of the death penalty. For example, Iran, which has one of the highest execution rates in the world, executed 251 people in 2022, down from 314 in the previous year. This decline is largely due to changes in the country's drug laws, which have reduced the number of people sentenced to death for drug-related offenses. Saudi Arabia, another country with a high execution rate, also saw a decline in executions in 2022. The country executed 147 people, down from 184 in the previous year. This decline is thought to be due to the country's de facto moratorium on executions that was imposed in November 2020. Despite the progress that has been made, the report also highlights the challenges that remain in the fight to end the death penalty. In some countries, use of the death penalty is increasing, such as in Egypt, which executed 83 people in 2022, up from 43 in the previous year. Additionally, some countries continue to use the death penalty for a wide range of offenses, including political crimes and apostasy. Amnesty International called on all countries to abolish the death penalty, saying that it is "a cruel and inhumane punishment that has no place in the 21st century." "The death penalty is not a deterrent to crime, it does not provide closure to victims' families, and it does not make societies safer," said Callamard. "It is time for all countries to end this barbaric practice."

title: Bank of Mum and Dad 'feels the pinch'
text: In the midst of the cost-of-living crisis, the "Bank of Mum and Dad" is facing unprecedented strain. The soaring cost of living has left many young adults struggling to make ends meet, forcing them to turn to their parents for financial support. A recent study by the Centre for Economics and Business Research (CEBR) found that the average amount of financial assistance provided by parents to their children has increased by 15% in the past year, to a record £2,000. This is putting a significant burden on many parents, who are also grappling with rising costs and reduced incomes. Emma Jones, CEO of Enterprise Nation, a small business support network, says: "Parents are increasingly having to step in and provide financial support to their children. This is a worrying trend, as it can put a strain on relationships and lead to resentment on both sides." One in four young adults aged 18-34 now rely on their parents for financial support, according to the survey. This is a significant increase from the one in five reported in 2021. The study also found that the average age at which young adults become financially independent has increased to 27, up from 25 in 2021. The rising cost of housing is a major factor driving the increase in parental support. The average house price in the UK has increased by more than 10% in the past year, making it increasingly difficult for young people to afford to buy their own homes. Rents have also been rising rapidly, making it more expensive for young people to rent privately. This is leaving many young adults with no choice but to live with their parents or other family members. The cost-of-living crisis is not just affecting young people. Many older people are also struggling to make ends meet. The CEBR study found that the number of over-65s relying on their children for financial support has increased by 10% in the past year. This is a worrying trend, as it suggests that the cost-of-living crisis is having a wider impact on society. It is essential that the government takes action to address the rising cost of living and help those who are struggling to make ends meet.

title: Niels Högel: German ex-nurse convicted of killing 85 patients
text: Niels Högel, a former nurse in Germany, has been convicted of murdering 85 patients in his care. Högel was found guilty of administering lethal doses of medication to patients at two hospitals in Oldenburg and Delmenhorst between 1999 and 2005. The court heard that Högel deliberately targeted vulnerable patients who were close to death or who had serious illnesses. He would inject them with drugs such as ajmaline and potassium, which would cause their hearts to stop. Högel initially denied the charges but later confessed to killing the patients. He said he did it out of boredom and a desire to play the role of a "savior" by ending their suffering. The court rejected Högel's claims that he was motivated by mercy, saying that he had acted out of a "base motive" of self-gratification. The judge said that Högel had shown "no remorse or empathy" for his victims. Högel's conviction is one of the worst cases of serial killing in German history. The case has shocked the country and raised questions about how such a thing could have happened in a modern healthcare system. Högel's crimes were only discovered after he was caught trying to kill a patient in 2005. He was immediately arrested and charged with attempted murder. During the investigation, police found evidence that he had killed dozens of other patients. Högel's trial began in 2015 and lasted for more than two years. During the trial, prosecutors presented evidence that Högel had killed at least 85 patients. They also presented evidence that Högel had attempted to kill several other patients. Högel was found guilty of 85 counts of murder and two counts of attempted murder. He was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole. The case of Niels Högel is a reminder of the importance of trust in the healthcare system. Patients must be able to trust that the people who are caring for them are acting in their best interests. Högel's crimes have shattered that trust.

title: Australia climate change: Thousands rally in Sydney amid bushfires
text: Thousands of people have rallied in Sydney to demand urgent action on climate change, as devastating bushfires continue to burn across Australia. The protesters marched through the city centre, chanting slogans and carrying placards that read "Climate Action Now" and "Stop Adani". The rally was organised by a coalition of environmental groups, including the Australian Youth Climate Coalition, Greenpeace Australia Pacific and the Nature Conservation Council. Speakers at the rally included Aboriginal elder Uncle Warren Mundine, who spoke about the impact of climate change on Indigenous communities. "We are the traditional owners of this land, and we have a responsibility to protect it," he said. "Climate change is a threat to our culture, our way of life and our future." Other speakers included climate scientist Professor Will Steffen, who warned that Australia is facing "a climate emergency". "The fires we are seeing now are a wake-up call," he said. "We need to take urgent action to reduce our emissions and transition to a clean energy future." The rally comes as Australia continues to grapple with the devastating effects of bushfires. So far, the fires have killed at least 25 people and destroyed more than 2,000 homes. The fires have also caused widespread damage to the environment, killing millions of animals and destroying vast tracts of bushland. The government has been criticised for its response to the fires, with many people accusing it of not doing enough to address climate change. Prime Minister Scott Morrison has said that the government is "doing everything we can" to fight the fires, but he has also been criticised for his support for the coal industry. The rally in Sydney is part of a growing movement of people around the world who are demanding action on climate change. In recent months, there have been large protests in cities across Europe, Asia and North America. The protests have been sparked by the increasing frequency and severity of extreme weather events, such as heatwaves, floods and droughts. The protests are a clear sign that people are becoming increasingly frustrated with the lack of action on climate change. Governments around the world need to listen to the demands of their citizens and take urgent action to reduce emissions and transition to a clean energy future.

title: Star Wars: In defence of the prequels from 1999 to 2005
text: Amidst the sprawling cinematic tapestry of "Star Wars," the prequel trilogy (1999-2005) often finds itself mired in controversy. Detractors denounce it for its clunky dialogue, wooden acting, and excessive use of CGI. However, a closer examination reveals that beneath the surface flaws lies a saga that is both ambitious and deeply resonant. Political Intrigue and Technological Evolution The prequels delve into the political complexities that led to the rise of the Galactic Empire. The Republic, once a beacon of democracy, becomes embroiled in a web of corruption and manipulation. The rise of the Trade Federation and the Separatist movement reflects real-world concerns about globalism, corporate power, and the erosion of democratic ideals. Moreover, the prequels explore the technological evolution of the "Star Wars" universe. The gleaming starfighters, vast droid armies, and towering battleships represent a leap forward from the iconic ships and weapons of the original trilogy. While some may find the CGI overwhelming, it allows for breathtaking visual spectacles that push the boundaries of filmmaking. Character Development and Redemption While the performances in the prequels may not always be stellar, the characters themselves are complex and relatable. Anakin Skywalker, the central figure, is not simply a one-dimensional villain but a tragic hero whose descent into darkness is both heartbreaking and understandable. Obi-Wan Kenobi, the wise and enigmatic mentor, grapples with the weight of responsibility and the challenges of teaching his wayward apprentice. Padmé Amidala, the queen-turned-senator, embodies strength, compassion, and the enduring hope in the face of adversity. Thematic Depth Beyond the action and adventure, the prequels explore profound themes that resonate with audiences of all ages. The struggle between good and evil, the dangers of unchecked power, and the importance of choice are woven throughout the narrative. Moreover, the prequels offer insights into the nature of prophecy and destiny. Anakin is often portrayed as the "Chosen One" destined to bring balance to the Force, but his journey teaches us that prophecy is not always straightforward and that personal choices ultimately shape one's destiny. Legacy and Impact Despite their initial mixed reception, the prequels have had a lasting impact on the "Star Wars" franchise. They introduced beloved characters such as Darth Maul and General Grievous, expanded the lore of the universe, and provided a backstory for the original trilogy. Furthermore, the prequels have inspired a new generation of fans and filmmakers, who have embraced the darker and more complex elements of the "Star Wars" mythology. From the animated series "The Clone Wars" to the recent "Obi-Wan Kenobi" miniseries, the prequels have left an indelible mark on the franchise's history. In conclusion, while the "Star Wars" prequels may not be perfect, they offer a compelling and thought-provoking addition to the beloved saga. With their political intrigue, technological advancements, complex characters, and profound themes, the prequels deserve a second look and a more nuanced appreciation for their contributions to the "Star Wars" universe.

title: Greg Clark stands by refusal to publish Nissan letter
text: Business Secretary Greg Clark has defended his refusal to publish a letter from Nissan warning of the potential impact of Brexit on its Sunderland plant. In a letter to the Commons' Brexit Committee, Clark said that the letter contained "confidential commercial information" and that publishing it would "harm Nissan's commercial interests". However, the committee has said that it is "disappointed" by Clark's decision and has called on him to reconsider. The letter from Nissan, which was sent to the government in January, warned that the company could be forced to cut production at its Sunderland plant if the UK leaves the EU without a deal. The plant is Nissan's biggest in Europe and employs around 7,000 people. Clark said that he had "carefully considered" the request from the committee but that he had concluded that it would not be in the public interest to publish the letter. He said that the letter contained "detailed and sensitive information" about Nissan's business plans and that publishing it would "give our competitors an unfair advantage". Clark also said that he had met with Nissan executives on several occasions to discuss the company's concerns about Brexit. He said that the government was "working closely with Nissan to support their business in the UK" and that he was confident that the company would continue to invest in the country. However, the Brexit Committee said that it was "disappointed" by Clark's decision and has called on him to reconsider. Committee chairman Hilary Benn said that the letter was "clearly in the public interest" and that the public had a right to know what Nissan had said to the government. Benn said that the committee would "continue to press the government to publish the letter" and that it would "consider all options available to it" to ensure that the letter is published. The government has said that it is "committed to transparency" but that it also has a duty to protect confidential information. A government spokesperson said that the government was "always happy to share information with the committee" but that it had to "balance that with our duty to protect sensitive information".

title: Cost overtakes green concerns in electric car debate
text: Cost overtakes green concerns in electric car debate The rising cost of living is causing consumers to prioritize affordability over environmental concerns when considering electric vehicles (EVs). A recent survey found that 60% of respondents are now more likely to purchase a gasoline-powered car due to the high cost of EVs. This is a significant increase from just 40% last year. The average price of a new EV has risen by 20% in the past year, while the price of gasoline has remained relatively stable. This has made EVs less affordable for many consumers. In addition, the availability of government incentives for EVs has declined in recent months. This has also made EVs less attractive to consumers. As a result of these factors, the growth of the EV market is expected to slow in the coming years. In 2022, EVs accounted for just 5% of new car sales. This is expected to rise to only 10% by 2025. The shift away from EVs is a major setback for the fight against climate change. EVs are zero-emission vehicles, which means they do not produce any harmful pollutants. This makes them an important part of the transition to a clean energy future. However, the high cost of EVs is a major barrier to adoption. If the cost of EVs does not come down soon, the growth of the EV market will continue to be slow. There are a number of things that can be done to make EVs more affordable. Governments can provide more financial incentives for EVs. Car manufacturers can also reduce the cost of producing EVs. Until the cost of EVs comes down, consumers will continue to prioritize affordability over environmental concerns. This will make it difficult to achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement on climate change.

title: Covid: 'I’m one of those people who’s been left out'
text: In the wake of the Covid-19 pandemic, the world has been grappling with its far-reaching consequences. While many have been fortunate enough to regain a sense of normalcy, there are those who have been left behind, their lives irrevocably altered. Among them is Sarah, a 35-year-old mother of two. Before the pandemic, she worked as a physiotherapist, enjoying a fulfilling career and a happy family life. But when the virus struck, everything changed. "My husband and I both got sick," she recalls. "It was a horrible time. I had a fever, chills, and a cough that just wouldn't go away." As the days turned into weeks, Sarah's symptoms persisted. She was unable to work, and the family's finances took a heavy toll. But it was the lingering effects of the virus that would prove to be the most devastating. "Even after I recovered from the initial infection, I still had this terrible fatigue," she says. "I couldn't get out of bed some days, and even simple tasks like walking up the stairs left me exhausted." Sarah's symptoms fit the constellation of conditions known as "long Covid." Experts believe it may affect up to 10% of people who have had Covid-19, with symptoms that can include fatigue, shortness of breath, brain fog, and muscle pain. For Sarah, the impact of long Covid has been profound. She has been unable to return to work, and her family has had to rely on her husband's income. The financial strain has been stressful, and Sarah worries about the future. "I feel like I've been left out of the recovery," she says. "Everyone else seems to be moving on, but I'm still stuck here, struggling with these symptoms." Sarah's story is not an isolated one. Millions around the world are living with the lingering effects of Covid-19. Some have been able to manage their symptoms and return to their normal lives, but for others, the road to recovery remains long and uncertain. As the pandemic continues to evolve, it is essential to remember those who have been left behind. They are not forgotten, and their struggles deserve our attention and support. Research into long Covid is ongoing, and there is hope that one day, effective treatments will be found. Until then, we must ensure that those living with this condition have access to the care and resources they need.

title: Paris police officers suspended over beating of black music producer
text: Two Paris police officers have been suspended after a video emerged appearing to show them beating a black music producer. The footage, which was widely shared on social media, shows the officers repeatedly punching and kicking Michel Zecler in his studio in the 17th arrondissement. Zecler, who is in his 40s, said he was the victim of a "racist attack" and that he had been "humiliated" by the police. The incident has sparked outrage in France, with many people calling for the officers to be prosecuted. The Paris prosecutor's office has opened an investigation into the incident and the two officers have been suspended from duty. Interior Minister Gérald Darmanin said the footage was "shocking" and that he had ordered an immediate investigation. "The images are shocking and unacceptable," Darmanin said. "I have ordered an immediate investigation to shed light on the circumstances of this incident." The incident comes at a time of heightened tensions between the police and the black community in France. In recent months, there have been several high-profile cases of police violence against black people, which have sparked protests and calls for reform. The French government has said it is committed to tackling police violence and has announced a number of measures to improve relations between the police and the public. However, critics say that the government has not done enough to address the issue of racial profiling and police brutality. The incident involving Zecler is likely to further fuel tensions between the police and the black community in France. It is also likely to put pressure on the government to take more action to address the issue of police violence. Zecler's lawyer, Hafida El Ali, said her client had been "traumatized" by the incident. "He is in shock," El Ali said. "He has been humiliated and he feels betrayed by the police." El Ali said she hoped the investigation would lead to the officers being prosecuted. "We want justice for Michel," she said. "We want the officers to be punished for what they did."

title: Marks and Spencer sees first profit rise for four years
text: Marks & Spencer has reported its first annual profit increase in four years, boosted by strong sales of food and homeware. The retailer said pre-tax profits rose 29.4% to £345.1m in the year to 2 April, as total sales increased 9.8% to £10.6bn. Clothing and home sales also returned to growth after two consecutive years of decline, the company said. Chief executive Steve Rowe said the results showed the group was "back in growth". "We have made significant progress this year, enhancing our customer offer and delivering against our transformation plan," he added. M&S had been struggling in recent years as it faced competition from online retailers and discount chains. But Mr Rowe, who took over as chief executive in 2016, has been overseeing a major overhaul of the business, including closing dozens of stores, revamping its clothing ranges and investing in its online operations. The company's food business has been a key driver of growth in recent years, and this continued in the latest financial year. Food sales increased by 6.7% to £6.3bn, with particularly strong demand for fresh produce and ready meals. Clothing and home sales also performed well, with sales increasing by 1.9% and 6.2% respectively. This was the first time that clothing sales had returned to growth in two years. Mr Rowe said the company was now "well-positioned to continue to grow". "We are confident that we can continue to deliver sustainable, profitable growth in the years ahead," he added. Analysts welcomed the results, saying they showed that M&S was "back on track". Clive Black, an analyst at Shore Capital, said the results were "a genuine step change" for the company. "M&S has reported a material improvement in its trading performance, with some structural progress evident in all three divisions," he said. "Whilst not quite out of the woods, we believe that the company can continue to expand market share in food, clothing and home."

title: Isle of Man can 'beat Covid-19 again', say residents
text: The Isle of Man is a small island located in the Irish Sea between Great Britain and Ireland. It is a self-governing British Crown Dependency, with its own parliament, laws, and currency. The island has a population of around 85,000 people. In March 2020, the Isle of Man, like many other countries around the world, went into lockdown in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The lockdown measures were successful in suppressing the virus on the island, and by June 2020, the Isle of Man was one of the few places in the world to have no active cases of COVID-19. However, in September 2020, a new outbreak of COVID-19 occurred on the island. The outbreak was linked to a group of people who had traveled to the island from the United Kingdom. The outbreak quickly spread, and within a few weeks, there were over 100 active cases of COVID-19 on the island. In response to the outbreak, the Isle of Man government reimposed lockdown measures. The lockdown measures were successful in slowing the spread of the virus, and by November 2020, the number of active cases had fallen to below 10. The Isle of Man is now in the process of easing its lockdown measures. The government has announced a plan to gradually reopen the island's economy and society. The plan includes a phased reopening of businesses, schools, and other public places. The Isle of Man government is confident that the island can beat COVID-19 again. The government has praised the people of the Isle of Man for their cooperation and resilience during the pandemic. One resident, Jennifer Shimmin, said: "I am confident that we can beat COVID-19 again. We have done it before, and we can do it again. We are a strong community, and we will get through this together." Another resident, Peter Karran, said: "The Isle of Man has a great track record in dealing with crises. We have a strong sense of community, and we are always willing to help each other out. I am sure that we will get through this pandemic and come out stronger than ever."

title: Family Guy's Cleveland enlists music stars
text: Family Guy's Cleveland Brown is set to enlist some chart-topping music stars for his upcoming solo venture. The lovable patriarch, voiced by Mike Henry, will be joined by a stellar cast of musicians including Snoop Dogg, Pharrell Williams, Ariana Grande, and Ed Sheeran. title: Former Stonehenge A303 road proposal 'still popular locally'
text: Former Stonehenge A303 road proposal 'still popular locally' Despite being rejected by the government in 2020, a controversial plan to build a tunnel under Stonehenge remains popular among local residents, a new survey has found. The proposal, which would have seen the A303 trunk road diverted away from the iconic stone circle, was met with fierce opposition from heritage groups and environmentalists. However, a survey conducted by Wiltshire Council has found that 57% of local residents support the plan. The survey, which was carried out in January and February 2023, found that support for the tunnel was highest among people who live in the villages of Amesbury and Winterbourne Stoke, which are located near Stonehenge. These villages have long been affected by traffic congestion caused by the A303, which runs directly past the stone circle. Supporters of the tunnel argue that it would improve traffic flow and reduce pollution in the area. They also say that it would enhance the setting of Stonehenge, which is currently dominated by the busy road. Opponents of the tunnel, however, argue that it would damage the archaeological landscape around Stonehenge. They also say that it would be a waste of money, as there are other, less damaging ways to improve traffic flow in the area. The government rejected the tunnel proposal in 2020, saying that it would have "irreversible and detrimental impacts" on the World Heritage Site. However, it said that it would continue to work with stakeholders to find a solution to the traffic congestion problem. The results of the Wiltshire Council survey suggest that there is still significant local support for the tunnel proposal. However, it is unclear whether the government will be willing to reconsider its decision. A spokesperson for the Department for Transport said: "We are aware of the results of the Wiltshire Council survey. We will continue to work with stakeholders to find a solution to the traffic congestion problem in the Stonehenge area." The National Trust, which owns the land around Stonehenge, said: "We believe that the best way to protect Stonehenge is to manage the traffic that passes it. We are working with the government and other stakeholders to find a solution that will reduce traffic congestion and improve the setting of the stone circle."

title: Thailand election date set and campaign ban lifted
text: Thailand's Election Commission has set March 24, 2024, as the date for the next general election. The announcement came after a meeting of the commission on Friday, November 18, 2023. The election date was widely expected, as the current government's term is due to expire in March 2025. The election will be the first since the military-backed constitution was amended in 2019. The election campaign period will officially begin on February 24, 2024, with the campaign ban lifted on that day. This means that political parties will be able to hold rallies, distribute campaign materials, and engage in other campaign activities. The election will be closely watched by both domestic and international observers. It will be the first test of the new constitution, which was drafted by a military-appointed committee. The constitution has been criticized by some for giving the military too much power over the political process. There are currently 40 political parties registered with the Election Commission. The main contenders in the election are expected to be the ruling Palang Pracharath Party, the main opposition Pheu Thai Party, and the new Thai Sang Thai Party. The Palang Pracharath Party is led by Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha, who took power in a military coup in 2014. The Pheu Thai Party is the largest opposition party and is associated with former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra. The Thai Sang Thai Party is a new party led by former Deputy Prime Minister Suthep Thaugsuban. The election is expected to be competitive, with all three main parties having a chance of winning. The outcome of the election will likely have a significant impact on Thailand's political future.

title: Expert "suspected" Shakespeare folio theft accused
text: A renowned Shakespeare expert has been charged with the theft of a rare first edition of the playwright's collected works, known as the First Folio. Dr. Edward Capell, a professor at the University of Cambridge, was arrested at his home on Wednesday and is due to appear in court on Thursday. The First Folio is one of the most valuable books in the world and is estimated to be worth millions of pounds. It was published in 1623 and contains 36 plays by Shakespeare, including some that had never been printed before. The book was stolen from the library of the University of Birmingham in 2015 and has not been seen since. Dr. Capell has been a suspect in the case since shortly after the theft, but this is the first time he has been charged. The arrest of Dr. Capell has shocked the world of academia. He is a highly respected scholar who has written extensively about Shakespeare and the First Folio. He is also a former president of the Shakespeare Birthplace Trust. The university has released a statement saying that it is "deeply concerned" about the charges against Dr. Capell. The statement says that the university is "cooperating fully with the police investigation" and that "the university will take appropriate action if Dr. Capell is found guilty." The charges against Dr. Capell have also raised concerns about the security of rare books and manuscripts. The First Folio is not the only valuable book that has been stolen in recent years. In 2014, a rare copy of the Gutenberg Bible was stolen from the University of Münster in Germany. The theft of rare books and manuscripts is a serious problem and it is important to take steps to protect these valuable artifacts. Libraries and museums need to improve their security measures and law enforcement agencies need to do more to catch and prosecute those who steal these priceless items. The case of Dr. Capell is a reminder that even the most respected scholars are not immune to temptation. It is also a reminder that the theft of rare books and manuscripts is a serious crime that must be punished to the full extent of the law.

title: Scottish economy 'needs better balance'
text: Scotland's Economy Needs Better Balance Scotland's economy has long been dominated by a few key industries, such as oil and gas, financial services, and tourism. This has led to a number of challenges, including a lack of diversification and a vulnerability to fluctuations in global markets. In recent years, there have been increasing calls for the Scottish government to take action to address this imbalance. A number of reports have highlighted the need for a more diverse and resilient economy, with a greater focus on sectors such as renewable energy, manufacturing, and creative industries. The Scottish government has taken some steps to address these concerns. It has invested in a number of new industries, such as life sciences and digital technology. It has also introduced a number of measures to support businesses, including tax breaks and grants. However, more needs to be done to ensure that Scotland's economy is fit for the future. The government needs to continue to invest in new industries and support businesses. It also needs to work with the private sector to develop a long-term plan for economic development. One of the key challenges facing the Scottish government is the need to attract and retain skilled workers. Scotland has a highly educated workforce, but it is often difficult to attract workers to the country's more remote areas. The government needs to do more to promote Scotland as an attractive place to live and work. Another challenge is the need to improve productivity. Scotland's productivity has lagged behind that of other parts of the UK for a number of years. The government needs to take action to address this issue, such as investing in education and training. The Scottish economy is at a crossroads. It has the potential to be a thriving and prosperous economy, but only if the government takes action to address the challenges it faces. Recommendations The Scottish government should take the following steps to address the challenges facing the economy: Invest in new industries, such as renewable energy, manufacturing, and creative industries. Support businesses with tax breaks, grants, and other measures. Develop a long-term plan for economic development in conjunction with the private sector. Promote Scotland as an attractive place to live and work. Invest in education and training to improve productivity. By taking these steps, the Scottish government can help to create a more diverse, resilient, and prosperous economy for the future.

title: Faces of Egyptian mummies on show in Manchester
text: Unveiled today at the Manchester Museum, the faces of ancient Egyptian mummies have been digitally reconstructed, revealing the identities of individuals who lived thousands of years ago. Using advanced medical imaging techniques, scientists have meticulously recreated the faces of three mummies, providing unprecedented insights into their lives and appearances. The innovative project, a collaboration between the University of Manchester and the Egyptian Mummy Project, sheds new light on the enigmatic individuals who once inhabited the enigmatic land of the pharaohs. The centerpiece of the exhibition is the meticulously reconstructed face of a woman named Meresamun. Her mummified remains were discovered in the Valley of the Kings, a testament to her status and significance in ancient Egyptian society. Meresamun's delicate features and elaborate headdress suggest she was a member of the elite, possibly even a royal. Her reconstructed face reveals a woman of remarkable beauty, with almond-shaped eyes, a slender nose, and a gentle smile. Alongside Meresamun, the exhibition showcases the reconstructed faces of two other individuals, a man named Neswaiu and a child known only as "Manchester Mummy." Neswaiu, a priest from the 22nd dynasty, exudes an air of authority and wisdom. His strong jawline and piercing gaze reflect his status as a respected figure within his community. In contrast, the Manchester Mummy, a child of around six years old, evokes a sense of innocence and wonder. Her plump cheeks and wide eyes capture the vulnerability of childhood, providing a poignant reminder of the fragility of life in ancient Egypt. The exhibition not only offers a glimpse into the physical appearances of these ancient individuals but also delves into their personal stories and historical context. Through the use of interactive displays and immersive technology, visitors are transported back in time, experiencing the sights and sounds of ancient Egypt. They learn about the mummification process, the beliefs and rituals surrounding death, and the social hierarchy that shaped the lives of Meresamun, Neswaiu, and the Manchester Mummy. The Faces of Egyptian Mummies exhibition at the Manchester Museum is a groundbreaking achievement in the field of Egyptology. It humanizes the ancient Egyptians, revealing their individuality and the complexities of their lives. Through the power of science and technology, we are now able to connect with these individuals on a personal level, bridging the vast gulf of time that separates us. As we gaze upon their reconstructed faces, we are reminded of the enduring legacy of human existence and the timeless fascination with the mysteries of the past.

title: 'Serious concerns' remain over funeral pricing
text: 'Serious concerns' remain over funeral pricing The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has said it has "serious concerns" about the way funeral directors set and advertise their prices. Following a year-long investigation, the CMA has found that the market for funerals is not working well for consumers. Most funeral directors fail to provide itemised pricing or accurate cost comparisons, making it difficult for bereaved families to compare prices and find the best deal. The CMA also found that some funeral directors used misleading or aggressive sales tactics, and that many consumers felt pressured into buying more expensive services than they wanted. The CMA has made a number of recommendations to improve the market, including: Funeral directors should be required to provide clear and accurate itemised pricing, including a breakdown of all costs. Funeral directors should be banned from using misleading or aggressive sales tactics. The government should consider introducing a price cap on funeral costs. The CMA's investigation found that the average cost of a funeral in the UK is now around £4,000. However, the cost can vary significantly depending on the type of funeral and the services chosen. The CMA's chief executive, Andrea Coscelli, said: "Our investigation has found that the market for funerals is not working well for consumers. "We have serious concerns about the way funeral directors set and advertise their prices, and we are concerned that some consumers are being taken advantage of at a time when they are most vulnerable." The CMA's findings have been welcomed by consumer groups. Which? executive director, Richard Lloyd, said: "The CMA's report exposes the scandalous rip-off in the funeral market. "For too long, funeral directors have taken advantage of grieving families by charging sky-high prices and using misleading sales tactics. "The CMA's recommendations are a step in the right direction, but the government must now take action to ensure that these changes are implemented." The Funeral Directors Association (FDA) said it was "disappointed" with the CMA's findings. The FDA said that its members were "committed to providing a high standard of service to bereaved families" and that they "comply with all relevant laws and regulations". The FDA said it would "carefully consider" the CMA's recommendations and "work with the government to ensure that any changes to the market are in the best interests of consumers".

title: Charles Bronson cleared of trying to attack prison governor
text: Charles Bronson has been cleared of attempting to attack a prison governor. The jury at Leeds Crown Court found Bronson not guilty of plotting to cause grievous bodily harm with intent to Mark Humphreys, the governor of HMP Wakefield. Bronson, 68, who has spent much of his adult life in prison, had denied the charge. The trial heard that Bronson had sent a series of letters to Humphreys in which he made threats of violence. In one letter, Bronson wrote: "I'm going to rip your f head off and s* down your neck." He also said he would "smash your f head in with a snooker ball in a sock". However, the jury accepted Bronson's defense that he was simply trying to intimidate Humphreys and had no intention of carrying out the threats. The jury also heard that Bronson has a long history of self-harm and has often made threats of violence to prison staff. In his closing speech, Bronson's barrister, Richard Wright QC, said: "He is a man who has spent his life in prison and has had a troubled relationship with the prison service. "He has made threats in the past, but he has never carried them out. "He is a fantasist and a self-harmer. He makes these threats as a way of getting attention and as a way of lashing out at the system." The jury deliberated for two days before returning a verdict of not guilty. Bronson, who has been in prison for more than 40 years, is one of Britain's most notorious prisoners. He has been convicted of a string of violent offenses, including robbery, assault, and kidnapping. In 1999, he was sentenced to life imprisonment for taking a prison officer hostage. Bronson has been the subject of several books and documentaries. In 2008, a film about his life, Bronson, was released starring Tom Hardy.

title: Coronavirus: New York City orders international visitors to quarantine
text: Coronavirus: New York City orders international visitors to quarantine New York City has ordered all international visitors to quarantine for 14 days upon arrival, regardless of whether they are showing symptoms of coronavirus. The order, which went into effect on Saturday, applies to anyone who has traveled to any country outside the United States within the past 14 days. Visitors are required to self-quarantine at their place of residence or at a hotel. They are not allowed to leave their quarantine except to seek medical care or to get food and other essential supplies. The order is the latest in a series of measures that New York City has taken to try to slow the spread of the coronavirus. The city has also closed schools, restaurants, and bars, and has banned large gatherings. As of Saturday, there were more than 9,000 confirmed cases of coronavirus in New York City, and more than 200 people had died. The city's health commissioner, Dr. Oxiris Barbot, said the quarantine order is necessary to protect the health of New Yorkers. "We know that people who have traveled internationally are at higher risk for having been exposed to the virus," Barbot said. "This order will help to reduce the risk of transmission." The order has been met with mixed reactions. Some people have praised the city for taking aggressive action to protect public health. Others have criticized the order, saying it is too restrictive and will hurt the city's economy. The city's mayor, Bill de Blasio, has defended the order, saying it is necessary to save lives. "We are in a public health emergency," de Blasio said. "We need to do everything we can to slow the spread of this virus." The quarantine order is expected to remain in effect for at least two weeks. The city will then reassess the situation and decide whether to extend the order. Here is some additional information about the quarantine order: The order applies to all international visitors, regardless of their citizenship or visa status. Visitors are required to self-quarantine at their place of residence or at a hotel. Visitors are not allowed to leave their quarantine except to seek medical care or to get food and other essential supplies. Visitors who violate the order may be subject to fines or imprisonment.

title: New Welsh Education Minister Huw Lewis' big decisions
text: Huw Lewis, the newly appointed Welsh Education Minister, has outlined his ambitious plans to transform the education system in Wales. title: Smart motorways to be reviewed over driver safety fears
text: Smart motorways are to be reviewed over concerns about driver safety, the government has announced. Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said he had asked National Highways to carry out a stocktake of all smart motorways without a hard shoulder. It comes after a number of fatal accidents on smart motorways, including one in which a woman was killed when her car was hit from behind by a lorry. The review will look at the safety of smart motorways and consider whether any changes need to be made. Smart motorways use technology to manage traffic flow, such as variable speed limits and overhead gantries. They have been introduced on a number of major roads in England in recent years. However, there have been concerns about their safety, particularly in relation to the lack of a hard shoulder. In the event of a breakdown or accident, drivers are advised to pull over into an emergency refuge area. However, these areas are often spaced several miles apart. Critics argue that this can leave drivers stranded in dangerous situations, particularly at night or in bad weather. The government has previously defended smart motorways, saying that they are safer than traditional motorways. However, the recent spate of fatal accidents has led to renewed calls for a review of their safety. The RAC welcomed the announcement of the review, saying it was "long overdue". "We've been calling for a full and independent review of smart motorways for some time now," said RAC head of roads policy Nicholas Lyes. "The government has finally listened to our concerns and we hope that this review will lead to some much-needed changes." The AA also welcomed the review, but said it should be "wide-ranging and independent". "We need to look at all aspects of smart motorways, including the design, the technology and the way they are operated," said AA president Edmund King. "We also need to look at the impact of smart motorways on drivers, particularly those who are vulnerable." The Transport Secretary said he wanted the review to be completed as soon as possible. "I want to be absolutely sure that our roads are as safe as they can be," he said. "That's why I've asked National Highways to carry out this stocktake of all smart motorways without a hard shoulder." The review is expected to report back to the government in the autumn.

title: Toy sellers bet on Christmas as sales dip
text: Toymakers and retailers are placing their bets on a bumper Christmas to offset a year of falling sales. Figures from the NPD Group show that sales of toys in the UK fell by 3% in the first half of 2023, with the value of the market dropping by £50 million to £803 million. The decline follows a boom in toy sales during the pandemic, when children were stuck at home and parents were looking for ways to keep them entertained. But with the cost of living crisis putting pressure on household budgets, families are now cutting back on non-essential spending - and toys are often one of the first things to go. Despite the challenging market conditions, toymakers and retailers are hoping that Christmas will provide a much-needed boost. NPD's UK toy market analyst Frederique Tutt said: "The Christmas period is crucial for the toy industry, accounting for around 60% of annual sales. "We expect to see a return to more traditional festive spending patterns this year, with families looking to make the most of the occasion after two years of disrupted celebrations." Toymakers have been working hard to develop new and innovative products that will appeal to children this Christmas. One of the biggest trends this year is the rise of STEM toys - products that combine science, technology, engineering and maths. These toys are designed to be educational as well as fun, and they can help children to develop important skills such as problem-solving, critical thinking and creativity. Another big trend this year is the resurgence of classic toys. Products such as board games, dolls and action figures are all seeing a resurgence in popularity, as parents and grandparents look for ways to connect with their children and grandchildren through shared experiences. Retailers are also getting ready for the Christmas rush. Many are offering discounts and promotions to attract shoppers, and they are also increasing their stocks of popular toys to ensure that they have plenty to meet demand. The British Toy and Hobby Association (BTHA) is confident that the toy industry will have a successful Christmas. BTHA chief executive Roland Earl said: "We know that families are facing financial pressures at the moment, but we believe that toys will still be a priority for many people this Christmas. "Toys provide children with essential play and learning experiences, and they can also help to create special memories that will last a lifetime."

title: Greggs to open shops despite first loss in 36 years
text: Greggs to Open Shops Despite First Loss in 36 Years Despite suffering its first annual loss in 36 years, Greggs has announced plans to open new shops and roll out a delivery service. The bakery chain reported a pre-tax loss of £14.7 million for 2020, as the COVID-19 pandemic forced it to close stores and reduce operating hours. However, Greggs said it is "cautiously optimistic" about the future and plans to invest in its business. As part of its expansion plans, Greggs will open 100 new shops in the UK this year, creating around 500 jobs. The company will also trial a delivery service in partnership with Just Eat. Greggs CEO Roger Whiteside said: "We have emerged from a challenging year in a strong position. Our business model has proven to be resilient, and we have a loyal customer base. We are now well-placed to take advantage of the opportunities that lie ahead." The company's decision to open new shops and invest in delivery comes as other retailers have been forced to close stores due to the pandemic. However, Greggs believes that its value-for-money offerings and convenient locations will continue to attract customers. Greggs has been a fixture on British high streets for over 80 years. The company is known for its affordable pasties, sausage rolls, and other baked goods. In recent years, Greggs has also expanded its menu to include healthier options, such as salads and sandwiches. The company's first loss in 36 years is a sign of the challenges that the retail sector has faced during the pandemic. However, Greggs' plans to open new shops and invest in delivery suggest that it is confident about the future. Analysis Greggs' decision to open new shops and invest in delivery despite its first loss in 36 years is a bold move. However, the company has a strong track record of success and is well-positioned to take advantage of the opportunities that lie ahead. The company's value-for-money offerings and convenient locations are likely to continue to attract customers, even as other retailers struggle. Greggs is also well-placed to benefit from the growing trend towards online shopping. If Greggs can successfully execute its expansion plans, it is likely to emerge from the pandemic even stronger than before. The company's commitment to investing in its business is a positive sign for the future of the UK retail sector.

title: Four Irish language groups lose key funding
text: Four Irish Language Groups Lose Key Funding Four Irish language groups have lost out on key funding that has supported their work for decades. The groups, which include Conradh na Gaeilge, Glór na nGael and Foras na Gaeilge, have been told that their funding from the Department of Rural and Community Development will not be renewed. The decision has been met with dismay by the groups, who say it will have a devastating impact on their work promoting and preserving the Irish language. Conradh na Gaeilge President Aodán Mac Póilin said the loss of funding would be "a hammer blow" to the group. "We have been working for over a century to promote the Irish language, and this funding has been essential to our work," he said. "This decision is a betrayal of the Irish language and of the people who have worked so hard to keep it alive." Glór na nGael Director Seán Ó Coinn said the loss of funding would mean the closure of the group's Irish language radio station, Raidió na Gaeltachta. "This is a vital service for the Irish-speaking community in Ireland and abroad," he said. "It provides a platform for Irish language news, music and culture, and it is a lifeline for many people who live in isolated areas." Foras na Gaeilge Chief Executive Seán Ó Cuirreáin said the loss of funding would have a "crippling" impact on the group's work to promote the Irish language in education and the media. "We have been working with schools, universities and media outlets to increase the use of Irish," he said. "This funding has been essential to our work, and its loss will set us back years." The groups have appealed to the Department of Rural and Community Development to reconsider its decision. They have also launched a campaign to raise public awareness of the issue. The Department of Rural and Community Development said the decision to cut funding was made as part of a wider review of its budget. "We recognise the important work that these groups do, but we have to make difficult decisions in order to balance the books," a spokesperson said. The decision has been criticised by politicians from all parties. Sinn Féin President Mary Lou McDonald said the loss of funding was "a disgrace". "This is a government that is supposed to be committed to the Irish language," she said. "But this decision shows that they have no real interest in supporting our national language." Fianna Fáil leader Micheál Martin said the decision was "short-sighted". "The Irish language is part of our heritage and our culture," he said. "This decision will do nothing to promote the language, and it will only serve to alienate the Irish-speaking community."

title: Online health check 'broken promise' claim on over-50s in Wales
text: Online Health Check 'Broken Promise' Claim on Over-50s in Wales The Welsh government has been accused of breaking a promise to offer an online health check to all over-50s in Wales. The health check was announced in 2021 as part of a wider NHS Digital Health and Care Plan. It was due to be rolled out to all over-50s in Wales by the end of 2022. However, the Welsh government has now admitted that this deadline will not be met. It says that the online health check is still in development and that it is now expected to be rolled out by the end of 2023. The delay has been met with criticism from some health experts. Dr. David Bailey, a public health consultant, said: "This is a broken promise. The Welsh government promised to deliver an online health check to all over-50s in Wales by the end of 2022. They have now broken that promise." Dr. Bailey said that the delay could have a negative impact on the health of over-50s in Wales. He said: "The online health check is a vital tool for early detection of health problems. By delaying the rollout of the health check, the Welsh government is putting the health of over-50s in Wales at risk." The Welsh government has defended the delay, saying that it is necessary to ensure that the online health check is delivered in a way that is safe and effective. A spokesperson for the Welsh government said: "We are committed to delivering an online health check to all over-50s in Wales. However, we need to ensure that the health check is delivered in a way that is safe and effective. This means that we need to take the time to develop and test the health check properly." The spokesperson said that the Welsh government is working closely with NHS Wales to develop and deliver the online health check. They said: "We are working closely with NHS Wales to develop and deliver the online health check. We are committed to rolling out the health check as soon as possible, but we need to make sure that it is delivered in a way that is safe and effective."
