title: Police seek man subject to TPim terror control measure
text: Police are searching for a man who is subject to a Terrorism Prevention and Investigation Measure (Tpim) after he failed to answer bail. Yahya Rashid, 25, of no fixed address, was released on bail in October 2022 after being charged with a number of terror-related offences, including preparing for acts of terrorism and possessing a firearm without a certificate. He was due to appear at the Old Bailey on Wednesday, but failed to attend. Rashid is a British citizen who was born in Sudan. He has been subject to a Tpim since 2015, which restricts his movements and activities. Under the Tpim, Rashid is required to live at a specified address, observe a curfew, and report regularly to the police. He is also banned from contacting certain people and using the internet. The Tpim is a preventative measure that can be imposed on individuals who are suspected of being involved in terrorism, but who have not been charged with an offence. It is designed to disrupt and restrict their activities, and to protect the public from harm. The Metropolitan Police has said that Rashid is not considered to be a direct threat to the public at this time. However, officers are urging anyone who sees him to call 999 and not to approach him. In a statement, the Met said: "Yahya Rashid is wanted for failing to answer his bail on charges of preparing acts of terrorism and possessing a firearm without a certificate. "He is a dangerous individual and should not be approached. If you see him, please call 999 immediately." Anyone with information about Rashid's whereabouts is asked to call the Metropolitan Police's Counter Terrorism Command on 0800 789 321.

title: Third Menai crossing construction 'could start by 2021'
text: Work on a third Menai crossing could start by 2021, the Welsh Government has said. The project to build a new bridge or tunnel linking Anglesey to mainland Wales has been discussed for decades. The Welsh Government said a public consultation would begin in the autumn. It said construction could begin on the preferred option by 2021, subject to all necessary approvals. The Menai Suspension Bridge was built in 1826 and the Britannia Bridge was built in 1850. Traffic congestion on both bridges is a regular problem, particularly during the summer months. The Welsh Government said its preferred option is a new bridge next to the existing Britannia Bridge. It said this would be the most cost-effective option and would cause the least disruption to the environment and local communities. The other options are a tunnel or a new bridge next to the Menai Suspension Bridge. The public consultation will run from October 1 to November 29. The Welsh Government said it would also be carrying out technical studies and environmental assessments. It said a preferred route would be announced next summer. The project is expected to cost between £1bn and £1.5bn. The Welsh Government said it was committed to funding the project but would also seek financial support from the UK Government. The UK Government has said it is "fully supportive" of the project and is "working closely" with the Welsh Government. The Menai crossing is a key part of the Welsh Government's infrastructure plans. It says it will improve connectivity between north and south Wales and boost the economy of the region. The project has been welcomed by business leaders and politicians in north Wales. However, some environmental groups have expressed concerns about the potential impact on the Menai Strait. The Menai Strait is a Site of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI) and is home to a number of protected species. The Welsh Government said it would take all necessary steps to protect the environment during the construction and operation of the new crossing.

title: Iran sanctions: US moves to isolate 'major' banks
text: US moves to isolate 'major' Iranian banks The United States has taken steps to isolate two Iranian banks, accusing them of funding terrorism. The Trump administration has revoked the licenses of Bank Melli and Bank Saderat, which allow them to operate in the US. The Treasury Department said the banks were "major" financial institutions that had "knowingly facilitated" transactions for terrorist organisations. The move is the latest in a series of sanctions imposed by the US on Iran since President Trump took office. The sanctions have been aimed at pressuring Iran to change its behaviour, including its nuclear programme and its support for terrorism. The Iranian government has condemned the sanctions as "economic terrorism" and has accused the US of trying to destabilise the country. The US Treasury Department said that Bank Melli and Bank Saderat had "knowingly facilitated" transactions for terrorist organisations, including Hezbollah and Hamas. The department said that the banks had provided financial services to the organisations and had "moved money on their behalf." The Treasury Department also said that the banks had "failed to conduct adequate due diligence" on their customers and had "turned a blind eye" to their terrorist activities. The US has also sanctioned several other Iranian banks in recent months, including Bank Sepah and Bank Ansar. The sanctions have had a significant impact on the Iranian economy, making it difficult for businesses to trade with the country. The International Monetary Fund has estimated that the Iranian economy will contract by 6% this year and that inflation will rise to 37%. The US has also imposed sanctions on Iran's oil industry, which is a major source of revenue for the government. The sanctions have made it difficult for Iran to sell its oil and have led to a sharp decline in its oil exports. The US has said that it is willing to lift the sanctions if Iran changes its behaviour. However, the Iranian government has said that it will not negotiate with the US while the sanctions are in place. The US sanctions have been controversial. Some critics have argued that the sanctions are ineffective and that they are causing unnecessary hardship to the Iranian people. Others have argued that the sanctions are necessary to pressure Iran to change its behaviour and that they will ultimately be successful.

title: Covid-19: BAME communities urged to accept vaccine
text: COVID-19: BAME communities urged to accept vaccine Health leaders are urging people from Black, Asian, and minority ethnic (BAME) backgrounds to accept the COVID-19 vaccine amid concerns about vaccine hesitancy within these communities. Research has shown that people from BAME backgrounds are more likely to be hospitalized and die from COVID-19. They are also more likely to have underlying health conditions that can make them more vulnerable to the virus. Despite this, there is evidence that people from BAME backgrounds are less likely to accept the COVID-19 vaccine. A recent survey found that only 57% of Black people and 62% of Asian people in the UK said they would definitely or probably get the vaccine, compared to 79% of white people. There are a number of reasons why people from BAME backgrounds may be hesitant to accept the vaccine. Some people may have concerns about the safety of the vaccine, while others may not trust the government or healthcare system. However, health leaders are urging people from BAME backgrounds to overcome their hesitancy and accept the vaccine. They say that the vaccine is safe and effective, and that it is the best way to protect themselves and their loved ones from COVID-19. "We know that people from BAME backgrounds are more likely to be hospitalized and die from COVID-19," said Dr. Habib Naqvi, a consultant in public health medicine. "That's why it's so important that people from these communities get vaccinated. The vaccine is safe and effective, and it's the best way to protect yourself and your loved ones." "I understand that some people may have concerns about the vaccine," said Dr. Naqvi. "But I want to assure you that the vaccine has been thoroughly tested and it is safe. It is the best way to protect yourself and your loved ones from this deadly virus." If you are unsure about whether or not to get the vaccine, please speak to your doctor or another healthcare professional. They can provide you with more information about the vaccine and help you make a decision. The COVID-19 vaccine is free for everyone in the UK. You can book your appointment online or by calling 119.

title: The Last Of Us Part II: 'A game about bad people doing bad things to survive'
text: In the desolate and unforgiving world of "The Last of Us Part II," the lines between good and evil blur, leaving behind a haunting exploration of the depths of human nature. This sequel to the critically acclaimed "The Last of Us" once again thrusts players into a post-apocalyptic world ravaged by a deadly fungal infection, but this time, it's a story about bad people doing bad things to survive. At the heart of this gripping narrative is Ellie, a young woman whose life has been shaped by tragedy. Haunted by the loss of her loved ones, she sets out on a quest for revenge against those who wronged her. Along the way, she encounters a cast of diverse characters, each with their own motivations and justifications for their actions. As players delve into Ellie's journey, they'll witness the brutal realities of survival in a world where every decision carries a weighty consequence. The game confronts players with ethical dilemmas, forcing them to question their own beliefs and morals. In a world where trust is scarce, characters lie, betray, and manipulate each other in their desperate pursuit of survival. The game's hyper-realistic graphics and immersive environment further heighten the emotional impact of the story. Players will feel the tension of every encounter, the weight of every choice, and the lingering trauma of Ellie's past. "The Last of Us Part II" is a game that will undoubtedly stay with players long after the credits roll. However, the game's relentless focus on violence and brutality has sparked controversy. Critics argue that it glorifies violence and desensitizes players to its horrors. Defenders, on the other hand, contend that the game's unflinching portrayal of the human condition is necessary to fully explore the complexities of life in a post-apocalyptic world. Ultimately, "The Last of Us Part II" is a thought-provoking and challenging game that pushes the boundaries of storytelling in video games. It's a masterpiece that will undoubtedly be debated and analyzed for years to come. While it may not be an easy game to play, it's a game that will leave a lasting impact on those who dare to experience its unflinching portrayal of the human condition.

title: Edward Snowden 'smeared by UK officials'
text: Edward Snowden Smeared by UK Officials Secret documents leaked by Edward Snowden have revealed that senior UK officials attempted to discredit him by smearing his character and spreading false information about his motives. According to the files, British intelligence agencies worked with media outlets to portray Snowden as a "traitor," "egoist," and "attention seeker." They also claimed that he was motivated by a desire for personal revenge against the government. These allegations have been strongly denied by Snowden, who maintains that he leaked the documents in order to expose the government's mass surveillance program, which he believed was a threat to civil liberties. The documents, which were obtained by the Intercept website, also show that British officials were aware of the US government's plans to prosecute Snowden and extradite him to the US. However, they did not offer him asylum or take any steps to protect him from prosecution. This has led to accusations that the UK government was complicit in the US government's attempts to silence Snowden. The revelations have been met with widespread criticism from human rights groups and journalists. They have called on the UK government to apologize to Snowden and to drop any charges against him. Snowden, who is currently living in exile in Russia, said that the documents "vindicate everything I have said about the global surveillance system." He added that he was "deeply disappointed" by the actions of the UK government. The allegations against British officials come at a time of heightened scrutiny of government surveillance programs. In recent years, several whistleblowers have come forward to expose the extent to which governments around the world are collecting data on their citizens. The Snowden leaks have been particularly damaging to the UK government, which has been accused of being too close to the US and of failing to protect the privacy of its citizens. The revelations are likely to further damage the already strained relationship between the UK and Russia. The two countries have been at odds over a number of issues, including the annexation of Crimea and the poisoning of former Russian spy Sergei Skripal. The Snowden leaks have also raised questions about the future of whistleblowing. In an era of mass surveillance, it is becoming increasingly difficult for whistleblowers to expose government wrongdoing without risking prosecution or persecution.

title: Firefighters in Scotland reject pay deal for second time
text: Firefighters in Scotland Reject Pay Deal for Second Time In a resounding rejection, firefighters in Scotland have voted against a proposed pay deal for the second time, escalating tensions between the Scottish Fire Brigades Union (SFBU) and the Scottish government. The union, which represents over 3,500 firefighters and control staff, held a second ballot on the pay offer. According to the results released on Thursday, 87% of members voted against the deal. The rejected offer included a 5% pay increase over two years, but fell short of the union's demand for a 10% rise to match inflation. The SFBU has argued that firefighters have lost significant purchasing power in recent years due to rising living costs. Martin Blunden, the SFBU's executive director, said the result of the ballot was "a clear and unequivocal mandate" from members. "The government has failed to take into account the real-terms pay cut firefighters have suffered over the years," Blunden said. "This offer was simply not good enough." The Scottish government has expressed disappointment at the outcome of the ballot but has remained committed to finding a resolution. "We believe the pay offer was fair and reasonable and above the average pay increase in the public sector," said Shona Robison, the cabinet secretary for social justice, housing and local government. "We will continue to engage with the Scottish Fire Brigades Union and other stakeholders to find a way forward," Robison added. The rejection of the pay deal has raised concerns about the potential for industrial action. The SFBU has not ruled out the possibility of a strike if the government does not meet its demands. "Our members are determined to secure a fair and just pay deal," Blunden said. "We will consider all options available to us, including industrial action." The Scottish government has urged the union to reconsider its position and has reiterated its commitment to ongoing negotiations. The last time firefighters in Scotland took industrial action was in 2015, when they staged a 48-hour strike over pay and conditions. The strike caused widespread disruption across the country and highlighted the importance of the fire service. The current pay dispute is expected to continue for some time, with both sides expressing a desire to reach a compromise. However, the outcome of the second ballot has put pressure on the government to improve its offer.

title: Lockdown party crash: South Wales PC Tasia Stephens' gross misconduct
text: A police officer has been found guilty of gross misconduct after organising an illegal lockdown party. PC Tasia Stephens, 45, of South Wales Police, held a gathering of more than 30 people at her home in Llanharan on December 12, 2020. The party was reported to police and officers attended and broke it up. Stephens was subsequently charged with organising the event and pleaded guilty to the offence at Cardiff Magistrates' Court in November. A disciplinary hearing was held on Monday and Stephens was found guilty of gross misconduct. The hearing was told that Stephens had invited guests to the party via a WhatsApp group and had told them to bring their own food and drink. She had also arranged for a DJ to play music and had hired a bouncy castle for the children attending. The hearing was told that Stephens had ignored the government's lockdown rules and had put her colleagues and the public at risk. In a statement, South Wales Police said: "We expect the highest standards of behaviour from our officers and staff and will not tolerate any breaches of the law or our own policies. "PC Stephens' actions fell well below the standards expected of a police officer and she has rightly been found guilty of gross misconduct." Stephens has been dismissed from South Wales Police with immediate effect. The force said: "We hope her dismissal sends a clear message that we will not tolerate any breaches of the law or our own policies." The Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC) said it had investigated the matter and had found that Stephens had breached the standards of professional behaviour. The IOPC said: "We welcome the decision of the force to dismiss PC Stephens. Her actions were a clear breach of the standards of professional behaviour and she has rightly been held to account." The IOPC said it had also referred the matter to the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) which had decided not to bring any charges against Stephens. The CPS said: "We have carefully considered the evidence in this case and have concluded that there is insufficient evidence to bring any charges against PC Stephens." The CPS said it had taken into account the fact that Stephens had pleaded guilty to the offence of organising an illegal gathering and had been dismissed from the police force.

title: Bodleian and Vatican digitise 1.5 million ancient texts
text: In an endeavor of unparalleled scholarly significance, the venerable Bodleian Libraries of Oxford University and the Vatican Library have embarked upon a monumental project to digitize an astonishing 1.5 million ancient texts. This colossal undertaking, spanning centuries of human knowledge, will render a vast repository of wisdom and history accessible to scholars and the public alike. The texts, meticulously preserved within the hallowed halls of these two esteemed institutions, encompass an extraordinary range of subjects. From ancient papyri and medieval manuscripts to early printed books and rare maps, this digital archive promises to unlock a world of knowledge previously concealed within the confines of physical collections. Among the Bodleian's contributions to this transformative initiative are rare and precious manuscripts, including the celebrated Codex Mendoza, a pictorial account of Aztec life from the 16th century. The Vatican Library, renowned for its unparalleled collection of medieval codices, will contribute thousands of illuminated manuscripts, including the famed Codex Vaticanus, one of the oldest known copies of the Bible. The digitization process, employing cutting-edge technology, will meticulously capture every page of these ancient texts, preserving their intricate details and delicate hues. High-resolution digital images will provide scholars with unprecedented access to the texts, enabling them to explore, analyze, and share these precious artifacts with the world. This collaborative endeavor is not merely an act of preservation; it is a transformative leap into the future of scholarship. By digitizing these ancient texts, the Bodleian and Vatican Libraries are opening up new avenues of research, education, and public engagement. Researchers will now have the ability to search, compare, and analyze texts from across vast collections, fostering a deeper understanding of historical events, cultural traditions, and the development of human thought. Students and educators will benefit from the accessibility of these digitized materials, enriching their academic pursuits and inspiring future generations. Moreover, the public will gain unprecedented access to this collective treasury of knowledge. Online platforms will showcase these digitized texts, allowing individuals worldwide to delve into the wisdom of the past and explore the rich tapestry of human history. The digitization of 1.5 million ancient texts by the Bodleian and Vatican Libraries is a testament to the enduring power of collaboration and the shared commitment to preserving and sharing humanity's intellectual heritage. This monumental project will undoubtedly shape the future of scholarship, bringing ancient worlds to life and unlocking new frontiers of knowledge for generations to come.

title: Liam Fox still in running for WTO chief as race narrows
text: Liam Fox still in running for WTO chief as race narrows Liam Fox is still in the running to become the next director-general of the World Trade Organization (WTO), despite a process that has been dogged by delays and allegations of a lack of transparency. The former UK trade secretary is one of just two candidates left in the race, after Nigeria's Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala withdrew her candidacy on Wednesday. The other remaining candidate is South Korea's Yoo Myung-hee. The WTO has been without a permanent director-general since Roberto Azevêdo stepped down in August 2020. The selection process has been beset by delays and allegations of a lack of transparency. In October, the WTO's selection committee was forced to restart the process after the United States blocked the appointment of Okonjo-Iweala. The US has since said that it will support Yoo, but it is not clear whether she has the support of the other WTO members. Fox has said that he is "confident" that he can win the race. He has promised to "reform the WTO and make it fit for the 21st century". He has also said that he will "work to ensure that the WTO plays a central role in the global economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic". However, Fox's candidacy has been met with some criticism. Some have questioned whether he has the necessary experience to lead the WTO. Others have pointed to his close ties to the UK government, which has been accused of protectionism. Despite these criticisms, Fox remains a contender for the role. The WTO is expected to announce the new director-general in March. The successful candidate will face a number of challenges, including the need to reform the WTO and to address the challenges of the global trading system. Fox has said that he is "up for the challenge" and that he is "determined to make the WTO a more effective and efficient organization".

title: What to expect from record year of privatisations
text: What to expect from record year of privatisations The UK government is set to privatise more public assets than ever before as it seeks to raise funds and reduce the national debt. In the coming year, a number of high-profile companies are expected to be sold off, including Royal Mail, Channel 4, and Ordnance Survey. Lower quality services: Privatisation can also lead to lower quality services, as companies are no longer obliged to provide the same level of service as they were when they were in the public sector. This is because private companies are not subject to the same level of accountability as public sector companies. This is because private companies are not subject to the same level of employment protection as public sector companies. The government has said that it will take steps to protect consumers and workers from the negative effects of privatisation. However, it is important to be aware of the potential risks before these companies are sold off. Ordnance Survey: Ordnance Survey is the UK's national mapping agency. It is currently owned by the government, but it is expected to be sold off in the coming year. The government has said that it will retain a "golden share" in Ordnance Survey, which will give it the power to veto any decisions that could damage the company. The government's privatisation programme is likely to be controversial. However, it is important to remember that privatisation is not always a bad thing. In some cases, it can lead to increased efficiency, competition, and investment. However, it is important to be aware of the potential risks before these companies are sold off.

title: Skomer Island: Funding fears for 40-year bird research
text: Skomer Island, a haven for wildlife off the coast of Pembrokeshire, is facing an uncertain future for its long-term bird monitoring program due to funding concerns. For four decades, researchers have meticulously collected data on the island's breeding seabirds, providing invaluable insights into their population trends and the impact of environmental changes. This vital research has highlighted the island's significance as a nesting site for Atlantic puffins, European storm petrels, and Manx shearwaters. The data has also revealed worrying declines in some species, emphasizing the need for continued monitoring and conservation efforts. Skomer Island is owned and managed by the Wildlife Trust of South and West Wales, which has traditionally funded the bird monitoring program. However, the trust is now facing financial pressures, leaving the future of the research in jeopardy. "We're incredibly concerned about the potential loss of this long-term dataset," said Dr. Jennifer Gill, a researcher involved in the monitoring program. "The data we've collected over the past 40 years is not just a record of bird numbers; it's a priceless resource that helps us understand the health of our marine ecosystems and the impact of human activities." The Wildlife Trust of South and West Wales is actively seeking funding to secure the continuation of the bird monitoring program. They are calling on individuals, organizations, and government agencies to support their efforts. "Skomer Island is a national treasure," said Dr. Gill. title: Irish rivals Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil agree plan for government
text: Irish rivals Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil agree plan for government After months of negotiations, Ireland's two main political rivals, Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil, have agreed on a plan to form a government. The agreement, which was announced on Tuesday, will see Fine Gael leader Leo Varadkar become Taoiseach (Prime Minister) and Fianna Fáil leader Micheál Martin become Tánaiste (Deputy Prime Minister). The two parties will rotate the positions of Taoiseach and Tánaiste every two and a half years. The agreement also includes a number of policy commitments, including: Increasing investment in housing and healthcare Reducing carbon emissions by 51% by 2030 Reforming the education system Investing in rural Ireland The agreement is a significant breakthrough after months of political deadlock. Ireland has been without a government since February, when the previous government collapsed following a vote of no confidence. The new government will face a number of challenges, including the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and the economic fallout from the pandemic. However, the agreement between Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil is a sign that the two parties are willing to work together to address the challenges facing Ireland. The agreement was welcomed by President Michael D. Higgins, who said it was "a positive and constructive step" that would "provide stability and certainty for the people of Ireland." The agreement was also welcomed by the European Union, which said it was a "positive development" that would "strengthen Ireland's position in the EU." The new government is expected to be formed in the coming weeks. Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil: A history of rivalry Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil are the two largest political parties in Ireland. They have been rivals for much of their history. Fine Gael was founded in 1922 by supporters of the Anglo-Irish Treaty, which established the Irish Free State. Fianna Fáil was founded in 1926 by opponents of the treaty. The two parties have fought many elections over the years, and have often been in opposition to each other. However, they have also formed coalition governments on a number of occasions. The most recent coalition government between Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil was formed in 2016. The government collapsed in 2020 following a vote of no confidence. The agreement between Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil to form a new government is a significant development in Irish politics. It is a sign that the two parties are willing to work together to address the challenges facing Ireland.

title: 'Drive on demand' car-sharing scheme reaches Birmingham
text: Birmingham has become the latest UK city to embrace a 'drive on demand' car-sharing scheme, offering residents and visitors a flexible and affordable alternative to car ownership. The scheme, operated by Co-wheels, provides access to a fleet of vehicles that can be booked and unlocked via a smartphone app. Users pay a monthly membership fee, plus an hourly rate for the time they use a car. With locations across the city, including residential areas, business districts, and transport hubs, Co-wheels aims to make car-sharing accessible to everyone. The scheme is particularly beneficial for those who only need occasional access to a vehicle or who live in areas with limited parking. "We're delighted to bring our car-sharing service to Birmingham," said Richard Dilks, Co-wheels' Managing Director. "We believe that car-sharing can play a vital role in reducing congestion, improving air quality, and creating a more sustainable city." The scheme has been welcomed by local authorities and environmental groups. Birmingham City Council's Cabinet Member for Transport and Environment, Councillor Waseem Zaffar, said: "We're committed to promoting sustainable transport in Birmingham, and car-sharing is an important part of that." "Car-sharing can help to reduce the number of cars on the road, which will improve air quality and reduce congestion," added Rob Ball, Policy Officer at Friends of the Earth Birmingham. "It can also make it easier for people to get around without having to own a car, which can save them money and reduce their environmental impact." Co-wheels is a not-for-profit organization that operates car-sharing schemes in over 130 locations across the UK. The scheme has over 100,000 members who have access to a fleet of over 4,000 vehicles. To use the scheme, members simply download the Co-wheels app, which allows them to search for and book available cars. Cars can be unlocked using a contactless card or via the app. Co-wheels offers a range of vehicles to suit different needs, including electric cars, hybrids, and larger vehicles for families or businesses. The hourly rates vary depending on the type of vehicle and the time of day. For those who use cars infrequently, car-sharing can be a more cost-effective alternative to owning a car. title: Long Covid: More than a million affected in February, survey suggests
text: More than a million people in the UK were experiencing symptoms of long Covid in February, according to a major survey. The study, by the Office for National Statistics (ONS), found that 1.3 million people aged two and over in private households in the UK self-reported experiencing long Covid symptoms four weeks after the onset of their first Covid-19 infection. Of these, 821,000 people reported that their ability to carry out day-to-day activities was limited because of long Covid. The survey, which was carried out between 1 and 20 February, found that the prevalence of long Covid was highest in the 35 to 49 age group, with an estimated 3.8% of people in this age group experiencing symptoms. Women were more likely to report symptoms of long Covid than men, with 2.1% of women and 1.5% of men reporting symptoms. The most common symptoms of long Covid reported in the survey were fatigue (63%), headache (52%), and shortness of breath (40%). Other common symptoms included muscle ache (34%), sore throat (29%), and changes to sense of smell (28%). The survey also found that the prevalence of long Covid was higher in people who had been admitted to hospital with Covid-19, with 27% of people who had been hospitalized with Covid-19 reporting symptoms of long Covid. The ONS said that the survey suggests that the number of people experiencing long Covid symptoms in the UK is "substantial". The organization said that the findings of the survey are "consistent with other studies that have estimated the prevalence of long Covid in the UK and other countries". The ONS said that further research is needed to understand the long-term impacts of long Covid and to develop effective treatments. The findings of the survey come as the UK government is considering introducing a new scheme to provide support to people with long Covid. The scheme, which is being developed by the Department of Health and Social Care, is expected to provide access to a range of services, including specialist medical care, rehabilitation and financial support.

text: East Midlands Ambulance Service Misses Care Targets The East Midlands Ambulance Service (EMAS) has once again missed its key response time targets, with only 67.1% of the most serious calls being reached within eight minutes in December. This falls well short of the national target of 75%. The figures, published by NHS England, also show that EMAS missed its target for responding to category A calls within 19 minutes, with only 83.5% of these calls being met within the target time. This is down from 87.1% in November. Category A calls are the most life-threatening, such as cardiac arrest and major trauma. The target is to respond to these calls within eight minutes, although this can be extended to 19 minutes in some circumstances. The figures for December show that EMAS is facing significant challenges in meeting its response time targets. The service has been under increasing pressure in recent months due to a combination of factors, including rising demand, staff shortages, and delays in handover at hospitals. title: Trains, buses, ferries and trams face service cuts
text: Trains, Buses, Ferries and Trams Face Service Cuts Public transport services across the country are facing severe cuts as a result of the ongoing funding crisis. Trains, buses, ferries and trams are all affected, with some facing reductions in frequency, capacity and routes. Train operators have warned that the cuts will lead to longer journey times, overcrowding and a deterioration in the quality of service. Passengers will also have to pay more for their tickets, as fares are set to increase to offset the funding shortfall. Bus services are also being hit hard, with some operators cutting routes and reducing the frequency of services. This will have a particularly significant impact on rural communities, where public transport is often the only way to get around. Ferries are also facing cuts, with some services being axed altogether. This will make it more difficult for people to travel to and from islands and coastal towns. Tram services are also being affected, with some lines being closed and others seeing a reduction in the frequency of services. This will have a major impact on commuters who rely on trams to get to work and school. The cuts are being blamed on a combination of factors, including the rising cost of fuel and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. However, critics say that the government has failed to provide adequate funding for public transport, which is an essential service for many people. The cuts are likely to have a significant impact on the economy, as well as on the lives of individual passengers. Businesses will be affected by the increased cost and reduced availability of public transport, while passengers will find it more difficult and expensive to get around. The government has said that it is committed to supporting public transport, but it has not yet announced any concrete plans to address the funding crisis. In the meantime, the cuts are continuing to take effect, and the future of public transport in the UK is uncertain. Transport operators have called on the government to provide urgent funding to prevent further cuts and to ensure the future of public transport. They have also urged passengers to make their voices heard by contacting their local MPs and signing petitions.

title: Greensill: Nonsense to claim Greensill was desperate, says David Cameron
text: Former Prime Minister David Cameron has defended his actions in relation to the collapsed financial firm Greensill Capital, saying it was "nonsense" to claim he was "desperate" for the company to succeed. Cameron was questioned on Tuesday by MPs about his lobbying on behalf of Greensill, which collapsed in March 2021, leaving billions of pounds of losses. The former prime minister said he had been "motivated by a desire to help British businesses" and that he had acted "in good faith." Cameron admitted that he had "made mistakes" and that he "could have handled things better." However, he insisted that he had not lobbied ministers on behalf of Greensill in order to benefit personally. "I was not desperate for Greensill to succeed," Cameron told MPs. "I believed in the company and I believed in its founder, Lex Greensill." Cameron said he had never received any payment from Greensill, nor had he ever owned any shares in the company. He also said that he had not been offered a job by Greensill, and that he had not discussed a potential job offer with the company's founder. The former prime minister's appearance before the Treasury Select Committee was the latest in a series of inquiries into the collapse of Greensill Capital. The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is investigating the firm's collapse, and the government has ordered an independent inquiry into the role of Cameron and other government officials in the scandal. Cameron has denied any wrongdoing and has said he will cooperate fully with the inquiries. However, the former prime minister's reputation has been damaged by the scandal, and he has been criticized for his close links to Greensill. In a statement to the Treasury Select Committee, Cameron said he "deeply regretted" the collapse of Greensill Capital. He said he had "learned lessons" from the experience and that he would "be more careful in future."

title: The Princess and the Poitín
text: In the quaint Irish countryside, where rolling hills met glistening lakes, a tale unfolded that intertwined royalty and illicit spirits. It was the story of the enigmatic Princess Anne and the infamous poitín. Princess Anne, renowned for her beauty and regal bearing, was an anomaly in the bustling capital of Dublin. Her heart yearned for the serenity of her ancestral home, Castle Haddon, nestled in the heart of the Wicklow Mountains. Unbeknownst to her court, Anne harbored a secret penchant for poitín, a potent Irish moonshine. Its fiery taste and intoxicating effects had become her guilty pleasure, a lifeline to her wild and rebellious spirit. Meanwhile, deep within the secluded valleys, Seamus MacMahon, a notorious poitín distiller, skillfully crafted his potent brew. His secret still, hidden amidst the ancient forest, produced an elixir that locals whispered possessed magical qualities. One fateful night, as the princess ventured into the forest to escape the confines of her castle, she stumbled upon Seamus's illicit operation. Intrigued by the tantalizing aroma, she cautiously approached. Seamus, taken aback by the sight of a princess in his humble abode, initially hesitated. But as he poured Anne a generous glass of poitín, a bond began to form between the two unlikely companions. Over the following weeks, Anne became a regular visitor to Seamus's still. She relished the warmth and camaraderie of the locals who gathered there, sharing stories and laughter while sipping on poitín. However, their secret rendezvous could not remain hidden forever. Rumors of the princess's affinity for illicit spirits soon reached the ears of the royal court. Outraged, Anne's father, King James, dispatched a detachment of guards to arrest Seamus. As the guards approached Seamus's hideout, Anne defied her father's orders and rode to his defense. A fierce battle ensued, with Anne's spirited intervention saving Seamus from capture. In the aftermath of the conflict, King James reluctantly acknowledged the bond between his daughter and the poitín distiller. Recognizing the futility of trying to separate them, he granted Seamus his freedom and allowed Anne to return to her secret rendezvous. And so, in the annals of Irish history, the tale of the Princess and the Poitín became a legend, a testament to the indomitable spirit of those who dared to defy convention, even in the face of royal wrath.

title: Syria rebels 'break government siege' of Aleppo
text: Syrian rebels break government siege of Aleppo By BBC News Aleppo, Syria - Syrian rebels have broken a government siege of the eastern part of Aleppo, a major victory for the opposition in the country's five-year civil war. The rebels breached the siege on Saturday, after weeks of intense fighting. They were able to break through the government's defenses and open a corridor into the besieged area. The breach of the siege is a significant setback for the Syrian government, which has been trying to retake the city for months. It is also a major boost for the rebels, who have been struggling to hold onto their territory in recent weeks. The siege had been in place for more than two months, and had cut off food, water, and medical supplies to hundreds of thousands of civilians. The UN had warned that the siege could lead to a humanitarian catastrophe. The breaking of the siege is a major relief to the people of eastern Aleppo. They had been living under constant bombardment from government forces, and many had been forced to flee their homes. The rebels are now in control of a large part of eastern Aleppo, but the fighting is still ongoing. The government is still in control of the western part of the city, and it is unclear if the rebels will be able to take full control of the city. The Syrian civil war has been going on for five years, and has killed more than 250,000 people. The war has also displaced millions of people, and has created a humanitarian crisis in the region. The breaking of the siege of Aleppo is a glimmer of hope for the people of Syria. It shows that the rebels are still capable of fighting the government, and it gives the people of Aleppo a chance to rebuild their lives. However, the war is not over yet. The government is still determined to retake Aleppo, and the rebels are still fighting for their survival. It is unclear how long the fighting will continue, or what the outcome will be.

title: Aberthaw pollution position 'untenable', says court legal adviser
text: Aberthaw pollution position 'untenable', says court legal adviser A legal adviser to the High Court has said that the position of the owners of the Aberthaw power station in Wales over pollution allegations is "untenable". The Master also said that the company had failed to properly investigate complaints from local residents about dust pollution. He said that the company's position was "not supported by the evidence" and that it was "difficult to see how it can be maintained at trial". The full trial is due to start in January 2024. RWE npower has said that it is "disappointed" by the Master's ruling, but that it will "continue to defend itself vigorously against the allegations". The company said that it has "invested heavily" in dust control measures at the Aberthaw power station and that it is "committed to operating the station in a responsible manner". Local residents have welcomed the Master's ruling. They said that they hope that the trial will "finally expose the truth" about the company's pollution record and that it will "force them to take responsibility for their actions". The Aberthaw power station is a 1,560-megawatt coal-fired power station located in the Vale of Glamorgan, Wales. text: Red Peak: New Zealanders Rally Behind 'Fifth' Flag Design A new flag design, known as "Red Peak," has emerged as a frontrunner in New Zealand's ongoing flag debate. title: Why politicians still dream of controlling the internet
text: In the digital age, the internet has become an indispensable tool, connecting people across borders, facilitating global communication, and empowering individuals with access to information. However, this profound connectivity has also exposed fundamental fault lines in our society, with concerns mounting over data privacy, misinformation, and online extremism. Amid these challenges, some politicians have succumbed to the allure of controlling the internet, driven by a desire for order, security, and political gain. The quest for control manifests in various forms, ranging from censorship and surveillance to platform regulation and algorithmic manipulation. Arguments for internet control often revolve around the need to protect citizens from harmful content and ensure national security. Governments assert that regulating online spaces is crucial to combat terrorism, hate speech, and the spread of false information. They argue that unchecked internet access can lead to social unrest, political polarization, and even violence. Proponents of a controlled internet also point to the rise of digital monopolies, which they contend stifle competition and limit consumer choice. They suggest that government intervention is necessary to ensure a level playing field and promote a more diverse and vibrant online ecosystem. However, the pursuit of internet control carries significant risks. Critics argue that censorship and surveillance can stifle free speech, undermine privacy, and create a chilling effect on online discourse. They point to examples of authoritarian regimes using internet control to suppress dissent and maintain power. Furthermore, attempts to regulate the internet often prove complex and counterproductive. Technology is constantly evolving, making it difficult for governments to keep pace and effectively enforce regulations. Moreover, the global nature of the internet makes it challenging to apply national laws to online content and platforms. Instead of seeking to control the internet, policymakers should focus on fostering a healthy and responsible digital environment. This includes promoting digital literacy, supporting independent journalism, and encouraging critical thinking skills. Governments should also work with industry leaders to develop ethical standards for online content and platform behavior. Ultimately, the internet is a double-edged sword. While it offers immense opportunities for progress and connection, it also presents challenges that require careful consideration. Rather than seeking to control the internet, policymakers should embrace its transformative power and work to mitigate its risks through responsible policies and collaborative efforts.

title: Google fights French 'right to be forgotten' order
text: Google has filed a legal challenge against a French data protection order that requires it to remove search results about people from its global search engine. The order, issued by France's data protection agency, the CNIL, follows a ruling by the European Court of Justice (ECJ) in 2014 that gave people the "right to be forgotten" online. The ECJ ruling said that individuals could ask search engines to remove links to information about them from search results if the information was inaccurate, inadequate, irrelevant or excessive. Google has complied with the order in France, but it has argued that it should not be required to remove results from its global search engine. The company says that doing so would violate the free speech rights of people who have published the information, and that it would also make it more difficult for people to find information about important topics. In its legal challenge, Google is arguing that the CNIL's order is disproportionate and that it does not take into account the public interest in accessing information. The company is also arguing that the order is not clear about what kind of information must be removed, and that it would be difficult to implement. The CNIL has defended its order, saying that it is necessary to protect people's privacy and that Google has not taken sufficient steps to comply with the ECJ ruling. The case is likely to be closely watched by other data protection authorities in Europe, as they grapple with the implications of the ECJ's "right to be forgotten" ruling. The ruling has sparked a debate about the balance between the right to privacy and the right to freedom of expression online. Supporters of the ruling say that it is necessary to protect people from having their personal information shared without their consent. Critics of the ruling say that it could lead to the censorship of legitimate information and that it could make it more difficult for people to find information about important topics. The outcome of Google's legal challenge could have a significant impact on the way that search engines operate in Europe and beyond.

title: Red defeat in Belarus Xmas 'star wars'
text: Red defeat in Belarus Xmas 'star wars' Tens of thousands of people took to the streets of Minsk, Belarus, on Christmas Day in defiance of a government ban, in the latest protests against the authoritarian rule of Alexander Lukashenko. title: US creates 242,000 jobs in February
text: The United States economy surged in February, adding 242,000 jobs, significantly exceeding expectations and marking the strongest monthly job growth in a year. The unemployment rate remained steady at 3.6%, near the lowest level in 50 years. The surge in hiring was broad-based, with gains across various sectors. Leisure and hospitality led the way with 128,000 new jobs, followed by professional and business services (60,000) and construction (28,000). Notably, manufacturing added 18,000 jobs, indicating a continued recovery in the industry. Despite the robust job growth, average hourly earnings rose by just 0.1%, suggesting that wage pressures may be easing. Over the past 12 months, average earnings have increased by 3.4%, slightly above the current rate of inflation. The strong labor market report comes as a welcome sign for the Federal Reserve, which has been raising interest rates to combat inflation. It indicates that the economy can withstand tighter monetary policy without a significant slowdown in hiring. However, economists caution that the labor market remains tight, and it is too early to declare victory over inflation. They argue that the Fed will likely continue to raise interest rates gradually to bring inflation under control. The robust job growth also raises concerns about a possible overheating of the economy. Some economists argue that the Fed may need to act more aggressively to curb inflation and prevent an economic slowdown later on. In conclusion, the US job market is showing remarkable resilience, with strong hiring across various sectors. While this is positive news for workers and the economy, it presents challenges for policymakers as they navigate the delicate balance between promoting growth and controlling inflation.

title: Botulism warning over Loyd Grossman korma sauce
text: Botulism warning over Loyd Grossman korma sauce The Food Standards Agency (FSA) has issued a product recall for Loyd Grossman korma sauce due to the potential presence of botulism. Symptoms can include nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, drooping eyelids, slurred speech, difficulty breathing, and paralysis. In severe cases, botulism can be fatal. The affected product is Loyd Grossman korma sauce with a best before date of October 2023. The FSA advises anyone who has purchased this product not to consume it and to return it to the store where it was purchased for a full refund. The FSA is working with Loyd Grossman to investigate the cause of the contamination. It is believed that the sauce may have been contaminated during the manufacturing process. Loyd Grossman has issued a statement apologizing for the inconvenience and stating that it is taking the matter very seriously. The company is working closely with the FSA to ensure that all affected products are removed from sale. If you have consumed any of the affected Loyd Grossman korma sauce and are experiencing any symptoms of botulism, you should seek immediate medical attention. Botulism is a serious illness, but it can be treated successfully if it is diagnosed and treated early. Symptoms typically develop within 12 to 36 hours of consuming contaminated food, but they can sometimes take longer to appear. If you are concerned that you may have consumed contaminated food, you should contact your doctor or the nearest hospital emergency department. The FSA has issued the following advice to consumers: Do not consume Loyd Grossman korma sauce with a best before date of October 2023. title: Russian military plane crash in Syria kills dozens

title: Care home residents say moving 'worse than death'
text: Care home residents have spoken of their distress and fear after being moved to new homes, with some saying the experience was "worse than death". One resident, who asked not to be named, said she was "heartbroken" after being moved from her care home of 10 years. "I've lost everything I know and love," she said. "My friends, my routine, my independence. I feel like I'm starting my life all over again, and I'm too old for that." Another resident, who has dementia, said he was "terrified" of being moved. "I don't know where I am or who these people are," he said. "I just want to go home." Moving care home residents can be a traumatic experience for a number of reasons. Residents may have lived in their care home for many years, and it may be the only home they know. They may have developed close relationships with the staff and other residents, and moving away from them can be very upsetting. Residents may also be worried about their new care home. They may not know what to expect, and they may be concerned about the quality of care they will receive. They may also be worried about being separated from their loved ones. Moving care home residents can also be a difficult experience for family and friends. They may worry about how their loved one will cope in their new home, and they may feel guilty about not being able to provide them with the care they need. There are a number of things that can be done to make moving care home residents less traumatic. These include: Giving residents plenty of notice of the move and explaining why it is necessary. Involving residents in the planning process as much as possible. Providing residents with support before, during, and after the move. Making sure that residents have a say in their new care home. By taking these steps, it is possible to make moving care home residents less traumatic and to ensure that they can continue to live a happy and fulfilling life.

title: RNLI rescued record number of people in Scotland in 2012
text: The Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI) rescued a record number of people in Scotland in 2012, with lifeboat crews launching to more than 1,000 incidents around the coast. The RNLI's annual report for Scotland shows that lifeboats launched 1,024 times in 2012, rescuing 1,482 people and saving 35 lives. The busiest month was July, with 232 launches, while the most common type of incident was people getting into difficulty in the water. The RNLI also launched to a number of serious incidents, including a major fire on a ferry in the Firth of Forth and a collision between a fishing boat and a tanker in the North Sea. David MacDougall, RNLI lifeboat operations manager for Scotland, said: "2012 was a very busy year for our volunteer lifeboat crews in Scotland. "We saw a significant increase in the number of people we rescued, and we also launched to a number of serious incidents. "This increase in activity reflects the growing popularity of Scotland's coastline, and it is vital that people take steps to stay safe when they are out on the water." The RNLI is urging people to follow its safety advice, which includes: Always wear a lifejacket when you are on or near the water Never swim alone Be aware of the tides and weather conditions Don't drink alcohol if you are going to be on or near the water If you see someone in trouble, call 999 or 112 and ask for the Coastguard The RNLI is a charity that relies on public donations to fund its lifesaving work. In 2012, the RNLI received £1.6 million in donations from people in Scotland. MacDougall added: "We are grateful to the people of Scotland for their continued support. Your donations help us to save lives at sea."

title: BT tops UK broadband complaints list
text: BT has once again topped the list of complaints about broadband providers in the UK, according to the latest figures from Ofcom. The telecoms giant received 11,836 complaints per 100,000 customers between April and June 2023, the third quarter of the financial year. This is up from 10,944 complaints per 100,000 customers in the previous quarter. Virgin Media was the second most complained-about provider, with 7,904 complaints per 100,000 customers. Sky was third, with 6,798 complaints per 100,000 customers. The most common complaints were about faults and slow speeds. BT received 3,765 complaints about faults per 100,000 customers, while Virgin Media received 2,733 complaints about faults per 100,000 customers. Sky received 2,296 complaints about faults per 100,000 customers. BT also received the most complaints about slow speeds, with 3,227 complaints per 100,000 customers. Virgin Media received 2,378 complaints about slow speeds per 100,000 customers, while Sky received 2,032 complaints about slow speeds per 100,000 customers. Ofcom said that the increase in complaints about BT may be due to the company's decision to raise prices in April. BT has said that the price increase was necessary to invest in its network. However, Ofcom said that it was concerned about the high number of complaints about BT. "We are concerned about the high number of complaints about BT," said Lindsey Fussell, Ofcom's Consumer Group Director. "We will be monitoring the situation closely and will take action if necessary." BT said that it was working to improve its customer service. "We are aware of the increase in complaints about our service and we are working hard to address the issues that are causing them," said a BT spokesperson. "We have increased our customer service team and we are investing in our network to improve speeds and reliability."

title: India police discover elephant smuggling racket
text: India Police Uncover Elephant Smuggling Ring In a major breakthrough, Indian authorities have dismantled a sophisticated elephant smuggling racket operating across the country. Law enforcement officials conducted raids in multiple locations, leading to the arrest of several suspects and the seizure of nine elephants. The investigation began after intelligence agencies received reports of illegal elephant trade activities. The suspects allegedly captured elephants from forests and sold them to wealthy individuals, primarily in the Middle East. During the raid, police discovered a network of handlers who managed the capture, transportation, and sale of the elephants. The animals were often transported across state borders using trucks or rail wagons, with their tusks and other body parts removed to avoid detection. The smuggling racket is believed to have been operating for several years, threatening the country's elephant population. Elephants are protected under Indian law, and poaching for their ivory or other body parts is a serious offense. The Indian government has intensified its efforts to combat wildlife crime in recent years, recognizing the threats it poses to endangered species and the environment. The discovery of this smuggling ring is a testament to the commitment of law enforcement agencies to protect the nation's wildlife. According to wildlife experts, elephant smuggling is driven by demand for ivory and other body parts, particularly in countries where they are used for traditional medicine or decorative purposes. The illegal trade also fuels corruption and organized crime. The captured elephants have been transferred to rehabilitation centers, where they will receive necessary medical care and undergo a rehabilitation process to prepare them for a life back in the wild. The arrested suspects face charges of wildlife smuggling, poaching, and animal cruelty. The Indian authorities have expressed their determination to crack down on wildlife crime and protect the country's precious wildlife heritage. The successful operation against the elephant smuggling racket sends a strong message that such activities will not be tolerated.

title: Government extends consultation on hunting trophy ban
text: Government extends consultation on hunting trophy ban The government has extended its consultation on a proposed ban on the import of hunting trophies into the UK. The consultation, which was due to close on 19 August, will now run until 19 September. The government has said that it wants to give people more time to respond to the consultation, which is asking for views on a proposal to ban the import of hunting trophies from animals that are listed as endangered or threatened under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES). The government has said that it is committed to protecting endangered species and that it believes that a ban on the import of hunting trophies would help to reduce the demand for these animals. However, the government has also said that it wants to ensure that any ban is proportionate and does not have a negative impact on the livelihoods of those who rely on hunting for food or income. The consultation is asking for views on a range of issues, including: The scope of the ban, including which animals would be covered The impact of the ban on the livelihoods of those who rely on hunting The effectiveness of the ban in reducing the demand for hunting trophies The government has said that it will consider all of the responses to the consultation before making a final decision on whether to introduce a ban. The proposed ban has been welcomed by animal welfare groups, who say that it would help to protect endangered species and reduce the suffering of animals. However, the ban has also been opposed by some hunting groups, who say that it would have a negative impact on the livelihoods of those who rely on hunting. The consultation is open to anyone who wishes to express their views on the proposed ban. Responses can be submitted online or by post. Additional information The consultation can be found at the following link: https://consult.defra.gov.uk/hunting-consultations/consultation-on-the-import-of-hunting-trophies/ The deadline for submitting responses is 19 September 2023. The government will publish a summary of the responses to the consultation in due course.

title: Lord Kilclooney clarifies 'not political equals' tweet
text: Lord Kilclooney clarifies 'not political equals' tweet Ulster Unionist peer Lord Kilclooney has clarified his controversial tweet suggesting that unionists and nationalists are not "political equals". Lord Kilclooney, a former Stormont minister, made the comment on Twitter on Monday, sparking a backlash from some quarters. In his tweet, Lord Kilclooney said: "Unionists and Nationalists are not political equals. One section of our community voted overwhelmingly to remain part of the UK, the other overwhelmingly to leave." The tweet was widely interpreted as suggesting that unionists were superior to nationalists, and was condemned by some as divisive and sectarian. However, Lord Kilclooney has since clarified his remarks, saying that he was not referring to the relative merits of each community, but to the different political goals they have. He said: "I was simply stating a fact. Unionists want to remain part of the UK, while nationalists want to leave. These are two different political goals, and they cannot be equated." Lord Kilclooney also said that he believes that all citizens of Northern Ireland are equal, regardless of their political beliefs. He said: "I have always believed that all citizens of Northern Ireland are equal, and I have always worked to promote peace and reconciliation in our community. "My tweet was not intended to be divisive, and I regret if it has caused offense." Lord Kilclooney's clarification has been welcomed by some, but others remain critical of his original tweet. The Alliance Party's Deputy Leader, Stephen Farry, said that Lord Kilclooney's remarks were "deeply offensive" and that they "undermine the very foundations of our democracy". However, the Democratic Unionist Party's leader, Arlene Foster, defended Lord Kilclooney, saying that he was "entitled to his opinion". The controversy over Lord Kilclooney's tweet highlights the deep divisions that still exist in Northern Ireland over the issue of constitutional status. While the vast majority of people in Northern Ireland now support the Good Friday Agreement and the power-sharing institutions that it created, there are still some who believe that the union with the UK should be dissolved. These divisions are likely to continue to be a source of tension in Northern Ireland for many years to come.

title: Theresa May in renewed effort to close gender pay gap
text: In a renewed effort to tackle the persistent gender pay gap, Prime Minister Theresa May has announced a series of measures aimed at boosting pay transparency, supporting women in the workplace, and encouraging businesses to take action. One of the key measures is the introduction of mandatory gender pay gap reporting for all companies with 250 or more employees. This will require companies to publish the difference between the average hourly pay of male and female employees, as well as the proportion of men and women in each quartile of their workforce. The government will also introduce a new code of practice on equal pay, which will provide guidance to employers on how to comply with the law and create a fairer workplace. The code will include measures to ensure that women are not paid less than men for the same work, and that they have equal opportunities for promotion and progression. In addition, the government will provide £5 million to fund a new initiative to support women in starting and growing their own businesses. This will include mentoring, training, and networking opportunities for women entrepreneurs. Theresa May said: "The gender pay gap is a persistent injustice that holds women back and damages our economy. We are committed to tackling this issue and creating a fairer workplace for everyone." The TUC welcomed the government's announcement, saying that it was a "step in the right direction." However, the union called for further action, including measures to tackle the "pay secrecy" that often prevents women from knowing how much their male colleagues earn. The CBI, which represents businesses, said that it supported the government's goal of closing the gender pay gap. However, the CBI warned that the mandatory reporting of gender pay gaps could be "counterproductive" if it led to companies simply "box-ticking" rather than taking meaningful action. The gender pay gap in the UK currently stands at 18.4%, meaning that women earn on average 18.4% less than men. The gap is particularly large in some sectors, such as finance and technology. The government's measures are designed to help close the gender pay gap by making it easier for women to compare their salaries with those of their male colleagues, by providing support to women who want to start their own businesses, and by encouraging businesses to take action to create a fairer workplace.

title: Steel pensions: Decision deadline 'cannot be extended'
text: Steel pensions: Decision deadline 'cannot be extended' The government has said it will not extend the deadline for steelworkers to make a decision on their pensions. The deadline for members of the British Steel Pension Scheme (BSPS) to decide whether to transfer their pension to another scheme or stay in the current scheme is 28 September. The government said it "recognises the challenges" faced by steelworkers, but it is "not possible" to extend the deadline. The decision comes after the government was urged to extend the deadline by the steelworkers' union, Community. Community said that the deadline was "unfair" and that many steelworkers were still waiting for information about their pensions. The union also said that the government had not done enough to help steelworkers understand the options available to them. However, the government said that it had "provided extensive support" to steelworkers, including setting up a dedicated helpline and providing information online. The government also said that it had "engaged with Community and other stakeholders throughout the process". The BSPS is a defined benefit pension scheme, which means that members are guaranteed a certain level of income in retirement. However, the scheme has been in deficit for a number of years, and the government has said that it is not sustainable in its current form. The government has offered steelworkers a choice of two options: Transfer their pension to a new scheme, which would be run by an insurance company. Stay in the current scheme, which would be restructured to make it more sustainable. The government has said that both options are "fair and affordable". However, Community has said that the government's offer is "not good enough" and that it will continue to campaign for a better deal for steelworkers. The deadline for steelworkers to make a decision on their pensions is 28 September.

title: Japan whaling ban welcomed in Australia and New Zealand
text: Japan whaling ban welcomed in Australia and New Zealand The Australian and New Zealand governments have welcomed Japan's decision to end commercial whaling in the Southern Ocean. The decision was announced by Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida at the International Whaling Commission (IWC) meeting in Panama City. Australia's Environment Minister Sussan Ley said the decision was a "significant step forward" for whale conservation. "This is a victory for whales and for all those who have campaigned for their protection," she said. New Zealand's Foreign Minister Nanaia Mahuta said the decision was a "positive outcome" for the whales and for the region. "We have long called for an end to commercial whaling in the Southern Ocean, and we are pleased that Japan has finally agreed to stop," she said. The IWC has been trying to ban commercial whaling since 1986, but Japan has continued to hunt whales under a loophole that allows for "scientific research". However, Japan has faced increasing international pressure to end its whaling program, and the IWC has been considering a proposal to close the loophole. Japan's decision to end commercial whaling is a significant victory for whale conservationists. It is estimated that around 10,000 whales have been killed by Japanese whalers in the Southern Ocean since 1986. The decision is also a boost for the Australian and New Zealand governments, which have been working for many years to end commercial whaling in the region. The Australian and New Zealand governments have both committed to providing financial assistance to Japan to help it transition to non-lethal whale research. The decision is also a victory for the whales themselves. Whales are highly intelligent and social animals, and they play an important role in the marine ecosystem. The end of commercial whaling in the Southern Ocean will help to protect these magnificent creatures and ensure that they can continue to thrive in the region.

title: HIE takes control of CairnGorm Mountain
text: HIE takes control of CairnGorm Mountain CairnGorm Mountain, one of Scotland's most popular tourist destinations, has been taken over by Highlands and Islands Enterprise (HIE), the Scottish government's economic and community development agency. HIE has acquired the mountain and its associated infrastructure, including the funicular railway, from CairnGorm Mountain Ltd, the previous owner. The move comes after the company was placed into administration in October 2022. HIE said it is committed to reopening the mountain for visitors as soon as possible. It is also working with stakeholders to develop a long-term plan for the sustainable development of CairnGorm. The acquisition of CairnGorm Mountain is a significant step for HIE, which has been working closely with the Scottish government and other partners to support the economic and social development of the area. HIE's chief executive, Charlotte Wright, said: "CairnGorm Mountain is a unique and iconic asset for the Highlands and Islands. We are committed to working with stakeholders to ensure that it is reopened for visitors as soon as possible and that it has a sustainable future." The Scottish government's Rural Affairs Minister, Mairi Gougeon, said: "CairnGorm Mountain is a vital part of the Highlands and Islands economy. I am pleased that HIE has taken over the mountain and is working to reopen it for visitors. This is a positive step for the area and I look forward to working with HIE to ensure that CairnGorm has a sustainable future." CairnGorm Mountain is located in the Cairngorms National Park, which is home to some of Scotland's most stunning scenery. title: AMs' report highlights gaps in muscular dystrophy care
text: Muscular Dystrophy UK: Report finds 'gaps' in care for people with muscular dystrophy A new report by the charity Muscular Dystrophy UK has found "significant gaps" in the care provided to people with muscular dystrophy (MD). The report, which surveyed over 1,000 people with MD and their families, found that many people are not receiving the care and support they need. Some of the key findings of the report include: Delays in diagnosis: Many people with MD experience delays in diagnosis, which can lead to a delay in accessing appropriate care and support. Lack of access to specialist care: Many people with MD do not have access to specialist care, which can lead to a lack of understanding of their condition and its management. Inadequate support for families: Many families of people with MD do not receive adequate support, which can lead to significant stress and financial hardship. The report also found that people with MD are more likely to experience mental health problems, such as anxiety and depression. The report concludes that there is a need for a "step change" in the care provided to people with MD. It calls for a number of improvements, including: Earlier diagnosis: The report calls for earlier diagnosis of MD, so that people can access appropriate care and support as soon as possible. Increased access to specialist care: The report calls for increased access to specialist care for people with MD, so that they can receive the best possible care and support. Improved support for families: The report calls for improved support for families of people with MD, so that they can cope with the challenges of caring for a loved one with MD. The report also calls for more research into MD, so that we can better understand the condition and develop new treatments. Muscular Dystrophy UK is a charity that provides support and information to people with MD and their families. The charity also campaigns for improved care and services for people with MD. Chief executive of Muscular Dystrophy UK, Catherine Woodhead, said: "This report shows that there are significant gaps in the care provided to people with muscular dystrophy. This is unacceptable. People with MD deserve to have access to the best possible care, and we will continue to campaign for improvements."

title: Mitsubishi Motors: How did it falsify its fuel economy data?
text: Mitsubishi Motors: How did it falsify its fuel economy data? In 2016, Mitsubishi Motors admitted to falsifying fuel economy data on four of its minicar models, resulting in a major scandal that tarnished the company's reputation and shook the Japanese auto industry. An investigation revealed a widespread pattern of deception, with employees instructed to manipulate test results to meet government targets for fuel efficiency. How it happened Mitsubishi's fuel economy deception involved two main methods: Engine idling: During fuel economy tests, the vehicles were put into a special "economy mode" that idled the engine more frequently, resulting in artificially inflated fuel efficiency readings. Weight reduction: The vehicles were tested with less weight than specified in the regulations, further improving fuel economy results. These practices were not limited to a few rogue employees but were reportedly sanctioned at high levels within the company. Employees were allegedly pressured to meet ambitious fuel economy targets, leading to a culture of cutting corners and falsifying data. The consequences The scandal had devastating consequences for Mitsubishi Motors: Financial losses: The company incurred billions of dollars in fines, compensation payments, and lost sales. Loss of trust: Mitsubishi's reputation was severely damaged, leading to a loss of consumer confidence and a drop in sales. Criminal charges: Several Mitsubishi executives were arrested and charged with falsifying data, resulting in prison sentences. Aftermath and reforms The Mitsubishi scandal prompted a major overhaul of the company's corporate culture and regulatory oversight in the Japanese auto industry. Mitsubishi implemented stricter internal controls, enhanced employee training, and appointed an independent auditor to monitor fuel economy testing. Government agencies also strengthened regulations and increased oversight of fuel economy tests. The Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association (JAMA) introduced new guidelines for fuel economy testing, including stricter vehicle weighing requirements and more realistic driving conditions. Lessons learned The Mitsubishi scandal highlighted the importance of ethical conduct, transparency, and regulatory compliance in the automotive industry. It demonstrated the risks of cutting corners to meet performance targets and the devastating consequences that can result from manipulating data. The scandal also underscored the need for strong corporate governance and independent oversight to prevent such misconduct from occurring in the future. By implementing comprehensive reforms and strengthening regulations, the industry has taken steps to restore trust and ensure the accuracy and integrity of fuel economy data.
